ko: 경쟁자[상대]가 없는, 무적의, 무쌍의, 비할 데 없는
syn: without equal, unparalleled, without parallel, matchless, unmatched, peerless, without peer, unsurpassed, unbeaten, unexcelled, incomparable, beyond compare, inimitable
etym: un- +‎ rivaled
en: If you describe something as unrivalled, you are emphasizing that it is better than anything else of the same kind.
example: He had an unrivalled knowledge of south Arabian society, religion, law and customs

zh_Hans: （偶然发现有趣或珍贵之物的）机缘，幸运
syn: happy chance, accident, happy accident, fluke
etym: From Serendip (“variant of Serendib: Ceylon, Sri Lanka”) +‎ -ity. Coined by English writer and politician Horace Walpole in 1754 based on the Persian story of The Three Princes of Serendip, who (Walpole wrote to a friend) were “always making discoveries, by accidents and sagacity, of things which they were not in quest of”.
en: Serendipity is the luck some people have in finding or creating interesting or valuable things by chance.
example: Some of the best effects in my garden have been the result of serendipity.
syn_n: chance, coincidence, fortuity, fortune, luck  providence

etym: Borrowed from Middle French cursif, from Medieval Latin cursīvus, from Latin cursus.
en: of or relating to handwriting in which letters are formed and joined in a rapid flowing style
syn_n: charm, spell, hex, jinx, expletive, malediction, oath, blasphemy, profanity, swearing, affliction, burden, trial, tribulation, vexation
syn_v: blaspheme, damn, profane, swear, afflict, plague, torment, vex

syn: dig up, unearth, bring out of the ground
etym: Latin ex and humāre (“to bury”).
en: If a dead person's body is exhumed, it is taken out of the ground where it is buried, especially so that it can be examined in order to find out how the person died.
example: His remains have been exhumed from a cemetery in Queen's, New York City.
syn_v: dig up, disentomb, excavate, unearth

syn: charm, fetish, amulet, mascot, totem, idol, juju, phylactery
etym: From French talisman, partly from Arabic طِلَسْم‎ (ṭilasm), from Ancient Greek τέλεσμα (télesma, “payment”); and partly directly from Byzantine Greek τέλεσμα (télesma, “talisman, religious rite, completion”), from τελέω (teléō, “to perform religious rites, to complete”), from τέλος (télos, “end, fulfillment, accomplishment, consummation, completion”).
en: A talisman is an object which you believe has magic powers to protect you or bring you luck.

zh_Hans: 极其愚蠢的；无意义的；无聊的
syn: foolish, stupid, fatuous, idiotic, absurd, ridiculous, ludicrous, laughable, risible, imbecilic, moronic, cretinous, unintelligent, witless, asinine, pointless, senseless, frivolous, nonsensical, brainless, mindless, thoughtless, vacuous, vapid, empty-headed
etym: From Middle French inane, from Latin inānis (“empty, vain, useless”) which is of unknown origin.
en: If you describe someone's behaviour or actions as inane, you think they are very silly or stupid.
example: He always had this inane grin
example_ko: an inane remark
syn_a: asinine, idiotic, ludicrous, moronic, pointless, senseless, banal, insipid, stupid, vapid, witless

etym: Middle English, from Middle French concentrique, from Medieval Latin concentricus, from Latin con- (“with, together”) + centrum (“circle, center”)
en: Concentric circles or rings have the same centre.
example: On a blackboard, he drew five concentric circles.
example_ko: concentric rings

ko: 감소, 감퇴; 경감, 완화; (가격·세 등의) 경감액
syn: dying away, dying down, dying out, dropping away, dropping off, lessening, easing, easing off, decrease, diminishing, moderation, decline, declining, fade, dwindling, cooling off, tailing off, petering out, tapering off, wane, waning, ebb, relenting, desisting, weakening
en: Abatement means a reduction in the strength or power of something or the reduction of it.
example: the abatement of carbon dioxide emissions.
example_ko: [V] The storm showed no signs of abating.

ko: 절대 반대(하는 것), 아주 싫은 것
syn: hateful, odious, repugnant, repellent, offensive
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin anathema (“curse, person cursed, offering”), itself a borrowing from Ancient Greek ἀνάθεμα (anáthema, “something dedicated, especially dedicated to evil”), from ἀνατίθημι (anatíthēmi, “I set upon, offer as a votive gift”), from ἀνά (aná, “upon”) + τίθημι (títhēmi, “I put, place”). The Ancient Greek term was influenced by Hebrew חרם‎ (herem), leading to the sense of "accursed," especially in Ecclesiastical writers.
en: If something is anathema to you, you strongly dislike it.
example: Violence was anathema to them.
example_ko: Racial prejudice is (an) anathema to me.
syn_n: curse, execration, imprecation, malediction, abhorrence, abomination, obscenity, taboo

syn: admired, highly rated, lionized, revered, honoured, esteemed, exalted, lauded, vaunted, much touted, well thought of, well received, acknowledged
en: If someone or something is acclaimed, they are praised enthusiastically.
example: She has been acclaimed for the TV drama 'Prime Suspect'
example_ko: a highly/widely acclaimed performance
syn_n: acclamation, applause, cheering, enthusiasm
syn_v: applaud, cheer, extol, hail, laud, praise

zh_Hans: 骇人听闻的；公然的；罪恶昭彰的
syn: glaring, obvious, overt, evident, conspicuous
etym: From French flagrant.
en: You can use flagrant to describe an action, situation, or someone's behaviour that you find extremely bad or shocking in a very obvious way.
example: The judge called the decision 'a flagrant violation of international law'
example_ko: a flagrant abuse of human rights
syn_a: blatant, brazen, conspicuous, obvious, outrageous, shameless

syn: deception, deceit, deceitfulness, duplicity, dishonesty, unscrupulousness, underhandedness, subterfuge, fraud, fraudulence, legerdemain, sophistry, sharp practice, skulduggery, swindling, cheating, duping, hoodwinking
etym: From French chicanerie (“trickery”), from chicaner.
en: Chicanery is using cleverness to cheat people.
syn_n: deceit, dishonesty, duplicity, falsehood, fraud, lying, betrayal, treachery, treason, artifice, craftiness, cunning, guile, subterfuge, bluff, hoax, ploy, pretense, ruse

zh_Hans: 道德败坏的，堕落的，恶毒的
syn: corrupted, perverted, deviant, degenerate, debased, degraded, immoral, unprincipled, reprobate
en: Depraved actions, things, or people are morally bad or evil.
example: a disturbing and depraved film
example_ko: This is the work of a depraved mind.
syn_v: adulterate, corrupt, debase, debauch, pervert, taint

zh_Hans: (价格、花费等的)大幅度提高，猛增；把(价格、税率等)大幅提高
syn: trek, tramp, trudge, traipse, slog, footslog, plod, march, journey on foot
etym: From English dialectal hyke (“to walk vigorously”), probably a Northern form of hitch, from Middle English hytchen, hichen, icchen (“to move, jerk, stir”). Cognate with Scots hyke (“to move with a jerk”), German dialectal hicken (“to hobble, walk with a limp”), Danish hinke (“to hop”). More at hick.
en: A hike is a long walk in the country, especially one that you go on for pleasure.
example: He hiked up his trousers and waded into the water.
example_ko: They went on a ten-mile hike through the forest.
syn_n: excursion, march, trek, walk, escalation, increase, jump, rise
syn_v: march, ramble, traipse, tramp, wander, escalate, increase, raise

syn: disfavour, disdain
etym: dis- +‎ taste
en: If you feel distaste for someone or something, you dislike them and consider them to be unpleasant, disgusting, or immoral.
example: He professed a distaste for everything related to money.
example_ko: He looked around the filthy room in distaste.
syn_a: bothersome, distasteful, unpleasant, disgusting, nasty, repulsive, unpalatable, cranky, ill-tempered, obnoxious, offensive, rude

syn: flick, flip, skim, browse, glance, look, riffle
etym: From per- +‎ use, from either Medieval Latin (peruti, perusitare (“wear out”)) or Anglo-Norman (peruser (“use up”)), originally leading to two concurrent meanings, but only those derived from "to examine" survive today.
en: If you peruse something such as a letter, article, or document, you read it.
example: We perused the company's financial statements for the past five years
example_ko: A copy of the report is available for you to peruse at your leisure.
syn_v: cover, read, scan, scrutinize  study

syn: volley, barrage, bombardment, cannonade, battery, burst, blast, hail, shower, rain, stream, broadside, blitz, discharge
etym: From French fusillade, from fusiller (“shoot with a firearm”), from fusil (“rifle, gun”)
en: A fusillade of shots or objects is a large number of them fired or thrown at the same time.
example: Both were killed in a fusillade of bullets fired at close range.
example_ko: a fusillade of bullets/stones

zh_Hans: 机敏的回答；巧妙的应对
syn: counter, rejoinder, sally, return, retaliation, answer, reply, response
etym: From French riposte, taken from Italian risposta, a derivative of the verb rispondere, "to respond".
en: A riposte is a quick, clever reply to something that someone has said.
example: Laura glanced at Grace, expecting a cheeky riposte.
example_ko: a witty riposte

syn: speculation, surmise, fancy, notion, belief, suspicion, presumption, assumption, theory, hypothesis, postulation, supposition
etym: From Old French, from Latin coniectūra (“a guess”), from coniectus, perfect passive participle of cōniciō (“throw or cast together; guess”), from con- (“together”) + iaciō (“throw, hurl”); see jet. Compare adjective, eject, inject, project, reject, subject, object, trajectory.
en: A conjecture is a conclusion that is based on information that is not certain or complete.
example: That was a conjecture, not a fact
example_ko: The truth of his conjecture was confirmed by the newspaper report.
syn_n: conjecture, speculation, surmise, forecast, prediction, prophecy, hypothesis, inference, postulate, theory, assumption, estimation, idea, presumption
syn_v: forecast, prophesy, believe, imagine, suggest, venture, assume, infer, presume, suppose, suspect

syn: capricious, temperamental, excitable, fickle, changeable, unpredictable, variable, protean, mutable, erratic, quicksilver, inconstant, inconsistent, unstable, unsteady, fluctuating, ever-changing, kaleidoscopic, fluid, wavering, vacillating, moody, flighty, wayward, whimsical, giddy, impulsive
etym: The annual mercury (Mercurialis annua), one of the varieties of mercurial (noun sense 1)A sample of a mercurial (noun sense 3), in this case a compound with the molecular formula Ag2HgI4An 18th-century jar used for storing mercurials (noun sense 4) in the form of pills[n 1]
en: If you describe someone as mercurial, you mean that they frequently change their mind or mood without warning.
example: his mercurial temperament.
example_ko: Emily’s mercurial temperament made her difficult to live with.
syn_a: capricious, temperamental, unpredictable, volatile, immediate, instantaneous, sudden

syn: awareness, shrewdness, acuity, sharpness, sharp-wittedness, cleverness, brightness, smartness
etym: Borrowed from Latin acūmen (“sharp point”).
en: Acumen is the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions.
example: His sharp business acumen meant he quickly rose to the top.
example_ko: business/commercial/financial acumen
syn_n: discernment, insight, intelligence, perception, perspicacity, sagacity, wit

syn: mistaken belief, misbelief, delusion, false notion, mistaken impression, misapprehension, misjudgement, miscalculation, misinterpretation, misconstruction, error, mistake, untruth, inconsistency, illusion, myth, fantasy, deceit, deception, sophism
etym: From Middle English, from Old French fallace, from Latin fallacia (“deception, deceit”), from fallax (“deceptive, deceitful”), from fallere (“to deceive”).
en: A fallacy is an idea which many people believe to be true, but which is in fact false because it is based on incorrect information or reasoning.
example: It's a fallacy that the affluent give relatively more to charity than the less prosperous
example_ko: It is a fallacy to say that the camera never lies.
syn_n: error, falsehood, falsity, misconception, untruth, fault, flaw, inconsistency

zh_Hans: 固执的，不妥协的，不让步的
syn: inflexible, unbending, unyielding, unshakeable, unwavering, resolute, unpersuadable, unmalleable, unaccommodating, uncooperative, stubborn, obstinate, obdurate, pig-headed, bull-headed, single-minded, iron-willed, hard-line, hard and fast, diehard, immovable, unrelenting, inexorable, inveterate, rigid, tough, firm, determined, adamant, tenacious
etym: Borrowed from French intransigeant, from Spanish intransigente, from Latin in- (“un-, not”) + trānsigēns, present participle of trānsigō (“to come to an understanding”), from trāns (“across”) +‎ agō (“to do”).
en: If you describe someone as intransigent, you mean that they refuse to behave differently or to change their attitude to something.
example: They put pressure on the Government to change its intransigent stance

syn: ridiculous, farcical, laughable, risible, preposterous, foolish, idiotic, stupid, inane, silly, asinine, nonsensical
etym: First attested in 1619. From Latin lūdicrus, from lūdō (“play”).
en: If you describe something as ludicrous, you are emphasizing that you think it is foolish, unreasonable, or unsuitable.
example: It was ludicrous to suggest that the visit could be kept secret
example_ko: a ludicrous suggestion
syn_a: absurd, laughable, outlandish, preposterous, silly, ridiculous

zh_Hans: 能表达清楚的，善于表达的；口齿伶俐的，有口才的
syn: fluent, communicative, effective, persuasive, coherent, lucid, vivid, expressive, silver-tongued, vocal
en: If you describe someone as articulate, you mean that they are able to express their thoughts and ideas easily and well.
example: She is an articulate young woman
example_ko: She struggled to articulate her thoughts.
syn_v: enunciate, pronounce, utter, vocalize, clarify, explain, explicate, expound
syn_a: eloquent, fluent, smooth, clear, definite, distinct, intelligible, lucid, hinged, jointed

syn: assault on, raid on, invasion of, storming of, overrunning of, foray into, blitz on, sortie into, sally against, sally into, advance into, advance on, push into, thrust into, descent on
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French, from Latin incursio, incursionem.
en: If there is an incursion into a country, enemy soldiers suddenly enter it.
example: armed incursions into border areas by rebel forces.
syn_n: aggression, assault, attack, onslaught, raid, encroachment, incursion, infringement, intrusion

zh_Hans: 想复仇的；报复性的；怀恨在心的
syn: out for revenge, revengeful, avenging, unforgiving, grudge-bearing, resentful, ill-disposed, implacable, unrelenting, acrimonious, bitter
etym: From Latin vindicta (“vengeance”), from vindico (“claim, vindicate”), from vindex (“defender”),  +‎ -ive.
en: If you say that someone is vindictive, you are critical of them because they deliberately try to upset or cause trouble for someone who they think has done them harm.
example: a vindictive woman desperate for revenge against the man who loved and left her.
example_ko: He accused her of being vindictive.
syn_a: hateful, malevolent, malicious, rancorous, spiteful, vengeful, venomous

syn: desultory
etym: From Late Latin perfunctōrius, from the past participial stem of perfungor, perfunct- (“perform, carry through”), from per- + fungor.
en: A perfunctory action is done quickly and carelessly, and shows a lack of interest in what you are doing.
example: She gave the list only a perfunctory glance
example_ko: a perfunctory nod/smile
syn_a: cursory, haphazard, hasty, mechanical, superficial, apathetic, halfhearted, indifferent, nonchalant

syn: analogy, metaphor, symbol, emblem
etym: From Middle English allegorie, from Old French allegorie, from Latin allegoria, from Ancient Greek ἀλληγορία (allēgoría), from ἄλλος (állos, “other”) + ἀγορεύω (agoreúō, “I speak”).
en: An allegory is a story, poem, or painting in which the characters and events are symbols of something else. Allegories are often moral, religious, or political.
example: The book is a kind of allegory of Latin American history.
example_ko: a political allegory
syn_n: analogy, comparison, symbol, fable  parable

etym: From Latin fīdūciārius (“held in trust”), from fīdūcia (“trust”).
en: Fiduciary is used to talk about things which relate to a trust, or to the people who are in charge of a trust.
example: They have a case against their directors for breach of fiduciary duty.
example_ko: the company’s fiduciary duty to its shareholders

syn: reproach, scold, admonish, reprove, remonstrate with, chastise, chide, upbraid, berate, take to task, pull up, castigate, lambaste, read someone the Riot Act, give someone a piece of one's mind, haul over the coals, criticize, censure
etym: From Middle English rebuken, from Anglo-Norman rebuker (“to beat back, repel”), from re- + Old French *buker, buchier, buschier (“to strike, hack down, chop”), from busche (“wood”), from Vulgar Latin buska (“wood, grove”), from Frankish *busc, *busk (“grove”), from Proto-Germanic *buskaz (“bush”); equivalent to re- +‎ bush.
en: If you rebuke someone, you speak severely to them because they have said or done something that you do not approve of.
example: The president rebuked the House and Senate for not passing those bills within 100 days.
example_ko: The company was publicly rebuked for having neglected safety procedures.
syn_v: admonish, censure, chide, reprimand, reprove, scold

syn: satirical
etym: From French sardonique[1], from Latin sardonius, from Ancient Greek σαρδόνιος (sardónios), alternative form of σαρδάνιος (sardánios, “bitter or scornful laughter”), which is often cited as deriving from the Sardinian plant (Ranunculus sardous), known as either σαρδάνη (sardánē) or σαρδόνιον (sardónion). When eaten, it would cause the eater's face to contort in a look resembling scorn (generally followed by death)[2]. It might also be related to σαίρω (saírō, “I grin”).
en: If you describe someone as sardonic, you mean their attitude to people or things is humorous but rather critical.
example: a big, sardonic man, who intimidated his students.
example_ko: a sardonic smile

ko: (특히 법적·사회적 사항 등의 변경을 강력히) 주장하다[요구하다]
syn: perturb, fluster, ruffle, disconcert, unnerve, disquiet, disturb, distress, unsettle, bother, concern, trouble, cause anxiety to, make anxious, alarm, work up, flurry, worry
etym: From Middle English, from Latin agitatus, past participle of agitare (“to put in motion”), from agere (“to move”). Compare with French agiter. See act, agent.
en: If people agitate for something, they protest or take part in political activity in order to get it.
example: The women who worked in these mills had begun to agitate for better conditions.
example_ko: [V] political groups agitating for social change
syn_v: disturb, excite, impassion, incite, provoke, churn, mix, shake

syn: truism, commonplace, banal saying, hackneyed saying, overworked saying, trite saying, banality, old chestnut
etym: From French platitude, from plat (“flat”), from Vulgar Latin *plattus, from Ancient Greek πλᾰτῠ́ς (platús).
en: A platitude is a statement which is considered meaningless and boring because it has been made many times before in similar situations.
example: Why couldn't he say something original instead of spouting the same old platitudes?
syn_n: banality, bromide, clich)  triteness

zh_Hans: 对…感到懊悔；对…感到后悔；因为…感到遗憾
syn: be sorry about, feel apologetic about, feel remorseful about, feel remorse for, repent of
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman ruwe, from Latin rūta, from Ancient Greek ῥυτή (rhutḗ).
en: If you rue something that you have done, you are sorry that you did it, because it has had unpleasant results.
example: Tavare was probably ruing his decision.
example_ko: He rued the day they had bought such a large house.
syn_v: bemoan, curse, grieve, lament, regret

zh_Hans: 假装，装作，佯装(有某种感觉或生病、疲倦等)
en: If someone feigns a particular feeling, attitude, or physical condition, they try to make other people think that they have it or are experiencing it, although this is not true.
example: One morning, I didn't want to go to school, and decided to feign illness
example_ko: a feigned illness
syn_v: affect, imitate, pretend, simulate, concoct, counterfeit, fabricate  invent

zh_Hans: 一知半解者；半吊子；业余爱好者
syn: potterer, tinkerer, trifler, dallier
etym: From Italian dilettante, prop. present participle of dilettare (“to delight”), from Latin dēlectāre (“to delight”).
en: You can use dilettante to talk about someone who seems interested in a subject, especially in art, but who does not really know very much about it.

zh_Hans: 无精打采的，萎靡不振的，不热心的
syn: lazy, lax, unenthusiastic, half-hearted, uninterested, lukewarm, indifferent, uncaring, unconcerned, casual, offhand, blasé, insouciant, leisurely, relaxed
etym: From the archaic interjection lackaday, lackadaisy.
en: If you say that someone is lackadaisical, you mean that they are rather lazy and do not show much interest or enthusiasm in what they do.
example: Dr. Jonsen seemed a little lackadaisical at times.
syn_a: idle, indolent, lazy, languid, lethargic, lifeless, listless, apathetic, impassive, indifferent, lackluster

etym: From Middle English forfenden (“to ward off, protect, prohibit”), equivalent to for- +‎ fend.
en: to protect or secure
example_ko: Heaven forfend that students are encouraged to think!

syn: wanting, defective, inadequate, insufficient, limited, poor, scant
etym: From Latin deficiens, present participle of deficere (“to lack, fail, be wanting”); see defect.
en: If someone or something is deficient in a particular thing, they do not have the full amount of it that they need in order to function normally or work properly.
example: a diet deficient in vitamin B.
example_ko: a diet that is deficient in vitamin A
syn_a: inadequate, lacking, wanting, insufficient, scanty, scarce, defective, faulty, flawed, impaired, inferior

syn: probation, trial period, test period, apprenticeship, training period, traineeship, training, initiation
etym: From Middle French novitiat, from Medieval Latin novitiatus (“a novitiate”), from Latin novicius, novitius (“a novice”), from novus (“new”).
en: the state of being a novice, esp in a religious order, or the period for which this lasts

zh_Hans: 半行;半行诗;诗的半句;不完全的诗行
etym: From French hémistiche, from Latin hemistichium, from Ancient Greek ἡμιστίχιον (hēmistíkhion), from ἡμι- (hēmi-, “half”) + στίχος (stíkhos, “verse”).
en: a half line of verse

zh_Hans: 辅助的，补充的；附属的，附加的
syn: subordinate, secondary, supportive
etym: From Latin ancillāris (“ancillary; relating to maids”), from ancilla (“maid”).
en: The ancillary workers in an institution are the people such as cleaners and cooks whose work supports the main work of the institution.
example: ancillary staff.
example_ko: ancillary staff/services/equipment
syn_a: accessory, additional, auxiliary, secondary, supplementary

syn: haven, safe haven, shelter, sanctuary, retreat, asylum, place of safety, place of security, port in a storm, oasis, sanctum
etym: From Old French refuge, from Latin refugium, from re- + fugiō (“flee”). Doublet of refugium.
en: If you take refuge somewhere, you try to protect yourself from physical harm by going there.
example: They took refuge in a bomb shelter
example_ko: A further 300 people have taken refuge in the US embassy.
syn_n: escape, haven, resort, retreat, sanctuary  shelter

syn: quiver, tremble, twinkle, glimmer, wink, blink
etym: From Middle English waveren, from Old Norse vafra (“to flicker”), akin to Old English wǣfre (“restless, wavering”). Related to wave.
en: If you waver, you cannot decide about something or you consider changing your mind about something.
example: Some military commanders wavered over whether to support the coup
example_ko: His voice wavered with emotion.
syn_v: reel, sway, totter, wobble, alternate, fluctuate, vacillate, falter, hesitate  pause

syn: WC, water closet, convenience, public convenience, cloakroom, facilities, powder room, urinal, privy, latrine, outhouse, earth closet, jakes
etym: From Middle English lavatorie, from Late Latin lavatorium, from Latin lavāre (“to wash”) + -ium (forming places related to an activity). Doublet of lavatorium. As a place to pan gold, via Spanish lavadero.[1] See also lave.
en: A lavatory is the same as a toilet.
example: the ladies' lavatory at the University of London.
example_ko: There’s a bathroom and a lavatory upstairs.

syn: get in before, get ahead of, steal a march on, anticipate, second-guess, nip in the bud, thwart, frustrate, foil, stave off, ward off, fend off, avert, preclude, obviate, prevent, intercept, check, block, hinder, impede, obstruct
en: If you forestall someone, you realize what they are likely to do and prevent them from doing it.
example: Large numbers of police were in the square to forestall any demonstrations.
example_ko: Try to anticipate what your child will do and forestall problems.
syn_v: avert, circumvent, deter, hinder, thwart

ko: 최대의 적, 대적(大敵); (때로 the archenemy) 사탄(Satan), 마왕, 악마(Devil).
zh_Hans: 大敌;魔王;头号敌人;死敌;主要敌人
etym: arch- (“chief, most extreme”) +‎ enemy
en: a chief enemy

zh_Hans: 短暂的，极短的；转瞬即逝的
syn: transient, fleeting, passing, short-lived, momentary, brief, short, cursory, temporary, impermanent, short-term
etym: From New Latin ephemerus, from Ancient Greek ἐφήμερος (ephḗmeros), the more common form of ἐφημέριος (ephēmérios, “of, for, or during the day, living or lasting but for a day, short-lived, temporary”), from ἐπί (epí, “on”) + ἡμέρα (hēméra, “day”).
en: If you describe something as ephemeral, you mean that it lasts only for a very short time.
example: He talked about the country's ephemeral unity being shattered by the defeat
syn_a: fleeting, momentary, passing, temporary, transitory

ko: [UC] 배교(背敎), 배신(背信); 변절, 탈당
syn: abandonment of belief, recantation
etym: From Latin apostasia, from Ancient Greek ἀποστασία (apostasía, “defection, revolt”), from ἀφίστημι (aphístēmi, “I withdraw, revolt”), from ἀπό (apó, “from”) + ἵστημι (hístēmi, “I stand”)
en: If someone is accused of apostasy, they are accused of abandoning their religious faith, political loyalties, or principles.
example: a charge of apostasy.
syn_n: desertion, forsaking, forswearing, rejection, renunciation

etym: From Ancient Greek εἰκών (eikṓn, “icon”) + -logy.
en: the study or field of art history concerning icons

zh_Hans: 独裁者；专制者；独断专行的人；专横的人
syn: dictator, despot, tyrant, monocrat
etym: Borrowed from French autocrate, itself from Ancient Greek αὐτοκρατής (autokratḗs, “sovereign”), from αὐτο- (auto-, “self”) (combinatory form of αὐτός (autós)) + κρατία (kratía, “rule”) (from κράτος (krátos, “strength, power”))
en: An autocrat is a person in authority who has complete power.
example: Many poor countries are abandoning autocracy.
syn_n: authoritarian, autocrat, despot, magnate, oppressor  tyrant

syn: children, young, family, brood
etym: From Old French progenie, from Latin prōgeniēs, from prōgignō (“beget”).
en: You can refer to a person's children or to an animal's young as their progeny.
example: Davis was never loquacious on the subject of his progeny.
example_ko: He was surrounded by his numerous progeny.
syn_n: child, heir, offspring, scion, descendants, issue, posterity, progeny, seed

zh_Hans: 敌意;深仇大恨;兰克;仇视;怨恨
syn: spite, hate, hatred, resentment, malice, ill will, malevolence, malignancy, animosity, antipathy, enmity, hostility, acrimony, venom, poison, vindictiveness, balefulness, vengefulness, vitriol, virulence, perniciousness, meanness, nastiness
etym: First attested in the 13th century as Middle English rancour, from Old French rancor, from Latin rancor (“rancidity, grudge, rancor”), from *ranceō (“be rotten or putrid, stink”), from which also English rancid.[1]
en: → see rancour
example_ko: have[nurse] rancor against a person
syn_n: animosity, bitterness, enmity, hostility, malice, resentment

syn: ease, relieve, soothe, take the edge off, assuage, allay, dull, soften, lessen, moderate, temper, mitigate, diminish, decrease, blunt, deaden, abate
etym: From Latin palliatus (“cloaked”) (in Late Latin the past participle of palliare (“to cover with a cloak”)), from pallium (“cloak”).
en: to lessen the severity of (pain, disease, etc) without curing or removing; alleviate; mitigate
syn_v: downplay, excuse, extenuate, justify, mitigate, alleviate, ease, reduce, relieve

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：avaric〔e〕贪心 + ious …的 → 贪婪的，贪心的
syn: acquisitive, covetous, greedy, rapacious, mercenary, materialistic, mean, miserly
etym: From Old French avaricieux, from avarice, from Latin avaritia (“greed”), from avarus (“greedy”), of avere (“crave, long for”).
en: An avaricious person is very greedy for money or possessions.
example: He sacrificed his own career so that his avaricious brother could succeed.
syn_a: acquisitive, avaricious, covetous, grasping, rapacious, miserly, parsimonious, selfish, stingy, devouring, gluttonous, ravenous, voracious

syn: dextral, at three o'clock
etym: Borrowed from Latin dexter, from Proto-Indo-European *deḱs(i)-tero-, from *deḱs- (“right”) (Pokorny, Watkins, 1969; et al.). Compare Epic Greek δεξιτερός (dexiterós, “right hand”), δεξιός (dexiós, “right”), Old Church Slavonic деснъ (desnŭ, “right”).
en: of or located on the right side
syn_n: agility, adroitness, deftness, facility, proficiency, skill

syn: recompense, refund, repay, square accounts with, settle up with
etym: 1610s, re- (“back”) +‎ imburse (“pay”) (imburse (literally “put in a purse”), circa 1530, now obsolete), from Middle French embourser, from Old French en- (“in”) + borser (“to get money”), from borse (“purse”), from Medieval Latin bursa (English purse).[1]
en: If you reimburse someone for something, you pay them back the money that they have spent or lost because of it.
example: I'll be happy to reimburse you for any expenses you might have incurred
example_ko: We will reimburse any expenses incurred.
syn_v: refund, remit, remunerate, repay  return

syn: waste, become emaciated, wither, shrivel, shrivel up, shrink, become shrunken, dry up, decay, wilt
etym: Borrowed from French atrophie, from Latin atrophia, from Ancient Greek ἀτροφία (atrophía, “a wasting away”), from ἄτροφος (átrophos, “ill-fed, un-nourished”), from ἀ- (a-, “not”) + τροφή (trophḗ, “nourishment”), from τρέφω (tréphō, “I fatten”).
en: If a muscle or other part of the body atrophies, it decreases in size or strength, often as a result of an illness.
example_ko: (비유,격식) The cultural life of the country will sink into atrophy unless more writers and artists emerge.
syn_n: decline, degeneration, deterioration, enervation
syn_v: decay, degenerate, shrivel, wither

syn: unlucky, luckless, out of luck, ill-starred, ill-fated, jinxed, cursed, doomed
etym: From about 1400, from hap (“luck”) +‎ -less.
en: A hapless person is unlucky.
example: his hapless victim.
example_ko: the hapless victims of exploitation
syn_a: ill-fated, jinxed, luckless, unfortunate, unlucky

syn: to the point, apposite, appropriate, suitable, fitting, fit, apt, applicable, material, germane, to the purpose, apropos
etym: Borrowed from French pertinent, from Latin pertinens, present participle of pertinere (“to extend, stretch out, belong, relate, pertain, have concern”), from per (“through”) + tenere (“to hold”).
en: Something that is pertinent is relevant to a particular subject.
example: She had asked some pertinent questions
example_ko: a pertinent question/fact
syn_a: applicable, appropriate, apropos, fitting, germane, relevant

syn: opening, slit
etym: From Old French incision, from Late Latin incisio from the verb incidō (“I cut into”) + action noun suffix -iō.
en: An incision is a sharp cut made in something, for example by a surgeon who is operating on a patient.
example: The technique involves making a tiny incision in the skin.
example_ko: Make a small incision below the ribs.
syn_n: cut, gash, slash  slit

zh_Hans: （批评或意见）尖锐的，尖刻的，犀利的
syn: cutting, pointed, piercing, penetrating, sharp, keen, acute, razor-sharp, razor-edged, rapier-like
etym: From Old French, from the present participle of trenchier (“to cut”).
en: You can use trenchant to describe something such as a criticism or comment that is very clear, effective, and forceful.
example: He was shattered and bewildered by this trenchant criticism
syn_a: effective, forceful, powerful, vigorous, acute, incisive, keen, penetrating, biting, bitter, caustic, cutting, sharp

syn: strident, screeching, squawky, squawking, sharp, grating, discordant, dissonant, inharmonious, unmelodious, jarring, brassy
etym: Borrowed from Latin raucus (“hoarse, husky, raucous”).
en: A raucous sound is loud, harsh, and rather unpleasant.
example: They heard a bottle being smashed, then more raucous laughter.
example_ko: raucous laughter
syn_n: harsh, loud, piercing, shrill, strident, boisterous, chaotic, disorderly

zh_Hans: 不可知论者; 不可知论的
en: An agnostic believes that it is not possible to know whether God exists or not. Compare atheist.
example_ko: The device-agnostic technology allows it to run on several kinds of electronic devices.
syn_n: cynic, empiricist, nonbeliever, skeptic

syn: obligatory, mandatory, necessary, compulsory, required, requisite, essential, imperative
etym: From Middle English, from stem incumbent-, of Medieval Latin incumbēns (“holder of a church position”), from Latin present participle of incumbō (“I lie down upon”).
en: An incumbent is someone who holds an official post at a particular time.
example: In general, incumbents have a 94 per cent chance of being re-elected.
example_ko: the present incumbent of the White House
syn_a: acting, elected, functioning, official, binding, compelling, compulsory, necessary  obligatory

syn: belief, creed, credo, attitude, rule, golden rule, guideline, formula, standard, criterion, tenet, truism, code, ethic, maxim, motto, axiom, aphorism, notion, dictum, dogma, canon, law
etym: Borrowed from Latin crēdō (“I believe”); see creed.
en: A credo is a set of beliefs, principles, or opinions that strongly influence the way a person lives or works.
example: Lord Clarendon's liberal credo was one of the foundations of his political conduct.
syn_n: belief, doctrine, dogma, faith  tenet

zh_Hans: （尤指为隐瞒真相而）说模棱两可的话，含糊其词
syn: be evasive, be non-committal, be vague, be ambiguous, dodge the issue, evade the issue, beat about the bush, hedge, hedge one's bets, fudge the issue
etym: From Medieval Latin aequivocātus, perfect passive participle of aequivocō (“I am called by the same name”), from Late Latin aequivocus (“ambiguous, equivocal”): compare French équivoquer. See equivocal.
en: When someone equivocates, they deliberately use vague language in order to deceive people or to avoid speaking the truth.
example: He is equivocating a lot about what is going to happen if and when there are elections
syn_v: dodge, elude, evade, hedge, lie  prevaricate

syn: false, untrue, wrong, incorrect, faulty, flawed, inaccurate, inexact, imprecise, mistaken, misinformed, misguided, misleading, deceptive, delusive, delusory, illusory, sophistic, specious, fictitious, spurious, fabricated, distorted, made up, trumped up
etym: fallacy +‎ -ous.
en: If an idea, argument, or reason is fallacious, it is wrong because it is based on a fallacy.
example: Their main argument is fallacious.
example_ko: a fallacious argument
syn_a: erroneous, false, illogical, incorrect, mistaken

syn: stubborn, stubborn as a mule, mulish, bull-headed, pig-headed, obdurate, headstrong, self-willed, wayward, wilful, perverse, contrary, recalcitrant, obstreperous, disobedient, insubordinate, rebellious, mutinous, defiant, stiff-necked, intractable, intransigent, unyielding, unmalleable, unmanageable, ungovernable, unpersuadable
etym: From Latin refractārius (“obstinate”), from refractus, past participle of refringere (“to break up”). Originally refractary, refractarie, but reanalysed after other adjectives in -ory.
en: Refractory people are difficult to deal with or control, for example because they are unwilling to obey orders.
example: refractory priests who refused to side with the king.

syn: presage, portend, prognosticate, foreshow, foretell, indicate, suggest, signal, herald, forewarn, warn of, promise, point to, anticipate
etym: From fore- +‎ shadow.
en: If something foreshadows an event or situation, it suggests that it will happen.
example: The disappointing sales figures foreshadow more redundancies
syn_v: augur, forebode, indicate, portend, presage  signify

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：herbi〔= herb 草〕+ vor 吃 + ous 有…性质的，关于…的 → 食草的
etym: From New Latin herbivorus, from Latin herba (“grass”) and -vorus, from vorō (“I eat”).
en: (of animals) feeding on grass and other plants

syn: ingratiating, obsequious, fawning, servile, self-abasing, grovelling, subservient, wheedling, cajoling, crawling, cringing, Uriah Heepish, humble, toadying, hypocritical, insincere, flattering, adulatory, honey-tongued, silver-tongued, gushing, effusive, suave, urbane, glib, smooth, smooth-tongued, smooth-spoken, smooth-talking, slick, slippery, saccharine
etym: Borrowed from Medieval Latin unctuōsus (“oily”), from Latin unctum, from unguere, ungere (“to anoint”).
en: If you describe someone as unctuous, you are critical of them because they seem to be full of praise, kindness, or interest, but are obviously insincere.
example: the kind of unctuous tone that I've heard often at diplomatic parties.
syn_a: greasy, oily, flattering, hypocritical, insincere, obsequious, sycophantic

syn: humiliation, embarrassment, mortification
etym: Borrowed from French ignominie, from Latin ignōminia, from ig- (“not”) + nomen (“name”) (prefix assimilated form of in-).
en: Ignominy is shame or public disgrace.
example: the ignominy of being made redundant
example_ko: They suffered the ignominy of defeat.
syn_n: blot, disgrace, dishonor, shame, stain, stigma, depravity, infamy, turpitude, villainy

syn: cloudy, filmy, blurred, smeared, hazy, misty, dirty, dingy, muddy, muddied, grimy, smeary
etym: From Middle English opake, from Latin opacus (“shaded, shady, dark”) (of unknown origin), later reinforced from Middle French opaque. Doublet of ubac.
en: If an object or substance is opaque, you cannot see through it.
example: You can always use opaque glass if you need to block a street view.
example_ko: opaque glass
syn_a: dark, impenetrable, ambiguous, hazy, nebulous, unclear, vague

syn: aggressive, threatening, antagonistic, pugnacious, bellicose, truculent, confrontational, argumentative, quarrelsome, disputatious, contentious, militant, combative
etym: From Latin belligerans (“waging war”), present active participle of belligerō (“I wage war”), from belliger (“waging war, warlike”), from bellum (“war”) + -ger (from gerō (“I lead, wage, carry on”)).
en: A belligerent person is hostile and aggressive.
example: He was almost back to his belligerent mood of twelve months ago.
example_ko: a belligerent attitude
syn_a: bellicose, contentious, pugnacious, truculent, aggressive, hostile, warring

syn: aka, also called, otherwise known as, otherwise
etym: From Latin alias (“at another time; (in the post-Augustan period) at another time or place, elsewhere, under other circumstances, otherwise”), feminine accusative plural of alius (“other”). See else and alien.
en: An alias is a false name, especially one used by a criminal.
example: Using an alias, he had rented a house in Fleet, Hampshire.
example_ko: Mick Clark, alias Sid Brown
syn_n: nickname, pen name  pseudonym

zh_Hans: （尤指处于震惊、失望或困境时的）镇静，沉着，冷静
syn: calmness, calm, level-headedness, self-possession, self-control, even-temperedness, coolness, cool-headedness, presence of mind
etym: From French équanimité, from Latin aequanimitās (“calmness, equanimity”), from aequus (“even; calm; fair”) + animus (“mind, soul”) + -itās. Surface analysis is equ- +‎ animus +‎ -ity.
en: Equanimity is a calm state of mind and attitude to life, so that you never lose your temper or become upset.
example: His sense of humour allowed him to face adversaries with equanimity
example_ko: She accepted the prospect of her operation with equanimity.

syn: warren, network, complex, web, coil, entanglement
etym: Borrowed from Latin labyrinthus, from Ancient Greek λαβύρινθος (labúrinthos, “maze”).
en: If you describe a place as a labyrinth, you mean that it is made up of a complicated series of paths or passages, through which it is difficult to find your way.
example: the labyrinth of corridors.
example_ko: We lost our way in the labyrinth of streets.
syn_n: complex, convolution, maze, network, puzzle, riddle, tangle  web

syn: for all I know, for all you know, it could be, it could be that, it may be, it may be that, it is possible, it is possible that, possibly, conceivably, feasibly
etym: Alteration (via plural -s or adverbial -s) of earlier perhap, equivalent to per +‎ hap (“chance, coincidence”).
en: You use perhaps to express uncertainty, for example, when you do not know that something is definitely true, or when you are mentioning something that may possibly happen in the future in the way you describe.
example: Millson regarded her thoughtfully. Perhaps she was right
example_ko: ‘Are you going to come?’ ‘Perhaps. I’ll see how I feel.’
syn_a: conceivably, maybe, perchance, possibly

ko: 사도(예수 열두 제자 중 한 사람)
zh_Hans: （信仰或政治运动的）宣导者，鼓吹者，先驱
syn: evangelist, evangelical, proselytizer, spreader of the faith, spreader of the word, preacher, teacher
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin apostolus, from Ancient Greek ἀπόστολος (apóstolos, “one sent forth, apostle”).
en: The apostles were the followers of Jesus Christ who went from place to place telling people about him and trying to persuade them to become Christians.
syn_n: disciple, evangelist, missionary, witness, emissary, envoy  messenger

syn: stick, fasten, bind, fix, post, secure, join, connect, couple
etym: Borrowed from Latin affixus, perfect passive participle of affigere (from ad- + figere).
en: If you affix one thing to another, you stick it or attach it to the other thing.
example: Complete the form and affix four tokens to its back
example_ko: The label should be firmly affixed to the package.
syn_n: addition, appendage, appendix, supplement
syn_v: attach, connect, fasten, fix, stick

syn: steep cliff, rock face, sheer drop, cliff, crag, bluff, height, escarpment, scarp, escarp, scar
etym: First attested in 1598, from Middle French precipice, from Latin praecipitium (“a steep place”), from praeceps (“steep”), from prae + caput (“head”). First meaning of the noun is recorded from 1632.
en: A precipice is a very steep cliff on a mountain.
example: The town is perched on the edge of a steep, precipitous cliff.
example_ko: (비유) The country was now on the edge of a precipice.

etym: From French microcosme, from Latin microcosmus, from Ancient Greek μικρός (mikrós, “small”) + κόσμος (kósmos, “world”); micro- +‎ -cosm
en: A microcosm is a small society, place, or activity which has all the typical features of a much larger one and so seems like a smaller version of it.
example: Kitchell says the city was a microcosm of all American culture during the '60s
example_ko: The family is a microcosm of society.

syn: statement, sworn statement, attestation, declaration, avowal, plea, submission, claim, contention, charge, allegation
etym: From Medieval Latin affidavit (“he has sworn”), the third person singular perfect tense of affido (“swear”), from fīdō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰidʰ-, zero-grade of Proto-Indo-European *bʰeydʰ- (“to command, to persuade, to trust”). Cognate to fidelity and faith (same Latin root), but not to affirm (shared Latin ad- prefix, but different Latin and Proto-Indo-European roots).
en: An affidavit is a written statement which you swear is true and which may be used as evidence in a court of law.
example_ko: The judge took an affidavit about his habit.
syn_n: deposition, oath, testimony  voucher

ko: 크로노미터(특히 항해 때 쓰는 정밀 시계)
syn: chronometer, small clock, timer
etym: From Ancient Greek χρόνος (khrónos, “time”) + μέτρον (métron, “measure”); synchronically, chrono- +‎ -meter.
en: A chronometer is an extremely accurate clock that is used especially by sailors at sea.

zh_Hans: 易受影响的，易受伤害的
syn: receptive to, vulnerable to, defenceless against
etym: From Late Latin susceptibilis, from Latin susceptus, from suscipiō.
en: If you are susceptible to something or someone, you are very likely to be influenced by them.
example: Young people are the most susceptible to advertisements
example_ko: He’s highly susceptible to flattery.
syn_a: open, prone, sensitive, vulnerable, defenseless, helpless, unprotected

syn: intimidate, browbeat, cow, badger, chivvy, harass, torment, plague
etym: From Hector (“in Greek and Roman mythology, a character in Homer’s Iliad who is the greatest warrior of Troy”), from Late Middle English Hector (“warrior with the qualities of Hector”),[1] from Latin Hectōr or Ancient Greek Ἕκτωρ (Héktōr), from ἕκτωρ (héktōr, “holding fast”), from ἔχειν (ékhein),[2] present active infinitive of ἔχω (ékhō, “to have, own, possess; to hold”), from Proto-Indo-European *seǵʰ- (“to hold; to overpower”).
en: If you say that someone is hectoring you, you do not like the way they are trying to make you do something by bothering you and talking to you aggressively.
example: I suppose you'll hector me until I phone him.

zh_Hans: 纠正，矫正；补偿，向…赔偿损失
syn: correct, make right, put right, set right, right, put to rights, compensate for, sort out, deal with, amend, remedy, repair, fix, cure, heal, make good, reform, harmonize, retrieve, improve, better, ameliorate, adjust, resolve, settle, square
en: If you redress something such as a wrong or a complaint, you do something to correct it or to improve things for the person who has been badly treated.
example: More and more victims turn to litigation to redress wrongs done to them.
example_ko: to redress an injustice
syn_n: amends, compensation, recompense
syn_v: amend, correct, rectify  remedy

syn: grow rapidly, multiply, become more numerous, mushroom, snowball, burgeon, escalate, rocket, run riot
etym: From Latin proles (“offspring”) + ferre (“to bear”) + -ate.
en: If things proliferate, they increase in number very quickly.
example: Computerized data bases are proliferating fast
example_ko: Books and articles on the subject have proliferated over the last year.
syn_v: breed, generate, propagate, reproduce, burgeon, expand, increase, multiply, mushroom, spread

syn: criticize, attack, censure, castigate, decry, revile, vilify, besmirch, discredit, damn, reject, proscribe
etym: From Old French denuncier, from Latin dēnūntiō (“to announce, to denounce, to threaten”), from de + nūntiō (“to announce, to report, to denounce”), from nūntius (“messenger, message”)
en: If you denounce a person or an action, you criticize them severely and publicly because you feel strongly that they are wrong or evil.
example: German leaders denounced the attacks and pleaded for tolerance
example_ko: She publicly denounced the government’s handling of the crisis.
syn_v: accuse, blame, censure, condemn, criticize, reprove

syn: lecture, diatribe, homily, polemic, rant, fulmination, broadside, verbal attack, verbal onslaught, invective
etym: From Middle English arang and French harangue, from Old Italian aringa (modern Italian arringa) from aringare (“speak in public”) (modern Italian arringare), from aringo (“public assembly”), from Gothic *𐌷𐍂𐌹𐌲𐌲𐍃 (*hriggs)[1], akin to Old High German hring (“ring”) (whence German Ring).
en: If someone harangues you, they try to persuade you to accept their opinions or ideas in a forceful way.
example: An argument ensued, with various band members joining in and haranguing Simpson and his girlfriend for over two hours.
syn_n: diatribe, invective, lecture, sermon, tirade
syn_v: bluster, rant, rave  scold

syn: aggressive, antagonistic, belligerent, pugnacious, bellicose, combative, confrontational, ready for a fight, hostile, obstreperous, argumentative, quarrelsome, contentious, uncooperative
etym: First attested circa 1540, from Middle French, from Latin truculentus (“fierce, savage”), from trux (“fierce, wild”).
en: If you say that someone is truculent, you mean that they are bad-tempered and aggressive.
example: Your secretary said you'd be wanting a cleaner,' she announced with her usual truculence.
syn_a: aggressive, bellicose, belligerent, combative, biting, harsh, scathing, vitriolic, brutal, cruel, ferocious, vicious

syn: happening at the same time, done at the same time, contemporaneous, concomitant, coinciding, coincident, synchronous, synchronized, synchronic
etym: From Ancient Greek συγχρονίζω (sunkhronízō).
en: If you synchronize two activities, processes, or movements, or if you synchronize one activity, process, or movement with another, you cause them to happen at the same time and speed as each other.
example: It was virtually impossible to synchronise our lives so as to take holidays and weekends together
example_ko: [V] The sound track did not synchronize with the action.
syn_v: adjust, align, calibrate, match  parallel

syn: sweet-sounding, mellow, mellifluous, dulcet, sweet, honeyed, lyrical, silvery, silver-toned, golden, bell-like, rhythmical, lilting, pleasant, agreeable, soothing
etym: euphony +‎ -ous (“possessing”).
en: to make pleasant to hear; render euphonious

zh_Hans: 中伤，诽谤;喷绕法；喷洒法
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：a 加强 + spers 散开 + ion 表名词 → 诽谤
syn: disparagement, denigration, defamation, defamation of character, abuse, vituperation, condemnation, criticism, censure, castigation, denunciation, flak, deprecation, opprobrium, obloquy, derogation, slander, revilement, reviling, calumny, calumniation, slurs, smears, execration, excoriation, lambasting, upbraiding, bad press, character assassination, attack, invective, libel, insults, slights, curses
etym: From Latin aspersiōnem, from aspersiō (“sprinkling”).
en: a disparaging or malicious remark; slanderous accusation (esp in the phrase cast aspersions (on))
example_ko: cast aspersion[/hw]s on a person's honor
syn_n: calumny, defamation, denigration, malediction, railing, slander, slur

zh_Hans: （试图武装推翻国家政治制度的）反抗者，造反者
syn: insurgent, revolutionist, mutineer, agitator, subversive, guerrilla, anarchist, terrorist
etym: From Old French rebelle, from Latin rebellis (“waging war again; insurgent”), from rebellō (“I wage war again, fight back”), from re- (“again, back”) + bellō (“I wage war”).
en: Rebels are people who are fighting against their own country's army in order to change the political system there.
example: fighting between rebels and government forces.
example_ko: rebel forces
syn_n: dissenter, iconoclast, insurgent, nonconformist, revolutionary, traitor
syn_v: defy, mutiny, renounce, resist, revolt, riot

syn: subtle, surreptitious, sneaking, cunning, crafty, Machiavellian, artful, guileful, sly, wily, tricky, slick, deceitful, deceptive, dishonest, underhand, backhanded, indirect
etym: From Middle French insidieux, from Latin īnsidiōsus (“cunning, artful, deceitful”), from īnsidiae (“a lying in wait, an ambush, artifice, stratagem”) + -ōsus, from īnsideō (“to sit in or on”), from in (“in, on”) + sedeō (“to sit”).
en: Something that is insidious is unpleasant or dangerous and develops gradually without being noticed.
example: The changes are insidious, and will not produce a noticeable effect for 15 to 20 years
example_ko: the insidious effects of polluted water supplies
syn_a: deceitful, perfidious, scheming, treacherous, covert, furtive, pernicious, stealthy, deluding, enticing, tempting

syn: unhurried, languorous, unenergetic, lacking in energy, slow, slow-moving
en: If you describe someone as languid, you mean that they show little energy or interest and are very slow and casual in their movements.
example: To his delight a familiar, tall, languid figure lowered itself down the steps of a club.
example_ko: a languid wave of the hand
syn_a: faint, feeble, weak, languorous, lethargic, lifeless, listless, torpid, apathetic, dispirited, impassive, indifferent

zh_Hans: 小瀑布（常指瀑布群的分支）
syn: falls, water chute, cataract, rapids, torrent, flood, deluge, outpouring, white water, fountain, shower, avalanche
etym: From French cascade, from Italian cascata, from cascare (“to fall”)
en: If you refer to a cascade of something, you mean that there is a large amount of it.
example: The women have lustrous cascades of black hair
syn_n: cataract, fall, rapids, waterfall, deluge, downpour, torrent
syn_v: plunge, pour, rush, surge, tumble

zh_Hans: 使惭愧；使羞愧；使困窘；使局促不安
syn: ashamed, shamefaced, remorseful, mortified, conscience-stricken, humiliated, humbled, taken aback, disconcerted, nonplussed, discomfited, discomposed, distressed, chagrined, perturbed, confounded, dismayed, dumbfounded, crestfallen, sheepish, red-faced, blushing, confused, put out of countenance, discountenanced, with one's tail between one's legs
etym: First attested in 1303. From Middle English abaisen, abaishen, abashen (“to gape with surprise”) etc., from Anglo-Norman abaïss, from Middle French abair, abaisser (“to astonish, alter”), from Old French esbaïr, (French ébahir), from es- (“utterly”) + baïr (“to astonish”), from Latin ex- (“out of”) + baer (“to gape”), from batāre (“to yawn, gape”).[1][2][3]
en: to cause to feel ill at ease, embarrassed, or confused; make ashamed
syn_v: chagrin, embarrass, humiliate, mortify, shame, bewilder, confound, confuse, disconcert

syn: disaster, catastrophe, destruction, devastation, demolition, annihilation, ravaging
etym: From French holocauste, from Late Latin holocaustum, from the neuter form of Ancient Greek ὁλόκαυστος (holókaustos), from ὅλος (hólos, “whole”) + καυστός (kaustós, “burnt”), from καίω (kaíō, “I burn”). Used to refer to mass killings since at least 1925.[1]
en: A holocaust is an event in which there is a lot of destruction and many people are killed, especially one caused by war.
example: A nuclear holocaust seemed a very real possibility in the '50s.
example_ko: a nuclear holocaust
syn_n: catastrophe, conflagration, destruction, inferno, annihilation, extermination, genocide, massacre  slaughter

syn: make amends for, make up for, do penance for, pay for, redress, redeem, offset, square, make good, make redress for, make reparation for, make recompense for, make restitution for, purge
etym: From Latin expiātus, past participle of expiō (“atone for”).
en: If you expiate guilty feelings or bad behaviour, you do something to indicate that you are sorry for what you have done.
example: It seemed that Alice was expiating her father's sins with her charity work.
example_ko: He had a chance to confess and expiate his guilt.
syn_v: do penance, expiate, make amends, repent  shrive

syn: urge, notion, fancy, whimsy, foible, idea, caprice, conceit, vagary, kink, megrim, crotchet, craze, fad, passion, inclination, bent
en: A whim is a wish to do or have something which seems to have no serious reason or purpose behind it, and often occurs suddenly.
example: We decided, more or less on a whim, to sail to Morocco
example_ko: He was forced to pander to her every whim.
syn_n: caprice, fancy, impulse, lark  notion

etym: From be- (prefix used as an intensifier) +‎ wilder (“to lead astray; to go astray, wander”).[1]
en: If something bewilders you, it is so confusing or difficult that you cannot understand it.
example: The silence from Alex had hurt and bewildered her.
example_ko: She was totally bewildered by his sudden change of mood.
syn_v: baffle, daze, fluster, perplex, puzzle, cloud, muddle, obscure, misconstrue, mistake, misunderstand

syn: slander, character assassination, defamation of character, calumny, vilification, traducement, obloquy, scandal, scandalmongering, malicious gossip, tittle-tattle, backbiting, aspersions, muckraking, abuse, malediction
etym: From Old French diffamacion (French diffamation), from Latin diffāmātiō.
en: Defamation is the damaging of someone's good reputation by saying something bad and untrue about them.
example: He sued for defamation.
example_ko: The company sued for defamation.
syn_n: calumny, denigration, disparagement, libel, slander, vilification

zh_Hans: 反驳，否定；（事实或声明）（与…）相矛盾，（与…）有抵触
syn: refute, rebut, dispute, counter
etym: Borrowed from Latin contradict-, the participle stem of contrādīcō (“I speak against”) (originally two words).
en: If you contradict someone, you say that what they have just said is wrong, or suggest that it is wrong by saying something different.
example: She dared not contradict him
example_ko: [VN] All evening her husband contradicted everything she said.
syn_v: counter, deny, dispute, oppose, protest, rebut, challenge, confute, differ, dissent, impugn

syn: intimidating, bullying, frightening, terrifying, scary, fearsome, mean-looking, alarming, forbidding, baleful
etym: Borrowed from Middle French minatoire, from Latin minatorius, from minari (“to threaten”).
en: threatening or menacing
example_ko: minatory words

syn: sarcastic, sardonic, satirical, scathing, cutting, razor-edged, incisive, penetrating, piercing, biting, stinging, searing, keen, caustic, trenchant, bitter, acrimonious, astringent, harsh, severe, devastating, abrasive, wounding, hurtful, unkind, cruel, vitriolic, virulent, mordant, venomous, waspish, poisonous, spiteful, vicious, malicious
etym: Attested since the 17th century, from Latin acerbus (“sour, bitter”).
en: Acerbic humour is critical and direct.
example: He was acclaimed for his acerbic wit and repartee
example_ko: The letter was written in her usual acerbic style.
syn_a: biting, brusque, caustic, curt, sarcastic, acidic, acrid, astringent, sour, tart

syn: clear, exonerate, exculpate, declare innocent, find innocent, pronounce not guilty
etym: From Middle English aquī̆ten (“to give in return; to pay, repay; to redeem (a pledge, security), to make good (a promise); to make amends; to relieve of an obligation; to acquit, clear of a charge; to free; to deprive of; to do one's part, acquit oneself; to act, behave (in a certain way)”), from Old French aquiter (“to act, do”) and Medieval Latin acquitāre (“to settle a debt”),[1] from ad- (“prefix meaning ‘to’”) + quitare (“to free”),[2] equivalent to a- +‎ quit. See quit and compare acquiet.
en: If someone is acquitted of a crime in a court of law, they are formally declared not to have committed the crime.
example: Mr Ling was acquitted of disorderly behaviour by magistrates.
example_ko: The jury acquitted him of murder.
syn_v: clear, exculpate, exonerate, pardon, vindicate, act, behave, comport, conduct

syn: be a hindrance to, obstruct, impede, inhibit, retard, balk, thwart, foil, baffle, curb, delay, arrest, interfere with, set back, slow down, hold back, hold up, forestall, stop, halt
etym: From Middle Dutch hinder, from the verb hinderen.
en: If something hinders you, it makes it more difficult for you to do something or make progress.
example: Further investigation was hindered by the loss of all documentation on the case.
example_ko: a political situation that hinders economic growth
syn_v: foil, frustrate, hamper, impede, obstruct, thwart, circumscribe, curb, inhibit, limit, restrain

etym: 19th century: from German Chromosom, ultimately from Ancient Greek χρῶμα (khrôma, “colour”) + σῶμα (sôma, “body”) (because they are stained under the microscope). Equivalent to chromo- +‎ -some.
en: A chromosome is a part of a cell in an animal or plant. It contains genes which determine what characteristics the animal or plant will have.
example: Each cell of our bodies contains 46 chromosomes.

syn: well deserved, earned, merited, warranted, justified, justifiable
etym: From Old French condigne, from Latin condignus, from con- +‎ dignus (“worthy”).
en: (esp of a punishment) fitting; deserved

syn: reply, response, retort, riposte, counter, sally
etym: From Middle French rejoindre, with infinitive used as noun frequent in Law French.
en: A rejoinder is a reply, especially a quick, witty, or critical one, to a question or remark.
syn_n: answer, reply, response, comeback, rebuttal  retort

zh_Hans: 无规律地混入；散布；点缀
syn: distribute, disperse, spread, strew, dot, sprinkle, pepper, litter
etym: From Latin interspersus.
en: If you intersperse one group of things with another or among another, you put or include the second things between or among the first things.
example: Originally the intention was to intersperse the historical scenes with modern ones.
example_ko: Lectures will be interspersed with practical demonstrations.
syn_v: distribute, interpolate, pepper, scatter, sprinkle  strew

zh_Hans: 摇晃，摇摇欲坠；蹒跚行走
syn: walk unsteadily, wobble, toddle
etym: Alteration of titter.
en: Teeter is used in expressions such as teeter on the brink and teeter on the edge to emphasize that something seems to be in a very unstable situation or position.
example: Three of the hotels are in receivership, and others are teetering on the brink of bankruptcy
example_ko: She teetered after him in her high-heeled shoes.

zh_Hans: （尤指不问场合）好开玩笑的；滑稽的，诙谐的
syn: flip, glib, frivolous, tongue-in-cheek, waggish, whimsical, joking, jokey, jesting, jocular, playful, roguish, impish, teasing, arch, mischievous, puckish
etym: From French facétieux, from Latin facētia (“jest, wit, humor”), from facētus (“witty, jocose, facetious”).
en: If you say that someone is being facetious, you are criticizing them because they are making humorous remarks or saying things that they do not mean in a situation where they ought to be serious.
example: The woman eyed him coldly. 'Don't be facetious,' she said.
example_ko: a facetious comment/remark
syn_a: jesting, joking, amusing, comical, funny, humorous

zh_Hans: 精明的；干练的；机敏的；灵巧的
syn: adept, dexterous, deft, agile, nimble, nimble-fingered, handy
etym: Borrowed from French adroit, from French à (“on the; to”) (from Old French a (“to; towards”), from Latin ad (“to; towards”), from Proto-Indo-European *ád (“at; near”)) + French droit (“right”) (from Old French droit, dreit, from Vulgar Latin *drēctus, syncopated form of Latin dīrectus (“laid straight; direct, straight; level; upright”), perfective passive participle of dīrigō (“to lay straight”), from dis- (“apart, in two”) (from Proto-Indo-European *dwís (“twice; in two”)) + regō (“to govern, rule; to guide, steer”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₃réǵeti (“to be straightening, setting upright”))).
en: Someone who is adroit is quick and skilful in their thoughts, behaviour, or actions.
example: She is a remarkably adroit and determined politician.
example_ko: an adroit negotiator
syn_a: apt, clever, deft, dexterous, proficient, skillful

syn: brusque, abrupt, clipped, blunt, gruff, short, brief, concise, succinct, to the point, compact, crisp, pithy, incisive, short and sweet, economical, laconic, epigrammatic, summary, condensed
etym: From Latin tersus (“clean, cleansed, rubbed or wiped off; neat, spruce; terse”), perfect passive participle of tergō, tergeō (“to clean, cleanse, rub, wipe, wipe off”),[1] from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to rub; to turn”).
en: A terse statement or comment is brief and unfriendly.
example: He issued a terse statement, saying he is discussing his future with colleagues before announcing his decision on Monday
example_ko: a terse style
syn_a: abrupt, brusque, curt, pithy, short, brief, compact, concise, epigrammatic, succinct

syn: disclose, divulge, leak, lay bare, make known, betray, impart, pass on, proclaim, announce, report, declare, intimate, uncover, unmask, expose, bring out into the open, unfold, vouchsafe, tell
etym: From Latin confīdō (“I trust fully, I am assured, confide, rely”), from con- (“together”) + fīdō (“I trust”); see faith, fidelity.
en: If you confide in someone, you tell them a secret.
example: I knew she had some fundamental problems in her marriage because she had confided in me a year earlier
example_ko: [VN] She confided all her secrets to her best friend.
syn_v: believe, depend on, trust, disclose, divulge, reveal

syn: dictatorial, totalitarian, despotic, tyrannical, autarchic, draconian, absolute, arbitrary, oppressive, repressive, illiberal, undemocratic, anti-democratic
etym: Circa 1880 authority +‎ -arian
en: If you describe a person or an organization as authoritarian, you are critical of them controlling everything rather than letting people decide things for themselves.
example: Senior officers could be considering a coup to restore authoritarian rule.
example_ko: an authoritarian regime/government/state
syn_n: disciplinarian, dictator, fascist, tyrant
syn_a: austere, harsh, inflexible, strict

syn: flash flood, torrent
etym: From Middle English deluge, from Old French deluge, alteration of earlier deluvie, from Latin dīluvium, from lavō (“wash”)
en: A deluge of things is a large number of them which arrive or happen at the same time.
example: A deluge of manuscripts began to arrive in the post
syn_n: deluge, inundation, overflow, cascade, downpour, stream, torrent
syn_v: drench, inundate, submerge, swamp, wash, glut, overwhelm, saturate

ko: (특히 예수 탄생을 기준으로 그 전후의) 천년
zh_Hans: 一千年，千周年；千周年纪念日
etym: From Late Latin millennium, from Latin mīlle (“thousand”) + -ennium (from annus (“year”)).
en: A millennium is a period of one thousand years, especially one which begins and ends with a year ending in `000', for example the period from the year 1000 to the year 2000.
example_ko: the second millennium AD

syn: tale, narrative, sketch
etym: Late 17th c., from French anecdote, from Ancient Greek ἀνέκδοτος (anékdotos, “accounts unpublished”), from ἀν- (an-, “not, un-”) + ἔκδοτος (ékdotos, “published”), from ἐκδίδωμι (ekdídōmi, “I publish”), from ἐκ- (ek-, “out”) + δίδωμι (dídōmi, “I give”).
en: An anecdote is a short, amusing account of something that has happened.
example_ko: amusing anecdotes about his brief career as an actor
syn_n: account, narrative, story, tale  yarn

zh_Hans: （通常指一直付到某人死亡的）年金；年金保险；年金保险投资
syn: pocket money, sum of money, remittance, contribution, consideration, handout, grant, subsidy, maintenance, financial support, subsistence, benefit, stipend, pension, annuity, keep, upkeep, expenses
etym: From French annuité, from Medieval Latin annuitās, from Latin annuus (“annual”).
en: An annuity is an investment or insurance policy that pays someone a fixed sum of money each year.
syn_n: hire, salary, wages, compensation, premium, recompense, reimbursement, restitution, disbursement, expenditure, expense, reprisal, retaliation, retribution  vengeance

zh_Hans: （论据或理由）令人信服的，有说服力的，强而有力的
syn: compelling, strong, forceful, powerful, potent, weighty
etym: From Latin cōgēns, present active participle of cōgō (“drive together, compel”), from cō + agō (“drive”).
en: A cogent reason, argument, or example is strong and convincing.
example: There were perfectly cogent reasons why Julian Cavendish should be told of the Major's impending return.
example_ko: She put forward some cogent reasons for abandoning the plan.
syn_a: convincing, forceful, influential, persuasive, powerful

syn: zealousness, committedness, ardour, love, fervour, fire, avidity, fondness, devotion, devotedness, enthusiasm, eagerness, keenness, appetite, taste, relish, gusto
etym: From Middle English zele, from Old French zel, from Late Latin zēlus, from Ancient Greek ζῆλος (zêlos, “zeal, jealousy”), from ζηλόω (zēlóō, “to emulate, to be jealous”). Related to jealous.
en: Zeal is great enthusiasm, especially in connection with work, religion, or politics.
example: his zeal for teaching
example_ko: her missionary/reforming/religious/political zeal
syn_n: ardor, enthusiasm, fervor, intensity, vigor, zest

zh_Hans: 令人愉快的；有吸引力的；迷人的
syn: appealing, attractive, pretty, delightful, lovely, pleasing, pleasant, agreeable, likeable, lovable, sweet, winning, winsome, fetching, dazzling, arresting, captivating, enchanting, bewitching, alluring, irresistible, dreamy, heavenly, divine, gorgeous
en: An engaging person or thing is pleasant, interesting, and entertaining.
example: one of her most engaging and least known novels
example_ko: an engaging smile
syn_a: attractive, charming, likeable, pleasant, winning

syn: leaving, exit, withdrawal, retreat, pull-out, exodus, issue
en: Also called : egression the act of going or coming out; emergence
syn_n: door, exit, outlet, departure, emergence

zh_Hans: （笔迹或字体）清晰的，易读的，清楚的
syn: easily read, easy to read, decipherable, easily deciphered, clear, distinct, plain, carefully written, neat, sharp, vivid, intelligible, understandable, comprehensible
etym: From Late Latin legibilis (“that can be read”), from Latin legō
en: Legible writing is clear enough to read.
example: My handwriting isn't very legible.
example_ko: legible handwriting
syn_a: clean, clear, neat, plain, readable

etym: hegemony +‎ -ic
en: Hegemony is a situation in which one country, organization, or group has more power, control, or importance than others.

syn: loquacious, garrulous, talkative, voluble, orotund, expansive, babbling, blathering, prattling, prating, jabbering, gushing, effusive
etym: From Latin verbosus.
en: If you describe a person or a piece of writing as verbose, you are critical of them because they use more words than are necessary, and so make you feel bored or annoyed.
example: verbose politicians
example_ko: a verbose speaker/style
syn_a: prolix, voluble, wordy, garrulous, loquacious, talkative, effusive, grandiloquent, profuse, tautological

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：in 使… + grat 令人高兴的；高雅 + iate 做 → 使高兴 → 讨好
syn: find the favour of, cultivate, win over, get on the good side of, get in someone's good books
etym: First attested in 1622. From Italian ingraziare, from ingratiare, from in gratia, from Latin in grātiam (“into favour”), from grātus.
en: If someone tries to ingratiate themselves with you, they do things to try and make you like them.
example: Many politicians are trying to ingratiate themselves with her.
example_ko: The first part of his plan was to ingratiate himself with the members of the committee.
syn_v: cajole, court, curry favor, flatter, toady  wheedle

syn: wind, twist, turn, curve, curl, bend, snake
etym: From Latin Maeander, from Ancient Greek Μαίανδρος (Maíandros) – a river in Asia Minor (present day Turkey) known for its winding course. (Turkish Büyük Menderes Nehri)
en: If a river or road meanders, it has a lot of bends, rather than going in a straight line from one place to another.
example: roads that meandered round the edges of the fields
example_ko: The stream meanders slowly down to the sea.
syn_v: bend, snake, twist, wind, zigzag, amble, mosey, promenade, saunter, stroll, wander

syn: extravagant, spendthrift, improvident, imprudent, immoderate, profligate, thriftless, excessive, intemperate, irresponsible, self-indulgent, reckless, wanton
etym: From Middle French prodigal, from Late Latin prōdigālis (“wasteful”), from Latin prōdigus (“wasteful, lavish, prodigal”), from prōdigere (“to consume, squander, drive forth”), from prōd- [from prō (“before, forward”)] + agere (“to drive”).
en: You can describe someone as a prodigal son or daughter if they leave their family or friends, often after a period of behaving badly, and then return at a later time as a better person.
example: All the family went to the airport to welcome home the prodigal son.
syn_n: profligate, spendthrift, squanderer, wastrel
syn_a: excessive, extravagant, immoderate, wasteful

zh_Hans: 烧灼术；烙术；灸;腐蚀剂；烙器
en: the coagulation of blood or destruction of body tissue by cauterizing

syn: inerasable, ineffaceable, unexpungeable, indestructible, permanent, lasting, persisting, enduring, stubborn, ingrained, unfading, imperishable
etym: From Latin indelebilis (“indestructible”).
en: If you say that something leaves an indelible impression, you mean that it is very unlikely to be forgotten.
example: My visit to India in 1986 left an indelible impression on me
example_ko: The experience made an indelible impression on me.
syn_n: fast, lasting, memorable, permanent, unforgettable

zh_Hans: （尤指人或其表情）高深莫测的，难以捉摸的
syn: unreadable, impenetrable, mysterious, impossible to interpret, cryptic
etym: From the Latin inscrutabilis, from in- (“not”) + scrutare (“to examine”), corresponding to in- +‎ scrutable
en: If a person or their expression is inscrutable, it is very hard to know what they are really thinking or what they mean.
example: In public he remained inscrutable.
syn_a: enigmatic, impenetrable, insoluble, mysterious, perplexing, unfathomable

syn: charitable, altruistic, humane, humanitarian, neighbourly, public-spirited, philanthropic
etym: From Latin *beneficens, *beneficent-, from bene (“well, good”) + -ficens, combining form from faciens, present participle of facere (“to make or do”). Compare English beneficence.
en: A beneficent person or thing helps people or results in something good.
example: optimism about the beneficent effects of new technology.
syn_a: charitable, generous, munificent, unselfish, advantageous, beneficial, helpful  valuable

syn: corroding, mordant, acid, alkaline, burning, stinging, acrid, harsh, destructive
etym: From the Latin causticus (“burning”), from the Ancient Greek καυστικός (kaustikós, “burning”).
en: Caustic chemical substances are very powerful and can dissolve other substances.
example: caustic cleaning agents
syn_a: acrimonious, biting, harsh, sarcastic, scathing, astringent, burning, corrosive

zh_Hans: 不稳定的；易变的；易怒的，喜怒无常的
syn: vaporous, vaporescent
etym: From Middle French volatile, from Latin volātilis (“flying; swift; temporary; volatile”), from volō (“I fly”).
en: A situation that is volatile is likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly.
example: The international oil markets have been highly volatile since the early 1970s
example_ko: a highly volatile personality
syn_a: eruptive, explosive, inflammatory, volcanic, changeable, inconstant, unstable, variable, erratic, impulsive, irresolute, evanescent, gaseous, vaporous

zh_Hans: 雌雄同体的;兼具两性的
etym: From andro- +‎ -gen.
en: any of several steroids, produced as hormones by the testes or made synthetically, that promote development of male sexual organs and male secondary sexual characteristics

zh_Hans: 没有明显性别区分的；男女不分的；兼有两性特征的
syn: intersex, epicene
etym: From Latin androgynus (“hermaphrodite”), from Ancient Greek ἀνδρόγυνος (andrógunos, “eunuch”), from ἀνδρός (andrós) (genitive of ἀνήρ (anḗr, “man”)) + γυνή (gunḗ, “woman”) + -ous.
en: In biology, an androgynous person, animal, or plant has both male and female sexual characteristics.

ko: 듣기 좋은 음조(opp. cacophony); [언어] 활(滑)음조, 음운 변화
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：eu 好 + phon 声音，嗓音；讲话 + y 表名词 → 好听的声音
syn: mellowness, sweetness, sweet sound, sweet tone, prettiness, silveriness, mellifluousness, melodiousness, musicality, lilt, lyricism, harmony, euphony
etym: eu- (“good”) + -phony, from Middle French euphonie, from Late Latin euphonia, from Ancient Greek εὐφωνία (euphōnía), from εὔφωνος (eúphōnos).
en: the alteration of speech sounds, esp by assimilation, so as to make them easier to pronounce

ko: 다시 젊어 보이게[젊은 기분이 들게] 하다, 활기를 되찾게 하다
zh_Hans: 使年轻；使恢复活力；使青春焕发
syn: revitalize, renew, regenerate, restore, breathe new life into, make someone feel young again, revivify, reanimate, resuscitate, refresh, reawaken, rekindle, put new life into, put new heart into, add some zest to, put some spark into, kick-start, uplift
etym: re- (“again”) +‎ Latin iuvenis (“young”)  +‎ -ate
en: If something rejuvenates you, it makes you feel or look young again.
example: Shelley was advised that the Italian climate would rejuvenate him
syn_v: invigorate, renew, restore, revitalize, revive

zh_Hans: 公开的严厉批评（或责骂）
syn: opprobrium, vituperation, condemnation, castigation, denunciation, abuse, criticism, censure, flak, defamation, denigration, disparagement, derogation, slander, revilement, reviling, calumny, calumniation, execration, excoriation, lambasting, upbraiding, bad press, character assassination, attack, invective, libel, insults, aspersions
etym: From Late Latin obloquium (“contradiction”), from Latin obloquor (“speak against, contradict”).
en: defamatory or censorious statements, esp when directed against one person
syn_n: censure, denunciation, rebuke, disgrace, humiliation, ignominy, shame

ko: (무엇에 대해 모르거나 책임이 없다고) 말하다, (책임 등을) 부인하다
zh_Hans: 声明拒绝承担（责任）；否认
syn: refuse to accept, refuse to acknowledge, reject, wash one's hands of
etym: From Anglo-Norman disclaimer, from Old French desclamer (French: déclamer), des- + clamer.
en: If you disclaim knowledge of something or disclaim responsibility for something, you say that you did not know about it or are not responsible for it.
example: She disclaims any knowledge of her husband's business.
example_ko: She disclaimed any knowledge of her husband’s whereabouts.
syn_v: deny, disavow, forswear, renounce, repudiate

syn: bewail, deplore, complain about, express regret about
etym: From Middle English bemenen, bimenen, from Old English bemǣnan (“to bemoan, bewail, lament”); equivalent to be- (“about, concerning”) +‎ moan. Alteration of vowel from Middle to Modern English due to analogy with moan.
en: If you bemoan something, you express sorrow or dissatisfaction about it.
example: Universities and other research establishments bemoan their lack of funds.
example_ko: They sat bemoaning the fact that no one would give them a chance.
syn_v: bewail, lament, mourn, regret, rue

syn: lay out, spend, expend, dole out, hand out, part with, donate, give
etym: From Old French desbourser (modern: débourser). Equivalent to dis- +‎ burse (“purse”).
en: To disburse an amount of money means to pay it out, usually from a fund which has been collected for a particular purpose.
example: The aid will not be disbursed until next year
syn_v: allocate, dispense, distribute, dole out, issue

syn: predominance, dominance
etym: From Latin praeponderare (“outweigh”), from prae- (“before”) + ponderare (“to weigh”)
en: If there is a preponderance of one type of person or thing in a group, there is more of that type than of any other.
example: a preponderance of bright, middle-class children in one group.

zh_Hans: （演讲或文章）有强烈倾向的；有偏见的
syn: disputed, contended, at issue, moot, disputable, debatable, arguable, vexed, open to discussion, open to question, under discussion
etym: From tendency +‎ -ious, after German tendenziös.
en: Something that is tendentious expresses a particular opinion or point of view very strongly, especially one that many people disagree with.
example: His analysis was rooted in a somewhat tendentious reading of French history.
example_ko: to display artistic, etc. tendencies

syn: lot, mass, host, plenitude, cornucopia, riot
etym: From Late Latin plēthōra (earlier plētūra), from Ancient Greek πληθώρη (plēthṓrē, “fullness”), from πλήθω (plḗthō, “I fill”).
en: A plethora of something is a large amount of it, especially an amount of it that is greater than you need, want, or can cope with.
example: A plethora of new operators will be allowed to enter the market.
syn_n: plenty, profusion, excess, glut, plethora, surfeit, affluence, opulence, prosperity, wealth

syn: debauched, decadent, intemperate, immoderate, profligate, abandoned, self-indulgent, wild, unrestrained, fast-living
en: If you describe someone as dissipated, you disapprove of them because they spend a lot of time drinking alcohol and enjoying other physical pleasures, and are probably unhealthy because of this.
example: Flynn was still handsome, though dissipated.
example_ko: [V] Eventually, his anger dissipated.
syn_v: deplete, squander, waste, dispel, disperse, scatter, disappear, evanesce, evaporate, vanish

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：myri 一万，无数 + ad 表状态 → 无数（的）
syn: a great number, a great quantity, a large number, a large quantity, a lot, scores, quantities, mass, crowd, throng, host, droves, horde, army, legion, sea, swarm
etym: From French myriade, from Late Latin myriadis (genitive of myrias), from Ancient Greek μυριάδος (muriádos), genitive of μυριάς (muriás, “number of 10,000”), from μυρίος (muríos, “numberless, countless, infinite”).
en: A myriad or myriads of people or things is a very large number or great variety of them.
