example: They face a myriad of problems bringing up children
example_ko: Designs are available in a myriad of colours.
syn_n: abundance, profusion, scores, thousands, horde, host, multitude, throng
syn_a: countless, incalculable, infinite, innumerable, untold

syn: exposed, desolate, stark, arid, desert, denuded, lunar, open, empty, windswept
en: If a situation is bleak, it is bad, and seems unlikely to improve.
example: The immediate outlook remains bleak
example_ko: a bleak outlook/prospect
syn_a: dismal, dreary, gloomy, grim, hopeless, bare, barren, desolate, lonely

zh_Hans: 和蔼可亲的，亲切的；令人愉悦的；友好的
syn: affable, amicable, cordial
etym: Middle English amyable, from Old French amiable, from Late Latin amīcābilis (“friendly”), from Latin amīcus (“friend”), from amō (“I love”). The meaning has been influenced by French aimable, Latin amābilis (“loveable”). Compare with amicable, amorous, amability.
en: Someone who is amiable is friendly and pleasant to be with.
example_ko: an amiable tone of voice
syn_a: agreeable, congenial, friendly, good-natured, likeable, pleasant

syn: inclination, tendency, leaning, disposition, propensity, bent, bias, penchant, predisposition, predilection, partiality, preference, taste, fondness, weakness, proneness
etym: From Latin prōclīvitās, from pro (“toward”) + clīvus (“a slope, hill”).
en: A proclivity is a tendency to behave in a particular way or to like a particular thing, often a bad way or thing.
example: He was indulging his own sexual proclivities.
example_ko: his sexual/criminal proclivities
syn_n: affinity, bent, inclination, penchant, predilection, propensity, tendency

syn: sway, swing from side to side, swing back and forth, swing backwards and forwards, swing to and fro, vibrate
etym: From Latin ōscillātus, perfect passive participle of Latin ōscillō (“swing”), from ōscillum (“a swing”), usually identified with ōscillum (“a little face or mask hung to a tree and swaying with the wind”), diminutive of ōs (“mouth, face”).
en: If an object oscillates, it moves repeatedly from one position to another and back again, or keeps getting bigger and smaller.
example: I checked to see if the needle indicating volume was oscillating.
example_ko: Her moods oscillated between depression and elation.
syn_v: seesaw, swing, turn, vibrate, fluctuate, vacillate, vary  waver

syn: reproduction, duplicate, photocopy, mimeograph, mimeo, replica, likeness, carbon, carbon copy, print, reprint, offprint, image
etym: From Latin fac simile (“make like”), from fac (“make”) (imperative of facere (“make”)) + simile (neuter of similis (“like, similar”)).
en: A facsimile of something is an copy or imitation of it.
example: a facsimile edition of Beethoven's musical manuscripts.
example_ko: a facsimile edition
syn_n: copy, duplicate, imitation, reproduction

zh_Hans: 和蔼可亲的；友善的；容易交谈的
syn: amiable, genial, congenial, cordial, warm, pleasant, pleasing, nice, likeable, personable, charming, agreeable, sympathetic, benevolent, benign, good-humoured, good-natured, kindly, kind, courteous, civil, gracious, approachable, accessible, amenable, sociable, outgoing, gregarious, convivial, jovial, clubbable, comradely, neighbourly, welcoming, hospitable, obliging, easy-going, informal, open, communicative, unreserved, uninhibited, natural, relaxed, easy
etym: French affable, Latin affābilis, from affor (“I address”), from ad + for (“speak, talk”). See fable.
en: Someone who is affable is pleasant and friendly.
example: Mr Brooke is an extremely affable and approachable man.
syn_a: amiable, congenial, cordial, friendly, pleasant, sociable

syn: placate, pacify, mollify, propitiate, assuage, calm down, soothe, humour, reconcile, disarm, win over, make peace with
etym: Borrowed from Latin conciliātus, perfect passive participle of conciliō (“I unite”), from concilium (“council, meeting”).
en: If you conciliate someone, you try to end a disagreement with them.
example: His duty was to conciliate the people, not to provoke them

zh_Hans: 发（射，流）出；流出物；射出物
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：ef 出，外 + flu 流 + ence 表行为 → 流出
syn: emission, release, outflow, outflowing, outpouring, outrush, rush, flood, deluge, spurt, jet, cascade, stream, torrent, gush
etym: From French effluence, from Latin effluentia.
en: the act or process of flowing out

syn: offender, wrongdoer, person responsible
etym: From Anglo-Norman cul. prit, contraction of culpable: prest (d'averrer nostre bille) 'guilty: ready (to prove our case)', words used by prosecutor in opening a trial, mistaken in English for an address to the defendant. See culpable.
en: When you are talking about a crime or something wrong that has been done, you can refer to the person who did it as the culprit.
example: All the men were being deported even though the real culprits in the fight have not been identified.
example_ko: The police quickly identified the real culprits.
syn_n: criminal, guilty party, malefactor, miscreant  offender

syn: sully, mar, impair, debase, degrade
etym: From French défilé.
en: To defile something that people think is important or holy means to do something to it or say something about it which is offensive.
example: He had defiled the sacred name of the Holy Prophet.
example_ko: Many victims of burglary feel their homes have been defiled.
syn_v: befoul, besmirch, dirty, spoil, blemish, smear, soil, stain, tarnish, debase, debauch, degrade, disgrace, dishonor, desecrate, profane, violate

etym: Borrowed from German Graphit (A. G. Werner 1789), from Ancient Greek γράφω (gráphō, “I write”).
en: Graphite is a soft black substance that is a form of carbon. It is used in pencils and electrical equipment.

zh_Hans: （尤指对不好的事情的）迂回曲折的说法；婉转语，遁词
syn: circuitousness, indirectness
etym: From Latin circumlocūtiō (“the act of speaking around; circumlocution, periphrasis”). Surface analysis circum- (“around”) +‎ locution (“talk”); see these for related terms. Probably a calque of Ancient Greek περίφρασις (períphrasis, “periphrasis”).
en: A circumlocution is a way of saying or writing something using more words than are necessary instead of being clear and direct.
example_ko: Without circumlocution, your offer is stupid.
syn_n: digression, rambling, tautology, vagueness, verbiage, verbosity

syn: sovereignty, autocracy, monocracy, absolutism, absolute power, despotism
etym: From Old French monarchie, from Late Latin monarchia, from Ancient Greek μοναρχία (monarkhía), from μόνος (mónos, “only”) + ἀρχή (arkhḗ, “power, authority”).
en: A monarchy is a system in which a country has a monarch.
example: a serious debate on the future of the monarchy.
example_ko: plans to abolish the monarchy

syn: important person, VIP, very important person, notable, notability, worthy, personage, luminary, public figure, pillar of society, leading light, leader, panjandrum
en: Dignitaries are people who are considered to be important because they have a high rank in government or in the Church.
syn_n: celebrity, dignitary, notable, star, celestial body, orb, star  sun

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：dys 不良 + troph 营养 + y 表情况 → 营养不良
etym: dys- +‎ -trophy
en: → see muscular dystrophy

zh_Hans: (旧时手工纺纱用的)纺纱杆，绕线杆
etym: Raffaello Sorbi, The Spinner (1872), from a private collection. The painting depicts a woman holding up a distaff (sense 1) in her left hand and a spindle in her right.
en: the rod on which flax is wound preparatory to spinning
example_ko: on thedistaff side

zh_Hans: 不活泼的；（尤指因懒惰或困倦）迟钝的，呆滞的
syn: sluggish, inert, inactive, slow, slow-moving, lifeless, dull, listless, languid, lazy, idle, indolent, shiftless, slothful, heavy, stagnant, somnolent, sleepy, tired, fatigued, languorous, apathetic, passive, supine, comatose, narcotic
etym: From Latin torpidus (“tired, numb”)
en: If you are torpid, you are mentally or physically inactive, especially because you are feeling lazy or sleepy.
syn_a: lackadaisical, lethargic, listless, sleepy, sluggish, apathetic, passive, dormant, hibernating, inert

syn: dissoluteness, degeneracy, debauchery, corruption, depravity, loucheness, vice, sinfulness, perversion, moral decay, immorality, lack of morals, lack of principles, lack of restraint, lack of control, lack of self-control, immoderateness, intemperance, licentiousness, wantonness, self-indulgence, hedonism, epicureanism
etym: From French décadence, from Medieval Latin decadentia (“decay”), from *decadens (“decaying”), present participle of *decadere (“to decay”); see decay.
example: The empire had for years been falling into decadence.
example_ko: the decadence of modern Western society
syn_n: corruption, degeneracy, perversion, decay, decline  deterioration

syn: rash, hasty, overhasty, reckless, heedless, foolhardy, incautious, imprudent, injudicious, ill-conceived, ill-considered, unplanned, unreasoned, unthought-out, unthinking
etym: From Middle English, from Old French impetueux, from Late Latin impetuōsus (“violent”), from Latin impetus (“attack, violence”).
en: If you describe someone as impetuous, you mean that they are likely to act quickly and suddenly without thinking or being careful.
example: He was young and impetuous
example_ko: an impetuous young woman
syn_a: hasty, headlong, impulsive, precipitate, rash, spontaneous, brash, careless, heedless, reckless, thoughtless, fiery, hotheaded, impatient, passionate, forceful, powerful, stormy, violent

syn: superabundant, plentiful, ample, profuse, full, extensive, considerable, substantial, generous, bumper, lavish, fulsome, liberal, bountiful, overflowing, abounding, teeming
etym: From Middle English, from Latin copiosus, copia (“abundance”), from Latin co- + ops (“wealth”)[1] + -osus (“full of”).
en: A copious amount of something is a large amount of it.
example: I went out for a meal last night and drank copious amounts of red wine
example_ko: copious amounts of water
syn_a: abundant, ample, bountiful, generous, plentiful, profuse

zh_Hans: （艺术家成名之后出版或被发现的）少年时期作品
etym: From Latin iuvenīlia, neuter plural of iuvenīlis (“of or pertaining to youth”).
en: works of art, literature, or music produced in youth or adolescence, before the artist, author, or composer has formed a mature style

syn: fair-mindedness, justness, justice, equitableness, fair play
etym: Attested in 14th century; from Old French equite [13th c.], from Latin aequitas (“uniformity”, “impartiality”, “fairness”).
en: In finance, your equity is the sum of your assets, for example the value of your house, once your debts have been subtracted from it.→ see also negative equity
example: To capture his equity, Murphy must either sell or refinance.
example_ko: private equity investment by financial institutions
syn_n: fairness, impartiality, justice, assets, cash value

zh_Hans: （常指因宗教原因）苦行的，禁欲的，过清苦生活的
syn: self-denying, abstinent, abstemious, non-indulgent, self-disciplined, frugal, simple, rigorous, strict, severe, hair-shirt, spartan, monastic, monkish, monklike, nunlike
etym: 17th century, from Medieval Latin asceticus, from Ancient Greek ἀσκητικός (askētikós), from ἀσκητής (askētḗs, “monk, hermit”), from ἀσκέω (askéō, “I exercise”).
en: An ascetic person has a way of life that is simple and strict, usually because of their religious beliefs.
example_ko: The monks lived a very ascetic life.
syn_n: celibate, eremite, hermit, monk, recluse
syn_a: abstemious, austere, rigorous, spartan, strict

zh_Hans: 联结点；枢纽；（公路的）交叉口；（铁路）联络车站
syn: joint, intersection, link, bond, weld, seam, coupling, connection, union, juncture
etym: From Latin iūnctiō (“union, joining, uniting”), from iungō (“join, attach together”).
en: A junction is a place where roads or railway lines join.in AM, usually use intersection
example: Follow the road to a junction and turn left
example_ko: It was near the junction of City Road and Old Street.
syn_n: crossing, crossroads, interchange, intersection, binding, linking, splicing, union, hinge, joint, pivot, seam, suture, alliance, bond, connection, league

syn: course, course of study, programme of study, educational programme, course outline
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin syllabus (“list”), which arose as a misprint, its accusative plural syllabos appearing in place of sittybas in a 1470s edition of Cicero's “Ad Atticum” IV.5 and 8.[1] The corrupt form was influenced by the stem of Ancient Greek συλλαμβάνω (sullambánō, “put together”), the source of σῠλλᾰβή (sullabḗ, “syllable”); the true etymon is σιττύβα (sittúba, “parchment label, table of contents”) of unknown origin.[2]
en: You can refer to the subjects that are studied in a particular course as the syllabus.
example: the GCSE history syllabus.

etym: From French lexicographe, from Ancient Greek λεξικός (lexikós, “of words”) + γράφω (gráphō, “write”); synchronically, lexico- +‎ -grapher.
en: Lexicography is the activity or profession of writing dictionaries.
example: A lexicographer's job is to describe the language.

syn: obscene, indecent, improper, indelicate, crude, lewd, erotic, titillating, arousing, suggestive, sexy, risqué, coarse, vulgar, gross, dirty, ribald, smutty, filthy, bawdy, earthy
etym: Derived from Latin salāx, salācis (“provocative, lustful”) +‎ English -ious.
en: If you describe something such as a book or joke as salacious, you think that it deals with sexual matters in an unnecessarily detailed way.
example: The newspapers once again filled their columns with salacious details.

syn: gullibleness, credulousness, naivety, naiveness, blind faith, trustfulness, over-trustfulness, lack of suspicion, innocence, ingenuousness, unworldliness, lack of experience, lack of sophistication, guilelessness, greenness, callowness, childlikeness, simpleness, simplicity, ignorance
etym: Borrowed from Old French credulité (French crédulité), from Latin crēdulitās.
en: Credulity is a willingness to believe that something is real or true.
example: The plot does stretch credulity.
example_ko: The plot of the novel stretches credulity to the limit.

syn: beautiful woman, dream, vision, picture, pin-up, goddess, Venus, siren, charmer, enchantress, seductress
etym: From French belle (“beautiful”), from Latin bella.
en: A belle is a beautiful woman, especially the most beautiful woman at a party or in a group.
syn_n: beauty, charmer, debutante, queen
syn_a: attractive, beautiful, bonny, fair, pretty

zh_Hans: 极令人不快的；令人厌恶的
syn: rude, derogatory, disrespectful, hurtful, wounding, abusive, objectionable, displeasing, annoying, exasperating, irritating, vexing, galling, provocative, provoking, humiliating, impertinent, impudent, insolent, personal, discourteous, uncivil, impolite, unmannerly, unacceptable, shocking, scandalous, outrageous
etym: From Middle English noy +‎ -some (short for annoy, from an(n)oien, enoien from Anglo-Norman anuier, from Old French enuier (French ennuyer), from Late Latin inodiare (“to make hateful”), from in- (intensive prefix) + odium (“hate”).[1]
en: If you describe something or someone as noisome, you mean that you find them extremely unpleasant.
example: Noisome vapours arise from the mud left in the docks
example_ko: noisome smells

syn: headstrong, wilful, unyielding, inflexible, unbending, intransigent, intractable, obdurate, mulish, stubborn as a mule, pig-headed, bull-headed, self-willed, strong-minded, strong-willed, contrary, perverse, recalcitrant, refractory, uncooperative, unmanageable, cross-grained, stiff-necked, stiff, rigid, steely, iron-willed, uncompromising, implacable, relentless, unrelenting, unpersuadable, immovable, unmalleable, unshakeable, inexorable, with one's feet dug in, with one's toes dug in, persistent, persevering, tenacious, pertinacious, dogged, single-minded, adamant, firm, steadfast, determined
etym: From Middle English obstinate, obstinat, from Latin obstinātus, past participle of obstinō (“set one's mind firmly upon, resolve”), from ob (“before”) + *stinare, from stare (“to stand”).
en: If you describe someone as obstinate, you are being critical of them because they are very determined to do what they want, and refuse to change their mind or be persuaded to do something else.
example: He is obstinate and determined and will not give up
example_ko: He can be very obstinate when he wants to be!
syn_a: adamant, implacable, inflexible, obdurate, resolute, stubborn

zh_Hans: （递送重要书信或文件的）信差 ，递送员
syn: special messenger, dispatch rider, letter carrier, mail carrier, runner, bearer, message bearer, message carrier, delivery man, delivery woman, conveyor, envoy, emissary, harbinger, herald
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman courrier, from Old French coreor, agent noun of corir (“to run”). Doublet of horse and course.
en: A courier is a person who is paid to take letters and parcels direct from one place to another.
example: The cheques were delivered to the bank by a private courier firm.
example_ko: We sent the documents by courier.
syn_n: carrier, courier, harbinger, herald, emissary, envoy, intermediary, representative

zh_Hans: （就重大政治或社会问题进行的）全民公决，全民公投
syn: plebiscite, popular vote, ballot, poll
etym: From Latin referendum (“that which ought to be announced”), from refero (“I announce”).
en: If a country holds a referendum on a particular policy, they ask the people to vote on the policy and show whether or not they agree with it.
example: Estonia said it too planned to hold a referendum on independence.
example_ko: Ireland decided to hold a referendum on divorce.

ko: 뭐라고요(상대방의 말을 알아듣지 못했을 때 다시 말해 달라는 뜻으로 하는 말)
zh_Hans: 原谅，宽恕（常用于礼貌的表达方式）
syn: absolution, remission, clemency, mercy, lenience, leniency, condonation
etym: From Middle English pardonen, from Old French pardoner (modern French pardonner), from Vulgar Latin *perdonare, from per- + donare, a loan-translation of a Germanic word represented by Frankish *firgeban (“to forgive, give up completely”), from fir- + geban. Akin to Old High German fargeban, firgeban (“to forgive”), Old English forġiefan (“to forgive”). More at forgive.
en: You say `Pardon?' or `I beg your pardon?' or, in American English, `Pardon me?' when you want someone to repeat what they have just said because you have not heard or understood it.
example: Will you let me open it?'-'Pardon?'-'Can I open it?'
example_ko: ‘You’re very quiet today.’ ‘Pardon?’ ‘I said you’re very quiet today.’
syn_n: absolution, grace, mercy, amnesty, clemency, leniency
syn_v: absolve, excuse, forgive, acquit, clear, exonerate

syn: crash into, come into collision, come into collision with, bang, bang into, slam, slam into, impact, impact with
etym: From Latin collidere (“to strike or clash together”), from com- (“together”) + laedere (“to strike, dash against, hurt”); see lesion.
en: If two or more moving people or objects collide, they crash into one another. If a moving person or object collides with a person or object that is not moving, they crash into them.
example: Two trains collided head-on in north-eastern Germany early this morning
example_ko: The car and the van collided head-on in thick fog.
syn_v: bump, crash, hit, jar, clash, conflict, differ, disagree

syn: intensely hot, red-hot, burning, fiery, on fire, blazing, ablaze, aflame
etym: From French incandescent, from Latin incandescens, from incandesco (“be heated, glow”), from in- (“intensifying prefix”) + candesco (“become white”), from candidus (“white”).
en: Incandescent substances or devices give out a lot of light when heated.
example: incandescent gases.
example_ko: incandescent lamps
syn_a: bright, effulgent, gleaming, radiant, resplendent, shiny, fluorescent, luminescent, luminous, phosphorescent

syn: confirm, affirm, verify, swear to, testify to, bear witness to, bear out, back up, support, corroborate, substantiate, prove, uphold, show the truth of, give substance to, give credence to, second, endorse, certify, warrant, validate, give assurance of
etym: Borrowed from Old French voucher, from Latin vocāre, present active infinitive of vocō.
en: to give personal assurance; guarantee
example: I'll vouch for his safety
example_ko: ( vouch +[전]+[명] ) vouch  for the truth of a report
syn_v: assure, guarantee, insure, warrant, authenticate, certify, confirm, endorse, verify

ko: (특히 무엇에 맞고 난 뒤) 방향을 바꾸다[바꾸게 하다]
syn: turn away, divert, avert, sidetrack
etym: From Latin deflecto, from de- + flecto (“to bend”).
en: If you deflect something such as criticism or attention, you act in a way that prevents it from being directed towards you or affecting you.
example: Cage changed his name to deflect accusations of nepotism
example_ko: [V] The ball deflected off Reid’s body into the goal.
syn_v: avert, divert, parry, shunt, turn

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：sub 下 + aqu 水 + e + ous …的 → 水下的
syn: submarine, sub-aquatic, subaqueous
etym: sub- +‎ aqueous
en: occurring, appearing, formed, or used under water

zh_Hans: （尤指对棘手或令人痛苦之事）率直的，坦诚的，直言不讳的
syn: outspoken, forthright, blunt, open, honest, truthful, sincere, direct, straightforward, plain-spoken, bluff, unreserved, downright, not afraid to call a spade a spade, straight from the shoulder, unvarnished, bald
etym: From Latin candidus (“white”).
en: When you are candid about something or with someone, you speak honestly.
example: I haven't been completely candid with him.
example_ko: a candid statement / interview
syn_a: blunt, direct, frank, open, straightforward, genuine, honest, sincere, truthful, extemporaneous, impromptu, spontaneous

syn: arcane, esoteric, little known, recherché, rarefied, recondite, difficult, hard, puzzling, perplexing, enigmatic, inscrutable, cryptic, Delphic, complex, complicated, involved, above one's head, over one's head, incomprehensible, unfathomable, impenetrable, mysterious
etym: From French abstrus[1] or its source, Latin abstrūsus (“hidden, concealed”), the perfect passive participle of abstrūdō (“conceal, to push away”)[2], itself from ab, abs (“away”) + trūdō (“thrust, push”).[3] Cognate with German abstrus.
en: You can describe something as abstruse if you find it difficult to understand, especially when you think it could be explained more simply.
example: fruitless discussions about abstruse resolutions.
example_ko: an abstruse argument
syn_a: abstract, complex, complicated, incomprehensible, obscure, recondite

syn: cut, cut down, cut back, decrease, lessen, diminish, slim down, tighten up, retrench, pare down, trim, dock, lop, shrink
etym: Alteration of curtal, from Old French courtault (“which has been shortened”), itself from court (“short”) (from Latin curtus) + -ault
en: If you curtail something, you reduce or limit it.
example: NATO plans to curtail the number of troops being sent to the region
example_ko: Spending on books has been severely curtailed.
syn_n: abbreviate, decrease, diminish, reduce, shorten

zh_Hans: 按事件发生的年代排列的顺序；（大事）年表
syn: order, course, series, chain, concatenation, train, string, cycle, progression
etym: From chrono- (“relating to time”) +‎ -logy (“study of, account of”), after New Latin chronologia.
en: The chronology of a series of past events is the times at which they happened in the order in which they happened.
example: She gave him a factual account of the chronology of her brief liaison.
example_ko: Historians seem to have confused the chronology of these events.

ko: (특히 다른 주문을 함으로써 앞의 주문을) 철회하다
zh_Hans: 取消，撤回（命令）；重新发布（命令）
syn: rescind, reverse, undo, repeal, retract, withdraw, take back, abrogate, abolish, quash, scrap, override, overturn, overrule, do away with, set aside, cancel, annul, invalidate, nullify, negate, veto, declare null and void
etym: From Old French contremander, from Medieval Latin contramandō, from contra- + mandō (“I order; I command”).
en: If you countermand an order, you cancel it, usually by giving a different order.
example: I can't countermand an order Winger's given.
syn_v: annul, cancel, rescind, repeal, void

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：de 离开 + vi 道路 + ate 使… → 使偏离道路 → 越轨
syn: digress, drift, stray, slew, veer, swerve, turn away, turn aside, get sidetracked, branch off, differ, vary, change, depart, be different
etym: Late Latin deviatus, past participle of deviare, from the phrase de via.
en: To deviate from something means to start doing something different or not planned, especially in a way that causes problems for others.
example: They stopped you as soon as you deviated from the script
example_ko: The bus had to deviate from its usual route because of a road closure.
syn_n: degenerate, maniac, pervert
syn_v: change, diverge, swerve, vary, veer, depart from, digress, err, stray, wander
syn_a: aberrant, abnormal, peculiar

syn: abuse, vituperation, condemnation, criticism, censure, castigation, denunciation, defamation, denigration, disparagement, obloquy, derogation, slander, revilement, reviling, calumny, calumniation, execration, excoriation, lambasting, upbraiding, bad press, character assassination, attack, invective, libel, insults, aspersions
etym: Learned borrowing from Latin opprobrium (“reproach, disgrace”), first attested [1656], from opprobrō (“reproach, taunt”), from ob (“against”) + probrum (“disgrace, dishonor”).
en: Opprobrium is open criticism or disapproval of something that someone has done.
example: His political opinions have attracted the opprobrium of the Left.
syn_n: ignominy

syn: hunk, brick, slab, lump, piece
etym: Borrowed from Latin occludĕre, from ob (“before”) and claudĕre (“to shut”).
en: to block or stop up (a passage or opening); obstruct
example_ko: an occluded artery

syn: prevent, remove, get rid of, do away with, get round, rule out, eliminate, make unnecessary, take away, foreclose, avoid, avert, counter
etym: From Latin obviāre (“to block, to hinder”).
en: To obviate something such as a problem or a need means to remove it or make it unnecessary.
example: The use of a solicitor trained as a mediator would obviate the need for independent legal advice
example_ko: This new evidence obviates the need for any further enquiries.

syn: spectre, spirit, phantom, apparition, manifestation, vision, shadow, presence, poltergeist, supernatural being
etym: First attested 1513, in a Middle Scots translation of the Aeneid (book 10 of the Eneados of Gawin Douglas): "Nor ȝit na vayn wrathys nor gaiſtis quent / Thi char conſtrenyt bakwart forto went" (c. X, ln. 81-82; "Nor yet no vain wraiths nor quaint ghosts / constrained Thy chariot to go backward"), "Syklyke as that, thai ſay, in diuers placis / The wraithis walkis of goiſtis that ar ded" (c. XI, ln. 95-96; "Such as that, they say, in diverse places / The wraiths walk of ghosts that are dead"), "Thydder went this wrath or ſchaddo of Ene, / That ſemyt, all abaſyt, faſt to fle" (c. XI, ln. 129-130; "Thither went this wraith or shade of Ene, / That seemed, all abased, fast to flee").
en: A wraith is a ghost.
example: That child flits about like a wraith.
example_ko: a wraith-like figure

zh_Hans: （艺术作品的）选集；（常指）精选集
syn: compilation, anthology, treasury, digest
etym: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ἀνθολογία (anthología, “flower-gathering”), from ἀνθολογέω (anthologéō, “I gather flowers”), from ἄνθος (ánthos, “flower”) + λέγω (légō, “I gather, pick up, collect”), coined by Meleager of Gadara circa 60 BCE, originally as Στέφανος (στέφανος (stéphanos, “garland”)) to describe a collection of poetry, later retitled anthology – see Greek Anthology. Anthologiai were collections of small Greek poems and epigrams, because in Greek culture the flower symbolized the finer sentiments that only poetry can express.
en: An anthology is a collection of writings by different writers published together in one book.
example: an anthology of poetry.
syn_n: collection, compendium, compilation, digest  treasury

ko: 몰수[압수]의; <세금 등을> 심하게 징수하는; 몰수와 마찬가지의
en: involving confiscation
example: There is concern that police use the law to confiscate assets from people who have committed minor offences
example_ko: Their land was confiscated after the war.

zh_Hans: 早已过时的，十分老式的
syn: prehistoric, primeval, primordial, primal, earliest, ancient, early
etym: From ante- (“before”) +‎ Latin dīluvium (“flood”); in reference to the story of Noah’s Ark (Genesis 6–9), an early episode in the Bible.
en: Antediluvian things are old or old-fashioned.
example: antediluvian attitudes to women.
syn_n: ancient, elder, patriarch
syn_a: antiquated, archaic, obsolete, aboriginal, prehistoric, primal, primitive

syn: content, cheerful, cheery, merry, joyful, jovial, jolly, joking, jocular, gleeful, carefree, untroubled, delighted, smiling, beaming, grinning, glowing, satisfied, gratified, buoyant, radiant, sunny, blithe, joyous, beatific, blessed
etym: From Latin iocōsus (“humorous”), from iocus (“jest, joke”).
en: characterized by humour; merry
syn_a: comical, droll, humorous, jocular, light, playful, witty

syn: bountiful, open-handed, magnanimous, philanthropic, princely, handsome, lavish, unstinting, free-handed, unstinted, liberal, free, charitable, big-hearted, beneficent, ungrudging
etym: Back-formation from munificence, from Latin mūnificentia.
en: A munificent person is very generous.
example: one of the country's most munificent artistic benefactors.
example_ko: a munificent patron/gift/gesture
syn_a: beneficent, generous, magnanimous, philanthropic, extravagant, lavish, opulent, profuse

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：in 进入 + flux 流动 → 流入 → 涌入
syn: inrush, rush, stream, flood, incursion, ingress
etym: From Latin īnfluxus (“inflow; influence”), from īnfluō (“flow or run into”).
en: An influx of people or things into a place is their arrival there in large numbers.
example: problems caused by the influx of refugees.
example_ko: a massive/sudden influx of visitors
syn_n: flood, incursion, inflow, inrush, inundation, invasion

syn: destiny, fortune, providence, the stars, God's will, what is written in the stars, one's doom, one's portion, one's lot, one's lot in life, karma, predestination, preordination, predetermination, what is to come, the writing on the wall
etym: From Ottoman Turkish قسمت‎ (kısmet, “fate, destiny”) (Turkish kısmet), from Arabic قِسْمَة‎ (qisma, “division, lot, destiny”).
en: the will of Allah
syn_n: destiny, doom, fate, fortune, luck  providence

syn: extol, praise, acclaim, pay homage to, pay tribute to, revere, reverence, venerate, worship, hero-worship, lionize, idolize, deify, esteem, hold in high regard, hold in high esteem, hold in awe, look up to
etym: From Old French exalter, from Latin exaltō
en: To exalt someone or something means to praise them very highly.
example: His work exalts all those virtues that we, as Americans, are taught to hold dear.
example_ko: The theater critics exalt the young actor to the skies.
syn_v: ennoble, enshrine, extol, glorify, honor, laud, elevate, exhilarate, inspire

syn: dermis
etym: Borrowed from Latin epidermis, from Ancient Greek ἐπιδερμίς (epidermís) (ἐπί, on top of) + dermis (< δέρμα(derma), skin)
en: Your epidermis is the thin, protective, outer layer of your skin.

syn: lacking courage, fearful, apprehensive, faint-hearted
etym: From Old French temoros, from Medieval Latin timorosus, from Latin timor fear, from timeō to be afraid.
en: If you describe someone as timorous, you mean that they are frightened and nervous of other people and situations.
example: He is a reclusive, timorous creature.
syn_a: apprehensive, cowardly, fainthearted, mousy, pusillanimous, timorous, bashful, retiring, shy, unassertive

syn: setting aside, suspension, revocation, repeal, rescinding, abrogation
etym: From Old French remission (compare French rémission), from Latin remissio (“release”). Compare remit.
en: If someone who has had a serious disease such as cancer is in remission or if the disease is in remission, the disease has been controlled so that they are not as ill as they were.
example: Brain scans have confirmed that the disease is in remission
example_ko: The patient has been in remission for the past six months.
syn_a: careless, inattentive, lax, negligent, slack

ko: 치명적인(특히 그 영향이 서서히 알아차리기 힘들게 진행되는 경우)
zh_Hans: 极其有害的；恶性的；恶劣的
syn: damaging, destructive, injurious, hurtful, detrimental, deleterious, dangerous, adverse, inimical, unhealthy, unfavourable, bad, evil, baleful, wicked, malign, malevolent, malignant, noxious, poisonous, cancerous, corrupting, ruinous, deadly, lethal, fatal
etym: From Middle English, from Old French pernicios, from Latin perniciōsus (“destructive”), from perniciēs (“destruction”), from per (“through”) + nex (“slaughter, death”).
en: If you describe something as pernicious, you mean that it is very harmful.
example: I did what I could, but her mother's influence was pernicious
syn_a: deadly, fatal, lethal, mortal, noxious, damaging, deleterious, detrimental, harmful, serious

syn: liberate, free, set free, let go, let out, allow to leave, let loose, set loose, turn loose
etym: From Medieval Latin exculpātus, perfect passive participle of exculpō, from Latin ex culpa, from ex- (“out, from”) + culpa (“fault; blame”).
en: to free from blame or guilt; vindicate or exonerate
example_ko: He exculpated himself from cheating in the College Scholastic Ability Test.
syn_v: acquit, exonerate, pardon, reprieve, vindicate

zh_Hans: 在一天内发生的；白天发生的；昼行性的
syn: non-nocturnal
etym: From Latin diurnālis, from diēs (“day”). Cognate with journal.
en: Diurnal means happening or active during the daytime.
example: Kangaroos are diurnal animals.

ko: (특정 주제나 전문 분야를 다루는) 신문[잡지], 저널, 학술지
syn: publication, magazine, gazette, digest, professional organ, review, newsletter, news-sheet, bulletin
etym: From Old French journal (“daily”), from Latin diurnālis, from diurnus (“of the day”), from diēs (“day”). Cognate with diurnal.
en: A journal is a magazine, especially one that deals with a specialized subject.
example: All our results are published in scientific journals.
example_ko: a scientific/trade journal
syn_n: chronicle, diary, memoir, record, register, gazette, magazine, periodical, publication, daybook, file, ledger  registry

zh_Hans: 自相矛盾的情况；似非而是的说法，悖论；诡论
syn: contradiction in terms, self-contradiction, inconsistency, incongruity, anomaly, conflict
etym: From Middle French paradoxe, from Latin paradoxum, from Ancient Greek παράδοξος (parádoxos, “unexpected, strange”).
en: You describe a situation as a paradox when it involves two or more facts or qualities which seem to contradict each other.
example: The paradox is that the region's most dynamic economies have the most primitive financial systems
example_ko: He was a paradox—a loner who loved to chat to strangers.
syn_n: contradiction, incongruity, inconsistency, ambiguity, dilemma  puzzle

syn: devoted, loyal, faithful, compliant, respectful, dedicated, affectionate, loving
etym: From Middle English filial, from Latin fīliālis, from filius (“son”) / filia (“daughter”).
en: You can use filial to describe the duties, feelings, or relationships which exist between a son or daughter and his or her parents.
example: His father would accuse him of neglecting his filial duties
example_ko: filial affection/duty

zh_Hans: （与死亡或暴力有关而）恐怖的，可怕的，令人毛骨悚然的
syn: grisly, grim, gory, morbid, ghastly, unearthly, lurid, grotesque, hideous, horrific, horrible, horrifying, horrid, horrendous, terrifying, frightening, frightful, fearsome, shocking, dreadful, appalling, loathsome, repugnant, repulsive, sickening
etym: Borrowed from French macabre, whose etymology is uncertain,[1] but possibly derives from the term danse macabre – the attribute of which was construed as an adjective – most commonly believed to be from corruption of the biblical name Maccabees; compare Latin Chorea Machabaeorum.
en: You describe something such as an event or story as macabre when it is strange and horrible or upsetting, usually because it involves death or injury.
example: Police have made a macabre discovery
example_ko: a macabre tale/joke/ritual
syn_a: gory, grotesque, gruesome, hideous, morbid

zh_Hans: （尤指组织或公司）无生气的，停滞不前的，失败的
syn: expiring, on one's deathbed, near death, near the end, at death's door, breathing one's last, fading fast, sinking fast, not long for this world, failing rapidly, on one's last legs, in extremis
etym: From French moribond, from Latin moribundus (“dying”)
en: If you describe something as moribund, you mean that it is in a very bad condition.
example: the moribund economy.
syn_a: ailing, deteriorating, dying, failing, waning

zh_Hans: 尖刻的，刻毒的；暴躁的，易怒的
syn: touchy, testy, irascible, cross, snappish, cantankerous, splenetic, short-tempered, ill-tempered, bad-tempered, foul-tempered, moody, crabbed, crotchety, grumpy, huffy, ratty, petulant, peevish, querulous, angry, sharp
etym: From wasp +‎ -ish.
en: A waspish remark or sense of humour is sharp and critical.
example_ko: a privileged Wasp background
syn_a: cantankerous, irascible, irritable, splenetic, testy, cranky, mean, nasty, ornery, spiteful

syn: put off, adjourn, delay, hold off, hold over, put back, carry over
en: If you defer an event or action, you arrange for it to happen at a later date, rather than immediately or at the previously planned time.
example: Customers often defer payment for as long as possible
example_ko: [VN] The department deferred the decision for six months.
syn_n: detainment, holdup, lag, wait, deferral, postponement, stay, suspension
syn_v: detain, retard, slow, stall, dally, dawdle, linger, loiter, postpone, procrastinate, shelve, suspend

syn: hate, detestation, dislike, distaste, abhorrence, abomination, execration, resentment, aversion, hostility, ill will, ill feeling, bad feeling
etym: abhor +‎ -ence
en: Someone's abhorrence of something is their strong hatred of it.
example: They are anxious to show their abhorrence of racism.
syn_n: execration, hatred, loathing, odium, contempt, disdain, scorn, aversion, disgust, repugnance, revulsion

syn: loathing, abhorrence, execration, revulsion, abomination, disgust, repugnance, horror, antipathy, odium, aversion, hostility, animosity, enmity, dislike, distaste, disdain, contempt
etym: From Middle French détestation.
en: intense hatred; abhorrence
example: My mother detested him
example_ko: [VN] They detested each other on sight.
syn_n: abhorrence, enmity, hatred, loathing, malice, malignity
syn_v: abhor, despise, detest, loathe

syn: expressive, articulate, fluent
etym: From Old French eloquent, from Latin eloquens (“speaking, having the faculty of speech, eloquent”), present participle of eloqui (“to speak out”), from e (“out”) + loqui (“to speak”).
en: Speech or writing that is eloquent is well expressed and effective in persuading people.
example: I heard him make a very eloquent speech at that dinner.
example_ko: an eloquent speech/speaker
syn_a: articulate, expressive, fluent, rhetorical, well-spoken, effective, meaningful, persuasive

zh_Hans: （根据事实作出的）意见，决定；（尤指）判决，裁决
syn: adjudication, adjudgement, decision, finding, ruling, resolution, pronouncement, decree, order, settlement, result, conclusion, opinion, prognosis, conviction, assumption, presumption
etym: From Middle English verdit, from Old French verdit, from veir (“true”) + dit (“saying”).
en: In a court of law, the verdict is the decision that is given by the jury or judge at the end of a trial.
example: The jury returned a unanimous guilty verdict
example_ko: Has the jury reached a verdict?
syn_n: decision, decree, determination, judgment, resolution, adjudication, ruling, sentence  settlement

syn: dull, boring, tedious, monotonous, tiresome, wearisome, prosaic, unexciting, uninteresting, uneventful, unvarying, unvaried, unremarkable, repetitive, repetitious, routine, ordinary, everyday, day-to-day, quotidian, run-of-the-mill, commonplace, common, workaday, usual, pedestrian, customary, regular, normal
etym: From Middle English mondeyne, from Old French mondain, from Late Latin mundanus, from Latin mundus (“world”). Compare Danish mondæn.
en: Something that is mundane is very ordinary and not at all interesting or unusual.
example: Be willing to do even mundane tasks.
example_ko: a mundane task/job
syn_a: boring, dreary, humdrum, tedious, tiresome, commonplace, ordinary, routine, uneventful, earthly, temporal, terrestrial, worldly

zh_Hans: 反传统信仰者；反传统者
syn: sceptic, questioner
etym: Borrowed from French iconoclaste, from Byzantine Greek εἰκονοκλάστης (eikonoklástēs, literally “image breaker”).
en: If you describe someone as an iconoclast, you mean that they often criticize beliefs and things that are generally accepted by society.
syn_n: critic, nonconformist, rebel, renegade, apostate, dissenter, heretic, despoiler, vandal

ko: 동철 (동음) 이의어(‘…할 수 있는’의 뜻을 나타내는 can과 ‘통조림으로 만들다’는 뜻의 can처럼 철자는 같으나 뜻은 다른 단어. 발음도 동일할 수 있음)
etym: From homo- +‎ -onym.
en: one of a group of words pronounced or spelt in the same way but having different meanings Compare homograph, homophone

syn: substitute, mild alternative, indirect term, understatement, underplaying, softening, politeness, genteelism, coy term
etym: Recorded since 1656; from Ancient Greek εὐφημισμός (euphēmismós), from εὐφημίζω (euphēmízō), from εὔφημος (eúphēmos, “uttering sound of good omen, abstaining from inauspicious words”), from εὖ (eû, “well”) + φήμη (phḗmē, “a voice, a prophetic voice, rumor, talk”), from φάναι (phánai, “to speak, say”).
en: A euphemism is a polite word or expression that is used to refer to things which people may find upsetting or embarrassing to talk about, for example sex, the human body, or death.
example: The term 'early retirement' is nearly always a euphemism for redundancy nowadays.
example_ko: ‘Pass away’ is a euphemism for ‘die’.

syn: tuneful, melodic, musical, dulcet, round, sweet-sounding, sweet-toned, silvery, silvery-toned, euphonious, mellifluous, lyrical, soothing
etym: From Old French melodios
en: A melodious sound is pleasant to listen to.
example: She spoke in a quietly melodious voice.
example_ko: a rich melodious voice
syn_a: dulcet, harmonious, mellifluous, mellow, singing, lyrical, melodic, musical

zh_Hans: 怪异地;怪异的;奇异的;可怕地
etym: eerie +‎ -ly
example: Monrovia after the fighting is eerily quiet.
example_ko: an eerie yellow light

zh_Hans: 箴言;警句;名人警句;四句箴言
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：apo 与…有关 + the 神 + gm → 神的告诫 → 格言
syn: saying, proverb, aphorism, adage, saw, axiom, formula, expression, phrase, rule, dictum, precept, epigram, gnome
etym: Mid 16th century: from French apophthegme or Medieval Latin apothegma, from Ancient Greek ἀπόφθεγμα (apóphthegma), from ἀποφθέγγομαι (apophthéngomai, “speak out”)
en: a variant spelling of apophthegm

etym: From Latin attenuans, present participle of attenuare: compare French atténuant. See attenuate.
en: causing dilution or thinness, esp of the blood

syn: concision, succinctness, economy of language, compendiousness, shortness, briefness, pithiness, pith, incisiveness, crispness, compactness, compression
etym: First attested in English in 1509; either:
en: The brevity of something is the fact that it is short or lasts for only a short time.
example: The bonus of this homely soup is the brevity of its cooking time.
example_ko: The report is a masterpiece of brevity.
syn_n: concision, succinctness  terseness

zh_Hans: 连续不断的，没完没了的
syn: unceasing, constant, continual, unabating, interminable, endless, unending, never-ending, everlasting, eternal, perpetual, continuous, non-stop, uninterrupted, unbroken, ongoing, unremitting, persistent, relentless, unrelenting, unrelieved, sustained, unflagging, unwearying, untiring
etym: From Old French incessant
en: An incessant process or activity is one that continues without stopping.
example: incessant rain.
example_ko: incessant noise/rain/chatter
syn_n: ceaseless, constant, continuous, interminable, persistent, unrelenting, unremitting

etym: From Ancient Greek ἀμφίβιον (amphíbion), from ἀμφί (amphí, “of both kinds”) + βίος (bíos, “life”)
en: Amphibians are animals such as frogs and toads that can live both on land and in water.

zh_Hans: （讲话、写作、风格等）太严肃的，枯燥乏味的
syn: congested
etym: From Latin turgidus (“swollen, inflated”), from turgeō (“to swell”).
en: If you describe something such as a piece of writing or a film as turgid, you think it is boring and difficult to understand.
example: He used to make extremely dull, turgid and frankly boring speeches
syn_a: bloated, distended, swollen, tumid, bombastic, flamboyant, grandiloquent

zh_Hans: 贫嘴的;饶舌的; 聒噪的
syn: chatty, loquacious, garrulous, voluble, conversational, gossipy, gossiping, chattery, chattering, babbling, blathering, gibbering, communicative
etym: gab +‎ -y
en: inclined to chatter; talkative
syn_n: effusive, garrulous, loquacious, verbose, wordy

syn: planner, builder, building consultant, draughtsman
etym: Middle French architecte, from Ancient Greek ἀρχιτέκτων (arkhitéktōn, “master builder”), from ἀρχι- (arkhi-, “chief”) + τέκτων (téktōn, “builder”).
en: An architect is a person who designs buildings.
example: He studied classical architecture and design in Rome.
example_ko: to study architecture

zh_Hans: 厌恶人类的；遁世的，不与他人交往的
syn: unsociable, unfriendly, reclusive, uncongenial, unneighbourly, inhospitable, cynical, suspicious, distrustful, sceptical, jaundiced, narrow-minded
etym: From misanthrope +‎ -ic.
en: If you describe a person or their feelings as misanthropic, you mean that they do not like other people.
syn_a: anti-social, cynical, inhospitable, inhumane, unsociable

syn: cushion, pad, support, rest
etym: From Middle English bolster, bolstre, from Old English bolster (“pillow”), from Proto-Germanic *bulstraz, *bulstrą (“pillow, cushion”). Cognate with Scots bowster (“bolster”), West Frisian bulster (“mattress”), Dutch bolster (“husk, shell”), German Polster (“bolster, pillow, pad”), Swedish bolster (“soft mattress, bolster”), Icelandic bólstur (“pillow”).
en: If you bolster something such as someone's confidence or courage, you increase it.
example: Hopes of an early cut in interest rates bolstered confidence.
example_ko: to bolster sb’s confidence/courage/morale
syn_n: livelihood, maintenance, sustenance, backing, patronage, promotion, blessing, favor, succor, brace, foundation, prop, truss, defense, evidence, justification, reasoning
syn_v: brace, prop, strengthen, sustain, finance, fund, maintain, subsidize, advance, advocate, champion, promote, bear, endure, suffer, tolerate
ant2: opposition, neglect, superstructure, weaken, oppose  succumb

syn: humbleness, modestness, meekness, lack of pride, lack of vanity, diffidence, unassertiveness
etym: From Middle English humilite, from Old French (h)umilité, from Latin humilitas (“lowness, meanness, baseness, in Late Latin humility”), from humilis (“low, lowly, humble, earth”); see humble.
en: Someone who has humility is not proud and does not believe they are better than other people.
example: a deep sense of humility
example_ko: Her first defeat was an early lesson in humility.
syn_n: lowliness, meekness, mildness, modesty, submissiveness

zh_Hans: （因无法分清字形而造成的）读写障碍
etym: Circa 1890, from New Latin dys- + lexia, from Ancient Greek δυσ- (dus-) expressing the idea of difficulty, and λέξις (léxis, “diction”, “word”).
en: If someone suffers from dyslexia, they have difficulty with reading because of a slight disorder of their brain.

syn: predecessor, forefather, father, parent, antecedent, ancestor, forebear, progenitor
etym: Borrowed from Latin praecursor (“forerunner”).
en: A precursor of something is a similar thing that happened or existed before it, often something which led to the existence or development of that thing.
example: He said that the deal should not be seen as a precursor to a merger.

zh_Hans: （尤指在生意或财务方面）精明的，机灵的
syn: astute, sharp, sharp-witted, discerning, acute, penetrating, discriminating, perceptive, perspicacious, clever, intelligent, wise, sagacious, sensible, judicious, circumspect, careful, prudent, cautious
etym: Northern English dialect from can (“to know”)[1], from Middle English can, first and third person singular of cunnen, connen (“to be able, know how to”), from Old English cunnan (“to know how to, be able to”). Compare Scots canny, Old English cann (“knowledge, assertion”). More at can, cunning.
en: A canny person is clever and able to think quickly. You can also describe a person's behaviour as canny.
example: He was far too canny to risk giving himself away
example_ko: a canny politician
syn_a: bright, intelligent, quick, smart, alert, astute, keen, sharp, piquant, scintillating, sparkling, witty, imaginative, ingenious, inventive, resourceful, adroit, dexterous, expert, skillful, cagey, crafty, cunning, shrewd, sly
ant2: stupid, dull, witless, obtuse, clumsy  candid

syn: rot, putrefy, go bad, go off, spoil, fester, perish, deteriorate
etym: From Middle English decayen, dekeyen (“to decrease, diminish”), from Anglo-Norman decäir (“to fall away, decay, decline”), from Medieval Latin *dēcadere, restored form of Latin decidere (“to fall away, fail, sink, perish”), from de (“down”) + cadere (“to fall”); compare decadent and decadence.
en: When something such as a dead body, a dead plant, or a tooth decays, it is gradually destroyed by a natural process.
example: The bodies buried in the fine ash slowly decayed
example_ko: tooth decay
syn_n: putrefaction, rot, spoilage, crumbling, decadence, decline
syn_v: corrode, decompose, disintegrate

syn: happy, jolly, merry, bright, glad, sunny, joyful, joyous, light-hearted, in good spirits, in high spirits, sparkling, bubbly, exuberant, ebullient, cock-a-hoop, elated, gleeful, breezy, airy, cheery, sprightly, jaunty, animated, radiant, smiling, grinning, laughing, mirthful, frolicsome
etym: From Old French jocond, from Latin iūcundus (“pleasant, agreeable”).
en: of a humorous temperament; merry
syn_a: cheerful, happy, jocund, jolly, light-hearted, lively, merry, spirited

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：ef 出，外 + fulg 发光 + ent 具有…性质的 → 发出光 → 光辉灿烂的
syn: light, brilliant, vivid, blazing, dazzling, beaming, intense, glaring
etym: From Latin effulgēns (“flashing, glittering”), present participle of effulgeō (“to shine or gleam forth, flash, glitter”), from ē- (variant of ex- (prefix meaning ‘out; away’)) + fulgeō (“to flash, gleam, glisten, glitter, shine”) (from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“shiny; white”)).[1]
en: radiant; brilliant
syn_a: bright, brilliant, gleaming, radiant, resplendent, shining

ko: (음식·물 등) 생명을 건강하게 유지시켜 주는 것, 자양물
syn: food, nutriment, nutrition, fare, diet, daily bread, provisions, rations, means of keeping body and soul together
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French, from sustenir (14c) with the suffix -ance, from Vulgar Latin *sustenire, from Latin sustinere. Cf. also Late Latin sustinentia.
en: Sustenance is food or drink which a person, animal, or plant needs to remain alive and healthy.
example: The state provided a basic quantity of food for daily sustenance, but little else.
example_ko: There’s not much sustenance in a bowl of soup.

syn: do away with, get rid of, scrap, end, stop, terminate, eradicate, eliminate, exterminate, destroy, annihilate, stamp out, obliterate, wipe out, extinguish, quash, expunge, extirpate
etym: From late Middle English abolisshen, from Middle French abolir, aboliss- (extended stem),[1] from Latin abolēre (“to retard, check the growth of, (and by extension) destroy, abolish”), inchoative abolēscere (“to wither, vanish, (Classical) cease”),[2] probably from ab (“from, away from”) + *olēre (“to increase, grow”) which is found only in compound.[3]
en: If someone in authority abolishes a system or practice, they formally put an end to it.
example: The following year Parliament voted to abolish the death penalty for murder
example_ko: This tax should be abolished.
syn_v: abrogate, annul, cancel, invalidate, negate, destroy, eradicate, exterminate

syn: acute, sharp, sharp-witted, razor-sharp, keen, rapier-like, astute, shrewd, trenchant, piercing, perceptive, insightful, percipient, perspicacious, discerning, analytical, intelligent, canny, clever, smart, quick
etym: Borrowed from Middle French incisif.
en: You use incisive to describe a person, their thoughts, or their speech when you approve of their ability to think and express their ideas clearly, briefly, and forcefully.
example: a shrewd operator with an incisive mind
example_ko: incisive comments/criticism/analysis
syn_a: astute, keen, penetrating, perceptive, probing, trenchant

etym: 15th century partial re-Latinization of early 14th century Middle English lettorne, lettron, from Old French leitrun, from Medieval Latin lectrinum, from Late Latin lectrum, from lectus (from whence also lecture), form of Latin legō (“I read”).[1]
en: A lectern is a high sloping desk on which someone puts their notes when they are standing up and giving a lecture.

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：fatu 笨 + ity 具备某种性质，状况 → 愚蠢，愚昧
etym: Borrowed from Middle French fatuité.
en: complacent foolishness; inanity

ko: 공제(共濟)의(사상·이해관계가 같은 개인·집단이 서로 돕기 위한 것)
syn: sibling
etym: Borrowed from Middle French fraternel, from Medieval Latin frāternālis (“fraternal”), from Latin frāternus (“of or pertaining to a brother, fraternal”), from frāter (“brother”).
en: Fraternal actions show strong links of friendship between two people or groups of people.
example: the fraternal assistance of our colleagues and comrades
example_ko: a fraternal organization / society
syn_a: affectionate, brotherly, devoted, friendly  kind

syn: reprimand, reproach, admonishment, admonition, reproval, remonstration
en: If you say or do something in reproof, you say or do it to show that you disapprove of what someone has done or said.
example: She raised her eyebrows in reproof.
example_ko: His words were a mixture of pity and reproof.
syn_n: admonition, censure, chastisement, correction, rebuke, reprimand, scolding

etym: From Latin bi two + centum hundred + annus year + -al; surface analyses bi- + centennial and bi- +‎ cent- +‎ -ennial.
en: A bicentennial is the same as a bicentenary.

ko: 우등으로(미국 대학 학위 취득자 우등 등급의 세 번째 등급)
zh_Hans: （拉丁语）以优等成绩毕业（美国大学优等学位荣誉中的第三等）
etym: From Latin cum (“with”) + laude (ablative of laus, "praise").
en: with praise: the lowest of three designations for above-average achievement in examinations Compare magna cum laude, summa cum laude
example: a dining-room-cum-study
example_ko: He graduated cum laude.

zh_Hans: 责难;指责;谴责;责备;斥责
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：re 反 + prehend 抓 → 反过来抓住〔别人的缺点〕→ 责难
syn: censure, condemn, castigate, chastise, lambaste, pillory, savage, find fault with, fulminate against, abuse
etym: From Latin reprehendō (“I hold back, check, blame”), from re- (“back”) + prehendō (“I hold, seize”). Confer French reprendre (“to reprove”).
en: to find fault with; criticize

syn: obsolescent, out of date, anachronistic, old-fashioned, outmoded, behind the times, bygone, antiquated, antique, superannuated, antediluvian, past its prime, having seen better days, olde worlde, old-fangled
etym: From archaism (“ancient or obsolete phrase or expression”) or from French archaïque, ultimately from Ancient Greek ἀρχαϊκός (arkhaïkós, “old-fashioned”), from ἀρχαῖος (arkhaîos, “from the beginning, antiquated, ancient, old”), from ἀρχή (arkhḗ, “beginning, origin”), from ἄρχω (árkhō, “I am first”).
en: Archaic means extremely old or extremely old-fashioned.
example: archaic laws that are very seldom used
example_ko: ‘Thou art’ is an archaic form of ‘you are’.
syn_a: antediluvian, antiquated, obsolete, old-fashioned, outdated, pass)

zh_Hans: 简朴的，清苦的；斯巴达式的
syn: harsh, hard, frugal, stringent, rigorous, arduous, strict, stern, severe, rigid
etym: By analogy with the ancient Spartans, who famously possessed these qualities.
en: A spartan lifestyle or existence is very simple or strict, with no luxuries.
example: Their spartan lifestyle prohibits a fridge or a phone

syn: mid, mean, medium, medial, median, midway, halfway, equidistant, mesial
etym: From Middle French équidistant, from Late Latin aequidistantem, from aequī (“equal”) +‎ distantem (“distant”).
en: A place that is equidistant from two other places is the same distance away from each of these places.
example: Horsey is equidistant from Great Yarmouth and Mundesley.
example_ko: All points on a circle are equidistant from the centre.

zh_Hans: 防腐剂；（尤指）杀菌剂，消毒剂
syn: germicidal, bactericidal
etym: From anti- +‎ septic.
en: Antiseptic is a substance that kills germs and harmful bacteria.
example: She bathed the cut with antiseptic.
syn_n: disinfectant, germicide
syn_a: aseptic, clean, pure, sterile

zh_Hans: （尤指词语或想法）不连贯的，没有条理的，杂乱无章的
syn: disconnected, without unity, disunited, discontinuous, fragmented, fragmentary, disorganized, disordered, muddled, mixed up, jumbled, garbled, incoherent, confused, fitful, erratic, spasmodic, patchy, scrappy, bitty, piecemeal
en: Disjointed words, thoughts, or ideas are not presented in a smooth or logical way and are therefore difficult to understand.
example: Sally was used to his disjointed, drunken ramblings.
syn_a: broken, detached, divided, separated, unattached, disconnected, discontinuous, disorganized, incoherent, irrational

syn: humble, cow, squash, deflate, flatten, bring down, bring low, take down a peg or two, humiliate, mortify
etym: From Middle English chastien, from Old French chastier (“punish”), from Latin castīgāre. See also chastise, castigate and chaste.
en: If you are chastened by something, it makes you regret that you have behaved badly or stupidly.
example: He has clearly not been chastened by his thirteen days in detention
example_ko: He felt suitably chastened and apologized.
syn_v: castigate, chastise, chide, punish, reprimand, reprove, scold

zh_Hans: 毫无道德观念的；没有道德的
syn: without standards, without morals
etym: From a- (“not”) +‎ moral.
en: If you describe someone as amoral, you do not like the way they behave because they do not seem to care whether what they do is right or wrong.
example: I strongly disagree with this amoral approach to politics
syn_a: dissolute, evil, iniquitous, profane, sinful, wicked, corrupt, unethical, unprincipled, unscrupulous, base, debauched, decadent, degenerate, depraved

zh_Hans: 内在的；固有的，生来就有的
syn: innate, immanent, built-in, inborn, ingrained, deep-rooted
etym: From Latin inhaerentem, accusative singular of inhaerēns, present active participle of inhaereō (“I am closely connected with; adhere to”).
en: The inherent qualities of something are the necessary and natural parts of it.
example: Stress is an inherent part of dieting.
example_ko: the difficulties inherent in a study of this type
syn_a: inborn, innate, intrinsic, native, natural

zh_Hans: （尤指年轻人）幼稚的；不自信的；不谙世事的
syn: inexperienced, naive, green, as green as grass, born yesterday, raw, unseasoned, untrained, untried
etym: From Middle English calwe (“bald”), from Old English calu (“callow, bare, bald”), from Proto-Germanic *kalwaz (“bare, naked, bald”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel(H)wo- (“naked, bald”). Cognate with West Frisian keal (“bald”), Dutch kaal (“bald”), German kahl (“bald”), Russian го́лый (gólyj, “nude”), Latin calvus (“bald”), Persian کل‎ (kal), Sanskrit कुल्व (kulvá).
en: A callow young person has very little experience or knowledge of the way they should behave as an adult.
example: a callow youth.
example_ko: a callow youth
syn_a: green, immature, inexperienced, innocent, juvenile, naive

ko: (흔히 좋지 않은 일이 곧 일어날) 조짐
syn: sign, indicator, indication, signal, prelude, portent, omen, augury, forewarning, presage, announcer
etym: Originally, a person that is sent in advance to arrange lodgings. From Middle English herbergeour, from Old French herbergeor (French hébergeur), from Frankish *heriberga (“lodging, inn”, literally “army shelter”), from Proto-Germanic *harjaz (“army”) + *bergô (“protection”). Compare German Herberge, Italian albergo, Dutch herberg, English harbor. More at here, borrow.
en: Something that is a harbinger of something else, especially something bad, is a sign that it is going to happen.
example: The November air stung my cheeks, a harbinger of winter.
syn_n: forerunner, herald, precursor, usher, vanguard, clue, indication, omen  portent

zh_Hans: （态度或说话）简短失礼的，唐突的，草率的
syn: brusque, abrupt, clipped, blunt, short, monosyllabic, summary, snappy, snappish, sharp, crisp, tart
etym: From the Latin curtus (“shortened”). Cognate with German kurz, Galician corto, Italian corto, Portuguese corto, and Spanish corto.
en: If you describe someone as curt, you mean that they speak or reply in a brief and rather rude way.
example: Her tone of voice was curt
example_ko: a curt reply
syn_a: abrupt, blunt, curt, gruff, harsh, short

syn: cut up, cut open, lay open, dismember
etym: Borrowed from Latin dissectus past participle of dissecare (“to cut asunder, cut up”), from dis- (“asunder”) + secare (“to cut”); see section.
en: If someone dissects the body of a dead person or animal, they carefully cut it up in order to examine it scientifically.
example: We dissected a frog in biology class.
syn_v: anatomize, analyze, explore, inspect, scrutinize  study

syn: make out, pick out, detect, recognize, notice, observe, see, spot
etym: From Middle English descrien, descryen, from Old French descrier (“to proclaim, announce, cry”), from des- + crier (“shout, cry”).
en: to discern or make out; catch sight of

zh_Hans: 教唆，唆使，怂恿；伙同…作案
syn: aid, help, lend a hand, support, back, encourage
etym: From Middle English abetten, abette, from Old French abeter (“to entice”), from a- (“to”) + beter (“hound on, urge, to bait”), either from Middle Dutch bētan (“incite”) or from Old Norse beita (“to cause to bite, bait, incite”)[1], from Proto-Germanic *baitijaną (“to cause to bite”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰeyd- (“to split”). Cognate with Icelandic beita (“to set dogs on; to feed”).
en: If one person abets another, they help or encourage them to do something criminal or wrong. Abet is often used in the legal expression `aid and abet'.
example: His wife was sentenced to seven years imprisonment for aiding and abetting him
example_ko: He was abetted in the deception by his wife.
syn_v: aid, assist, help, support, advance, encourage, foster, further, promote

ko: 의심[불신]의 눈으로; 옆으로, 비스듬히; 곁눈으로; 빗대어, 어물어물
syn: with suspicion, sceptically, with misgivings, cynically, mistrustfully, distrustfully, with distrust, doubtfully, dubiously, with doubt
etym: Unknown. Possibly from Middle English askances (“as if”), or from Old French a escone (“hidden”) or Italian a scancio (“obliquely”). Compare asquint, Middle English askoyn (“at a slant, askance”), Dutch schuin, schuins (“sideways”), schuiven (“to shove”), schuinte (“slope”).
en: If you look askance at someone or something, you have a doubtful or suspicious attitude towards them.
example: They have always looked askance at the western notion of democracy.
example_ko: They all looked askance at the movie star.
syn_a: obliquely, sidelong, sideways, disdainfully, distrustfully, scornfully, skeptically, suspiciously

syn: wordbook, synonym dictionary, synonym lexicon
etym: 16th century, from Latin thēsaurus, from Ancient Greek θησαυρός (thēsaurós, “storehouse, treasure”); its current English usage/meaning was established soon after the publication of Peter Roget's Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases in 1852
en: A thesaurus is a reference book in which words with similar meanings are grouped together.

zh_Hans: （讲话或写作）言简意赅的，简洁有力的
syn: short, brief, compact, condensed, crisp, laconic, terse, tight, to the point, economic, pithy, thumbnail, summary, short and sweet, in a few well-chosen words, compendious, epigrammatic, synoptic, aphoristic, gnomic
etym: pith +‎ -y
en: A pithy comment or piece of writing is short, direct, and full of meaning.
example: His pithy advice to young painters was, 'Above all, keep your colours fresh.'
syn_a: cogent, meaty, pregnant, profound, substantial, weighty, brief, concise, succinct, tight

etym: From bi- +‎ lateral.
en: Bilateral negotiations, meetings, or agreements, involve only the two groups or countries that are directly concerned.
example: bilateral talks between Britain and America.
example_ko: bilateral relations/agreements/trade/talks

zh_Hans: 不可能错误的；永无过失的；不会犯错误的
syn: error-free, unfailing, faultless, flawless, impeccable, perfect, true, uncanny, precise, accurate, meticulous, scrupulous
etym: From Medieval Latin infallibilis, from Latin in- + fallibilis. Compare French infaillible.
en: If a person or thing is infallible, they are never wrong.
example: Although he was experienced, he was not infallible
example_ko: infallible advice
syn_a: faultless, perfect, unerring, certain, irrefutable, sure, dependable, reliable, unfailing

syn: assisted suicide, physician-assisted suicide
etym: First attested in 1606, from Ancient Greek εὐθανασία (euthanasía), from εὐ- (eu-, “good”) + θάνατος (thánatos, “death”)
en: Euthanasia is the practice of killing someone who is very ill and will never get better in order to end their suffering, usually done at their request or with their consent.
example_ko: They argued in favour of legalizing voluntary euthanasia.

ko: (어떤 것을 더 강하게·성공적이 되게 하기 위한) 투입
syn: broth, bouillon, juice, gravy, liquid, infusion, extract, concentrate, decoction
etym: Borrowed from Old French infusion, from Latin infusio, infusionem (“a pouring into, a wetting, a dyeing, a flow”), from infundo.
en: If there is an infusion of one thing into another, the first thing is added to the other thing and makes it stronger or better.
example: He brought a tremendous infusion of hope to the people.
example_ko: a cash infusion into the business
syn_v: fill, imbue, indoctrinate, ingrain, instill, impregnate, inundate, permeate, pervade  saturate

ko: 몹시 곤란을 겪는, 어찌할 바를 모르는.
zh_Hans: (不断)烦扰;折磨;反复进攻;不断袭击
example: harried businessmen scurrying from one crowded office to another.
example_ko: She has been harried by the press all week.
syn_v: badger, bother, harass, hound, pester, pillage, plunder, raid

syn: rebound, be deflected
en: Also called (in Britain and certain other countries) : cannon

syn: innocent, simple, childlike, trusting, trustful, over-trusting, unwary, unsuspicious, unguarded, unsceptical, uncritical, unworldly, wide-eyed, inexperienced, green
etym: Borrowed from Latin ingenuus (“of noble character, frank”).
en: If you describe someone as ingenuous, you mean that they are innocent, trusting, and honest.
example: He seemed too ingenuous for a reporter
example_ko: You’re too ingenuous.
syn_a: genuine, guileless, honest, open, trusting, candid, direct, forthright, frank

syn: separation, divorce, split, gulf, chasm
etym: From Ancient Greek διχότομος (dikhótomos, “equally divided, cut in half”) + -y.
en: If there is a dichotomy between two things, there is a very great difference or opposition between them.
example: There is a dichotomy between the academic world and the industrial world.

zh_Hans: 神秘古怪的；故弄玄虚的
syn: ill-starred, ill-omened, star-crossed, under a curse, cursed, jinxed, foredoomed, hapless, damned, bedevilled, luckless, unlucky
en: If you describe someone as fey, you mean that they behave in a shy, childish, or unpredictable way, and you are often suggesting that this is unnatural or insincere.
example: Her fey charm and eccentric ways were legendary.
syn_n: charge, cost, expense, fare, tariff, toll, compensation, emolument, salary  wage

syn: immorality, depravity, corruption, corruptness, vice, degeneracy, evil, baseness, iniquity, sinfulness, vileness
etym: Borrowed from Middle French turpitude, from Latin turpitūdō (“baseness, infamy”), from turpis (“foul, base”).
en: Turpitude is very immoral behaviour.

ko: (분실하거나 빼앗긴 물건 등을) 되찾다[돌려 달라고 하다]
syn: claim back, have returned, recover, take back, regain, retrieve, recoup
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman reclamer (noun reclaim), Middle French reclamer (noun reclaim), from Latin reclāmō, reclāmāre.
en: If you reclaim something that you have lost or that has been taken away from you, you succeed in getting it back.
example: In 1986, they got the right to reclaim South African citizenship
example_ko: You’ll have to go to the police station to reclaim your wallet.

syn: compulsion, force, pressure, pressurization, intimidation, threats, constraint, enforcement, exaction
etym: Borrowed from Old French duresse, from Latin duritia (“hardness”), from durus (“hard”).
en: To do something under duress means to do it because someone forces you to do it or threatens you.
example: He thought her confession had been made under duress.
example_ko: He signed the confession under duress.
syn_n: coercion, compulsion, force, pressure

ko: (특히 남들은 달리 생각할 때) …의 정당성을 입증하다
syn: clear, absolve, free from blame, declare innocent, exonerate, exculpate, discharge, liberate, free, deliver, redeem
etym: Borrowed from Latin vindicātus, perfect passive participle of vindicō (“lay legal claim to something; set free; protect, avenge, punish”), from vim, accusative singular of vīs (“force, power”), + dīcō (“say; declare, state”). See avenge.
en: If a person or their decisions, actions, or ideas are vindicated, they are proved to be correct, after people have said that they were wrong.
example: The director said he had been vindicated by the experts' report
example_ko: I have every confidence that this decision will be fully vindicated.
syn_v: absolve, acquit, clear, exculpate, exonerate, corroborate, justify, support

syn: rental
en: If you rent something, you regularly pay its owner a sum of money in order to be able to have it and use it yourself.
example: She rents a house with three other girls
example_ko: How much rent do you pay for this place?
syn_n: hole, rip, tear, breach, break, rift
syn_v: charter, hire, lease, let

syn: unhappy, doleful, woebegone, dejected, downcast, downhearted, despondent, dispirited, crestfallen, cast down, depressed, fed up, disappointed, disheartened, discouraged, demoralized, crushed, desolate, heartbroken, broken-hearted, inconsolable, heavy-hearted, low-spirited, forlorn, in the doldrums, melancholy, miserable, long-faced, wretched, glum, gloomy, dismal
etym: From Medieval Latin discōnsōlātus (“comfortless”), from dis- (“away”) +‎ cōnsōlātus (“consoled”).
en: Someone who is disconsolate is very unhappy and depressed.
example: He did not have much success, but tried not to get too disconsolate.
syn_a: dejected, depressed, despondent, heartbroken, forlorn, melancholy

zh_Hans: （使）放松，（使）轻松；（使身体部位）松弛，放松
syn: loosen up, ease off, ease up, let up, slow down, de-stress, unbend, rest, repose, put one's feet up, take it easy, take time off, take time out, slack off, be at leisure, take one's leisure, take one's ease, laze, luxuriate, do nothing, sit back, lounge, loll, slump, flop, idle, loaf, enjoy oneself, amuse oneself, play, entertain oneself
etym: Borrowed from Old French relaxer, from Latin relaxāre (“relax, loosen, open”), from re- (“back”) + laxāre (“loosen”), from laxus (“loose, free”).
en: If you relax or if something relaxes you, you feel more calm and less worried or tense.
example: I ought to relax and stop worrying about it
example_ko: When I get home from work I like to relax with the newspaper.
syn_v: loaf, repose, rest, vacation, calm, soothe, bend, ease, loosen, slacken

ko: (~로 하여금 ~하지) 못하게 하다, (~가 ~하는 것을) 불가능하게 하다
syn: make it impossible for, make it impracticable for, rule out, put a stop to, stop, prohibit, debar, interdict, block, bar, hinder, impede, inhibit, exclude, disqualify, forbid
etym: Borrowed from Latin praecludo.
en: If something precludes an event or action, it prevents the event or action from happening.
example: At 84, John feels his age precludes too much travel
example_ko: [VN] Lack of time precludes any further discussion.
syn_v: arrest, check, curb, halt, stop, foil, hamper, impede, obstruct, prevent, thwart

syn: fondness, preference, partiality, taste, penchant, weakness, soft spot, fancy, inclination, leaning, bias, propensity, bent, proclivity, proneness, predisposition, tendency, affinity, appetite, love
etym: Borrowed from French prédilection.
en: If you have a predilection for something, you have a strong liking for it.
example: his predilection for fast cars and fast horses.
syn_n: attraction, fondness, partiality, passion, preference, bias, inclination, predisposition, proclivity, propensity, tendency

syn: idiomatic expression, turn of phrase, set phrase, fixed expression, phrase
etym: From Middle French idiome, and its source, Late Latin idioma, from Ancient Greek ἰδίωμα (idíōma, “a peculiarity, property, a peculiar phraseology, idiom”), from ἰδιοῦσθαι (idioûsthai, “to make one's own, appropriate to oneself”), from ἴδιος (ídios, “one's own, pertaining to oneself, private, personal, peculiar, separate”).
en: A particular idiom is a particular style of something such as music, dance, or architecture.
example: McCartney was also keen to write in a classical idiom, rather than a pop one
example_ko: ‘Let the cat out of the bag’ is an idiom meaning to tell a secret by mistake.
syn_n: dialect, patois, vernacular, jargon, lingo, slang, expression, localism, provincialism, parlance  style

syn: ease, alleviate, soothe, mitigate, dampen, allay, calm, palliate, abate, lull, temper, suppress, smother, stifle, subdue, tranquillize, mollify, moderate, modify, tone down, attenuate, dilute, lessen, diminish, decrease, reduce, lower
etym: Middle English aswagen, from Old French asuagier (“to appease, to calm”), from Vulgar Latin *assuaviō (“I sweeten, I 'butter up', I calm”), derived from ad- + suavis (“sweet”) + -ō.
en: If you assuage an unpleasant feeling that someone has, you make them feel it less strongly.
example: To assuage his wife's grief, he took her on a tour of Europe
syn_v: alleviate, ease, mitigate, relieve, soothe, temper

syn: go into raptures about, go into raptures over, wax lyrical about, sing the praises of, praise to the skies, heap praise on, eulogize, rhapsodize over, rave about, enthuse about, enthuse over, gush about, gush over, throw bouquets at, express delight over, acclaim
etym: Borrowed from Latin extollō (“elevate, raise high”).
en: If you extol something or someone, you praise them enthusiastically.
example: Now experts are extolling the virtues of the humble potato
example_ko: Doctors often extol the virtues of eating less fat.
syn_v: celebrate, glorify, hail, laud, praise

zh_Hans: 隐姓埋名地，隐藏身分地
syn: under a false name, with one's identity concealed, in disguise, disguised, under cover, in plain clothes, camouflaged
etym: Borrowed from Italian incognito, from Latin incognitus (“unknown”), from in- (“not”) + cognitus (“known”), perfect passive participle of cognoscere.
en: Someone who is incognito is using a false name or wearing a disguise, in order not to be recognized or identified.
example: Hotel inspectors have to travel incognito
example_ko: Movie stars often prefer to travel incognito.
syn_a: concealed, disguised, masked, nameless, unknown, clandestinely, secretly, under cover

zh_Hans: 掩盖，掩饰（动机、感情、真相等）
syn: pretend, deceive, feign, act, masquerade, sham, fake, bluff, counterfeit, pose, posture, hide one's feelings, be dishonest, put on a false front, lie
etym: From Latin dissimulare.
en: When people dissemble, they hide their real intentions or emotions.
example: Henry was not slow to dissemble when it served his purposes.
example_ko: [V] She was a very honest person who was incapable of dissembling.
syn_v: camouflage, conceal, disguise, hide, mask, screen

syn: satisfy, take the edge off, sate, satiate, relieve, assuage, gratify
etym: From Middle English slaken (“to render slack, to slake”), from Middle English sleacian, from sleac (“slack”).
en: If you slake your thirst, you drink something that stops you being thirsty.
example_ko: I need to slake my thirst.
syn_v: assuage, quench, satiate, satisfy, alleviate, calm, decrease, soothe

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：acid 酸的 + ul〔= ule 小…〕+ ous …的 → 微酸的
syn: sour, tart, bitter, unsweetened, sharp, biting, acrid, pungent, acerbic, vinegary, vinegarish, acetic, acetous
etym: From Latin acidulus (“sourish, acidulous”), diminutive of acidus (“acid, sour”). See acid.
en: rather sour

zh_Hans: （尤指疾病或不好的事物）慢性的，长期的
syn: long-standing, long-term, constantly recurring
etym: From chronical, from Old French cronike, from Latin chronicus, from Ancient Greek χρονικός (khronikós, “of time”), from χρόνος (khrónos, “time”).
en: A chronic illness or disability lasts for a very long time. Compare acute.
example: chronic back pain.
example_ko: chronic bronchitis / arthritis / asthma
syn_a: constant, lasting, persistent, confirmed, habitual, inveterate, continuous, incessant, perpetual, intermittent, periodic, recurrent

syn: rebuke, scold, reprove, upbraid, chastise, chide, censure, castigate, lambaste, berate, reproach, lecture, criticize, take to task, pull up, read the Riot Act to, give a piece of one's mind to, haul over the coals
etym: Middle English admonesten or admonissen, from Old French amonester (modern French admonester), from an unattested Late Latin or Vulgar Latin *admonestrāre, from Latin admoneō (“remind, warn”), from ad + moneō (“warn, advise”). See premonition.
en: If you admonish someone, you tell them very seriously that they have done something wrong.
example: They admonished me for taking risks with my health
example_ko: [VN] She was admonished for chewing gum in class.
syn_v: advise, caution, counsel, warn, censure, chide, reprimand, reproach, reprove

zh_Hans: 不可知论者（对神存在与否不能肯定或认为不可知）
syn: doubter, questioner, doubting Thomas, challenger, scoffer, cynic
etym: First attested in 1870; coined by Thomas Huxley. Either from Ancient Greek ἄγνωστος (ágnōstos, “ignorant, not knowing”) or from a- +‎ Gnostic. Deriving (either way) from Ancient Greek ἀ- (a-, “not”) + γιγνώσκω (gignṓskō, “I know”).
en: An agnostic believes that it is not possible to know whether God exists or not. Compare atheist.
example_ko: The device-agnostic technology allows it to run on several kinds of electronic devices.
syn_n: cynic, empiricist, nonbeliever, skeptic

zh_Hans: （人）派系的，教派性的，（尤指）排斥其他信仰的；有门户之见的
syn: schismatic, cliquish, clannish, partisan, parti pris
etym: From Medieval Latin sectarius  +‎ -an
en: Sectarian means resulting from the differences between different religions.
example: He was the fifth person to be killed in sectarian violence
example_ko: sectarian attacks/violence

syn: virgin, intact, maidenly, maiden, unmarried, unwed
etym: Borrowed from Old French chaste (“morally pure”), from Latin castus (“pure”).
en: If you describe a person or their behaviour as chaste, you mean that they do not have sex with anyone, or they only have sex with their husband or wife.
example: He remained chaste
example_ko: to remain chaste
syn_a: modest, pure, spotless, virginal, virtuous, clean, decent, moral, righteous, wholesome

syn: lifetime, duration, length of life
etym: Borrowed from Ancient Greek αἰών (aiṓn, “age”).
en: → see aeon

zh_Hans: 豪门望族的后裔，富家子弟
syn: graft, slip
etym: From Middle English sion, sioun, syon, scion, cion, from Old French cion, ciun, cyon, sion; from Frankish *kīþō, *kīþ, from Proto-Germanic *kīþô, *kīþą, *kīþaz (“sprout”), from Proto-Indo-European *geye (“to split open, sprout”), same source as Old English ċīþ (“a young shoot; sprout; germ; sprig”), Old Saxon kīth (“sprout; germ”), Old High German kīdi (“offshoot; sprout; germ”). See also French scion and Picard chion.[1] Doublet of chit.
en: A scion of a rich or famous family is one of its younger or more recent members.
example: Nabokov was the scion of an aristocratic family.
syn_n: child, daughter, offspring, son, descendant, heir, successor, issue, posterity, progeny, seed

zh_Hans: 吉兆;（复数）支持；赞助；资助；主办；保护;（以飞鸟行动为根据的）占卜
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：au〔= av 鸟〕+ spic 看 + e → 看到鸟〔喜鹊〕→ 吉兆
syn: aegis, umbrella, protection, guidance, support, backing, guardianship, trusteeship, sponsorship, supervision, influence, control, charge, responsibility, keeping, care
etym: From Middle French auspice, from Latin auspicium, in turn from auspex.
en: patronage or guidance (esp in the phrase under the auspices of)
syn_n: divination, prognostication, prophecy, harbinger, indication, omen, portent  sign
