syn: deceit, deception, deviousness, two-facedness, double-dealing, underhandedness, dishonesty, falseness, falsity, fraud, fraudulence, sharp practice, swindling, cheating, chicanery, trickery, craft, guile, artifice, subterfuge, skulduggery, treachery, unfairness, unjustness, perfidy, improbity
etym: From Latin duplicare (double).
en: If you accuse someone of duplicity, you mean that they are deceitful.
example: Malcolm believed he was guilty of duplicity in his private dealings.
syn_n: chicanery, cunning, deception, duplicity, fraud, trickery

etym: Originally Latin ontologia (1606, Ogdoas Scholastica, by Jacob Lorhard (Lorhardus)), from Ancient Greek ὤν (ṓn, “on”), present participle of εἰμί (eimí, “being, existing, essence”) + λόγος (lógos, “account”).
en: Ontology is the branch of philosophy that deals with the nature of existence.

syn: confidence, sureness, positiveness, conviction, reliability, assuredness, assurance
etym: From Middle French certitude, from Late Latin certitūdō, from Latin certus.
en: Certitude is the same as certainty.
example: We have this definite certitude that Cicippio will be freed.
example_ko: ‘You will like Rome,’ he said, with absolute certitude.

syn: predict, estimate, calculate, gauge, reckon, expect, extrapolate
etym: From extra- +‎ (inter)polate.
en: If you extrapolate from known facts, you use them as a basis for general statements about a situation or about what is likely to happen in the future.
example: Extrapolating from his American findings, he reckons about 80% of these deaths might be attributed to smoking
example_ko: [V] The figures were obtained by extrapolating from past trends.
syn_v: conclude, deduce, infer  reason

syn: violation of an oath, giving false evidence, giving false testimony, bearing false testimony, bearing false witness, forswearing oneself, making false statements, wilful falsehood
etym: From Anglo-Norman perjurie, from Latin perjurare (“swear falsely”), from per- +‎ jūrāre.
en: If someone who is giving evidence in a court of law commits perjury, they lie.
example: This witness has committed perjury and no reliance can be placed on her evidence.
syn_n: dishonesty, falsehood, forswearing, lying, prevarication

etym: carouse +‎ -al
en: a merry drinking party
syn_v: debauch, live it up, party  revel

syn: bullish, hopeful, buoyant, positive, disposed to look on the bright side, confident, cheerful, cheery, bright, assured
etym: From Middle English sanguine, borrowed from Old French sanguin, ultimately from Latin sanguineus (“of blood”), from sanguis (“blood”), of uncertain origin, perhaps Proto-Indo-European *h₁sh₂-én-, from *h₁ésh₂r̥ (“blood”). Doublet of sanguineous.
en: If you are sanguine about something, you are cheerful and confident that things will happen in the way you want them to.
example: He's remarkably sanguine about the problems involved
example_ko: They are less sanguine about the company’s long-term prospects.
syn_a: buoyant, cheerful, hopeful, optimistic, sunny, flushed, reddish, rosy, ruddy

syn: conclude, finish, accomplish, achieve
etym: From Latin consummatus, past participle of consummare (“to sum up, finish, complete”), from com- (“together”) + summa (“the sum”) (see sum, summation).
en: You use consummate to describe someone who is extremely skilful.
example: He acted the part with consummate skill
example_ko: The marriage lasted only a week and was never consummated.
syn_v: complete, crown, fulfill, perfect
syn_a: accomplished, gifted, superb, talented, complete, total, utter

syn: centrepiece, prop, linchpin, cornerstone, pillar, bulwark, buttress, chief support, backbone, anchor, foundation, base, bastion
etym: From Middle English main stai, equivalent to main +‎ stay (“rope”).
en: If you describe something as the mainstay of a particular thing, you mean that it is the most basic part of it.
example: Fish and rice were the mainstays of the country's diet
example_ko: Cocoa is the country’s economic mainstay.
syn_n: backbone, pillar, reliance, strength  support

ko: ~에 좋은(어떤 일이 일어나기 쉽게 한다는 의미로)
syn: helpful to, instrumental in, calculated to produce, productive of, useful for
etym: conduce +‎ -ive, 1640s[1], from Latin condūcere, patterned after forms like conductive.[2]
en: If one thing is conducive to another thing, it makes the other thing likely to happen.
example: Sometimes the home environment just isn't conducive to reading.
example_ko: Chairs in rows are not as conducive to discussion as chairs arranged in a circle.
syn_a: contributory, favorable, instrumental

zh_Hans: 航空（学）；飞行（术）；航空工业
syn: flying, air transport, aerial navigation, aeronautics
etym: Borrowed from French aviation, from Latin avis (“bird”), from Proto-Indo-European *awi- (“bird”).
en: Aviation is the operation and production of aircraft.
example_ko: civil/military aviation

syn: truism, commonplace, banal saying, hackneyed saying, overworked saying, trite saying, banality, old chestnut
etym: From brom(ine) + -ide. First used in the sense “dull person” by Gelett Burgess.[1]
en: Bromide is a drug which used to be given to people to calm their nerves when they were worried or upset.
example: a dose of bromide.

syn: become larger, widen, become wider, expand, distend, swell
etym: From Middle French dilater, from Latin dīlātō (“I spread out”), from di- (variant of dis-) + latus (“wide”).
en: When things such as blood vessels or the pupils of your eyes dilate or when something dilates them, they become wider or bigger.
example: At night, the pupils dilate to allow in more light
example_ko: [V] Her eyes dilated with fear.
syn_n: distend, enlarge, expand, inflate, swell

zh_Hans: 催速（催化；加速；促进；促凝；触媒）剂
etym:
First attested in 1854.
accelerate +‎ -ant
en: another name for accelerator (sense 3)

etym: Borrowed from Latin mītigātus, from mītigō, from mītis (“gentle, mild, ripe”) + agō (“do, make”), from Proto-Indo-European *meh₁i- (“mild, soft”).[1]
en: To mitigate something means to make it less unpleasant, serious, or painful.
example: ways of mitigating the effects of an explosion
example_ko: action to mitigate poverty
syn_v: allay, blunt, moderate, palliate, temper

zh_Hans: （对敌人或失败者）宽宏大量的，大度的
syn: charitable, benevolent, beneficent, open-handed, big-hearted, great-hearted, munificent, bountiful, liberal, handsome, princely, altruistic, kind, kindly, philanthropic, chivalrous, noble
etym: From Latin magnanimus, from magnus (“great”) + animus (“soul, mind”).
en: If you are magnanimous, you behave kindly and generously towards someone, especially after defeating them or being treated badly by them.
example: I was prepared to be magnanimous, prepared to feel compassion for him
example_ko: a magnanimous gesture
syn_a: altruistic, benevolent, charitable, generous, philanthropic, big-hearted, forgiving, merciful

zh_Hans: 具有开拓性的；有深远影响的
syn: formative, groundbreaking, pioneering, original, creative, innovative
etym: From Middle English seminal, semynal, from Old French seminal, seminale, from Latin sēminālis.
en: Seminal is used to describe things such as books, works, events, and experiences that have a great influence in a particular field.
example: author of the seminal book 'Animal Liberation'
example_ko: a seminal work/article/study

zh_Hans: 渴望的；急切的；热衷的；干劲十足的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：av 渴望 + id …的 → 渴望的；贪婪的
syn: eager, enthusiastic, ardent, passionate, devoted, dedicated, fervent, fervid, zealous, fanatical, voracious, insatiable
etym: From French avide, from Latin avidus (“eager, desirous; greedy”), from aveō (“wish, desire, long for, crave”).
en: You use avid to describe someone who is very enthusiastic about something that they do.
example: He misses not having enough books because he's an avid reader.
example_ko: an avid reader/collector
syn_a: anxious, ardent, eager, intense, zealous, avaricious, covetous, grasping, greedy

syn: body, cadaver, carcass, skeleton
etym: Recorded since c.1500, borrowed from Latin cadāver.
en: A cadaver is a dead body.
syn_n: body, carcass, corpse, remains  stiff

zh_Hans: 无异于;等于;效果与…一样坏
syn: equal to, amounting to, as good as, more or less, synonymous with, virtually the same as, much the same as, comparable to, on a par with, commensurate with, along the lines of, as serious as, identical to
etym: From Anglo-Norman tant amount, from amunter, from tant (“as much”) amonter (“to amount to”).
en: If you say that one thing is tantamount to a second, more serious thing, you are emphasizing how bad, unacceptable, or unfortunate the first thing is by comparing it to the second.
example: What Bracey is saying is tantamount to heresy
example_ko: If he resigned it would be tantamount to admitting that he was guilty.
syn_a: analogous, commensurate, equivalent, identical, indistinguishable, synonymous

zh_Hans: （信仰、想法或活动）非正统的，异端的
syn: heretical, dissenting, dissident, blasphemous, nonconformist, apostate, freethinking, iconoclastic, schismatic, rebellious, renegade, separatist, sectarian, revisionist
etym: From Ancient Greek ἕτεροδοξος (héterodoxos), from ἕτερος (héteros, “other, another, different”) + δόξα (dóxa, “opinion”).
en: Heterodox beliefs, opinions, or ideas are different from the accepted or official ones.

syn: rein, tether, rope, cord, chain, line, strap
etym: From Middle English leesshe, leysche, lesshe, a variant of more original lease, from Middle English lees, leese, leece, lese, from Old French lesse (modern French laisse), from Latin laxa (“thong, a loose cord”), feminine form of laxus (“loose”); compare lax.
en: A dog's leash is a long thin piece of leather or a chain, which you attach to the dog's collar so that you can keep the dog under control.
example: All dogs in public places should be on a leash.
example_ko: Like all youngsters, he’s straining at the leash to leave home.
syn_n: lead, rein, restraint, tether, chain, cord, rope
syn_v: confine, control, hamper, restrain, harness, secure, tether

zh_Hans: 无味的；无特色的；无生气的；乏味的
syn: flavourless, unflavoured, savourless, bland, weak, thin, watery, watered-down, unappetizing, unpalatable
etym: From French insipide, from Latin īnsipidus (“tasteless”), from in- (“not”) + sapidus (“savory”). In some senses, perhaps influenced by insipient (“unwise, foolish, stupid”).
en: If you describe food or drink as insipid, you dislike it because it has very little taste.
example: It tasted indescribably bland and insipid, like warmed cardboard.
example_ko: a cup of insipid coffee
syn_a: banal, dull, dumb, empty, pointless, flat, savorless, stale, tasteless

syn: dispossess, rob, divest, strip
etym: From Middle English bireven, from Old English berēafian (“to bereave, deprive of, take away, seize, rob, despoil”), from Proto-Germanic *biraubōną, and Old English berēofan (“to bereave, deprive, rob of”); both equivalent to be- +‎ reave. Cognate with Dutch beroven (“to rob, deprive, bereave”), German berauben (“to deprive, rob, bereave”), Danish berøve (“to deprive of”), Norwegian berove (“to deprive”), Swedish beröva (“to rob”), Gothic 𐌱𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌿𐌱𐍉𐌽 (biraubōn).
en: to deprive (of) something or someone valued, esp through death
example_ko: The ceremony was an ordeal for those who had been recently bereaved.
syn_n: deprive, dispossess, rob, strip

syn: social, company-loving, companionable, convivial, clubbable
etym: From Latin gregārius.
en: Someone who is gregarious enjoys being with other people.
example: She is such a gregarious and outgoing person.
syn_a: companionable, convivial, friendly, outgoing, sociable

zh_Hans: 同意(请求、建议等);就任;就职;(尤指君主)即位
syn: consent to, accept, assent to, acquiesce in, endorse, comply with, go along with, concur with, allow, recognize, grant, surrender to, yield to, give in to, give way to, defer to
etym: First attested in the early 15th century. From Middle English acceden, from Latin accēdō (“approach, accede”), formed from ad (“to, toward, at”) + cēdō (“move, yield”) (English cede). Compare French accéder. Unrelated to ascend, aside from the common ad prefix.
en: If you accede to someone's request, you do what they ask.
example: Britain would not accede to France's request.
example_ko: [V] He acceded to demands for his resignation.
syn_v: acquiesce, concede, submit, surrender, yield, allow, approve, consent, grant, inherit, succeed to

zh_Hans: 聚集体，集成体；总数，合计
syn: sum total, sum, whole amount, grand total, totality, entirety, summation, gross, result, final figure
etym: From Latin aggregātus, perfect passive participle of aggregō (“I flock together”), from ag- (combining form of ad (“to, toward”)) + gregō (“I flock or group”), from grex (“flock”). Compare gregarious.
en: An aggregate is a number of people or things that are being considered as a single thing.
example: society viewed as an aggregate of individuals.
example_ko: They won 4–2 on aggregate.
syn_n: combination, composite, conglomeration, mixture
syn_v: accumulate, assemble, combine, gather
syn_a: entire, total, whole

syn: determined, resolute, indomitable, intrepid, doughty, plucky, spirited, game, mettlesome, gritty, steely, confident, undaunted, undismayed, unalarmed, unflinching, unshrinking, unabashed, unfaltering, unflagging, bold, audacious, valiant, brave, stout-hearted, lionhearted, gallant, courageous, heroic, daring, daredevil
etym: daunt +‎ -less
en: A dauntless person is brave and confident and not easily frightened.
example: their dauntless courage.
syn_v: challenge, confront, dare, defy
syn_a: dauntless, fearless, intrepid, unafraid, undaunted, courageous, gallant, heroic, stouthearted, valiant, bold, confident, daring, game

zh_Hans: 冗长的；啰唆的；好长篇大论的
syn: long-winded, long-drawn-out, overlong, prolonged, protracted, interminable, laborious, ponderous, endless, unending, verbose, wordy, full of verbiage, verbal, diffuse, discursive, digressive, rambling, wandering, circuitous, meandering, maundering, periphrastic, circumlocutory
etym: From Old French prolixe, from Latin prōlixus (“courteous, favorable”).
en: (of a speech, book, etc) so long as to be boring; verbose

syn: sad, wistful, doleful, pathetic, pitiful, piteous, melancholy, melancholic, sorrowful, unhappy, wretched, woeful, grief-stricken, broken-hearted, heartbroken, desolate, heart-rending, forlorn, woebegone, disconsolate
etym: From Middle English pleintif, plentyff, from French plaintif (“aggrieved, lamenting”), from plainte (“lament, complaint”); see plaint. Doublet of plaintiff.
en: A plaintive sound or voice sounds sad.
example: They lay on the firm sands, listening to the plaintive cry of the seagulls
example_ko: a plaintive cry/voice
syn_a: lamentable, mournful, pathetic, sad, sorrowful, despondent, dismal, dreary, melancholy, morose

example: gently undulating hills.
example_ko: undulating countryside/fields/terrain/ground

syn: slow up, slow, go slower, ease up, slack up, reduce speed, lessen one's speed, brake, put the brakes on, hit the brakes
etym: From de- +‎ (ac)celerate.
en: When a vehicle or machine decelerates or when someone in a vehicle decelerates, the speed of the vehicle or machine is reduced.
example: the sensation of the train decelerating.
syn_v: check, curb, decelerate, delay, retard
syn_a: sluggish, torpid, extended, lingering, long, prolonged, delayed, late, overdue, tardy, boring, dull, tedious, backward, dense, dull-witted, retarded
ant2: fast, quick, early, exciting, precocious  hurry

zh_Hans: 预知的，有预知能力的，有先见之明的
syn: predictive, visionary
etym: From praesciēns (“foreknowing; foretelling, predicting”), present participle of) Latin praesciō (“to foreknow”), from prae- (prefix meaning ‘before; in front’) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *preh₂- (“before; in front”)) + sciō (“to know, understand; to have knowledge of”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *skey- (“to dissect; to split”)). The word is cognate with Middle French prescient (modern French prescient (“prescient”)), Italian presciente (“prescient”).[1]
en: If you say that someone or something was prescient, you mean that they were able to know or predict what was going to happen in the future.
example: Bob Roberts', an eerily prescient comedy about a populist multimillionaire political candidate.

etym: anti- +‎ body, a calque of  German Antikörper.
en: Antibodies are substances which a person's or an animal's body produces in their blood in order to destroy substances which carry disease.

syn: censure, condemn, castigate, chastise, lambaste, pillory, savage, find fault with, fulminate against, abuse
etym: From Latin obiūrgō.
en: to scold or reprimand
syn_v: reprove

syn: enthusiast, extremist, radical, Young Turk, diehard, activist, militant
etym: Initially only found as Middle English zelote, an epithet of w:Simon the Zealot, acquiring its current senses in the 16th and 17th centuries. The Middle English derives from Latin zēlōtēs, from Ancient Greek ζηλωτής (zēlōtḗs, “emulator, zealous admirer, follower”), from ζῆλος (zêlos, “zeal, jealousy”), from ζηλόω (zēlóō, “to emulate, to be jealous”).
en: If you describe someone as a zealot, you think that their views and actions are very extreme, especially in following a particular political or religious belief.
example: He was forceful, but by no means a zealot.
syn_n: enthusiast, extremist, fanatic, radical

zh_Hans: 担任裁判；判决，裁定，裁决
syn: adjudge, try, hear, examine, arbitrate, decide on, decide, settle, resolve, determine, pronounce on, give a ruling on, sit in judgement on, pass judgement on, give a verdict on, make a ruling on
etym: Borrowed from Latin adiūdicō, adiūdicātus, from ad + iūdicō (“to judge”). Doublet of adjudge.
en: If you adjudicate on a dispute or problem, you make an official judgment or decision about it.
example: a commissioner to adjudicate on legal rights
example_ko: [V] A special subcommittee adjudicates on planning applications.
syn_v: arbitrate, hear, judge, referee, umpire, decree, determine, pronounce, rule  settle

syn: idle, slothful, loafing, work-shy, shiftless, apathetic, lackadaisical, inactive, inert, lifeless, sluggish, lethargic, listless, languid, torpid, slow, slow-moving, dull, plodding
etym: From French indolent, from Latin indolentem, from in- (“not”) + dolēns (“pain”)
en: Someone who is indolent is lazy.
syn_a: idle, lazy, lethargic, slothful

syn: indirect, winding, meandering, serpentine, tortuous, twisting
etym: First attested in 1664. From Latin circuitōsus, from circuitus, from circumeō (“I go around”), from circum (“around”) + eō (“I go”).
en: A circuitous route is long and complicated rather than simple and direct.
example: The cabdriver took them on a circuitous route to the police station
example_ko: The race ended with eight laps of a city centre circuit.
syn_a: ambiguous, circular, meandering, rambling, roundabout

zh_Hans: 为和解的;为赢回好感的;安抚的
etym: From the Latin propitiātor.
en: If you propitiate someone, you stop them being angry or impatient by doing something to please them.
example: I've never gone out of my way to propitiate people
example_ko: Sacrifices were made to propitiate the gods.

syn: rascal, scoundrel, good-for-nothing, villain, wretch, unprincipled person, rake, profligate, degenerate, debauchee, libertine
en: If you describe someone as a reprobate, you mean that they behave in a way that is not respectable or morally correct.
example: a drunken reprobate.
syn_n: degenerate, rogue, scoundrel, villain
syn_v: censure, condemn, disapprove, reproach
syn_a: corrupt, depraved, perverted, roguish, unprincipled

zh_Hans: 投身（活动）；支持，拥护（观点）
syn: embrace, take up, take to, take to one's heart, receive enthusiastically, receive wholeheartedly, accept, welcome
etym: From Middle English espousen, borrowed from Old French espouser, from Latin spōnsāre, present active infinitive of spōnsō (frequentative of spondeō), from Proto-Indo-European *spend-.
en: If you espouse a particular policy, cause, or belief, you become very interested in it and give your support to it.
example: She ran away with him to Mexico and espoused the revolutionary cause.
example_ko: They espoused the notion of equal opportunity for all in education.
syn_v: advocate, champion, defend, support, adopt, embrace, take up, marry, wed

zh_Hans: （对行为或性格的改善）有益的
syn: good, good for one, advantageous, profitable, productive, helpful, useful, of use, of service, valuable, worthwhile, practical
etym: Borrowed from Middle French salutaire and its source, Latin salutaris (“healthful”), from salus (“health”).
en: A salutary experience is good for you, even though it may seem difficult or unpleasant at first.
example: It was a salutary experience to be in the minority
example_ko: a salutary lesson/experience/warning
syn_n: accolade, applause, honor, recognition, greeting, salutation
syn_v: honor, pay tribute, praise, address, greet, hail, welcome

syn: superficial, shallow, glib, thoughtless, carefree, irresponsible, insouciant, offhand
etym: 1595, from Northern English dialectal flippand (“prattling, babbling, glib”), present participle of flip (“to babble”), of North Germanic origin. Cognate with Icelandic fleipa (“to babble, prattle”), Swedish dialectal flepa (“to talk nonsense”). Alteration of -and suffix (a variant of the participial -ing) to -ant probably due to influence from words in -ant.
en: If you describe a person or what they say as flippant, you are criticizing them because you think they are not taking something as seriously as they should.
example: Don't be flippant, damn it! This is serious!
example_ko: a flippant answer/attitude
syn_a: frivolous, glib, light, nonchalant, offhand, superficial

zh_Hans: 在…之前；居…之先；胜过；超越
en: to go before, as in time, order, etc; precede
syn_n: forerunner, precursor, predecessor
syn_a: foregoing, preceding, previous

syn: disposition, nature, character, personality, make-up, constitution, mind, spirit, stamp, mettle, mould
etym: From Middle English temperen, tempren, from Old English ġetemprian, temprian, borrowed from Latin temperare (“to divide or proportion duly, mingle in due proportion, qualify, temper, regulate, rule, intransitive observe measure, be moderate or temperate”), from tempus (“time, fit season”). Compare also French tempérer. Doublet of tamper. See temporal.
en: If you refer to someone's temper or say that they have a temper, you mean that they become angry very easily.
example: He had a temper and could be nasty
example_ko: a violent/short/quick, etc. temper
syn_n: disposition, humor, nature, temperament, anger, choler, fit, passion, rage, calmness, composure, equilibrium, tranquility
syn_v: harden, strengthen, toughen, allay, mellow, moderate, season, soothe

syn: desultory, casual, superficial, token, uninterested, half-hearted, inattentive, unthinking, offhand, mechanical, automatic, routine
etym: Borrowed from Middle French cursoire (“rapid”), from Latin cursorius (“hasty, of a race or running”)
en: A cursory glance or examination is a brief one in which you do not pay much attention to detail.
example: Burke cast a cursory glance at the menu, then flapped it shut
example_ko: a cursory glance/examination/inspection
syn_a: casual, desultory, hasty, perfunctory, summary, superficial

syn: cleansing, bathing, showering, scrubbing, purification
etym: From Middle English, ablucioun (“cleansing of impurities”), from Old French ablution, and its source, Late Latin ablūtiō (“a washing away”), from abluō (“wash away”), from ab (“away”) + lavō (“wash”)[1].
en: the ritual washing of a priest's hands or of sacred vessels

zh_Hans: 在一州境内(尤指美国的州内)
etym: From intra- +‎ state.
en: of, relating to, or confined within a single state, esp a state of the US

syn: mock, jeer at, scoff at, jibe at, make fun of, poke fun at, laugh at, hold up to ridicule, pillory
etym: From Middle French dérider, from Latin dērīdeō (“to mock, laugh at”), from dē- (“from, down from”) + rīdeō (“to laugh”).
en: If you deride someone or something, you say that they are stupid or have no value.
example: Opposition MPs derided the Government's response to the crisis
example_ko: His views were derided as old-fashioned.
syn_v: jeer, mock, ridicule, scoff, scorn, sneer

syn: viridescent
etym: From Latin aqua (“water”) + marinus (“marine”), adjective form from mare (“sea”)
en: Aquamarines are clear, greenish-blue stones, sometimes used to make jewellery.
example: A necklace set with aquamarines.

zh_Hans: 堆积，积聚；逐渐的增加，增大
syn: collecting, gathering, amassing, cumulation, accrual, growth, formation, enlargement, increase, gain, augmentation, rise, mushrooming, snowballing
etym: Borrowed from Latin accrētiō, from ad (“to”) + crēscō (“grow”). First attested in the 1610s. Compare crescent, increase, accrue, and so on.
en: An accretion is an addition to something, usually one that has been added over a period of time.
example: The script has been gathering editorial accretions for years.
syn_n: accrual, accumulation, addition, buildup, expansion, growth, increase

ko: 귀에 거슬리는, [음악] 불협화(음)의; 조화되지 않은(opp. harmonious)
zh_Hans: 刺耳的；不谐和的；不调和的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：dis 不 + son 声音 + ant …的 → 不同的声音 → 不和谐的
syn: disharmonious, discordant, unmelodious, atonal, tuneless, off-key, cacophonous
etym: From Middle French dissonant.
en: discordant; cacophonous
syn_a: cacophonous, discordant, inharmonious, strident, contradictory, discrepant, incompatible, irreconcilable

syn: fault, flaw, split, break, breach, fissure, fracture, cleft, crevice, gap, cranny, slit, chink, interstice, cavity, opening, space, hole, aperture
etym: From the verb rive
en: A rift between people or countries is a serious quarrel or disagreement that stops them having a good relationship.
example: The interview reflected a growing rift between the President and the government
example_ko: The rift within the party deepened.
syn_n: break, crack, crevasse, fracture, rupture, breach, breakup, disagreement, misunderstanding, quarrel

zh_Hans: 好说教的；说教式的；自以为是的
syn: moralizing, sanctimonious, self-righteous, pietistic, pious, priggish, Pecksniffian, judgemental, canting
etym: From Latin sententiōsus, from sententia (“opinion, purpose”).
en: characterized by or full of aphorisms, terse pithy sayings, or axioms

syn: make off, run off, run away, flee, bolt, take off, take flight, disappear, vanish, slip away, steal away, sneak away, beat a hasty retreat, escape, make a run for it, make one's getaway, leave, depart, make oneself scarce
etym: French décamper, Old French descamper.
en: If you decamp, you go away from somewhere secretly or suddenly.
example: We all decamped to the pub.

syn: sinfulness, immorality, impropriety, vice, evil, sin
etym: From Middle English iniquite, jniquite (“evil, wickedness, iniquity; evil act; hostility, malevolence; hostile act; a calamity, misfortune”),[1] from Old French iniquité (modern French iniquité (“iniquity”)), from Latin inīquitās (“iniquity; inequality, unfairness; inequity, injustice”), from inīquus (“unequal, uneven, unfair; disadvantageous, unfavourable; hostile, unkind; unsuitable; wicked, wrong”) + -itās (variant of -tās (suffix forming a noun indicating a state of being)). Inīquus is derived from in- (prefix meaning ‘not’) + aequus (“equal; fair, impartial, just”).[2] Compare inequity.
en: You can refer to wicked actions or very unfair situations as iniquity.
example: He rails against the iniquities of capitalism
example_ko: the iniquity of racial prejudice
syn_n: evil, immorality, iniquity, vice, failing, transgression, weakness, anger, envy, gluttony, greed, lust, pride, sloth
syn_v: err, transgress, trespass

syn: die away, die down, die out, drop away, drop off, lessen, ease, ease off, let up, decrease, diminish, moderate, decline, fade, dwindle, slacken, recede, cool off, tail off, peter out, taper off, wane, ebb, relent, desist, weaken, become weaker, come to an end
etym: From Latin abbātem, accusative form of abbās, from Ancient Greek ἀββᾶς (abbâs), from Aramaic אבא‎ (’abbā, “father”).
en: If something bad or undesirable abates, it becomes much less strong or severe.
example: The storms had abated by the time they rounded Cape Horn.
example_ko: [V] The storm showed no signs of abating.
syn_n: attenuate, decline, decrease, diminish, dwindle, subside

zh_Hans: （某一想法或政治制度的）主要支持者，主要拥护者
syn: leading actress, leading performer, leading player, leading lady, leading man, lead, star
etym: From Ancient Greek πρωταγωνιστής (prōtagōnistḗs, “a chief actor”), from πρῶτος (prôtos, “first”) + ἀγωνιστής (agōnistḗs, “a combatant, pleader, actor”).
en: Someone who is a protagonist of an idea or movement is a supporter of it.
example: the main protagonists of their countries' integration into the world market.

syn: brood, sit on, cover
etym:
From Latin incubatus, past participle of
incubare (“to hatch”), from Latin
in- (“on”) and cubare (“to lie”).
en: When birds incubate their eggs, they keep the eggs warm until the baby birds come out.
example: The birds returned to their nests and continued to incubate the eggs.
syn_v: brood, incubate, conceive, concoct, contrive, devise, fashion  invent

syn: give a donation of, make a donation of, make a gift of, contribute, make a contribution of, present, gift, subscribe, hand out, grant, bestow, pledge, put oneself down for, put up, come up with, accord
etym: Circa 1845, back-formation from donation, chiefly in American English. Ultimately from Latin donare (to give).
en: If you donate something to a charity or other organization, you give it to them.
example: He frequently donates large sums to charity
example_ko: He donated thousands of pounds to charity.
syn_v: bestow, confer, contribute, give, grant, present, provide

syn: smelly, foul-smelling, evil-smelling, malodorous, stinking to high heaven, reeking, pungent, acrid, high, rank, foul, unpleasant, nasty, noxious
etym: Borrowed from Latin fētidus (“having offensive odour”), originally fēteō (“to stink”).
en: Fetid water or air has a very strong unpleasant smell.
example: the fetid river of waste.
syn_a: foul, gamy, malodorous, putrid, rank, stinking

syn: friction, enmity, antipathy, animus, opposition, dissension, rivalry, feud, conflict, discord, contention
etym: From Ancient Greek ἀνταγωνιστής (antagōnistḗs, “opponent”), from ἀνταγωνίζεσθαι (antagōnízesthai, “antagonize”), from ἀγών (agṓn, “contest”) (English agon).
en: Antagonism between people is hatred or dislike between them. Antagonisms are instances of this.
example: There is still much antagonism between trades unions and the oil companies
example_ko: The antagonism he felt towards his old enemy was still very strong.
syn_n: conflict, discord, friction, hostility, strife, animosity, aversion, enmity, hatred, rancor

syn: body of laws, constitution, rules, rulings, regulations, acts, bills, statutes, enactments, charters, ordinances, measures, canon, code
etym: Borrowed from Latin iūrisprūdentia (“astuteness in the law”).
en: Jurisprudence is the study of law and the principles on which laws are based.
example_ko: a professor of jurisprudence

etym: holo- +‎ -graph
en: a book or document handwritten by its author; original manuscript; autograph

syn: state, assert, aver, proclaim, pronounce, attest, swear, avow, vow, guarantee, promise, certify, pledge, give one's word, give an undertaking
etym: From Middle English affirmen, affermen, from Old French afermer, affermer, from Latin affirmare, adfirmare (“to present as fixed, aver, affirm”), from ad (“to”) + firmare (“to make firm”), from firmus (“firm”).
en: If you affirm that something is true or that something exists, you state firmly and publicly that it is true or exists.
example: The House of Lords affirmed that the terms of a contract cannot be rewritten retrospectively.
example_ko: [VN] Both sides affirmed their commitment to the ceasefire.
syn_v: assert, attest, avow, maintain, profess, confirm, establish, validate

ko: 암시하다, 시사(示唆)하다, 넌지시 말하다 ((to)) ((직접 언급할 때는 refer, mention을 씀; ⇒ refer [유의어/] ))
syn: suggest, hint at, imply, mention, touch on, mention in passing, mention en passant, speak briefly of, make an allusion to, cite
etym: From Middle French alluder, from Latin alludere (“to play with or allude”), from ad + ludere (“to play”).
en: If you allude to something, you mention it in an indirect way.
example: She also alluded to her rival's past marital troubles.
example_ko: ( allude +[전]+[명] ) allude  to one's poverty
syn_v: hint, imply, insinuate, intimate, suggest, cite, mention, refer to, speak of

syn: whirlpool, gyre, maelstrom, eddy, swirl, swirling, countercurrent, counterflow
etym: From Latin vortex.
en: A vortex is a mass of wind or water that spins round so fast that it pulls objects down into its empty centre.
example: The polar vortex is a system of wintertime winds.
syn_n: cyclone, eddy, maelstrom  whirlpool

syn: set forth, set out, present, outline, depict, portray, represent, characterize
etym: From Latin dēlīneātus, past participle of dēlīneo (“to sketch out, to delineate”), from de- + līnea (“line”).
en: If you delineate something such as an idea or situation, you describe it or define it, often in a lot of detail.
example: Biography must to some extent delineate characters
example_ko: Our objectives need to be precisely delineated.
syn_v: define, depict, describe, draft, outline, sketch, trace, picture, portray  render

zh_Hans: （无伤大雅的）怪癖，小毛病，小缺点
syn: weak point, weak spot, failing, shortcoming, flaw, imperfection, blemish, fault, defect, frailty, infirmity, inadequacy, limitation
etym: (1640-50) From Early Modern French foible (“feeble”) (contemporary French faible). Doublet of feeble.
en: A foible is a habit or characteristic that someone has which is considered rather strange, foolish, or bad but which is also considered unimportant.
example: human foibles and weaknesses.
example_ko: We have to tolerate each other’s little foibles.
syn_n: deficiency, failing, frailty, imperfection, shortcoming, weakness

syn: abundant, profuse, prolific, plentiful, luxuriant
etym: Borrowed from Latin opulēns, opulentus, from ops (“wealth, power, resources”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃op- (“to work; produce in abundance”).
en: Opulent things or places look grand and expensive.
example: an opulent office on Wimpole Street in London's West End.
syn_a: affluent, flush, wealthy, well-to-do, ample, bounteous, copious, plentiful, extravagant, lavish, rich, sumptuous

ko: (바퀴 하나에 기다란 손잡이가 달린) 거리 측정계
zh_Hans: 手推童车，婴儿车（pram的正式说法）
en: a formal word for pram

syn: reproduce, replicate, duplicate, mimic, parallel, be a mock-up of
etym: Borrowed from Latin simulātus, past participle of simulō (“make like, imitate, copy, represent, feign”), from similis (“like”). See similar.
en: If you simulate an action or a feeling, you pretend that you are doing it or feeling it.
example: They rolled about on the Gilligan Road, simulating a bloodthirsty fight
example_ko: I tried to simulate surprise at the news.
syn_v: fabricate, fake, feign, pretend, ape, copy, imitate  mimic

zh_Hans: 良心的不安；内疚；自责；后悔
syn: misgivings, qualms, worries, unease, uneasiness, hesitation, hesitancy, doubts, reluctance, reservations
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French, from Late Latin compunctionem (“a pricking”), from Latin compunctus, the past participle of compungere (“to severely prick”), from com- + pungere (“to prick”).
en: If you say that someone has no compunction about doing something, you mean that they do it without feeling ashamed or guilty.
example: He has no compunction about relating how he killed his father.
example_ko: She felt no compunction about leaving her job.
syn_n: apprehension, hesitation, misgiving, reservation, conscience, regret, remorse  shame

zh_Hans: 终止;失败;倒闭;死亡;逝世;一命呜呼
syn: dying, passing, passing away, passing on, loss of life, expiry, expiration, end, departure from life, final exit
etym: From Latin demissa, feminine singular of perfect passive participle of dēmittō, apparently via Middle French démise, the feminine singular past participle of démettre.
en: The demise of something or someone is their end or death.
example: the demise of the reform movement
syn_n: death, decease, expiration, collapse, fall, ruin

syn: belief, doctrine, precept, creed, credo, article of faith, dogma, canon, rule
etym: Borrowed from Latin tenet (“it holds”), from teneō (“hold; have”). Compare obsolete tenent.
en: The tenets of a theory or belief are the main principles on which it is based.
example: Non-violence and patience are the central tenets of their faith
example_ko: one of the basic/central tenets of Christianity
syn_n: canon, conviction, creed, doctrine, dogma  principle

ko: 치사스럽지만[자기 격에 떨어지지만] 한다는 듯이 굴다
syn: stoop, lower oneself, descend, think fit, see fit, deem it worthy of oneself, consent, vouchsafe
etym: From Middle English deignen, borrowed from Old French deignier (“consider worthy”), from Latin dīgnō, dīgnārī (“consider worthy”), from dīgnus (“worthy”). Cognate to dignity and French daigner.
en: If you say that someone deigned to do something, you are expressing your disapproval of the fact that they did it unwillingly, because they thought they were too important to do it.
example: At last, Harper deigned to speak
example_ko: She just grunted, not deigning to look up from the page.
syn_v: stoop, disdain  patronize

zh_Hans: （美国某些大学的）女生联谊会，姊妹会
syn: gang, mob, pack, troop, troupe, company, party, bevy, crew, body, working party, posse
etym: From Renaissance Latin sorōritās, from Latin soror (“sister”), from Proto-Indo-European *swésōr. Akin to Spanish sororidad, Portuguese sororidade, French sororité.
en: In the United States, a sorority is a society of female university or college students.

zh_Hans: 柔和动听的，轻柔悦耳的
syn: sweet-sounding, mellifluous, euphonious, soothing, mellow, honeyed, pleasant, agreeable
etym: From Middle English doucet, from Old French doucet, from dulz, dulce (“sweet, pleasant”) + diminutive -et, from Latin dulcis (“sweet, pleasant”). Cognate with Spanish dulce, French doux, Italian dolce, Portuguese doce, and Romanian dulce.
en: People often use the expression dulcet tones to refer to someone's voice.
example: You hear his dulcet tones on the Radio 1 trailers in the morning.
example_ko: I thought I recognized your dulcet tones.
syn_a: lyrical, mellifluous, melodious, musical, silvery, sweet

syn: invective, condemnation, castigation, chastisement, opprobrium, rebuke, scolding, criticism, flak, disapprobation, fault-finding
etym: From Latin vituperātiō (“censure, blame”), equivalent to vituperate +‎ -ion
en: Vituperation is language that is full of hate, anger, or insults.

syn: hostile, malevolent, malicious, malign, evil-intentioned, baleful, full of hate, vicious, nasty, poisonous, venomous, acrimonious, rancorous, splenetic, cruel
etym: From Middle French malignant, from Late Latin malignans. See malign.
en: A malignant tumour or disease is out of control and likely to cause death.
example: She developed a malignant breast tumour.
example_ko: malignant cells
syn_a: malevolent, malicious, mean, spiteful, venomous, deadly, lethal, poisonous, toxic

syn: invocation, conjuration, magic spell, magic formula, rune
etym: From Old French incantation, from Latin incantatio. More at enchant.
en: An incantation is a series of words that a person says or sings as a magic spell.
example: strange prayers and incantations.

syn: make known, divulge, tell, impart, communicate, pass on, vouchsafe, unfold
etym: From Middle English disclosen, from Middle French desclos, from Old French desclore, itself from Vulgar Latin disclaudere, from Latin dis- + claudere (“to close, shut”) or as a variant of discludo, discludere (cf. disclude).
en: If you disclose new or secret information, you tell people about it.
example: Neither side would disclose details of the transaction
example_ko: [VN] The spokesman refused to disclose details of the takeover to the press.
syn_v: confess, divulge, leak, reveal, tell, broadcast, publish, bare, expose, uncover, unveil

syn: itemize, catalogue, set out, set forth, give
etym: From Latin enumerātus, from enumerō.
en: When you enumerate a list of things, you name each one in turn.
example: I enumerate the work that will have to be done.
syn_v: cite, list, name, specify, add, count  number

syn: ban, bar, veto, proscription, interdiction, embargo, moratorium, injunction, restraining order
etym: Middle English entrediten, from Old French entredire (“forbid”), from Latin interdīcere, present active infinitive of interdīcō (“prohibit, forbid”), from inter (“between”) + dīcō (“say”), from Proto-Indo-European *deyḱ.
en: If an armed force interdicts something or someone, they stop them and prevent them from moving. If they interdict a route, they block it or cut it off.
example: Troops could be ferried in to interdict drug shipments.

syn: retrogress, relapse, lapse, backslide, go backwards, slip back, drift back, subside, sink back
etym: (verb) From Latin regressus, past participle of regredi (“to go back”), from re- (“back”) + gradi (“to go”).
en: When people or things regress, they return to an earlier and less advanced stage of development.
example: if your child regresses to babyish behaviour
syn_v: backslide, relapse, retrogress, revert, degenerate, deteriorate

syn: annoyance, irritation, vexation, exasperation, indignation, huff, moodiness, pet, pique, fit of pique, displeasure
etym: dys- +‎ Ancient Greek πέψις (pépsis, “digestion”)  +‎ -ia
en: Dyspepsia is the same as indigestion.

zh_Hans: （尤指怀念故人或往事的）挽歌；挽诗；哀歌
syn: funeral song, burial hymn, lament, dirge, plaint, requiem, keening
etym: From Middle French elegie, from Latin elegīa, from Ancient Greek ἐλεγεία ᾠδή (elegeía ōidḗ, “an elegiac song”), from ἐλεγεία (elegeía), feminine of ἐλεγεῖος (elegeîos, “elegiac”), from ἔλεγος (élegos, “poem or song of lament”), perhaps from Phrygian.[1]
en: An elegy is a sad poem, often about someone who has died.
example: a touching elegy for a lost friend.

zh_Hans: （论据、观点、计划）有条理的，连贯的，前后一致的
syn: reasoned, reasonable, well reasoned, rational, sound, cogent
etym: From Middle French coherent, from Latin cohaērēns, from co- + haereō.
en: If something is coherent, it is well planned, so that it is clear and sensible and all its parts go well with each other.
example: He has failed to work out a coherent strategy for modernising the service
example_ko: a coherent narrative/account/explanation
syn_a: intelligible, logical, lucid, rational, congruous, consistent, harmonious

syn: unstoppable, unavoidable, inescapable, inevitable, irrevocable
etym: From Middle French inexorable, from Latin inexōrābilis (“relentless, inexorable”) (or directly from the Latin word), from in- (prefix meaning ‘not’) + exōrābilis (“that may be moved or persuaded by entreaty; exorable”).[1] Exōrābilis is derived from exōrāre[2] (from exōrō (“to persuade, win over; to beg, entreat, plead”), from ex- (prefix meaning ‘out of’) + ōrō (“to beg, entreat, plead, pray; to deliver a speech, orate”), from ōs (“mouth”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃éh₁os (“mouth”)) + -bilis (suffix forming adjectives indicating a capacity or worth of being acted upon).
en: You use inexorable to describe a process which cannot be prevented from continuing or progressing.
example: the seemingly inexorable rise in unemployment.
example_ko: the inexorable rise of crime
syn_a: inflexible, relentless, unstoppable  unyielding

etym: English Wikipedia has an article on:fortnightWikipedia
en: A fortnight is a period of two weeks.
example: I hope to be back in a fortnight.
example_ko: a fortnight’s holiday

zh_Hans: （尤指作为结果而）接着发生，继而发生，因而产生
syn: follow, develop, stem, spring, arise, derive, evolve, proceed, emerge, emanate, issue, flow
etym: From Old French ensu- [1], stem of some conjugated forms of ensivre (“follow close upon, come afterward”) (French ensuivre), from Latin īnsequere, from īnsequi (“to pursue, follow, follow after; come next”), from in- (“upon”) (see in-) + sequi (“follow”) (see sequel).
en: If something ensues, it happens immediately after another event, usually as a result of it.
example: If the Europeans did not reduce subsidies, a trade war would ensue
example_ko: An argument ensued.
syn_v: develop, eventuate, follow, result, succeed

zh_Hans: 有害的；不利的；限制性的
syn: injurious, detrimental, deleterious, pernicious, damaging, hurtful, dangerous, destructive, ruinous, calamitous
etym: From Latin inimicus (“enemy”), from in- (“not”) + amicus (“friend”).
en: Conditions that are inimical to something make it difficult for that thing to exist or do well.
example: goals inimical to Western interests.
example_ko: These policies are inimical to the interests of society.
syn_a: antagonistic, contrary, hostile, malevolent, malicious

zh_Hans: （常指逐渐地）削弱信心、权威等，损害
syn: wear away, eat away at, chip away, undercut
etym: From under- +‎ mine.
en: If you undermine something such as a feeling or a system, you make it less strong or less secure than it was before, often by a gradual process or by repeated efforts.
example: Offering advice on each and every problem will undermine her feeling of being adult
example_ko: Our confidence in the team has been seriously undermined by their recent defeats.
syn_v: foil, frustrate, sabotage, subvert, thwart

syn: change the tone of, vary, inflect
etym: From Latin īnflectō, from in- (“in”) + flectō (“I bend”)
en: If a word inflects, its ending or form changes in order to show its grammatical function. If a language inflects, it has words in it that inflect.

zh_Hans: 预示，预兆（尤指不祥之事）
syn: augur, foreshadow, foretell, prophesy, be an omen of, herald, be a sign of, be the harbinger of, be a warning of, give a warning of, warn of, be an indication of, indicate, be a presage of, signal, bode, announce, promise, threaten
etym: From Middle French presage, from Latin praesāgium.
en: If something presages a situation or event, it is considered to be a warning or sign of what is about to happen.
example: the dawn's loud chorus that seemed to presage a bright hot summer's day.
syn_n: indication, portent, sign, warning, omen  prophecy
syn_v: forbode, portend, foretell, predict, prophesy

syn: make sharper, make sharp, whet, strop, grind, file, put an edge on
en: If you hone something, for example a skill, technique, idea, or product, you carefully develop it over a long period of time so that it is exactly right for your purpose.
example: Leading companies spend time and money on honing the skills of senior managers
example_ko: His body was honed to perfection.
syn_a: ethical, honorable, moral, trustworthy, upright, virtuous, candid, forthright, frank, sincere

syn: ladies' man, playboy, rake, roué, loose-liver, Don Juan, Lothario, Casanova, Romeo
en: If you refer to someone as a libertine, you mean that they are sexually immoral and do not care about the effect their behaviour has on other people.
syn_n: epicurean, hedonist, pleasure-seeker, freethinker, humanist, individualist, debauchee, lecher, profligate, rake, reprobate
syn_a: dissolute, immoral, licentious, loose, lustful, wanton

ko: (식욕·성욕 등을) 실컷 만족시키다, 물릴[질릴] 정도로 주다
zh_Hans: （尤指饮食或享乐）使饱足，使厌腻
syn: fully satisfy, sate
etym: Borrowed from Latin satiatus, past participle of satiare (“to fill full, satiate”), from sat + satis (“sufficient”) + satur (“full”).
en: If something such as food or pleasure satiates you, you have all that you need or all that you want of it, often so much that you become tired of it.
example: The dinner was enough to satiate the gourmets
syn_v: glut, sate, stuff, surfeit, appease, gratify, satisfy

syn: witticism, gem, play on words, jest, pun, sally, nice turn of phrase
etym: From Middle French epigramme, from Latin epigramma, from Ancient Greek ἐπίγραμμα (epígramma, “inscription”).
en: An epigram is a short saying or poem which expresses an idea in a very clever and amusing way.
syn_n: adage, aphorism, epigram, expression, maxim, motto  proverb

syn: invective, polemic, denunciation, rant, broadside, attack, harangue, verbal onslaught
etym: From French tirade (“monologue, speech, tirade”).
en: A tirade is a long angry speech in which someone criticizes a person or thing.
example: She launched into a tirade against the policies that ruined her business
example_ko: She launched into a tirade of abuse against politicians.
syn_n: diatribe, harangue, invective  vituperation

syn: mistake, error, slip
etym: Borrowed from French gaucherie.
en: the quality of being gauche

zh_Hans: （过于）坦诚的，直率的；直截了当的
syn: direct, straightforward, honest, candid, open, sincere, straight, straight to the point, blunt, plain-spoken, outspoken, downright, uninhibited, unreserved, point blank, no-nonsense, matter-of-fact, bluff, undiplomatic, tactless
etym: From Old English forþriht (“direct, plain”); equivalent to forth (adverb) +‎ right (adjective). The adverb is from Old English forþrihte (“straightway, at once, plainly”), with the adverbial suffix -e.
en: If you describe someone as forthright, you admire them because they show clearly and strongly what they think and feel.
example_ko: a woman of forthright views
syn_a: blunt, candid, direct, frank, straightforward

ko: (국가·조직 등에서 신임 지도자가 취임하기 전의) 최고 지도자 부재 기간
zh_Hans: （国家或组织的）权力空白期，空位期
syn: interlude, intervening time, intervening period, meantime, meanwhile
etym: From Latin inter- "between" + the accusative of regnum (which is regnum) meaning "reign", "power" or "kingdom". Literally meaning "between reign" or "between kingdom".
en: An interregnum is a period between the end of one person's time as ruler or leader and the coming to power of the next ruler or leader.

syn: conflict, friction, hostility
etym: Circa 1230, Middle English descorde, discorde; from Anglo-Norman, Old French descort (derivative of descorder), descorde (“disagreement”); from Latin discordia, from discors (“disagreeing, disagreement”), from dis- (“apart”) + cor, cordis (“heart”)
en: Discord is disagreement and argument between people.
example_ko: marital/family discord
syn_n: conflict, contention, disagreement, dissension, strife, cacophony, din, disharmony, noise, racket

syn: damaging, detrimental, injurious, inimical, hurtful, bad, adverse, disadvantageous, unfavourable, unfortunate, undesirable
etym: From Medieval Latin deleterius, from Ancient Greek δηλητήριος (dēlētḗrios, “noxious, deleterious”), from δηλητήρ (dēlētḗr, “a destroyer”), from δηλέομαι (dēléomai, “I hurt, damage, spoil, waste”), 1640s.[1]
en: Something that has a deleterious effect on something has a harmful effect on it.
example: Petty crime is having a deleterious effect on community life.
syn_a: damaging, deleterious, detrimental, injurious, poisonous, unhealthy, unwholesome

zh_Hans: 慈善的；乐善好施的（尤指透过捐款帮助穷人）
syn: generous, benevolent, humanitarian, public-spirited, altruistic, socially concerned, magnanimous, munificent, open-handed, bountiful, liberal, ungrudging, unstinting, generous to a fault, beneficent, benignant, caring, compassionate, solicitous, unselfish, selfless, humane, kind, kind-hearted, big-hearted
etym: From French philanthropique
en: A philanthropic person or organization freely gives money or other help to people who need it.
example: Some of the best services for the ageing are sponsored by philanthropic organizations.
syn_a: altruistic, benevolent, charitable, generous, magnanimous, munificent

zh_Hans: （动作、行为等）不规则的，不确定的，无计划的
syn: inconsistent, changeable, variable, inconstant, uncertain, irregular, unstable, turbulent, unsteady, unsettled, unreliable, undependable, changing, ever-changing, volatile, varying, shifting, fluctuating, fluid, mutable, protean, fitful, wavering, full of ups and downs, peaky
etym: Borrowed from Old French erratique, from Latin erraticus.
en: Something that is erratic does not follow a regular pattern, but happens at unexpected times or moves along in an irregular way.
example: Argentina's erratic inflation rate threatens to upset the plans.
example_ko: The electricity supply here is quite erratic.
syn_a: inconsistent, irregular, shifting, unpredictable, wandering

syn: chastise, upbraid, berate, castigate, lambaste, rebuke, reprimand, reproach, reprove, admonish, remonstrate with, lecture, criticize, censure
etym: From Middle English chiden (“to chide, rebuke, disapprove, criticize; complain, grumble, dispute; argue, debate, dispute, quarrel”), from Old English ċīdan (“to chide, reprove, rebuke; blame, contend, strive, quarrel, complain”). Cognate with German kiden (“to sound”); Old High German kīdal (“wedge”).
en: If you chide someone, you speak to them angrily because they have done something wicked or foolish.
example: Cross chided himself for worrying
example_ko: [VN] She chided herself for being so impatient with the children.
syn_v: chasten, lecture, reprimand, scold, upbraid

etym: From Middle French cardiaque, from Latin cardiacus, from Ancient Greek καρδιακός (kardiakós, “relating to the heart”), from καρδία (kardía, “heart”).
en: Cardiac means relating to the heart.
example: The king was suffering from cardiac weakness.
example_ko: cardiac disease/failure/surgery

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：hypo 下，低；次等 + chondr 软骨 + iac 有…病的 → 患疑病症的
syn: valetudinary, malingering, neurotic, health-obsessed, obsessed with one's health, preoccupied with ill health, anxious about one's health
etym: From French hypocondriaque, from Ancient Greek ὑποχονδριακός (hupokhondriakós, “of the region between the ribs and navel”), from ὑποχόνδριος (hupokhóndrios, “the space between the ribs and the navel”), from ὑπό (hupó, “below”) + χόνδρος (khóndros, “cartilage”)
en: A hypochondriac is a person who continually worries about their health, although there is really nothing wrong with them.
example_ko: Don’t be such a hypochondriac!—there’s nothing wrong with you.

syn: muddy, thick
etym: From Middle English turbide, borrowed from Latin turbidus (“disturbed”), from turba (“mass, throng, crowd, tumult, disturbance”).
en: muddy or opaque, as a liquid clouded with a suspension of particles
syn_a: clouded, cloudy, dirty, muddy, murky

syn: immediate, instantaneous, hurried, hasty, quick, swift, rapid, speedy, precipitate
etym: First attested in 1583. Borrowed from Latin abruptus (“broken off”), perfect passive participle of abrumpō (“break off”), formed from ab (“from, away from”) + rumpō (“to break”).[1][2]
en: An abrupt change or action is very sudden, often in a way which is unpleasant.
example: Rosie's idyllic world came to an abrupt end when her parents' marriage broke up
example_ko: an abrupt change/halt/departure
syn_a: hasty, hurried, sudden, perpendicular, precipitous, sheer, steep, blunt, brusque, curt, short

zh_Hans: （通常指因工作而）巡回的，流动的；漫游的
syn: itinerant, travelling, wandering, roving, roaming, migrant, migratory, ambulatory, unsettled, vagabond, vagrant
etym: From French péripatétique, from Latin peripatēticus, from Ancient Greek περιπατητικός (peripatētikós, “given to walking around”), from περιπατέω (peripatéō, “I walk around”), from περί (perí, “around”) (English peri-)+ πατέω (patéō, “I walk”).
en: If someone has a peripatetic life or career, they travel around a lot, living or working in places for short periods of time.
example: Her father was in the army and the family led a peripatetic existence.
example_ko: a peripatetic music teacher

etym: From infatuate +‎ -ed.
en: If you are infatuated with a person or thing, you have strong feelings of love or passion for them which make you unable to think clearly or sensibly about them.
example: He was utterly infatuated with her
example_ko: She was completely infatuated with him.
syn_a: captivated, doting, enamored, overfond, preoccupied, taken

syn: transparent, glassy, glasslike, crystal clear, crystalline, see-through, translucent, pellucid, unclouded, uncloudy
etym: From French limpide, from Latin limpidus.
en: If you say that something is limpid, you mean that it is very clear and transparent.
example: limpid blue eyes.
example_ko: limpid eyes/water
syn_a: clear, lucid, translucent, transparent, peaceful, placid, serene, still, tranquil

zh_Hans: 支吾，搪塞，含糊其词；顾左右而言他
syn: be evasive, be non-committal, be vague, be ambiguous, dodge the issue, evade the issue, beat about the bush, hedge, hedge one's bets, fudge the issue
etym: From the participle stem of Latin praevāricārī (“to walk crookedly, to play a false or double part”), from prae- + vāricāre (“to stand with feet apart, straddle”), from vārus (“deviating from the right line, bent outwards, different”), from Proto-Indo-European *wā- (“to bend apart”) (the root of various).
en: If you prevaricate, you avoid giving a direct answer or making a firm decision.
example: British ministers continued to prevaricate.
example_ko: [V] Stop prevaricating and come to the point.
syn_v: deceive, falsify, fib, lie  perjure

syn: banal, clichéd, platitudinous, vapid, commonplace, ordinary, common, stock, conventional, stereotyped, predictable
etym: Compare Tocharian A trit
en: If you say that something such as an idea, remark, or story is trite, you mean that it is dull and boring because it has been said or told too many times.
example: The movie is teeming with obvious and trite ideas
syn_a: banal, clich), hackneyed, stale, stereotyped, insipid, shallow, superficial

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：vituper 责备 + ate 表动词 → 严厉责备
syn: rail against, inveigh against, fulminate against, attack, upbraid, berate, harangue, lambaste, reprimand, castigate, chastise, rebuke, scold, chide, censure, condemn, damn, denounce, find fault with, run down, take to task, vilify, denigrate, calumniate, insult, abuse, curse, slander, smear
etym: From Latin vituperātus, perfect passive participle of vituperō (“I blame, I censure”), from vitium (“fault, defect”) + parō (“I furnish, I provide, I contrive”).
en: to berate or rail (against) abusively; revile

ko: 무릎을 꿇다(경의를 표하거나 예배를 드리기 위해 한 쪽 또는 양 쪽 무릎을 꿇는 것)
zh_Hans: （尤指进出天主教教堂时）下跪，跪拜
syn: get down on one's knees, genuflect, bow, bow down, make obeisance, kowtow, curtsy, show reverence, show deference
etym: PIE word*ǵónu
en: If you genuflect, you bend one or both knees and bow, especially in church, as a sign of respect.
example: He genuflected in front of the altar.

zh_Hans: 逊位；退（位），让（位），正式放弃（王位）
syn: retire, quit, stand down, step down, bow out, renounce the throne
etym:
First attested in 1541.
From Latin abdicātus (“renounced”), perfect passive participle of abdicō (“renounce, reject, disclaim”), formed from ab (“away”) + dicō (“proclaim, dedicate, declare”), akin to dīcō (“say”).
en: If a king or queen abdicates, he or she gives up being king or queen.
example: The last French king was Louis Philippe, who abdicated in 1848.
example_ko: [V] He abdicated in favour of his son.
syn_v: abjure, renounce, resign, surrender, yield

syn: deter, prevent, disincline, turn aside, divert, sidetrack
etym: From Middle French dissuader, from Latin dissuādeō (“I urge differently”, “I advise against”, “I dissuade”), from dis- (“away from”, “asunder”) + suādeō (“I recommend”, “I advise”, “I urge”).
en: If you dissuade someone from doing or believing something, you persuade them not to do or believe it.
example: Doctors had tried to dissuade patients from smoking
example_ko: I tried to dissuade him from giving up his job.
syn_v: dampen, daunt, depress, dishearten, dismay, deter, hinder, obstruct, disincline, dissuade, shake

zh_Hans: （对国王或女王）忠诚的，忠心耿耿的
syn: faithfulness, fidelity, obedience, fealty, adherence, homage, devotion, bond
etym: From Middle English fealtye, feaute, feawte, feute, fewte, from Anglo-Norman fëalté and Old French fëauté, fëuté, from Latin fidēlitās (“faithfulness”). Doublet of fidelity.
en: In former times, if someone swore fealty to their ruler, they promised to be loyal to him or her.
example_ko: I did fealty to the nation.

zh_Hans: 假定存在的，被认为存在的
syn: seeming, alleged, putative, reputed, rumoured, claimed, purported, ostensible, specious
etym: First attested 1432, from Middle French putatif, from Latin putātīvus (“supposed, purported”), from putātus (“thought”), from putō (“I think, I consider, I reckon”).
en: If you describe someone or something as putative, you mean that they are generally thought to be the thing mentioned.
example: a putative father.
example_ko: the putative father of this child

zh_Hans: （人或组织）腐朽的；颓废的；堕落的
syn: dissipated, degenerate, corrupt, depraved, louche, rakish, shameless, sinful, unprincipled, immoral, licentious, wanton, abandoned, unrestrained, profligate, intemperate, fast-living
etym: From French décadent, back-formation from décadence, from Medieval Latin decadentia, from Late Latin decadens, present participle of decadō (“sink, fall”). Cognate with French décadent.
en: If you say that a person or society is decadent, you think that they have low moral standards and are interested mainly in pleasure.
example: the excesses and stresses of their decadent rock 'n' roll lifestyles.
example_ko: the decadent rich
syn_a: corrupt, debauched, degenerate, depraved, dissolute, immoral, perverted

syn: dispute, disagree with, argue with, dissent from, contradict, repudiate, declare untrue, challenge, oppose, contest, counter, fly in the face of
etym: From Middle English gainsayen, ȝeinseggen (“to say against, say in opposition to”), equivalent to gain- +‎ say. Compare Old Danish gensige (“to speak against; gainsay”), Swedish gensaga (“a speaking against; protest”).
en: If there is no gainsaying something, it is true or obvious and everyone would agree with it.
example: There is no gainsaying the fact that they have been responsible for a truly great building.
example_ko: Nobody can gainsay his claims.

syn: idle, indolent, work-shy, inactive, inert, sluggish, apathetic, lethargic, listless, languid, torpid, slow-moving, slow, heavy, dull, enervated, shiftless, lackadaisical
etym: sloth +‎ -ful
en: Someone who is slothful is lazy and unwilling to make an effort to work.
example: He was not slothful: he had been busy all night.
syn_a: idle, lazy, shiftless, drowsy, listless, sluggish

syn: impede, obstruct, thwart, frustrate, foil, suppress, smother, repress
etym: From Latin stultus (“stupid, foolish”),  +‎ -ify.
en: If something stultifies you, it makes you feel empty or dull in your mind, because it is so boring.
example: This attitude stultifies scientific progress
example_ko: the stultifying effects of work that never varies

syn: book list, list of books, catalogue, record
etym: From Ancient Greek βιβλιογραφία (bibliographía, “the act or habit of writing books”), from βιβλιογράφος (bibliográphos, “a writer of books”), from βιβλίον (biblíon, “small book”) + γράφω (gráphō, “I write”).
en: A bibliography is a list of books on a particular subject.
example: At the end of this chapter there is a select bibliography of useful books.

zh_Hans: （作出评判、决定或处理的）标准，准则
syn: point of reference, standard, norm, yardstick, benchmark, touchstone, test, formula, measure, gauge, scale, barometer, indicator, litmus test
etym: From New Latin criterion, from Ancient Greek κριτήριον (kritḗrion, “a test, a means of judging”), from κριτής (kritḗs, “judge”), from κρίνω (krínō, “to judge”); see critic.
en: A criterion is a factor on which you judge or decide something.
example: The most important criterion for entry is that applicants must design and make their own work
example_ko: The main criterion is value for money.
syn_n: gauge, measure, model, rule, standard  yardstick

etym: opulent +‎ -ly
en: Opulent things or places look grand and expensive.
example: an opulent office on Wimpole Street in London's West End.
syn_a: affluent, flush, wealthy, well-to-do, ample, bounteous, copious, plentiful, extravagant, lavish, rich, sumptuous

syn: scorn, scornfulness, contemptuousness, derision, disrespect
etym: From Old French desdeignier (modern French dédaigner).
en: If you feel disdain for someone or something, you dislike them because you think that they are inferior or unimportant.
example: Janet looked at him with disdain
example_ko: to treat sb with disdain
syn_n: arrogance, contempt, scorn, aloofness, detachment, indifference
syn_v: despise, dislike, reject, spurn, disregard, ignore, slight, snub

ko: <말·습관 등이> 쇠퇴해 가는, 사용되지 않게 되는; <기계 등이> 구식의
zh_Hans: 在逐步废弃的；即将淘汰的；逐渐过时的
syn: becoming obsolete, going out of use, going out of fashion, on the decline, declining, waning, on the wane, disappearing, past its prime, ageing, moribund, on its last legs, out of date, outdated, old-fashioned, outmoded
etym: From Latin obsolescentum.
en: If something is obsolescent, it is no longer needed because something better has been invented.
example: outmoded, obsolescent equipment.
example_ko: an obsolescent word

syn: sharpness, roughness, abrasiveness, severity, acerbity, astringency, bitterness, acidity, tartness, edge, acrimony, virulence, sarcasm
etym: From Old French asprete, from Latin asperitatem, from asper (“rough”).
en: If you say something with asperity, you say it impatiently and severely.
example: I told you Preskel had no idea,' remarked Kemp with some asperity.
example_ko: She answered my question with asperity.
syn_n: acrimony, churlishness, crossness, harshness, irascibility, surliness

zh_Hans: 令人不解的;不知道如何处置的
en: If you find something perplexing, you do not understand it or do not know how to deal with it.
example: It took years to understand many perplexing diseases
example_ko: [VN] They were perplexed by her response.
syn_v: bewilder, confuse, mystify, nonplus, puzzle

syn: evaluate, estimate, judge, rate, gauge, sum up, review, consider
en: If you appraise something or someone, you consider them carefully and form an opinion about them.
example: This prompted many employers to appraise their selection and recruitment policies
example_ko: an appraising glance/look
syn_v: assess, estimate, gauge, value, evaluate, examine, inspect  judge

ko: (경험·지식 부족 등으로) 순진해 빠진, (모자랄 정도로) 순진한
syn: unsophisticated, artless, ingenuous, inexperienced, guileless, unworldly, childlike, trusting, trustful, dewy-eyed, starry-eyed, wide-eyed, fond, simple, natural, unaffected, unpretentious
etym: Borrowed from French naïve, from Latin nativus (“native, natural”). Doublet of native.
en: If you describe someone as naive, you think they lack experience and so expect things to be easy or people to be honest or kind.
example: It's naive to think that teachers are always tolerant
example_ko: to be politically naive
syn_a: ingenuous, innocent, unsophisticated, credulous, gullible, trusting, unsuspecting

syn: pithy, short and to the point, short and sweet, potted, thumbnail, brief, crisp, compact, concise, condensed, shortened, contracted, compressed, abridged, abbreviated, summarized, summary, abstracted
etym: From Old French compendieux, from Latin compendiosus (“advantageous, abridged, brief”), from compendium.
en: containing or stating the essentials of a subject in a concise form; succinct
example_ko: a compendious description

zh_Hans: 道德败坏；淫荡；沉湎酒色（或毒品）
syn: dissoluteness, degeneracy, corruption, vice, turpitude, depravity, loucheness, rakishness, libertinism, immodesty, indecency, perversion, shamelessness, iniquity, wickedness, sinfulness, sinning, impropriety, lack of morals, lack of principles, immorality, impurity, unchastity, lasciviousness, salaciousness, lechery, lecherousness, lewdness, bawdiness, lust, lustfulness, libidinousness, licentiousness, promiscuity, wantonness, abandonment, abandon, profligacy, decadence, immoderateness, intemperance, lack of restraint, indulgence, self-indulgence, pleasure-seeking, hedonism, sybaritism
etym: From debauch +‎ -ery, 1640s.
en: You use debauchery to refer to the drinking of alcohol or to sexual activity if you disapprove of it or regard it as excessive.
example: scenes of drunkenness and debauchery.
syn_n: excess, immoderation, indulgence, dissipation, intemperance, profligacy, depravity, evil, immorality

syn: harangue, verbal onslaught, verbal attack, stream of abuse, denunciation, broadside, fulmination, condemnation, criticism, stricture, reproof, reproval, reprimand, rebuke, admonishment, admonition
etym: First attested 1581, borrowed from French diatribe, from Latin diatriba (“learned discussion or discourse”), from Ancient Greek διατριβή (diatribḗ, “way of spending time, lecture”), from διά (diá, “through”) + τρίβω (tríbō, “I waste, wear out”)
en: A diatribe is an angry speech or article which is extremely critical of someone's ideas or activities.
example: The book is a diatribe against the academic left.
example_ko: He launched a bitter diatribe against the younger generation.
syn_n: diatribe, harangue, invective  vituperation

syn: shock, startle, impel, stir, spur, prod, urge, motivate, stimulate, electrify, excite, rouse, arouse, awaken, invigorate, fire, fuel, animate, vitalize, energize, exhilarate, thrill, dynamize, inspire
etym: From French galvaniser, from galvanisme, named after Italian physiologist Luigi Aloisio Galvani (1737–1798).
en: To galvanize someone means to cause them to take action, for example by making them feel very excited, afraid, or angry.
example: The aid appeal has galvanised the German business community
example_ko: The urgency of his voice galvanized them into action.
syn_v: arouse, electrify, excite, stimulate, activate, charge, energize  vitalize

syn: suggest, hint, intimate, whisper, indicate, convey the impression, give a clue, give an inkling, allude to the fact, make reference to the fact, let it be known, give someone to understand, give someone to believe
etym: From Latin īnsinuō (“to push in, creep in, steal in”), from in (“in”) + sinus (“a winding, bend, bay, fold, bosom”)
en: If you say that someone insinuates that something bad is the case, you mean that they say it in an indirect way.
example: The libel claim followed an article which insinuated that the President was lying
example_ko: [V that] The article insinuated that he was having an affair with his friend’s wife.
syn_v: hint, imply, intimate, suggest

syn: cynic, sceptic, churl, grouch, grump, recluse, hermit, anchorite
etym: From Ancient Greek from μισέω (miséō, “I hate”) and ἄνθρωπος (ánthrōpos, “man; human”); compare miser.
en: A misanthrope is a person who does not like other people.

ko: [법] 법인격 부여, 법인[[미] 회사] 설립; [C] 결사, 법인 단체, 회사(corporation)
zh_Hans: 法人；社团；公司；结合，合并；（国际法）并入说；〈美〉并入理论
etym: From Middle English incorporacioun, from Old French incorporacion, from Late Latin incorporatio
example: the incorporation of Piedmont Airlines and PSA into US Air.
example_ko: Many of your suggestions have been incorporated in the plan.
syn_v: affiliate, assimilate, consolidate, merge, unite, comprise, embody, exemplify, include

zh_Hans: （行动）灵活的，敏捷的；（头脑）机敏的，敏锐的
syn: lithe, sprightly, acrobatic, light-footed, nimble-footed, light, light on one's feet, fleet-footed, spry, lively, active, quick, quick-moving, graceful, supple, limber, lissom, flexible, skilful, deft, dexterous, adroit
etym: From Middle English nymyl, nemel, nemyll, nymell (“agile, quick, ready, able, capable”), merger of Old English nǣmel (“receptive, quick to grasp”) and Old English numol (“able to take, capable of holding”), both from niman (“to take”) + -el, -ol (associative suffix), corresponding to nim +‎ -le. Compare German nehmen, Gothic 𐌽𐌹𐌼𐌰𐌽 (niman), Old Norse nema (“to take”). More at nim.
en: Someone who is nimble is able to move their fingers, hands, or legs quickly and easily.
example: Everything had been stitched by Molly's nimble fingers
example_ko: You need nimble fingers for that job.
syn_a: agile, lively, quick, sprightly, spry, adroit, deft, dexterous, handy

zh_Hans: 控告，连累（某人）受罪，归罪于;连累（某人）；牵连（进某一犯罪或非法行为中）
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：in 使… + culp 错，罪 + ate 使… → 使〔别人〕有罪 → 归罪
syn: implicate, involve
etym: From Late Latin inculpare.
en: to incriminate; cause blame to be imputed to
syn_v: ensnare, frame, implicate, inculpate, involve, accuse, blame, charge, indict

zh_Hans: 新生的，萌芽的；开始发展的
syn: beginning, coming out, arising, dawning
etym: Borrowed from Latin nascēns, nascēntis, present participle of nascor (“I am born”).
en: Nascent things or processes are just beginning, and are expected to become stronger or to grow bigger.
example: Kenya's nascent democracy.
syn_a: beginning, budding, embryonic, emerging, inceptive, incipient

zh_Hans: （尤指政府或组织）正式批准，使正式生效，正式签署
syn: approve, sanction, endorse, agree to, accept, consent to, assent to, affirm, uphold, corroborate, authorize, formalize, certify, validate, recognize
etym: From Old French ratifier, from Medieval Latin ratifico, from Latin ratus (“reckoned”).
en: When national leaders or organizations ratify a treaty or written agreement, they make it official by giving their formal approval to it, usually by signing it or voting for it.
example: The parliaments of Australia and Indonesia have yet to ratify the treaty.
example_ko: The treaty was ratified by all the member states.
syn_v: approve, confirm, endorse, sanction, support, enact, legalize, legislate, pass, authenticate, corroborate, substantiate, validate, verify

syn: ruling, direction, directive, command, instruction, demand
en: An injunction is a court order, usually one telling someone not to do something.
example: He took out a court injunction against the newspaper demanding the return of the document.
example_ko: to seek/obtain an injunction

syn: forefather, forebear, parent
etym: From Middle English, from Middle French progeniteur (Modern French progéniteur), from Latin progenitor, from progenitus, perfect participle of progignere (“to beget”), itself from pro- (“forth”) + gignere (“to beget”).
en: A progenitor of someone is a direct ancestor of theirs.
example: He was also a progenitor of seven presidents of Nicaragua.
example_ko: He was the progenitor of a family of distinguished actors.
syn_n: forebear, forefather, parent, progenitor, forerunner, precursor, predecessor, prototype

syn: racket, noise, discord, dissonance, discordance, caterwauling, raucousness, screeching, jarring, stridency, grating, rasping
etym: From French cacophonie, from Ancient Greek κακοφωνία (kakophōnía), from κακός (kakós, “bad”) + φωνή (phōnḗ, “sound”).
en: You can describe a loud, unpleasant mixture of sounds as a cacophony.
example: All around was bubbling a cacophony of voices.
syn_n: discord, dissonance, stridency

syn: threatening, unfriendly, hostile, antagonistic, evil, evil-intentioned, wicked, nasty, hate-filled, bitter, acrimonious, malevolent, malicious, malignant, malign, sinister, deadly, harmful, injurious, dangerous, noxious, virulent, pernicious, venomous, poisonous, vitriolic, vindictive
etym: From Middle English baleful, balful, baluful, from Old English bealuful, which being equivalent to bealu +‎ -ful. Surface analysis as bale (“evil, woe”) +‎ -ful. See bale for further etymology.
en: Baleful means harmful, or expressing harmful intentions.
example: a baleful look.
example_ko: a baleful look/influence
syn_a: evil, malevolent, malignant, ominous, sinister, threatening

zh_Hans: 难驾驭的；难对付的；难解决的
syn: uncontrollable, ungovernable, out of control, out of hand, impossible to cope with
etym: From in- +‎ tractable
en: Intractable people are very difficult to control or influence.
example: What may be done to reduce the influence of intractable opponents?
syn_a: disobedient, incorrigible, rebellious, uncontrollable, unmanageable, unruly, froward, obdurate, stubborn, uncooperative, uncompromising, unsubmissive, unyielding

syn: inference, insinuation, innuendo, hint, intimation, imputation, indication
etym: From Middle French implication, from Latin implicationem (accusative of implicatio).
en: The implications of something are the things that are likely to happen as a result.
example: The Attorney General was aware of the political implications of his decision to prosecute
example_ko: The development of the site will have implications for the surrounding countryside.
syn_n: connotation, effect, insinuation, ramification, significance, association, connection  involvement

syn: funny, witty, comic, comical, amusing, chucklesome, droll, entertaining, diverting, joking, jesting, hilarious, facetious, tongue-in-cheek
etym: From Latin iocularis, from ioculus (“a little jest”), diminutive of iocus (“a jest”).
en: If you say that someone has a jocular manner, you mean that they are cheerful and often make jokes or try to make people laugh.
example: He was in a less jocular mood than usual
example_ko: a jocular comment
syn_a: comical, droll, humorous, jocular, light, playful, witty

zh_Hans: 效仿，模仿；和…竞争，努力赶上
syn: copy, reproduce, mimic, mirror, echo, follow, model oneself on, take as a model, take as an example
etym: From Latin aemulor (“to rival, emulate”).
en: If you emulate something or someone, you imitate them because you admire them a great deal.
example: Sons are traditionally expected to emulate their fathers.
example_ko: She hopes to emulate her sister’s sporting achievements.
syn_v: copy, follow, imitate, model  pattern

syn: equal, corresponding, correspondent, comparable, proportionate, proportional
etym: From Latin com- (“together, with”) + mēnsūrō.
en: If the level of one thing is commensurate with another, the first level is in proportion to the second.
example: Employees are paid salaries commensurate with those of teachers
example_ko: Salary will be commensurate with experience.

syn: deferential, respectful, submissive, self-effacing, unassertive, unpresuming
etym: From Old French, from Latin humilis (“low, slight, hence mean, humble”) (compare Greek χαμαλός (khamalós, “on the ground, low, trifling”)), from humus (“the earth, ground”), humi (“on the ground”).
en: A humble person is not proud and does not believe that they are better than other people.
example: He gave a great performance, but he was very humble
example_ko: Be humble enough to learn from your mistakes.
syn_v: abase, degrade, demean, disgrace, humiliate, subdue
syn_a: meek, mild, modest, unassuming, unpretentious, obsequious, servile, submissive, common, mean, modest, plain, simple

zh_Hans: 异常的人（或事物）；不规则；（同一种类中的）畸形
syn: peculiarity, abnormality, irregularity, inconsistency, incongruity, deviation, aberration, quirk, freak, exception, departure, divergence, variation
etym: From Latin anomalia, from Ancient Greek ἀνωμαλία (anōmalía, “irregularity, anomaly”), from ἀνώμαλος (anṓmalos, “irregular, uneven”), negating the meaning of ὁμαλός (homalós, “even”), from ὁμός (homós, “same”).
en: If something is an anomaly, it is different from what is usual or expected.
example: The British public's wariness of opera is an anomaly in Europe.
example_ko: the many anomalies in the tax system
syn_n: aberration, deviation, digression, exception  irregularity

etym: Borrowed from Old French cent, from Latin centum, from Proto-Indo-European *ḱm̥tóm.
en: A cent is a small unit of money worth one hundredth of some currencies, for example the dollar and the euro.→ see also per cent
example: A cup of rice which cost thirty cents a few weeks ago is now being sold for up to one dollar
example_ko: in the 20th cent.

syn: allowance, endowment, contribution, donation, bursary, gift, present, investment, bestowal, benefaction, allocation, allotment, handout
etym: Borrowed from Medieval Latin bursaria, from bursarius.
en: A bursary is a sum of money which is given to someone to allow them to study in a college or university.

syn: support, defend, maintain, confirm, ratify, endorse, approve, approve of, agree to, consent to, assent to, sanction
etym: Alteration influenced by Medieval Latin indorsare of Middle English endosse, from Old French endosser (“to put on back”), from Latin dossum, alternative form of dorsum (“back”),[1] from which also dorsal (“of the back”). That is, the ‘r’ was dropped in Latin dossum, which developed into Old French and then Middle English endosse, and then the ‘r’ was re-introduced into English via the Medieval Latin indorsare, which had retained the ‘r’. Note that the alternative spelling indorse also uses the initial ‘i’ from Latin (in-, rather than en-), but this form is now rare.
en: If you endorse someone or something, you say publicly that you support or approve of them.
example: I can endorse their opinion wholeheartedly.
example_ko: I wholeheartedly endorse his remarks.
syn_v: authorize, notarize, sponsor, subscribe, underwrite, approve, back, recommend, sanction, support
