etym: circa 1870: ant- +‎ -onym
en: The antonym of a word is a word which means the opposite.
example_ko: The word 'left' is an auto antonym, meaning 'remaining' or 'departed'.

ko: (갇히거나 구속되어 있는 상태에서) 풀어 주다, 석방[해방]하다
syn: set free, let go, allow to leave, let loose, set loose, turn loose, let out, liberate, set at liberty, deliver, rescue, ransom, emancipate
en: If a person or animal is released from somewhere where they have been locked up or looked after, they are set free or allowed to go.
example: He was released from custody the next day
example_ko: to release a prisoner/hostage
syn_n: emancipation, liberation, circulation, distribution, announcement, item, statement, disclaimer, waiver
syn_v: deliver, free, liberate, rescue, detach, disengage, open, unbind, unfasten, air, circulate, communicate, distribute, present

zh_Hans: 博学的；有学问的；博大精深的
syn: scholarly, well educated, knowledgeable, well read, widely read, well versed, well informed, lettered, cultured, cultivated, civilized, intellectual
etym: From Latin ērudītus, participle of ērudiō (“educate, train”), from e- (“out of”) + rudis (“rude, unskilled”).
en: If you describe someone as erudite, you mean that they have or show great academic knowledge. You can also use erudite to describe something such as a book or a style of writing.
example: He was never dull, always erudite and well informed.
syn_a: educated, intellectual, learned, literate, scholarly, cultured, polished, refined, sophisticated

zh_Hans: 贬低；降低…的身份；侮辱…的人格
syn: demeaned, debased, cheapened, cheap, ashamed, abased
etym: From Middle French dégrader
en: Something that degrades someone causes people to have less respect for them.
example: the notion that pornography degrades women
example_ko: This poster is offensive and degrades women.
syn_v: debase, demean, disgrace, humiliate, lower, shame

zh_Hans: （尤指为了使某人或者某物显得重要而）卖弄词藻的，言辞浮夸的，过分华丽的
syn: bombastic, magniloquent, pretentious, ostentatious, high-flown, high-sounding, rhetorical, orotund, fustian, florid, flowery
etym: From Middle French grandiloquent, from Latin grandiloquus, from grandis (“great, full”) + loquēns, present participle of loquor (“I speak”). Compare eloquent.
en: Grandiloquent language or behaviour is very formal, literary, or exaggerated, and is used by people when they want to seem important.
syn_a: bombastic, grandiose, lofty, pompous, pretentious

syn: wary, careful, chary, guarded, on one's guard
etym: From Latin circumspectō (“look around”).
en: If you are circumspect, you are cautious in what you do and say and do not take risks.
example: The banks should have been more circumspect in their dealings
syn_a: careful, cautious, deliberate, guarded, prudent, vigilant

syn: respected, esteemed, honoured
etym: From Latin venerātus, perfect passive participle of veneror (“worship, reverence”).
en: If you venerate someone or something, you value them or feel great respect for them.
example: My father venerated General Eisenhower.
example_ko: a venerable old man
syn_v: admire, esteem, honor, respect, revere, reverence

zh_Hans: 应受谴责的；该受处罚的；该对错误负责的
syn: guilty, at fault, in the wrong, blameworthy, blameable, censurable, reproachable, reprovable, found wanting
etym: From Middle English culpable, from Old French culpable, from Latin culpabilis (“blameworthy”), from culpare (“to blame, condemn”), from culpa (“fault, crime, mistake”).
en: If someone or their conduct is culpable, they are responsible for something wrong or bad that has happened.
example: Their decision to do nothing makes them culpable.
example_ko: I hold him culpable because he is a player.
syn_a: blameworthy, censurable, culpable, reprehensible, ashamed, contrite, sorrowful, condemned, convicted, damned, judged, sentenced

ko: 말을 많이 하지 않는, 할 말만 하는
syn: concise, terse, succinct, short, economical, elliptical, crisp, pithy, to the point, incisive, short and sweet, compendious
etym: English Wikipedia has an article on:Laconic phraseWikipedia
en: If you describe someone as laconic, you mean that they use very few words to say something, so that they seem casual or unfriendly.
example: Usually so laconic in the office, Dr. Lahey seemed less guarded, more relaxed
syn_a: brief, concise, pithy, succinct, blunt, curt, terse

syn: stubborn as a mule, mulish, headstrong, wilful, strong-willed, self-willed, pig-headed, bull-headed, obdurate, awkward, difficult, contrary, perverse, recalcitrant, refractory
etym: Mid-15th century, from Latin obduratus (“hardened”), form of obdūrō (“harden”), from ob- (“against”) + dūrō (“harden, render hard”), from durus (“hard”).[1] Compare durable, endure.
en: If you describe someone as obdurate, you think that they are being unreasonable in their refusal to change their decision or opinion.
example: Parts of the administration may be changing but others have been obdurate defenders of the status quo.
syn_a: intractable, recalcitrant, stubborn, unyielding, hardhearted, heartless, implacable, unsympathetic

en: Loathing is a feeling of great dislike and disgust.
example: She looked at him with loathing.
example_ko: She looked at her attacker with fear and loathing.
syn_v: abhor, abominate, despise, detest, hate

syn: erotic, amorous, romantic, sensual, libidinous, passionate, ardent, hot-blooded, sexy
etym: From Latin amātōrius (“pertaining to love or a lover”, adjective), from amātor (“a lover”), from amō (“I love”).
en: of, relating to, or inciting sexual love or desire
example_ko: his amatory exploits

etym: Coined in 1883 by Francis Galton.[1] From ἐΰς (eǘs, “good”) +‎ γίγνομαι (gígnomai, “breeding”), “well-bred”, “good in stock”. Parallel to Eugene.
en: Eugenics is the study of methods to improve the human race by carefully selecting parents who will produce the strongest children.

zh_Hans: （尤指被憎恨人的）模拟像，雕像；画像：
syn: statuette, carving, sculpture, graven image, model, dummy, figure, figurine, guy
etym: From French effigie, from Latin effigiēs (“likeness, effigy”), from effingō (“represent, portray”).
en: An effigy is a quickly and roughly made figure, often ugly or amusing, that represents someone you hate or feel contempt for.
example_ko: stone effigies in the church
syn_n: dummy, image, likeness, mannequin  scarecrow

zh_Hans: 巧取豪夺的，贪婪的，掠夺的
syn: greedy, avaricious, acquisitive, covetous, mercenary, materialistic, insatiable, predatory, voracious, usurious, extortionate
etym: Perhaps from rapacity  +‎ -ous, in any case ultimately from Latin rapax (“grasping, greedy”).
en: If you describe a person or their behaviour as rapacious, you disapprove of their greedy or selfish behaviour.
example: a rapacious exploitation policy.
syn_a: bestial, fierce, marauding, pillaging, predatory, savage, acquisitive, greedy, insatiable  ravenous

etym: frank +‎ -ness
example: The reaction to his frankness was hostile.
example_ko: a full and frank discussion
syn_a: candid, direct, explicit, forthright, open, outspoken, straightforward

zh_Hans: 防洪堤（在河边由土等材料筑成的墙，以防止河水溢出）
syn: barrier, wall, embankment, levee, barricade, obstruction, hindrance, blockage
en: an embankment alongside a river, produced naturally by sedimentation or constructed by man to prevent flooding

syn: faked, spurious, false, fraudulent, sham, deceptive, misleading, pretended
etym: Borrowed from Latin factītius (“artificial”), alternative form of factīcius, from facere (“to make, do”). Doublet of fetish.
en: artificial rather than natural
example: factitious demands created by the mass media

syn: spite, malevolence, maliciousness, animosity, hostility, ill will, ill feeling, hatred, hate, bitterness, venom, vindictiveness, vengefulness, revenge, malignity, malignance, evil intentions, animus, enmity, devilment, devilry, bad blood, backbiting, gall, rancour, spleen, grudge
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French malice, from Latin malitia (“badness, bad quality, ill-will, spite”), from malus (“bad”).
en: Malice is behaviour that is intended to harm people or their reputations, or cause them embarrassment and upset.
example: There was a strong current of malice in many of his portraits
example_ko: He sent the letter out of malice.
syn_n: animosity, malevolence, rancor, spite, spleen

zh_Hans: （尤指徒步的）旅行；漫游；旅程；游历
syn: wanderings, journeys, voyages, expeditions, explorations, perambulations, odysseys, trips, treks, excursions
etym: 1520s, either from Old French peregrinacion (“pilgrimage”) [12th c.],[1] or directly from the Latin peregrīnātiō (“journey”), from peregrīnor (“sojourn”).
en: a voyage, esp an extensive one

syn: hind, back, hinder, rearward
etym: From Middle English dorsal, dorsale, from Medieval Latin dorsālis (“of or relating to the back”).
en: Dorsal means relating to the back of a fish or animal.
example: a dolphin's dorsal fin.
example_ko: a shark’s dorsal fin

syn: charm, talisman, fetish, mascot, totem, idol, juju, phylactery
etym: From Middle French amulette, from Latin amuletum.
en: An amulet is a small object that you wear or carry because you think it will bring you good luck and protect you from evil or injury.
syn_n: charm, fetish  talisman

ko: 동형이의어(‘절하다’는 뜻의 bow/baʊ/와 ‘활’이라는 뜻을 갖는 bow/bæʊ/, /boʊ/처럼 철자는 같으나 뜻은 다른 낱말. 발음은 같을 수도 있고 다를 수도 있음)
zh_Hans: 同形异义词（读音可能相同或不同）
etym: From homo- +‎ -graph.
en: one of a group of words spelt in the same way but having different meanings Compare heteronym

zh_Hans: 双手都很灵巧的；左右开弓的
etym: From ambi- +‎ Latin dexter (“right”) + -ous (as if both hands are like the right hand, which is the stronger hand in most people).
en: Someone who is ambidextrous can use both their right hand and their left hand equally skilfully.

zh_Hans: 严厉指责，痛斥（戏剧、书、政治行为等）
syn: rub away, rub off, rub raw, scrape, scratch, chafe, damage
etym: From Late Latin excoriātus, perfect participle of Latin excoriō (“take the skin or hide off, flay”), from ex (“off”) + corium (“hide, skin”).
en: To excoriate a person or organization means to criticize them severely, usually in public.
example: He proceeded to excoriate me in front of the nurses.

zh_Hans: 脾气乖戾的老人，坏脾气的老人
etym: Numerous folk etymologies exist for this word.
en: If you call someone a curmudgeon, you do not like them because they are mean or bad-tempered.
example: such a terrible old curmudgeon.

syn: remorsefulness, repentance, penitence, sorrow, sorrowfulness, regret, contriteness, ruefulness, pangs of conscience, prickings of conscience
etym: Old French contriciun (French contrition), from Latin contritio.
en: deeply felt remorse; penitence
syn_n: guilt, penitence, regret, remorse, repentance  sorrow

syn: overworked, overdone, worn out, time-worn, platitudinous, vapid, stale, tired, threadbare
etym: hackney +‎ -ed
en: If you describe something such as a saying or an image as hackneyed, you think it is no longer likely to interest, amuse or affect people because it has been used, seen, or heard many times before.
example: Power corrupts and absolute power absolutely corrupts. That's the old hackneyed phrase, but it's true.
example_ko: a hackneyed phrase/subject
syn_a: banal, clichdic, corny, overdone, tired, trite

syn: spaceman, spacewoman, space traveller, space pilot, space flyer, space cadet
etym: Borrowed from Russian космона́вт (kosmonávt), from Ancient Greek κόσμος (kósmos, “universe”) + ναύτης (naútēs, “sailor”), may be decomposed as cosmos +‎ -naut
en: A cosmonaut is an astronaut from the former Soviet Union.

zh_Hans: 给人以假像；掩饰（感情等）
syn: be at odds with, call into question, give the lie to, prove to be false, show to be false
en: If one thing belies another, it hides the true situation and so creates a false idea or image of someone or something.
example: Her looks belie her 50 years.
example_ko: Her energy and youthful good looks belie her 65 years.
syn_v: camouflage, disguise, mask, misrepresent, contradict, disprove, negate, repudiate

ko: (영구적인 것이 나올 때까지 존속시키기 위한) 중간[임시/과도]의
syn: meanwhile, intervening time, interval, interlude
etym: From Latin interim (“meanwhile”).
en: Interim is used to describe something that is intended to be used until something permanent is done or established.
example: She was sworn in as head of an interim government in March.
example_ko: an interim government / measure / report
syn_n: break, interval, meantime, recess
syn_a: provisional, substitute, temporary

zh_Hans: 漠不关心的;漫不经心的
syn: untroubled, unworried, unruffled, unconcerned, lacking concern, indifferent, blasé, heedless, relaxed, calm, equable, equanimous, serene, composed, casual, easy, easy-going, airy, breezy, carefree, free and easy, free from care, free from worry, happy-go-lucky, light-hearted, frivolous, unserious
etym: From French insouciant, from in- (“not”, prefix) + souciant (“worrying”), 1828.[1]
en: An insouciant action or quality shows someone's lack of concern about something which they might be expected to take more seriously.
example: Programme-makers seem irresponsibly insouciant about churning out violence.
example_ko: She hid her worries behind an air of insouciance.

syn: inconstant, changeable, variable, unstable, mercurial, volatile, erratic, vacillating, irregular, inconsistent, fitful, arbitrary
etym: Borrowed from French capricieux, from Italian capriccioso, from capriccio.
en: Someone who is capricious often changes their mind unexpectedly.
example: The Union accused Walesa of being capricious and undemocratic.
syn_a: eccentric, erratic, fickle, flighty, impulsive, whimsical

syn: forsaken, cast aside, cast off, thrown over, betrayed, jilted
etym: First attested 14th century[1]. From Latin dēsertum, possibly a semi-learned term.
en: A desert is a large area of land, usually in a hot region, where there is almost no water, rain, trees, or plants.
example: the Sahara Desert.
example_ko: the Sahara Desert
syn_n: dunes, sand, wasteland, wilderness
syn_v: defect, depart, escape, abandon, forsake, leave
syn_a: arid, barren, desolate, infertile

ko: (어떤 책 등에서 그 속에 사용된 어휘들을 알파벳순으로 정리한) 용어 색인
zh_Hans: （书籍或作品中按字母顺序排列的）词语索引
syn: consistency, compatibility, conformity, coincidence, harmony, concord, accord, accordance, congruity
etym: From Old French concordance, from Late Latin concordantia.
en: If there is concordance between two things, they are similar to each other or consistent with each other.
example: a partial concordance between theoretical expectations and empirical evidence.
example_ko: a Bible concordance
syn_n: friendship, goodwill, harmony, peace, accord, agreement, treaty

syn: eradicate, expunge, blot out, rub out, wipe out, remove, eliminate, excise
etym: From Middle French effacer (“erase”), from Old French esfacier (“remove the face”).
en: To efface something means to destroy or remove it so that it cannot be seen any more.→ see also self-effacing
example: an event that has helped efface the country's traditional image
example_ko: He wants to efface himself.
syn_v: annul, cancel, delete, erase, destroy, eliminate, obliterate, terminate

ko: 빙빙 돌다, 선회하다; (특히 신체 일부를) 빙빙 돌리다
zh_Hans: （通常指很快地）旋转，回旋，转动
syn: revolve, move in circles, go round in circles, circle, spiral, wheel round, turn round, whirl, pirouette, twirl, swirl, spin, swivel
etym: from Ancient Greek γυρός (gurós, “round, curved”) through Latin into Middle English to English
en: If you gyrate, you dance or move your body quickly with circular movements.
example: The woman began to gyrate to the music.
example_ko: [V] They began gyrating to the music.
syn_v: revolve, rotate, spin, twirl  whirl

syn: encourage, try to persuade, adjure, admonish, press, prompt, prod, goad, egg on, spur, push, pressure, put pressure on, use pressure on, pressurize, lean on
etym: From Middle English enjoinen, from Old French enjoindre (“to join with”), from Latin iniungo (“to attach”), a compound of in- (“into” “upon”) and iungo.
en: If you enjoin someone to do something, you order them to do it. If you enjoin an action or attitude, you order people to do it or have it.
example: She enjoined me strictly not to tell anyone else
syn_v: advise, command, counsel, direct, urge, warn, ban, forbid, hinder, prohibit

syn: shock, surprise, consternation, concern, perturbation, disquiet, disquietude, discomposure, distress, upset, anxiety, trepidation, fear
etym: From Middle English dismayen, from Anglo-Norman *desmaiier, alteration of Old French esmaier (“to frighten”), probably from Vulgar Latin *exmagare (“to deprive (someone) of strength, to disable”), from ex- + *magare (“to enable, empower”), from Proto-Germanic *maginą, *maganą (“might, power”), from Proto-Indo-European *megʰ- (“to be able”). Akin to Old High German magan, megin (“power, might, main”), Old English mæġen (“might, main”), Old High German magan, mugan (“to be powerful, able”), Old English magan (“to be able”). Cognate with Portuguese desmaiar (“to faint”). See also Portuguese esmagar, Spanish amagar. More at main, may.
en: Dismay is a strong feeling of fear, worry, or sadness that is caused by something unpleasant and unexpected.
example: Local councillors have reacted with dismay and indignation
example_ko: She could not hide her dismay at the result.
syn_n: alarm, anxiety, apprehension, dread, trepidation, disappointment, discouragement, disillusionment
syn_v: discourage, dishearten, dispirit, frighten, intimidate, terrify, unnerve, shock, stun, surprise

zh_Hans: （有利的事）偶然发生的，碰巧的
syn: unexpected, unanticipated, unpredictable, unforeseen, unlooked-for, serendipitous, casual, incidental, coincidental, haphazard, random, accidental, inadvertent, unintentional, unintended, unplanned, unpremeditated
etym: From Latin fortuītus.
en: You can describe something as fortuitous if it happens, by chance, to be very successful or pleasant.
example: Their success is the result of a fortuitous combination of circumstances.
syn_a: fortunate, happy, lucky, serendipitous, accidental, casual, chance, haphazard, random

syn: everyday, day-to-day, quotidian
etym: From Anglo-Norman cotidian, cotidien, Middle French cotidian, cotidien, and their source, Latin cottīdiānus, quōtīdiānus (“happening every day”), from adverb cottīdiē, quōtīdiē (“every day, daily”), from an unattested adjective derived from quot (“how many”) + locative form of diēs (“day”).
en: Quotidian activities or experiences are basic, everyday activities or experiences.
example: the minutiae of their quotidian existence.

syn: innate, inborn, inbred, congenital, natural, native, constitutional, built-in, ingrained, deep-rooted, inseparable, permanent, indelible, ineradicable, ineffaceable
etym: From Middle French intrinsèque, from Latin intrīnsecus (“on the inside, inwardly”), from *intrim, an assumed adverbial form of inter (“within”) + secus (“by, on the side”).
en: If something has intrinsic value or intrinsic interest, it is valuable or interesting because of its basic nature or character, and not because of its connection with other things.
example: The paintings have no intrinsic value except as curiosities
example_ko: the intrinsic value of education
syn_a: inborn, indigenous, inherent, innate, natural, actual, authentic, genuine, real  true

syn: aperient, lenitive, cathartic, evacuant, purging
etym: From Middle French laxatif, from Latin laxatus
en: A laxative is food or medicine that you take to make you go to the toilet.
example: Foods that ferment quickly in the stomach are excellent natural laxatives.

zh_Hans: 极不寻常的；只有少数人（尤指内行）才懂的；限于小圈子的
syn: obscure, arcane, recherché, rarefied, recondite, abstract, difficult, hard, puzzling, perplexing, enigmatic, inscrutable, cryptic, Delphic
etym: From Ancient Greek ἐσωτερικός (esōterikós, “belonging to an inner circle”), from ἐσωτέρω (esōtérō, “further inside”), comparative of ἔσω (ésō, “within”), from ἐς (es), εἰς (eis, “into”) (esoteric originally referred to the secret teachings of Greek philosophers, versus public or exoteric ones).
en: If you describe something as esoteric, you mean it is known, understood, or appreciated by only a small number of people.
example: esoteric knowledge.
syn_a: confidential, inside, obscure, personal, private, privileged, secret

etym: From Ancient Greek μελαγχολικός (melankholikós, “atrabilious, impulsive, of atrabilious or melancholic temperament”), from μελαγχολία (melankholía, “melancholy”).
en: If you describe someone or something as melancholic, you mean that they are very sad.
example: his gentle, melancholic songs.
example_ko: A mood of melancholy descended on us.

zh_Hans: 向（院校、医院等）捐款，捐赠，资助
syn: pass down
etym: From Late Middle English endowen, endouen, enduen, indouen, indw (“to provide with assets, a livelihood, or privileges; to bestow, grant; (figuratively) to favour; to endow”),[1] from Anglo-Norman endouer, from Old French en- (prefix meaning ‘in, into’) + douer (“to endow”) (from Latin dōtāre, present active infinitive of dōtō (“to endow”), from dōs (“dowry; endowment, gift”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *deh₃- (“to give”)) + -ō (suffix forming regular first-conjugation verbs); modern French douer).[2]
en: You say that someone is endowed with a particular desirable ability, characteristic, or possession when they have it by chance or by birth.
example: You are endowed with wealth, good health and a lively intellect.
example_ko: She had endowed Marcus with the qualities she wanted him to possess.
syn_v: bequeath, bestow, confer, grant, accord, equip, provide, supply

zh_Hans: （尤指没有犯罪时间的）不在犯罪现场的证据
syn: defending evidence, plea
etym: Borrowed from Latin alibī (“elsewhere, at another place”, adverb).
en: If you have an alibi, you can prove that you were somewhere else when a crime was committed.
example_ko: The suspects all had alibis for the day of the robbery.
syn_n: defense, excuse, explanation, reason, story  vindication

zh_Hans: 使正式就任；正式吸收…为会员；使入门；传授
syn: allow into, introduce to, initiate into, install in, instate in, swear into
etym: Originated 1350–1400 from Middle English induct, borrowed from Latin inductus, perfect passive participle of indūcō, equivalent to induce + -tus (past participle suffix).
en: If someone is inducted into a particular job, rank, or position, they are given the job, rank, or position in a formal ceremony.
example: Six new members have been inducted into the Provincial Cabinet
syn_v: admit, enroll, initiate, receive, conscript, draft, enlist, levy, appoint, frock, inaugurate, install

syn: commiseration, commiserations, solace, comfort, consolation, fellow feeling, understanding, empathy, compassion, pity, solicitude, concern, support
etym: condole +‎ -ence, or from Middle French condoléance, or formed from the root of Latin condoleo (“to sympathize”), from con- (“together, with”) and doleo (“hurt, suffer, have pain”).
en: A message of condolence is a message in which you express your sympathy for someone because one of their friends or relatives has died recently.
example: Neil sent him a letter of condolence.
example_ko: to give/offer/express your condolences
syn_n: comfort, compassion, consolation, pity, support, sympathy

syn: censure, condemn, attack, inveigh against, rail against, lambaste, flay, savage, brand, stigmatize, denounce
etym: From Middle English revilen, from re + Old French aviler (“to make vile or cheap, disprize, disesteem”), from a- (“to”) + vil (“vile, cheap”); see vile.
en: If someone or something is reviled, people hate them intensely or show their hatred of them.
example: He was just as feared and reviled as his tyrannical parents
syn_v: berate, castigate, criticize, reprove, scold, upbraid

syn: crevice, crack, cleft, cranny, chink, slit, groove, gap, hole, breach, aperture, vent, interstice
etym: Borrowed from Old French fissure, Latin fissura.
en: A fissure is a deep crack in something, especially in rock or in the ground.

syn: hole, aperture, crack, slot, slit, cleft, cranny, chink, gap, space, vent, breach, break, rent, fissure, mouth, crevice, rift, perforation, pore
etym: From Middle French, from Old French, from Late Latin orificium (“an opening, literally the making of a mouth”), compound of os (“mouth”) + facio (“to make”).
en: An orifice is an opening or hole, especially one in your body such as your mouth.
example: After a massive heart attack, he was strapped to a bed, with tubes in every orifice.
example_ko: the nasal orifice

zh_Hans: 才开始的；不完全的；未发展完善的
syn: undeveloped, unformed, immature, incomplete, incipient, inchoate, just beginning
etym: From Latin incohātus (“begun, unfinished”), perfect passive participle of incohō (“begin”). Cognate with Spanish incoar (“to initiate, commence, begin”).
en: If something is inchoate, it is recent or new, and vague or not yet properly developed.
example: His dreams were senseless and inchoate.
example_ko: inchoate ideas

syn: rich, sonorous, deep, full-bodied, vibrant, fruity, clear, loud, strong
etym: Borrowed from Latin sonorus, from sonor (“sound”).
en: A sonorous sound is deep and rich.
example: Doctor McKee?' the man called in an even, sonorous voice.
example_ko: a sonorous voice
syn_a: deep, full, resonant, resounding, reverberating, vibrant

syn: bad, morally wrong, wrongful, wicked, evil, unprincipled, unscrupulous, dishonourable, dishonest, unconscionable, iniquitous, disreputable, fraudulent, corrupt, depraved, vile, villainous, nefarious, base, unfair, underhand, devious
etym: From im- +‎ moral.
en: If you describe someone or their behaviour as immoral, you believe that their behaviour is morally wrong.
example: those who think that birth control and abortion are immoral.
example_ko: It’s immoral to steal.
syn_a: dissolute, evil, iniquitous, profane, sinful, wicked, corrupt, unethical, unprincipled, unscrupulous, base, debauched, decadent, degenerate, depraved

ko: (방향·위치·상황의) 변동, 오르내림; 파동; (사람·마음의) 동요; [pl.] 성쇠, 흥망(ups and downs)
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：fluctu 波浪 + ation 状态 → 波动，起伏
syn: shift, change, alteration, swing, movement, oscillation, undulation, alternation, rise and fall, rising and falling, see-sawing, yo-yoing, instability, unsteadiness
etym: Borrowed from Latin fluctuatiōnem, accusative singular of fluctuatiō, from fluctuō, from fluctus.
example: Don't worry about tiny fluctuations in your weight
syn_v: alternate, change, oscillate, shift, sway, vacillate, waver

zh_Hans: （电影、书籍等的）概要，梗概，提要
syn: precis, résumé, abstract, outline, condensation, digest, summarization, summing-up, rundown, round-up, abridgement, review, sketch, compendium
etym: From Late Latin synopsis, itself from Ancient Greek σύνοψις (súnopsis), from σύν (sún, “with or whole”) + ὄψις (ópsis, “view”) meaning whole view
en: A synopsis is a summary of a longer piece of writing or work.
example: For each title there is a brief synopsis of the book.
syn_n: abstract, outline, review, sketch  summary

zh_Hans: 背信弃义（行为）；不忠贞（行为）
syn: duplicity, deceit, perfidiousness, deceitfulness, disloyalty, infidelity, faithlessness, unfaithfulness, betrayal, treason, falseness, falsity, double-dealing, dishonesty, two-facedness, untrustworthiness, breach of trust
etym: From Middle French perfidie, from Latin perfidus (“faithless, treacherous, false”), from fides (“faith”); related to, for example, English fidelity.
en: Perfidy is the action of betraying someone or behaving very badly towards someone.

zh_Hans: 不复存在的；死亡的；失灵的
syn: no longer in use, unused, inoperative, non-functioning, unusable, obsolete
etym: From Old French defunct (French défunt), from Latin dēfunctus, past participle of dēfungor (“to finish, discharge”).
en: If something is defunct, it no longer exists or has stopped functioning or operating.
example: the leader of the now defunct Social Democratic Party
syn_a: dead, extinguished, finished, perished, bygone, defunct, lost, vanished, archaic, obsolete, outmoded, pass)

syn: just
etym: From French équitable, from Old French, from equité (“equity”).
en: Something that is equitable is fair and reasonable in a way that gives equal treatment to everyone.
example: He has urged them to come to an equitable compromise that gives Hughes his proper due
syn_a: evenhanded, fair, impartial, just, objective

syn: diversified, wide, broad, broad-based, eclectic, indiscriminate
etym: From Old French catholique, from Latin catholicus, from Ancient Greek καθολικός (katholikós), from κατά (katá, “according to”) + ὅλος (hólos, “whole”)
en: The Catholic Church is the branch of the Christian Church that accepts the Pope as its leader and is based in the Vatican in Rome.→ see also Anglo-Catholic
example: the Catholic Church.
example_ko: Are they Catholic or Protestant?

syn: upbraid, berate, reprimand, reprove, rebuke, admonish, chide, censure, castigate, lambaste, lecture, criticize, pull up, take to task, haul over the coals, bring to book
etym: From Old French chastier, from Latin castigo. See also the doublets chasten and castigate and cf. also chaste.
en: If you chastise someone, you speak to them angrily or punish them for something wrong that they have done.
example: Thomas Rane chastised Peters for his cruelty
example_ko: He chastised the team for their lack of commitment.
syn_v: admonish, castigate, chide, rebuke, reprimand, reproach

zh_Hans: 失败的；夭折的；无结果的
syn: unsuccessful, non-successful, vain, thwarted, futile, useless, worthless, ineffective, ineffectual, to no effect, inefficacious, fruitless, unproductive, unavailing, to no avail, sterile, nugatory
etym: First attested in 1382, with the meaning "causing stillbirth or miscarriage". From Middle English, from Old French abortif,[1] from Latin abortīvus (“causing abortion”), from aborior (“miscarry, disappear”), from ab (“amiss”) + orīor (“appear, be born, arise”)[2].
en: An abortive attempt or action is unsuccessful.
example: an abortive attempt to prevent the current President from taking office.
example_ko: an abortive military coup
syn_a: futile, unavailing, unsuccessful, useless, vain, worthless

zh_Hans: 驳斥；反驳；否认…的正确性（或真实性）
syn: prove false, prove wrong, prove to be false, prove to be wrong, show to be false, show to be wrong, rebut, confute, give the lie to, demolish, explode, debunk, drive a coach and horses through, discredit, invalidate
etym: From Latin refūtō
en: If you refute an argument, accusation, or theory, you prove that it is wrong or untrue.
example: It was the kind of rumour that it is impossible to refute.
example_ko: to refute an argument/a theory, etc.
syn_v: contradict, discredit, disprove, rebut

syn: lily-livered, chicken-hearted, pigeon-hearted, spiritless, spineless, craven
etym: Derived from Latin pusillanimis (“faint-hearted, timid”).
en: If you say that someone is pusillanimous, you mean that they are timid or afraid.
example: The authorities have been too pusillanimous in merely condemning the violence.
syn_a: craven, dastardly, fainthearted, gutless, pusillanimous, spineless, timid

syn: fast, swiftly, rapidly, speedily, briskly, without delay, post-haste, expeditiously, at full speed, at full tilt
etym: From Middle English apās (“step by step, slowly; quickly, rapidly; at once, promptly”), from Old French à pas (“at a quick pace”).[1]
en: If something develops or continues apace, it is developing or continuing quickly.
example_ko: to continue/grow/proceed/develop apace

syn: unprejudiced, neutral, non-partisan, non-discriminatory, anti-discrimination, disinterested, uninvolved, uncommitted, detached, dispassionate, objective, open-minded, equitable, even-handed, fair, fair-minded, just
etym: Borrowed from Middle French impartial. See im- +‎ partial.
en: Someone who is impartial is not directly involved in a particular situation, and is therefore able to give a fair opinion or decision about it.
example: Careers officers offer impartial advice to all pupils.
example_ko: an impartial inquiry/observer
syn_a: disinterested, dispassionate, neutral, objective, unbiased, unprejudiced

zh_Hans: 保证，担保；断言，公开承认，主张
syn: maintain, state, aver, affirm, contend, argue, insist, hold, profess, move, claim, allege, avow, vow, swear, attest, testify, certify
etym: Borrowed from Old French avouchier, from Latin advocāre, present active infinitive of advocō. Doublet of advocate, advoke, and avow.
en: to vouch for; guarantee
example_ko: I avouch myself as a player.
syn_v: affirm, attest, aver, avouch, avow, declare, profess, allege, claim, maintain, advance, argue, contend, insist, propound, accuse, charge, impugn, impute

zh_Hans: （常指为达成行动决议而）商讨，商议，协商
syn: present to, present with, grant to, award to, decorate with, honour with, give to, give out to, gift with, endow with, vest in, hand out to, extend to, vouchsafe to, accord to
etym: From Early Modern English conferre, from Middle French conférer, from Old French conferer, from Latin cōnferō. Compare Dutch confereren (“to confer”), German konferieren (“to confer”), Danish konferere (“to confer”), Swedish konferera (“to confer”).
en: When you confer with someone, you discuss something with them in order to make a decision. You can also say that two people confer.
example: He conferred with Hill and the others in his office
example_ko: He wanted to confer with his colleagues before reaching a decision.
syn_v: accord, award, bestow, give, grant, consult, converse, deliberate, parley

zh_Hans: 使认识；使了解；使熟悉；使知悉
syn: make familiar, make conversant, get up to date, keep up to date
etym: From Middle English aqueinten, acointen, from Old French acointier, from Late Latin accognitāre, from Latin ad + cognitus, past participle of cognoscere (“to know”), from con- + noscere (“to know”). See quaint, know.
en: If you acquaint someone with something, you tell them about it so that they know it. If you acquaint yourself with something, you learn about it.→ see also acquainted
example: efforts to acquaint the public with their rights under the new law
example_ko: Please acquaint me with the facts of the case.
syn_v: accustom, familiarize, introduce, present, apprise, inform  tell

syn: guilty, culpable, misbehaving, delinquent, lawless, lawbreaking, criminal, transgressing, aberrant, deviant, errant, sinning
etym: From Middle English erren, from Old French errer (“to wander, err, mistake”), from Latin errō (“wander, stray, err, mistake”, verb), from Proto-Indo-European *ares- (“to be angry, lose one's temper”). Cognate with Old English eorre, ierre (“anger, wrath, ire”), Old English iersian (“to be angry with, rage, irritate, provoke”), Old English ierre (“wandering, gone astray, confused”)
en: If you err, you make a mistake.
example: It criticises the main contractor for seriously erring in its original estimates
example_ko: To err is human…
syn_n: assignment, charge, commission, mission, task  trust

zh_Hans: 长期存在的；常年的；不断发生的；反覆的
syn: perpetual, eternal, continuing, unending, never-ending, endless, undying, ceaseless, abiding, enduring, lasting, persisting, permanent, constant, continual, unfailing, unchanging, never-changing
etym: 1644, from Latin perennis (“lasting through the whole year”), from per- (“through”) + annus (“year”) + -al; surface analysis per- +‎ -ennial.
en: You use perennial to describe situations or states that keep occurring or which seem to exist all the time; used especially to describe problems or difficulties.
example: the perennial urban problems of drugs and homelessness
example_ko: the perennial problem of water shortage
syn_n: ceaseless, constant, continual, perpetual, enduring, fixed, immutable, permanent, undying

zh_Hans: 滑稽可笑的，古怪离奇的
syn: humorous, amusing, comic, comical, mirthful, chucklesome, hilarious, rollicking
etym: From French drôle (“comical, odd, funny”), from drôle (“buffoon”) from Middle French drolle (“a merry fellow, pleasant rascal”) from Old French drolle (“one who lives luxuriously”), from Middle Dutch drol (“fat little man, goblin”) from Old Norse troll (“giant, troll”) (compare Middle High German trolle (“clown”)), from Proto-Germanic *truzlą (“creature which walks clumsily”), from *truzlaną (“to walk with short steps”). See further at troll.
en: Something or someone that is droll is amusing or witty, sometimes in an unexpected way.
example: The band have a droll sense of humour.
syn_a: amusing, entertaining, hilarious, humorous, absurd, comical, laughable, ludicrous, whimsical, bizarre, curious, odd, strange, unusual

syn: eloquence, power of speech, command of language, expression, way with words, delivery, diction
etym: Borrowed from Old French rhetorique, from Latin rhētorica, from Ancient Greek ῥητορική (rhētorikḗ), ellipsis of ῥητορικὴ τέχνη (rhētorikḕ tékhnē), from ῥητορικός (rhētorikós, “concerning public speech”), from ῥήτωρ (rhḗtōr, “public speaker”).
en: If you refer to speech or writing as rhetoric, you disapprove of it because it is intended to convince and impress people but may not be sincere or honest.
example: What is required is immediate action, not rhetoric
example_ko: the rhetoric of political slogans
syn_n: discourse, elocution, oratory, utterance, bombast, verbosity  bravado

zh_Hans: 使衰弱；使无力；使丧失活力
syn: tire, fatigue, weary, wear out, devitalize, drain, sap, weaken, make weak, make feeble, enfeeble, debilitate, incapacitate, indispose, prostrate, immobilize, lay low, put out of action
etym: From Latin ēnervātus, past participle of ēnervō (“to weaken”).
en: to deprive of strength or vitality; weaken physically or mentally; debilitate
example_ko: an enervating disease/climate
syn_v: debilitate, devitalize, exhaust, fatigue, tire, weaken, cripple, disable, impair, paralyze

syn: massacre, mass murder, mass destruction, butchery, bloodbath, indiscriminate bloodshed, bloodletting, annihilation, destruction, decimation, havoc
etym: Borrowed from Middle French carnage [1], from a Norman or Picard variant Old Northern French) of Old French charnage, from char (“flesh”), or from Vulgar Latin *carnaticum (“slaughter of animals”), itself from Latin carnem, accusative of caro (“flesh”).
en: Carnage is the violent killing of large numbers of people, especially in a war.
example: his strategy for stopping the carnage in Kosovo.
example_ko: a scene of carnage
syn_n: bloodshed, butchery, killing  slaughter

zh_Hans: 自明之理，不言而喻的话
syn: commonplace, cliché, banal saying, hackneyed saying, overworked saying, trite saying, stock phrase, banality, old chestnut, bromide
etym: true +‎ -ism
en: A truism is a statement that is generally accepted as obviously true and is repeated so often that it has become boring.
example: Orpington seems an example of the truism that nothing succeeds like success
syn_n: axiom, fact, verity, adage, aphorism, maxim  saying

syn: adjourn, interrupt, break off, postpone, delay, defer, shelve, arrest, put off, intermit, prorogue, hold over, put aside, pigeonhole
etym: First attested in 1528. From Anglo-Norman abeiance (“legal expectation”), from Old French abeance (“desire”) from abeër (“to gape at, aspire after”), abaer, abair (“to desire”), from a (“to”) + baër (“to gape”),[1] bair (“yawn”), from Medieval Latin batō (“to yawn”)[2][3].
en: If something is in abeyance, it is not operating or being used at the present time.
example: The Russian threat is, at the least, in abeyance
syn_n: adjournment, delay, intermission, postponement, suspension

syn: evaluation, estimation, judgement, rating, gauging, sizing up, summing-up, consideration
etym: From appraise +‎ -al.
en: If you make an appraisal of something, you consider it carefully and form an opinion about it.
example: What is needed in such cases is a calm appraisal of the situation
example_ko: He had read many detailed critical appraisals of her work.
syn_n: assessment, estimate, evaluation  judgment

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：dubious 怀疑的 + ety 性质，状态 → 怀疑
syn: lack of certainty, unsureness, indecision, hesitation, hesitancy, dubiousness, suspicion, confusion
en: the state of being doubtful

syn: quick-tempered, short-tempered, bad-tempered, ill-tempered, hot-tempered, thin-skinned, snappy, snappish, tetchy, testy, touchy, edgy, crabby, waspish, dyspeptic
etym: From French irascible, from Late Latin īrāscibilis.
en: If you describe someone as irascible, you mean that they become angry very easily.
example: He had an irascible temper.
syn_a: cantankerous, choleric, irritable, ornery, testy, touchy

syn: sneak, slink, slip, slide, skulk, prowl, steal, edge, inch, ease, worm, nose, move furtively, move with stealth, tread warily
etym: The verb is from side +‎ -le (frequentative suffix), possibly a back-formation from sideling (“in a sidelong direction; askew, obliquely”, adverb), treating that word as the present participle of sidle.[1]
en: If you sidle somewhere, you walk there in a quiet or cautious way, as if you do not want anyone to notice you.
example: A young man sidled up to me and said, 'May I help you?'
example_ko: She sidled up to me and whispered something in my ear.

syn: sickness, ailment, disorder, complaint, disease, infection, indisposition, affliction, infirmity
etym: From Middle English maladie, from Old French maladie (“sickness, illness, disease”), from malade (“ill, sick”), from Latin male habitus (“ill-kept, not in good condition”), 1st century AD. See also malice and habit.
en: A malady is an illness or disease.
example: He was stricken at twenty-one with a crippling malady.
example_ko: Violent crime is only one of the maladies afflicting modern society.
syn_n: affliction, ailment, disease, disorder, illness  sickness

syn: gather, collect, come together, flock together, get together, convene, rally, rendezvous, muster, meet, amass, crowd, cluster, throng, group
etym: From Latin congregatus, past participle of congregare (“to congregate”), from con- (“with, together”) + gregare (“to collect into a flock”), from grex (“flock, herd”). See gregarious.
en: When people congregate, they gather together and form a group.
example: Visitors congregated on Sunday afternoons to view public exhibitions.
example_ko: Young people often congregate in the main square in the evenings.
syn_v: amass, assemble, collect, flock, gather, throng

syn: give in, yield, admit defeat, concede defeat, give up the struggle, submit, back down, climb down, give way, cave in, succumb, crumble, bow to someone, bow to something
etym: From the participle stem of Medieval Latin capitulare (“draw up under headings”), from Latin capitulum (“heading, chapter, title”), diminutive of caput (“head”).
en: If you capitulate, you stop resisting and do what someone else wants you to do.
example: The club eventually capitulated and now grants equal rights to women
example_ko: They were finally forced to capitulate to the terrorists’ demands.
syn_n: crop, output, production, dividend, interest, return, revenue
syn_v: accede, acquiesce, capitulate, relent, succumb, abdicate, relinquish, resign, surrender, bear, produce, earn, generate, pay, return

zh_Hans: 扩大…的权势；提高…的地位
syn: magnified, aggrandized, unwarranted, immoderate, pumped up, overblown, overripe, overstated, overplayed
etym: From French agrandir.
en: To aggrandize someone means to make them seem richer, more powerful, and more important than they really are. To aggrandize a building means to make it more impressive.
example: At the dinner table, my father would go on and on, showing off, aggrandising himself
syn_v: amplify, augment, enlarge, expand, increase, dignify, distinguish, exalt, glorify, magnify

syn: distinct, individual, detached, unattached, disconnected, discontinuous, disjunct, disjoined
etym: From Old French discret, from Latin discrētus, past participle of discernō (“divide”), from dis- + cernō (“sift”). Doublet of discreet.
en: Discrete ideas or things are separate and distinct from each other.
example: instruction manuals that break down jobs into scores of discrete steps.
example_ko: The organisms can be divided into discrete categories.
syn_a: different, disjunctive, distinct, independent, separate

etym: From Middle English apocalips, from Latin apocalypsis, from Ancient Greek ἀποκάλυψις (apokálupsis, “revelation”), literally meaning "uncovering", from ἀπό (apó, “after”) and καλύπτω (kalúptō, “I cover”).
en: The apocalypse is the total destruction and end of the world.
example_ko: Civilization is on the brink of apocalypse.
syn_n: Armageddon, catastrophe, destruction, holocaust, prophecy, revelation  vision

syn: break, interval, interruption, suspension, intermission, interlude, gap, lacuna, lull, rest, respite, breathing space, time out
etym: Borrowed from Latin hiātus (“opening”) (mid-16th century), from hiō (“stand open, yawn”).
en: A hiatus is a pause in which nothing happens, or a gap where something is missing.
example: Diplomatic efforts to reach a settlement resume today after a two-week hiatus
syn_n: break, gap, interruption, lacuna, lapse  pause

etym: holo- +‎ -gram, from Ancient Greek ὅλος (hólos, “whole”) + γραμμή (grammḗ, “letter, line”), coined in 1948 by Hungarian-born British scientist Dennis Gabor, the 1971 Nobel prize winner in physics for his work in holography.
en: A hologram is a three-dimensional photographic image created by laser beams.

zh_Hans: 乏力的;衰弱的;无精打采的
en: If you feel enervated, you feel tired and weak.
example_ko: an enervating disease/climate

syn: hinder, hamper, hold back, discourage, interfere with, obstruct, put a brake on, slow, slow down, retard
etym: From Latin inhibitus, perfect passive participle of inhibeō (“I hold in, check, restrain”), from in (“in, at, on”), + habeō (“I have, hold, keep”).
en: If something inhibits an event or process, it prevents it or slows it down.
example: The high cost of borrowing is inhibiting investment by industry in new equipment.
example_ko: A lack of oxygen may inhibit brain development in the unborn child.
syn_v: bridle, constrain, curb, obstruct, restrain, restrict, suppress

syn: project, plan of action, programme, strategy, stratagem, game plan
etym: From Medieval Latin schēma (“figure, form”), from Ancient Greek σχῆμα (skhêma, “form, shape”), from ἔχω (ékhō, “I hold”). Doublet of schema. Compare sketch.
en: A scheme is a plan or arrangement involving many people which is made by a government or other organization.in AM, use program
example: schemes to help combat unemployment.
example_ko: a training scheme
syn_n: design, method, plan, procedure, program, strategy, chart, diagram, layout, outline, conspiracy, intrigue, plot, stratagem
syn_v: connive, conspire, contrive, devise  machinate

zh_Hans: 似是而非的；貌似有理的；虚假的
syn: seemingly correct, misleading, deceptive, false, fallacious, unsound, casuistic, sophistic
etym: From Latin speciōsus (“good-looking”).
en: Something that is specious seems to exist or be true, but is not real or true.
example: It is unlikely that the Duke was convinced by such specious arguments.
example_ko: a specious argument

syn: fore, foremost part, anterior, forefront, nose, head
etym: From Latin anterior, comparative of ante (“forward, before”)
en: Anterior describes a part of the body that is situated at or towards the front of another part.
example: the left anterior descending artery.
syn_a: forward, front, antecedent, foregoing, preliminary, previous

syn: report, story, whisper, canard
etym: Borrowed from French canard (“duck, hoax”).
en: A canard is an idea or a piece of information that is false, especially one that is spread deliberately in order to harm someone or their work.
example: The charge that Harding was a political stooge may be a canard.

syn: wreck, destroy, upset, undo, mess up, make a mess of, dash, sabotage, scupper, scotch, torpedo, blast, vitiate
etym: From vitiātus[1], the perfect passive participle of Latin vitiō (“damage, spoil”), from vitium (“vice”).
en: If something is vitiated, its effectiveness is spoiled or weakened.
example: Strategic policy during the War was vitiated because of a sharp division between 'easterners' and 'westerners'

syn: bring to an end, come to an end, conclude, finish, terminate, wind up, break off, halt, call a halt to, discontinue, dissolve
etym: From Old French ajorner (French ajourner), from the phrase a jor (nomé) ("to an (appointed) day").
en: If a meeting or trial is adjourned or if it adjourns, it is stopped for a short time.
example: The proceedings have now been adjourned until next week
example_ko: The court adjourned for lunch.
syn_v: dismiss, dissolve, recess, suspend, move, repair, retire, withdraw

syn: better, ameliorate, upgrade, refine, enhance, boost, build on, help, raise, revamp, brush up, polish up, perk up, tweak
etym: Influenced by French améliorer and Latin a- (“to”) + melior (“better”).
en: If someone or something ameliorates a situation, they make it better or easier in some way.
example_ko: Steps have been taken to ameliorate the situation.
syn_v: better, help, improve, alleviate, ease, relieve

syn: safe, non-dangerous, non-poisonous, non-toxic, non-irritant, non-injurious, innocent
etym: From Latin innocuus (“harmless”).
en: Something that is innocuous is not at all harmful or offensive.
example: Both mushrooms look innocuous but are in fact deadly
example_ko: It seemed a perfectly innocuous remark.
syn_a: harmless, innocent, inoffensive, dull, insipid, meaningless, monotonous

syn: carefreeness, light-mindedness, high spirits, vivacity, liveliness, conviviality, cheerfulness, cheeriness, humour, gaiety, fun, jocularity, hilarity, frivolity, frivolousness, amusement, mirth, laughter, merriment, glee, comedy, funniness, wit, wittiness, jollity, joviality, joking, drollery, good cheer, sportiveness, nonsense, irreverence, facetiousness, flippancy, blitheness, triviality, silliness, foolishness, childishness, giddiness, skittishness
etym: Coined in 1564, from Latin levitās (“lightness, frivolity”), from levis (“lightness (in weight)”).[1] Cognate to lever, and more distantly, light.
en: Levity is behaviour that shows a tendency to treat serious matters in a non-serious way.
example: At the time, Arnold had disapproved of such levity.
syn_n: flippancy, frivolity, giddiness, jocularity, buoyancy, lightness, weightlessness

syn: aggressive, hostile, threatening, antagonistic, pugnacious, truculent, confrontational, argumentative, quarrelsome, disputatious, contentious, militant, combative
etym: From Middle English [Term?], from Latin bellicosus.
en: You use bellicose to refer to aggressive actions or behaviour that are likely to start an argument or a fight.
example: He expressed alarm about the government's increasingly bellicose statements.
syn_a: bellicose, contentious, pugnacious, truculent, aggressive, hostile, warring

syn: synthetic, simulated, man-made, manufactured, ersatz, substitute
etym: Derived from prefix pseudo-, itself derived from Ancient Greek ψευδής (pseudḗs, “false, lying”)
en: not genuine; pretended
example: pseudo-intellectual images.
example_ko: pseudo-intellectual
syn_a: bogus, counterfeit, fake, false, mock, phony

zh_Hans: （病人）不需卧床的，能走动的，晚上不需留院的
syn: peripatetic, wandering, wayfaring, roving, roaming, rambling, touring, nomadic, gypsy, migrant, migratory, ambulatory
etym: Latin ambulatorius
en: of, relating to, or designed for walking
example_ko: an ambulatory corridor

zh_Hans: （使）（骨头等硬物）破裂，（使）断裂，（使）折断
syn: breakage, cracking, cleavage, rupture, shattering, fragmentation, splintering, splitting, separation, bursting, disintegration
etym: Borrowed from Old French fracture, from Latin fractūra (“a breach, fracture, cleft”), from frangere (“to break”), past participle fractus, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰreg-, from whence also English break. See fraction. Doublet of fraktur.
en: A fracture is a slight crack or break in something, especially a bone.
example: At least one-third of all women over ninety have sustained a hip fracture.
example_ko: a fracture of the leg / skull
syn_n: breach, fault, fissure, rift, schism
syn_v: break, cleave, rend, shatter

syn: magistrates, judiciary, judicature
etym: Borrowed from Latin iudiciarius, judiciarius.
en: The judiciary is the branch of authority in a country which is concerned with law and the legal system.
example: The judiciary must think very hard before jailing non-violent offenders.
example_ko: an independent judiciary

syn: maxim, axiom, proverb, aphorism, saw, dictum, precept, epigram, epigraph, motto, truism, platitude, cliché, commonplace
etym: Borrowed from Middle French adage, from Latin adagium
en: An adage is something which people often say and which expresses a general truth about some aspect of life.
example: the old adage, 'Every baby brings its own love'.
syn_n: aphorism, epigram, maxim, proverb, saying, clich), platitude  truism

syn: backwards, reverse, rearward, directed backwards, retreating, retrogressive
en: A retrograde action is one that you think makes a situation worse rather than better.
example: The Prime Minister described transferring education to central government funding as 'a retrograde step'.
example_ko: The closure of the factory is a retrograde step.

zh_Hans: （尤指由于不公）可能招致不满的，易引起反感的
syn: awkward, difficult
etym: Borrowed from Latin invidiōsus, from invidia (“envy, ill will”), from in- (“upon”) + videō (“I see”). Doublet of envious, from Old French.
en: If you describe a task or job as invidious, you mean that it is unpleasant because it is likely to make you unpopular.
example: The local authority could find itself in the invidious position of having to refuse.
example_ko: We were in the invidious position of having to choose whether to break the law or risk lives.
syn_a: malicious, malignant, spiteful, vicious, insulting, objectionable, offending  slighting

syn: be sympathetic to, express sympathy for, send condolences to, offer condolences to, condole with, sympathize with, empathize with, feel pity for, feel sorry for, feel for, be moved by, mourn for, sorrow for, grieve for
en: If you commiserate with someone, you show them pity or sympathy when something unpleasant has happened to them.
example: When I lost, he commiserated with me.
example_ko: [V] She commiserated with the losers on their defeat.
syn_v: empathize, identify with, pity, understand, approve, endorse, sanction

zh_Hans: 毒打一顿；责骂;就…作过度的说明；向…唠叨;反复研究（或讨论）
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：be 加强 + labor 劳动，工作 → 劳作过多 → 过分啰嗦
syn: labour, discuss at length, dwell on, harp on about, hammer away at, expound on, expand on
en: → see labour
syn_v: dwell on, exhaust, hammer, overemphasize, rehash, reiterate, repeat

syn: discover, come to know, get to know, work out, make out, fathom, fathom out, become aware of, learn, ferret out, dig out, dig up, establish, fix, determine, settle, decide, verify, make certain of, confirm, deduce, divine, intuit, diagnose, discern, perceive, see, realize, appreciate, identify, pin down, recognize, register, understand, grasp, take in, comprehend
etym: From Old French acertener, from a- (“to, towards”) + certener (“make sure of”), from the adjective certain, from Latin certus (“certain, fixed”). Compare to Spanish acertar.
en: If you ascertain the truth about something, you find out what it is, especially by making a deliberate effort to do so.
example: Through doing this, the teacher will be able to ascertain the extent to which the child understands what he is reading
example_ko: [VN] It can be difficult to ascertain the facts.
syn_v: certify, conclude, establish, verify, detect, determine, discern, discover

zh_Hans: （尤指幽默）尖锐的，尖刻而又风趣的
syn: trenchant, biting, cutting, acerbic, sardonic, sarcastic, scathing, acid, sharp, keen, tart, pungent, stinging, astringent, incisive, devastating, piercing, rapier-like, razor-edged
etym: From French mordant.
en: Mordant humour is very critical and often mocks someone or something.
example: A wicked, mordant sense of humour has come to the fore in Blur's world.
example_ko: His mordant wit appealed to students.
syn_a: biting, caustic, cutting, sarcastic  gentle

syn: circumspect, cautious, wary, chary, guarded, close-lipped, close-mouthed
etym: From Middle English discrete, from Old French discret, from Latin discrētus, from past participle of discernēre. Doublet of discrete.
en: If you are discreet, you are polite and careful in what you do or say, because you want to avoid embarrassing or offending someone.
example: They were gossipy and not always discreet
example_ko: He was always very discreet about his love affairs.
syn_a: careful, cautious, circumspect, guarded, discriminating, judicious, politic, prudent, wise

syn: diversified, varied, varying, miscellaneous, assorted, mixed, sundry, contrasting, disparate, different, differing, divergent, unrelated, variegated, wide-ranging
etym: From Medieval Latin heterogeneus, from Ancient Greek ἑτερογενής (heterogenḗs, “of different kinds”), from ἕτερος (héteros, “other, another, different”) + γένος (génos, “kind”). Compare hetero- and -ous.
en: A heterogeneous group consists of many different types of things or people.
example: a rather heterogeneous collection of studies from diverse origins.
example_ko: the heterogeneous population of the United States
syn_a: assorted, diverse, miscellaneous, mixed, varied

zh_Hans: 神秘的，隐秘的；有隐义的；费解的
syn: mysterious, hard to understand, confusing, mystifying, perplexing, puzzling, obscure, abstruse, arcane, oracular, Delphic, ambiguous, elliptical, oblique
etym: From Late Latin crypticus, from Ancient Greek κρυπτικός (kruptikós), from κρυπτός (kruptós, “hidden”), from κρύπτω (krúptō, “to hide”). Also see: cryptology.
en: A cryptic remark or message contains a hidden meaning or is difficult to understand.
example: He has issued a short, cryptic statement denying the spying charges
example_ko: a cryptic message/remark/smile
syn_a: baffling, enigmatic, hidden, mysterious, obscure, puzzling, secret

syn: hostility, friction, antagonism, enmity, animus, opposition, aversion, acrimony, bitterness, rancour, resentment, dislike, ill feeling, bad feeling, ill will, bad blood, hatred, hate, loathing, detestation, abhorrence, odium
etym: From French animosité, from Latin animositas (“courage, spirit, vehemence”), from animosus, from animus (“courage, spirit, mind”); see animose, animate, transitive verb
en: Animosity is a strong feeling of dislike and anger. Animosities are feelings of this kind.
example: There's a long history of animosity between the two nations
example_ko: He felt no animosity towards his critics.
syn_a: enmity, hatred, hostility, malice, rancor, resentment

zh_Hans: 终结的预兆，完结的信号（同 death knell）
syn: tolling, ringing, chime, clang, dong, peal, stroke, resounding, reverberation, clangour, boom
etym: From Middle English knellen, knillen, knyllen, knullen, from Old English cnyllan (“to strike; knock; clap”), from Proto-Germanic *knuzlijaną (“to beat; push; mash”), from Proto-Indo-European *gen- (“to squeeze, pinch, kink, ball up”).
en: the sound of a bell rung to announce a death or a funeral
example: The tax increase sounded the death knell for the business

syn: girl, sweetheart, partner, significant other, inamorata, fiancée
etym: From the Italian innamorata, the feminine form of innamorato (“lover, boyfriend”), from innamorare (“to make somebody fall in love”), from in- (“in”) + amore (“love”).
en: a woman with whom one is in love; a female lover

syn: obstruct, hamper, handicap, hold back, hold up, delay, interfere with, disrupt, retard, slow, slow down, brake, put a brake on, restrain, fetter, shackle, hamstring, cramp, cripple
etym: Borrowed from Latin impedire (“to shackle”), from pes (“foot”) (compare pedestrian). First attested use as a verb was in William Shakespeare's Macbeth.
en: If you impede someone or something, you make their movement, development, or progress difficult.
example: Fallen rock is impeding the progress of rescue workers.
example_ko: Work on the building was impeded by severe weather.
syn_v: block, check, halt, obstruct, thwart, delay, frustrate, hamper, hinder, inhibit, restrict

syn: arise, follow, ensue, emanate, stem, spring, flow
etym:
First attested in mid 15th century.
From Middle English acrewen, borrowed from Old French acreüe, past participle of accreistre (“to increase”), from Latin accrēsco (“increase”), from ad (“in addition”) + crēscō (“to grow”).
Compare accretion, accresce, accrete, crew, crescent.
en: If money or interest accrues or if you accrue it, it gradually increases in amount over a period of time.
example: I owed ￡5,000-part of this was accrued interest
example_ko: economic benefits accruing to the country from tourism
syn_v: accrue, amass, collect, gather, hoard, store

ko: 솔직하지 못한(특히 아는 것을 모른다고 하는)
zh_Hans: （人或其行为）不够诚实的，不够坦白的
syn: deceitful, underhand, underhanded, duplicitous, double-dealing, two-faced, dissembling, insincere, false, lying, untruthful, mendacious
etym: dis- +‎ ingenuous
en: Someone who is disingenuous is slightly dishonest and insincere in what they say.
example: It would be disingenuous to claim that this is great art.
example_ko: It would be disingenuous of me to claim I had never seen it.

zh_Hans: 正反对的；对跖的；对踵的；恰恰相反的（to）
syn: opposed, opposing, oppositional, diametrically opposed, extreme, contrary, contradictory, antithetical, antagonistic, conflicting, counterbalancing
etym: From antipode +‎ -al.
en: of or relating to diametrically opposite points on the earth's surface

zh_Hans: 声音甜美的；圆润流畅的
syn: sweet-toned, dulcet, honeyed, mellow, soft, liquid, soothing, rich, smooth, euphonious, lyric, harmonious, tuneful, musical
etym: From Latin mellifluus (“flowing like honey”), from mel (“honey”) + fluō (“flow”). Compare superfluous and fluid, from same root, and with dulcet (“sweet speech”), alternative Latinate term with a similar meaning.
en: A mellifluous voice or piece of music is smooth and gentle and very pleasant to listen to.
example: I grew up around people who had wonderful, mellifluous voices

syn: self-possession, self-command, calmness, equanimity, equilibrium, calm, coolness, collectedness, serenity, tranquillity
etym: compose +‎ -ure
en: Composure is the appearance or feeling of calm and the ability to control your feelings.
example: For once Dimbleby lost his composure. It was all he could do to stop tears of mirth falling down his cheeks
example_ko: to keep/lose/recover/regain your composure
syn_n: aplomb, dignity, poise  self-control

ko: <눈금이>  백분도 (百分度) 의 ; <온도계가> 섭씨의(Celsius) ((略 C, c., Cent., cent.))
etym: centi- +‎ grade, degree.
en: Centigrade is a scale for measuring temperature, in which water freezes at 0 degrees and boils at 100 degrees. It is represented by the symbol C.
example: daytime temperatures of up to forty degrees centigrade.

etym: Latin renītēns, present participle of renītor (“resist, struggle”)
en: reluctant; recalcitrant

syn: charm, enchant, bewitch, fascinate, beguile, entrance, enrapture, delight, attract, allure, lure
etym: Borrowed from Latin captīvō; synchronically analyzable as captive +‎ -ate.
en: If you are captivated by someone or something, you find them fascinating and attractive.
example: I was captivated by her brilliant mind
example_ko: The children were captivated by her stories.
syn_v: charm, dazzle, enchant, entrance, fascinate, mesmerize, spellbind

syn: dispute, argument, debate, dissension, contention, disputation, altercation, wrangle, quarrel, squabble, war of words, storm
etym: From Old French controversie, from Latin contrōversia (“debate, contention, controversy”), from contrōversus (“turned in an opposite direction”).
en: Controversy is a lot of discussion and argument about something, often involving strong feelings of anger or disapproval.
example: The proposed cuts have caused considerable controversy.
example_ko: to arouse/cause controversy
syn_n: altercation, argument, debate, dispute, quarrel, conflict, contention, strife

syn: manacles, handcuffs, irons, leg irons, chains, bonds
etym: From Old English feter, from Proto-Germanic *feturaz (“fetter”), from Proto-Indo-European *ped- (“foot, step”). Cognate with Dutch veter (“lace”). Related to foot.
en: If you say that you are fettered by something, you dislike it because it prevents you from behaving or moving in a free and natural way.
example: a private trust which would not be fettered by bureaucracy
syn_n: fetters, chains, irons, manacles, shackles
syn_v: chain, confine, hobble, shackle, bind, hamper, hinder, restrain

syn: funeral service, funeral, burial ceremony, burial service, burial
en: funeral rites
example_ko: state obsequies

syn: rebuke, reproach, scold, admonish, remonstrate with, chastise, chide, upbraid, berate, take to task, pull up, castigate, lambaste, read someone the Riot Act, give someone a piece of one's mind, haul over the coals, criticize, censure
en: If you reprove someone, you speak angrily or seriously to them because they have behaved in a wrong or foolish way.
example: There's no call for talk like that,' Mrs Evans reproved him
example_ko: [VN] He reproved her for rushing away.
syn_v: admonish, castigate, censure, chasten, chide, rebuke

zh_Hans: 好动亢奋的，过度活跃的
syn: wild, frenetic, hectic, fraught, feverish, fevered, mad, crazed, manic, hyperactive, energetic, intense, furious, fast and furious, turbulent, tumultuous, confused, confusing
etym: hyper- +‎ active
en: Someone who is hyperactive is unable to relax and is always moving about or doing things.
example: His research was used in planning treatments for hyperactive children.

zh_Hans: 间接感受到的；间接获得的
syn: second-hand, secondary, derivative, derived, at one remove, surrogate, substitute, substituted, by proxy
etym: Borrowed from Latin vicārius (“vicarious, substituted”).
en: A vicarious pleasure or feeling is experienced by watching, listening to, or reading about other people doing something, rather than by doing it yourself.
example: She invents fantasy lives for her own vicarious pleasure
example_ko: He got a vicarious thrill out of watching his son score the winning goal.

syn: introduction, opening, introductory movement, voluntary
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman, Middle French overture, from Old French overture. Doublet of aperture.
en: An overture is a piece of music, often one that is the introduction to an opera or play.
example: The programme opened with the overture to Wagner's Flying Dutchman.
example_ko: Prokofiev’s overture to ‘Romeo and Juliet’
syn_n: invitation, offer, proposal, proposition, advance, approach, move, pass, introduction, prelude

syn: colour, dye, stain, shade, suffuse, flush, imbue, wash, overlay, bathe, saturate, steep, impregnate, permeate, penetrate, pervade, run through
etym: The verb is derived from Latin tingere,[1] present active infinitive of tingō (“to dip; to moisten; to colour, dye, tinge”), from Proto-Indo-European *teng- (“to dip; to soak”).
en: A tinge of a colour, feeling, or quality is a small amount of it.
example: His skin had an unhealthy greyish tinge
example_ko: white petals tinged with blue
syn_n: cast, shade, tincture, tint, hint, intimation, nuance  trace

syn: hunt, rummage, rummage around, forage, scrabble, grub, root about, root around, scavenge, fish about, fish around, rake around, feel around, grope around, nose around, ferret, ferret about, ferret around
etym: From Middle English forage, from Old French fourage, forage, a derivative of fuerre (“fodder, straw”), of Germanic origin, from Frankish *fōdar (“fodder, sheath”), from Proto-Germanic *fōdrą (“fodder, feed, sheath”), from Proto-Indo-European *patrom (“fodder”), *pat- (“to feed”), *pāy- (“to guard, graze, feed”). Cognate with Old High German fuotar (German Futter (“fodder, feed”)), Old English fōdor, fōþor (“food, fodder, covering, case, basket”), Dutch voeder (“forage, food, feed”), Danish foder (“fodder, feed”), Icelandic fóðr (“fodder, sheath”). More at fodder, food.
en: If someone forages for something, they search for it in a busy way.
example: They were forced to forage for clothing and fuel.
example_ko: He did an amazing job for his age.
syn_n: feed, fodder, provender, foray, incursion, invasion, raid
syn_v: hunt, rummage, scavenge, scrounge, search  seek

syn: tutor, instructor, pedagogue, schoolteacher, schoolmaster, schoolmistress, master, mistress, governess, educationalist, educationist
etym: Borrowed from Middle French pedagogue, from Latin paedagogus, from Ancient Greek παιδαγωγός (paidagōgós), from παῖς (paîs, “child”) + ἀγωγός (agōgós, “guide”) (from ἄγω (ágō, “lead”)).[1]
en: If you describe someone as a pedagogue, you mean that they like to teach people things in a firm way as if they know more than anyone else.
example: De Gaulle was a born pedagogue who used the public platform and the television screen to great effect.
syn_n: educator, instructor, lecturer, professor, teacher, tutor

syn: sensible, prudent, politic, shrewd, astute, canny, sagacious, common-sense, commonsensical, sound, well advised, well judged, well thought out, considered, thoughtful, perceptive, discerning, clear-sighted, insightful, far-sighted, percipient, discriminating, informed, intelligent, clever, enlightened, logical, rational
etym: Based on Middle French judicieux, itself ultimately derived from Latin iudico.
en: If you describe an action or decision as judicious, you approve of it because you think that it shows good judgment and sense.
example: The President authorizes the judicious use of military force to protect our citizens.
syn_a: cautious, discerning, logical, reasonable, wary, clever, diplomatic, shrewd, tactful

syn: show, reveal, be evidence of, display, exhibit, manifest, denote, evince, signify
etym: Borrowed from Middle French attester, from Latin attestor (“to witness to, bear witness”), from at-, combining form of ad (“to”) + testor (“to bear witness”), from testis (“a witness”).
en: To attest something or attest to something means to say, show, or prove that it is true.
example: Police records attest to his long history of violence
example_ko: [V] Contemporary accounts attest to his courage and determination.
syn_v: certify, confirm, guarantee, verify, warrant, witness

syn: spiteful, hostile, evil-minded, baleful, bitter, evil-intentioned, poisonous, venomous, evil, malign, malignant, rancorous, vicious, vindictive, revengeful, vengeful, pernicious
etym: From Middle English *malevolent (suggested by Middle English malevolence), from Old French malivolent and  Latin malevolentem, from male (“badly, wrongly”) + volens (“willing, wishing”), from velle (“to wish”).
en: A malevolent person deliberately tries to cause harm or evil.
example: Her stare was malevolent, her mouth a thin line.
syn_a: invidious, malignant, pernicious, spiteful, venomous

zh_Hans: （人）不守规章的，桀骜不驯的；（动物）不驯服的
syn: resistant, obstinate, uncooperative, non-compliant, recalcitrant, confrontational, challenging
etym: Borrowed from French récalcitrant, from Latin recalcitrāns, recalcitrantis, present participle of recalcitrō, recalcitrāre (“be disobedient, kick back [as a horse]”), from calx (“heel”), 1820s.
en: If you describe someone or something as recalcitrant, you mean that they are unwilling to obey orders or are difficult to deal with.
example: The danger is that recalcitrant local authorities will reject their responsibilities
syn_a: difficult, disobedient, rebellious, unmanageable, bullheaded, headstrong, inflexible, stubborn

syn: be adjacent to, border, border on, neighbour, verge on, abut, butt up against, butt up to, bound on, be contiguous with, be connected to, communicate with, link up with, extend as far as, extend to
etym: From Anglo-Norman adjoindre, from Latin adiungō.
en: If one room, place, or object adjoins another, they are next to each other.
example_ko: [VN] A barn adjoins the farmhouse.
syn_v: abut, border, meet, touch, attach, connect, join, unite

zh_Hans: 公开宣布放弃（以前的信仰）
syn: forswear, disavow, deny, repudiate, renege on, abjure, relinquish, abandon
etym: First attested in 1535, from Latin recantare, present active infinitive of recanto (“to sing back, reecho, sing again, repeat in singing, recant, recall, revoke, charm back or away”), from re- (“back”) + canto (“to chant, to sing”), frequentative of cano.
en: If you recant, you say publicly that you no longer hold a set of beliefs that you had in the past.
example: White House officials ordered Williams to recant.
syn_v: disavow, disclaim, rescind, retract

zh_Hans: 过分恭维的；谄媚的；言过其实的
syn: ample, profuse, extensive, generous, liberal, lavish, glowing, gushing, gushy
etym: From Middle English fulsum, equivalent to ful- +‎ -some. The meaning has evolved from an original positive connotation "abundant" to a neutral "plump" to a negative "overfed". In modern usage, it can take on any of these inflections. See usage note.
en: If you describe expressions of praise, apology, or gratitude as fulsome, you disapprove of them because they are exaggerated and elaborate, so that they sound insincere.
example: Newspapers have been fulsome in their praise of the former president.
example_ko: a fulsome apology

syn: plentiful, ample, bumper, superabundant, inexhaustible, prolific, profuse, teeming, copious, prodigal, considerable, vast, immense, great, liberal, lavish, generous, princely, handsome, luxuriant, rich
etym: bounty +‎ -ful
en: A bountiful supply or amount of something pleasant is a large one.
example: State aid is less bountiful than it was before.
example_ko: a bountiful supply of food
syn_a: abundant, bounteous, copious, plentiful, benevolent, charitable, generous, magnanimous

syn: auspicious, promising, providential, advantageous, fortunate, lucky, optimistic, bright, happy, rosy, full of promise, heaven-sent, hopeful, beneficial
etym: From Anglo-Norman and Old French propicius, from Latin propitius (“favorable, well-disposed, kind”). Compare French propice, Portuguese propício and Spanish propicio.
en: If something is propitious, it is likely to lead to success.
example: They should wait for the most propitious moment between now and the next election
example_ko: It was not a propitious time to start a new business.
syn_a: auspicious, fortunate, lucky, advantageous, beneficial, favorable, promising

syn: syringe
etym: hypoderm +‎ -ic
en: A hypodermic needle or syringe is a medical instrument with a hollow needle, which is used to give injections.

syn: social class, order, social order, social division, grade, grading, group, grouping, station, stratum, echelon, rank, level, degree, set
etym:
Borrowed from Portuguese or Spanish casta (“lineage, breed, race”), of uncertain origin. The OED derives it from Portuguese casto (“chaste”), from Latin castus.
Coromines (1987) argues instead for a hypothetical Gothic form *𐌺𐌰𐍃𐍄𐍃 (*kasts), cognate with English cast, from Proto-Germanic *kastuz.
en: A caste is one of the traditional social classes into which people are divided in a Hindu society.
example: Most of the upper castes worship the Goddess Kali.
example_ko: the caste system
syn_n: class, position, rank, station  status

zh_Hans: 不饶人的；坚定的；无法改变的
syn: unpacifiable, unplacatable, unmollifiable, unforgiving, unsparing, grudge-holding
etym: From Middle English implācāble (“immitigable, unappeasable”)[1] from Old French implacable (“harsh, unrelenting; implacable”) (modern French implacable), from Latin implācābilis (“unappeasable, implacable; irreconcilable”), from im- (variant of in- (prefix meaning ‘not’)) + plācābilis (“placable; appeasing, moderating, pacifying, propitiating; acceptable”) (from plācō (“to assuage, pacify, placate; to appease; to reconcile”) + -bilis (suffix forming adjectives indicating a capacity or worth of being acted upon)).[2]
en: If you say that someone is implacable, you mean that they have very strong feelings of hostility or disapproval which nobody can change.
example: the threat of invasion by a ruthless and implacable enemy
example_ko: implacable hatred
syn_a: inexorable, intractable, uncompromising, unrelenting, unyielding

syn: cut, cut down, cut short, curtail, truncate, lessen, trim, crop, clip, pare down, prune
etym: From Middle English abreggen (“curtail, lessen”), abregge, abrigge,[1] from Old French abregier abreger, from Late Latin abbrevio (“make brief”), from Latin ad + brēvio (“shorten”).[2]. Doublet of abbreviate.
en: to reduce the length of (a written work) by condensing or rewriting
syn_v: abbreviate, compress, condense, summarize, curtail, decrease, diminish, limit, restrict

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：pre 前 + eminent 杰出的，突出的 → 向前突出的 → 杰出的
syn: leading, foremost, best, finest, chief, outstanding, excellent, distinguished, prominent, eminent, important, major, star, top, top-tier, topmost, famous, renowned, celebrated, illustrious, towering, supreme, superior, exceptional, unrivalled, unsurpassed, unequalled, inimitable, incomparable, matchless, peerless, unmatched, arch-, transcendent
etym: From Middle French preeminent and its source, Latin praeēminēns, present participle of praeēminēre (“to stand out, excel”), from prae- (“pre-”) + ēminēre.
en: If someone or something is pre-eminent in a group, they are more important, powerful, or capable than other people or things in the group.
example: his fifty years as the pre-eminent political figure in the country
example_ko: a preeminent scientist
syn_a: celebrated, distinguished, eminent, famous, renowned, consummate, foremost, greatest, predominant, unparalleled, unrivaled

syn: way of behaving, performance, comportment, demeanour, bearing, deportment
etym: From Late Latin conductus (“defense, escort”), from Latin conductus, perfect passive participle of condūcō (“bring together”); see also conduce and conduit.
en: When you conduct an activity or task, you organize it and carry it out.
example: I decided to conduct an experiment
example_ko: to conduct an experiment/an inquiry/a survey
syn_n: bearing, behavior, demeanor  deportment
syn_v: chaperon, convoy, escort, guide, usher, carry, convey, transport, control, direct, govern, handle, manage, bear, behave, carry, comport

syn: placate, pacify, conciliate, humour, soothe, calm, calm down, still, quieten, propitiate
etym: Borrowed from Old French mollifier, from Late Latin mollificare, from Latin mollis (“soft”).
en: If you mollify someone, you do or say something to make them less upset or angry.
example: The investigation was undertaken primarily to mollify pressure groups.
syn_v: appease, assuage, pacify, placate, soothe

zh_Hans: 神秘的；秘密的；晦涩难懂的
syn: secret, hidden, concealed, covert, clandestine, enigmatic, dark
etym: Borrowed from Latin arcānus (“hidden, secret”), from arceō (“to shut up, enclose”); cognate with Latin arca (“a chest”).
en: Something that is arcane is secret or mysterious.
example: Until a few months ago few people outside the arcane world of contemporary music had heard of Gorecki.
syn_a: abstruse, enigmatic, esoteric, recondite, hidden, mysterious, secret

syn: slanted, sloping, at an angle, angled, diagonal, aslant, slant, slantwise, sloped, inclined, inclining, tilted, tilting, atilt, skew, on the skew, askew
etym: From Middle French oblique, from Latin oblīquus (“slanting, sideways, indirect, envious”)
en: If you describe a statement as oblique, you mean that is not expressed directly or openly, making it difficult to understand.
example: Mr Golding delivered an oblique warning, talking of the danger of sudden action.
example_ko: an oblique reference/approach/comment
syn_a: diagonal, inclined, sloping, tilted, askant, askew, crooked, lopsided, devious, furtive, indirect, roundabout, underhanded

ko: [U] 공평무사, 허심 탄회; 솔직, 정직; [고어] 순백; [폐어] 순수성, 순결
zh_Hans: 坦率，正直，公正；白色；光明
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：cand 白；发光 + or 表状态 → 坦白
syn: openness, honesty, candidness, truthfulness, sincerity, forthrightness, directness, lack of restraint, straightforwardness, plain-spokenness, plain dealing, plainness, calling a spade a spade, unreservedness, bluffness, bluntness, outspokenness
etym: From Latin candor (“brightness, whiteness”), from candeō (“I shine”).
en: When you are candid about something or with someone, you speak honestly.
example: I haven't been completely candid with him.
example_ko: a candid statement / interview
syn_n: directness, forthrightness, frankness, honesty, sincerity

syn: guiding light, inspiration, leader, expert, master, panjandrum, dignitary, VIP
