etym: From Late Middle English lūminārī, lūminārīe (“lamp; source of spiritual light, example of holiness; glory”), borrowed from Old French luminarie (“lamp, lights, lighting; candles; brightness, illumination”), variant of luminaire (“light fixture”) (modern French luminaire), from Medieval Latin lūminārium,[1] from lūmināre (“that which gives light; light; lamp; body giving light, especially a heavenly body”), from lūmen (“light; brightness”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *lewk- (“bright; to shine”))[2] + -āris (“suffix forming adjectives indicating a relationship or a pertaining to”).
en: If you refer to someone as a luminary, you mean that they are an expert in a particular subject or activity.
example: the political opinions of such luminaries as Sartre or de Beauvoir.
syn_n: celebrity, dignitary, notable, star, celestial body, orb, star  sun

syn: defamation, defamation of character, character assassination, misrepresentation of character, evil-speaking, calumniation, libel
etym: From Late Middle English calumnīe (“false accusation, slander; (law) objection raised in bad faith”),[1] borrowed from Old French calomnie (“slander, calumny”) (modern French calomnie), or directly from its etymon Latin calumnia (“false statement, misrepresentation; false accusation, malicious charge”),[2] perhaps related to calvor (“to deceive”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ḱelh₁- or *ḱh₂l-. The English word is a doublet of challenge.
en: Calumny or a calumny is an untrue statement made about someone in order to reduce other people's respect and admiration for them.
example: He was the victim of calumny.
syn_n: defamation, libel, misrepresentation
syn_v: attack, besmirch, defame, malign, sully

syn: placate, pacify, make peace with, propitiate, palliate, allay, reconcile, win over
etym: From Middle English apesen, from Old French apeser (“to pacify, bring to peace”).
en: If you try to appease someone, you try to stop them from being angry by giving them what they want.
example: Gandhi was accused by some of trying to appease both factions of the electorate
example_ko: The move was widely seen as an attempt to appease critics of the regime.
syn_v: calm, mollify, pacify, placate, soothe, abate, alleviate, assuage, temper, accommodate, concede, conciliate, propitiate

syn: reduced, lessened, decreased, diminished, impaired, enervated
etym: From Latin attenuāre, from attenuāt-, at- = ad-, ad- (“to”) + tenuāre (“to make thin”), tenuis (“thin”).
en: To attenuate something means to reduce it or weaken it.
example: You could never eliminate risk, but preparation and training could attenuate it
example_ko: The drug attenuates the effects of the virus.
syn_v: decrease, diminish, lessen, reduce, dilute, extend, stretch, weaken

syn: light, flashlight, beacon
etym: Borrowed from French flambeau.
en: a burning torch, as used in night processions

zh_Hans: 怪异的，古怪的；异乎寻常的
syn: uncommon, abnormal, irregular, aberrant, anomalous, odd, queer, strange, peculiar, weird, bizarre, off-centre, outlandish, freakish, extraordinary
etym: From Middle French excentrique, from Medieval Latin excentricus, from Ancient Greek ἔκκεντρος (ékkentros, “not having the earth as the center of an orbit”), from ἐκ (ek, “out”) + κέντρον (kéntron, “point”).
en: If you say that someone is eccentric, you mean that they behave in a strange way, and have habits or opinions that are different from those of most people.
example: He is an eccentric character who likes wearing a beret and dark glasses.
example_ko: eccentric behaviour/clothes
syn_n: character, kook, weirdo
syn_a: bizarre, curious, odd, peculiar, weird, erratic, idiosyncratic, whimsical, freakish, unconventional, unorthodox

syn: truth, accuracy, accurateness, correctness, exactness, precision, preciseness, realism, authenticity, faithfulness, fidelity
etym: From Middle French véracité, from Old French veracitie, from Medieval Latin vērācitās (“truthfulness”), from Latin vērāx (“truthful, speaking truth”), from vērus (“true, real”). See very.
en: Veracity is the quality of being true or the habit of telling the truth.
example: We have total confidence in the veracity of our research
example_ko: They questioned the veracity of her story.
syn_n: accuracy, truth, verity, candor, honesty, probity, sincerity

zh_Hans: 旁敲侧击的话;影射;暗示;旁敲侧击;含沙射影;巧妙进入
syn: inference, suggestion, hint, intimation, imputation, innuendo, reference, allusion, indication, undertone, overtone
etym: Borrowed from Middle French insinuation, from Old French, from Latin insinuatio, from īnsinuō (“to push in, creep in, steal in”), from in (“in”) + sinus (“a winding, bend, bay, fold, bosom”)
example: He speaks with rage of insinuations that there's a 'gay mafia' in Hollywood
example_ko: She resented the insinuation that she was too old for the job.
syn_v: hint, imply, intimate, suggest

syn: interior, inside, intramural
etym: From Latin intramuralis, from intra (“within”) + muralis (“of a wall”)
en: Intramural activities happen within one college or university, rather than between different colleges or universities.
example: a comprehensive, well-supported program of intramural sports.
example_ko: Jeff played intramural basketball in high school.

zh_Hans: （尤指搭乘交通工具的）旅行，行程
syn: expedition, period of travelling, tour, trek, voyage, cruise, safari, ride, drive, transfer
etym: From Middle English journe, jorney, from Old French jornee, from Medieval Latin diurnata (“a day's work, a day's journey, a fixed day, a day”), from Latin diurnus (“daily”), from diēs (“day”). Displaced native reys.
en: When you make a journey, you travel from one place to another.
example: There is an express service from Paris which completes the journey to Bordeaux in under 4 hours.
example_ko: They went on a long train journey across India.
syn_n: excursion, tour, trip, voyage
syn_v: cruise, fly, roam, travel  wander

zh_Hans: （尤指基于种族或性别原因）隔离并差别对待
syn: set apart, keep apart, sort out
etym: From Latin sēgregātus, perfect passive participle of sēgregō (“I separate”), from sē- (“apart”) + gregō (“I flock or group”), from grex (“flock”). Compare gregarious, aggregate.
en: To segregate two groups of people or things means to keep them physically apart from each other.
example: Police segregated the two rival camps of protesters
example_ko: a culture in which women are segregated from men
syn_v: divide, isolate, quarantine, seclude, separate, sequester

syn: respectability, decency, correctness, appropriateness, good manners, courtesy, politeness, rectitude, civility, modesty, demureness
etym: From Late Middle English propriete (“ownership”), borrowed from Anglo-Norman propreté, Middle French proprieté, from Latin proprietās. Doublet of property.
en: Propriety is the quality of being socially or morally acceptable.
example: Their sense of social propriety is eroded.
example_ko: Nobody questioned the propriety of her being there alone.
syn_n: appropriateness, correctness, seemliness, suitability, breeding, decorum, etiquette, protocol, refinement, proprieties, amenities, civilities, social graces

zh_Hans: 惯犯;但累犯;再犯;累犯;累犯,惯犯
etym: From French récidivisme, from Latin recidīvus (“returning, recurring”). Compare recidivous, -ism.
example: Their basic criticism was that prisons do not reduce the crime rate, they cause recidivism.

syn: incense, anger, madden, inflame, send into a rage, make someone's blood boil, stir up, fire up
etym: From Medieval Latin infuriatus (“enraged”), past participle of infurio (“to enrage”), from Latin furia (“rage, fury, frenzy”), perhaps via Italian infuriato.
en: If something or someone infuriates you, they make you extremely angry.
example: Jimmy's presence had infuriated Hugh
example_ko: [VN] Her silence infuriated him even more.
syn_v: anger, enrage, incense, inflame, madden, outrage

syn: falter, waver, teeter, vacillate, oscillate, fluctuate, change one's mind, be in two minds, be ambivalent, be indecisive, be unsure, be undecided
etym: Variant of didder, from Middle English didderen (“to tremble”), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *titrōną, whence also derived Old High German zittarōn (German zittern) and Old Norse titra (Faroese titra, Icelandic titra).
en: When someone dithers, they hesitate because they are unable to make a quick decision about something.
example: We're still dithering over whether to marry
example_ko: She was dithering over what to wear.

syn: motionless, immobile, still, stock-still, stationary, static, dormant, sleeping
etym: From French inerte, from Latin iners (“inactive, inert”).
en: Someone or something that is inert does not move at all.
example: He covered the inert body with a blanket.
example_ko: He lay inert with half-closed eyes.
syn_a: inactive, inanimate, lifeless, motionless, static, languid, listless, sluggish, torpid

zh_Hans: （尤指出现新进步和大变革的）时代，纪元，时期
syn: age, period, time, aeon, span
etym: From Medieval Latin epocha, from Ancient Greek ἐποχή (epokhḗ, “a check, cessation, stop, pause, epoch of a star, i.e., the point at which it seems to halt after reaching the highest, and generally the place of a star; hence, a historical epoch”), from ἐπέχω (epékhō, “I hold in, check”), from ἐπι- (epi-, “upon”) + ἔχω (ékhō, “I have, hold”).
en: If you refer to a long period of time as an epoch, you mean that important events or great changes took place during it.
example: The birth of Christ was the beginning of a major epoch of world history.
example_ko: The death of the emperor marked the end of an epoch in the country’s history.

zh_Hans: 欢乐的，愉快的；无忧无虑的
syn: uncaring, careless, casual, indifferent, thoughtless, unconcerned, unworried, untroubled
etym: From Middle English blithe, from Old English blīþe (“blithe, joyous, cheerful, pleasant; gracious, well-disposed, friendly, kind; agreeable, willing; quiet, peaceful, gentle”), from Proto-Germanic *blīþiz (“mild, pleasing, friendly”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰlī- (“light, pleasant, fine”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to shine”). Cognate Scots blithe (“joyous, cheerful, happy, well-pleased”), North Frisian blid (“happy, glad”), Saterland Frisian bliede (“happy, joyous, blithe”), West Frisian bliid (“glad, happy, joyful, joyous”), Dutch blijde, blij (“blithe, happy, joyous, glad”), Afrikaans bly (“happy”), German dialectal blid, blied (“glad, happy, cheerful”), Danish blid (“gentle”), Icelandic blíður (“gentle, kind, friendly, mild”). Related to bliss.
en: You use blithe to indicate that something is done casually, without serious or careful thought.
example: It does so with blithe disregard for best scientific practice.
example_ko: He drove with blithe disregard for the rules of the road.
syn_a: cheerful, content, delighted, glad, pleased, fortuitous, fortunate, lucky, opportune, seasonable, timely

zh_Hans: （通常指人的外表或行为）冷峻的，阴沉的，不苟言笑的
syn: unsmiling, unfriendly, frowning, poker-faced, severe, forbidding, morose, sour, gruff, surly, uncommunicative, grim, gloomy, dismal, sullen, sombre, grave, sober, serious, solemn, austere, mean-looking, stony, unsympathetic, disapproving
etym:
From Scots dour, from Latin dūrus (“hard, stern”), possibly via Middle Irish dúr.
Compare French dur, German Dauer, Italian duro, Portuguese duro, Romanian dur, Spanish duro. Doublet of dure.
en: If you describe someone as dour, you mean that they are very serious and unfriendly.
example: a dour, taciturn man
syn_a: forbidding, gloomy, sour, sullen, harsh, severe, stern, inflexible, intractable, unyielding

syn: animosity, antagonism, friction, antipathy, animus, opposition, dissension, rivalry, feud, conflict, discord, contention
etym: From Old French enemisté, ennemistié, from Late Latin, Vulgar Latin *inimīcitās, *inimīcitātem, from Latin inimīcus (“enemy”); cognates: French inimitié, Portuguese inimizade, Spanish enemistad.[1]
en: Enmity is a feeling of hatred towards someone that lasts for a long time.
example: I think there is an historic enmity between them
example_ko: the traditional problem of the enmity between Protestants and Catholics
syn_n: animosity, bitterness, hatred, hostility, rancor

syn: general truth, dictum, truism, principle
etym: A statue honouring the Greek mathematician Euclid (fl. 300 b.c.e.) at the Oxford University Museum of Natural History in Oxford, Oxfordshire, England, UK
en: An axiom is a statement or idea which people accept as being true.
example: the long-held axiom that education leads to higher income.
syn_n: assumption, postulate, precept, premise  principle

syn: kind, warm-hearted, good-natured, friendly, warm, affectionate, agreeable, amiable, good-humoured, genial, congenial, cordial, approachable, tender, tender-hearted, soft-hearted, gentle, sympathetic, compassionate, caring, considerate, thoughtful, helpful, well disposed, obliging, accommodating, generous, big-hearted, unselfish, benevolent, gracious, liberal, indulgent
etym: From Middle English benigne, benygne, from Old French benigne, from Latin benignus (“kind, good”), from bene (“well”) + genus (“origin, kind”). Compare malign.
en: You use benign to describe someone who is kind, gentle, and harmless.
example: They are normally a more benign audience
syn_a: benevolent, good, kind, tender, auspicious, encouraging, favorable, propitious, balmy, fair, temperate, harmless, innocuous, mild

zh_Hans: (动物)食肉的;(人)爱吃肉的，肉食性的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：carni〔= carn 肉〕+ vor 吃 + ous …的 → 食肉的
syn: flesh-eating, predatory, of prey, hunting, raptorial
etym: From Latin carnivorus (“flesh-eating”)
en: Carnivorous animals eat meat.
example: Snakes are carnivorous.

zh_Hans: 解放；给予人们政治或社会自由权利
syn: independent, unconstrained, unrepressed, uninhibited, free and easy, free, free-spirited
etym: From Latin emancipatus, past participle of emancipare (“to declare (a son) free and independent of the father's power by the thrice-repeated act of mancipatio and manumission, give from one's own power or authority into that of another, give up, surrender”), from e (“out”) + mancipare (“to transfer ownership in”), from manceps (“purchaser, a contractor, literally, one who takes in hand”), from manus (“hand”) + capere (“to take”). See manual, and capable.
en: If people are emancipated, they are freed from unpleasant or unfair social, political, or legal restrictions.
example: Catholics were emancipated in 1792
example_ko: Slaves were not emancipated until 1863 in the United States.
syn_v: free, liberate, release, unchain

syn: lesbian, lesbigay
etym: Borrowed from German Homosexual, from homo- (“same”) + sexual (“relating to sex (gender) or sexuality”), coined by Karl-Maria Kertbeny in 1869, and popularized in Richard von Krafft-Ebing's 1886 Psychopathia Sexualis (in German) and Charles Gilbert Chaddock's 1892 English translation thereof (compare bisexual), displacing the slightly older term Uranian. Equivalent to homo- +‎ -sexual.
en: A homosexual relationship is a sexual relationship between people of the same sex.
example_ko: a practising homosexual

syn: extreme poverty, pennilessness, impecuniousness, impoverishment, indigence, need, neediness, want, destitution, privation, deprivation, hardship, beggary, bankruptcy, insolvency, ruin, reduced circumstances, straitened circumstances
etym: From Latin penuria (“want”), related to paene (“scarcely”), c. 1400. Compare French pénurie.
en: Penury is the state of being extremely poor.
example: He was brought up in penury, without education.
syn_n: destitution, indigence, insolvency, poverty, privation, want

syn: high-handed, commanding, imperial, overbearing, overweening, domineering, authoritarian, dictatorial, authoritative, lordly, officious, assertive, dominating, bullish, forceful, bossy, arrogant
etym: From Latin imperiōsus (“mighty, powerful”), from imperium (“command, authority, power”)
en: If you describe someone as imperious, you mean that they have a proud manner and expect to be obeyed.
example: Her attitude is imperious at times
example_ko: an imperious gesture/voice/command
syn_a: arrogant, contemptuous, haughty, peremptory, despotic, domineering, oppressive, overbearing, tyrannical

syn: happening at the same time, done at the same time, contemporaneous, concomitant, coinciding, coincident, synchronous, synchronized, synchronic
etym: From Ancient Greek σύγχρονος (súnkhronos, “contemporaneous”), from σῠν- (sun-, “with, together”) + χρόνος (khrónos, “time”).
en: occurring at the same time; contemporaneous

syn: downhearted, despondent, disconsolate, dispirited, crestfallen, cast down, depressed, disappointed, disheartened, discouraged, demoralized, crushed, desolate, heartbroken, broken-hearted, heavy-hearted, low-spirited, in the doldrums, sad, unhappy, doleful, melancholy, miserable, woebegone, forlorn, long-faced, fed up, wretched, glum, gloomy, dismal
en: If you are dejected, you feel miserable or unhappy, especially because you have just been disappointed by something.
example: Everyone has days when they feel dejected or down.
example_ko: She looked so dejected when she lost the game.
syn_a: depressed, despondent, discouraged, disheartened, melancholy, sad

etym: From French centriste.
en: Centrist policies and parties are moderate rather than extreme.
example: He had left the movement because it had abandoned its centrist policies.
example_ko: The progressive girl wanted her father not to be a centrist dad.

ko: 남을 잘 믿는, 잘 속아 넘어가는
zh_Hans: 容易上当的，易受欺骗的，轻信的
syn: over-trusting, over-trustful, trustful, easily deceived, easily led, easily taken in, exploitable, dupable, deceivable, impressionable, unsuspecting, unsuspicious, unwary, unguarded, unsceptical, ingenuous, naive, innocent, simple, inexperienced, unworldly, green, as green as grass, childlike, ignorant
etym: Either gull +‎ -ible, or from dialect Middle English gull (“newly hatched bird”), perhaps from Old Norse gulr, from the hue of its down.[1]
en: If you describe someone as gullible, you mean they are easily tricked because they are too trusting.
example: I'm so gullible I would have believed him.
syn_a: credulous, ingenuous, innocent, naive, simple, trusting

syn: placate, mollify, pacify, make peace with, conciliate, make amends to, soothe, calm, humour, win over, satisfy
etym: From Latin propitiāre (“make favourable”), from propitius (“favourable, gracious”).
en: If you propitiate someone, you stop them being angry or impatient by doing something to please them.
example: I've never gone out of my way to propitiate people
example_ko: Sacrifices were made to propitiate the gods.
syn_v: calm, mollify, pacify, placate, soothe, abate, alleviate, assuage, temper, accommodate, concede, conciliate, propitiate

zh_Hans: 无秩序的，无计划的，随意的
syn: unplanned, unsystematic, unmethodical, disorganized, disorderly, irregular, indiscriminate, chaotic, hit-and-miss, arbitrary, orderless, aimless, undirected, careless, casual, slapdash, slipshod
etym: From archaic hap (“chance, luck”) +‎ hazard.
en: If you describe something as haphazard, you are critical of it because it is not at all organized or is not arranged according to a plan.
example: The investigation does seem haphazard
example_ko: The books had been piled on the shelves in a haphazard fashion.
syn_a: aimless, arbitrary, chance, chaotic, indiscriminate, offhand, random

syn: challenge, question, dispute, query, take issue with, impeach
etym: Borrowed from Middle French impugner, from Latin impugnō, from im- + pugnō (“fight”), from pugnus (“fist”), as in English pugilism (“fighting with fists, boxing”); from Proto-Indo-European roots.
en: If you impugn something such as someone's motives or integrity, you imply that they are not entirely honest or honourable.
example: The Secretary's letter questions my veracity and impugns my motives
syn_v: attack, censure, denigrate, execrate, oppose, libel, malign, slander

zh_Hans: 严格执行规章制度的人
syn: slave driver, stickler for discipline, taskmaster, taskmistress, authoritarian, tyrant
etym: From marteau (“hammer”), from Latin martulus (“hammer”)
en: If you say that someone is a martinet, you are criticizing them because they are very strict and demand that people obey their rules and orders.
example: He's a retired Lieutenant Colonel and a bit of a martinet.

syn: impending, growing, emerging, emergent, dawning
etym: Borrowed from Latin incipiēns, present participle of incipiō (“begin”).
en: An incipient situation or quality is one that is starting to happen or develop.
example: an incipient economic recovery
example_ko: signs of incipient unrest
syn_a: beginning, budding, developing, embryonic, nascent

zh_Hans: 收养，代养，抚育（他人子女，通常指有限的一段时间）
syn: promote, further, stimulate, advance, forward, cultivate, nurture, strengthen, enrich, help, aid, abet, assist, contribute to, support, endorse, champion, speak for, proselytize, sponsor, espouse, uphold, back, boost, give backing to, facilitate
etym: From Old Norse fóstr (“rear, raise”)
en: Foster parents are people who officially take a child into their family for a period of time, without becoming the child's legal parents. The child is referred to as their foster child.
example: Little Jack was placed with foster parents
example_ko: The club’s aim is to foster better relations within the community.
syn_v: nourish, nurse, nurture, rear, support, advance, encourage, further, promote

syn: personification, exemplification, type, epitome
etym: From Middle English incarnacion, borrowed from Old French incarnacion, from Medieval Latin, Ecclesiastical Latin incarnatio, from Late Latin incarnari (“to be made flesh”).
en: If you say that someone is the incarnation of a particular quality, you mean that they represent that quality or are typical of it in an extreme form.
example: The regime was the very incarnation of evil
example_ko: one of the incarnations of Vishnu
syn_v: actualize, embody, manifest, represent
syn_a: embodied, manifest, personified, revealed, typified, bodily, corporeal, fleshly, physical, actual, concrete, palpable, substantial, tangible

syn: lacking faith, backsliding, recidivist, apostate
etym: From French récidiviste, from Latin recidīvus (“returning, recurring”). Compare recidivous, -ist.
en: A recidivist is someone who has committed crimes in the past and has begun to commit crimes again, for example after a period in prison.
example: Six prisoners are still at large along with four dangerous recidivists.

zh_Hans: 来自世界各地的；国际大都会的；世界性的
syn: multiracial, worldwide, global, universal
etym: From cosmopolite +‎ -an. Compare metropolitan and megalopolitan.
en: A cosmopolitan place or society is full of people from many different countries and cultures.
example: London has always been a cosmopolitan city.
example_ko: a cosmopolitan city/resort
syn_a: cultivated, cultured, sophisticated, urbane, global, international, universal

ko: 덜시머(두 개의 나무망치로 철선을 두드려 소리를 내는 타악기)
etym: From Old French doulcemelle, probably from Latin dulce melos (“sweet song”), from Ancient Greek μέλος (mélos, “melody, song”).
en: a tuned percussion instrument consisting of a set of strings of graduated length stretched over a sounding board and struck with a pair of hammers

zh_Hans: 不拘一格的；相容并蓄的；博采众长的
syn: wide, broad, broad-ranging, broad-based, extensive, comprehensive, encyclopedic, general, universal, varied, diverse, diversified, catholic, liberal, cross-disciplinary, interdisciplinary, multidisciplinary, all-embracing, non-exclusive, inclusive, indiscriminate, many-sided, multifaceted, multifarious, heterogeneous, miscellaneous, assorted
etym: From French éclectique, from Ancient Greek ἐκλεκτικός (eklektikós, “selective”), from ἐκλέγω (eklégō, “I pick, choose”), from ἐκ (ek, “out, from”) + λέγω (légō, “I choose, count”).
en: An eclectic collection of objects, ideas, or beliefs is wide-ranging and comes from many different sources.
example: an eclectic collection of paintings, drawings, and prints.
example_ko: She has very eclectic tastes in literature.
syn_a: discriminating, particular, selective, complex, multiple, symbiotic, varied

zh_Hans: （行为）值得赞扬的，值得称赞的
syn: commendable, admirable, meritorious, worthy, deserving, creditable, worthy of admiration, estimable, of note, noteworthy, exemplary, reputable, honourable, excellent, sterling
etym: Borrowed from Old French laudable or directly from Latin laudabilis; equivalent to laud +‎ -able.
en: Something that is laudable deserves to be praised or admired.
example: One of Emma's less laudable characteristics was her jealousy
example_ko: a laudable aim/attempt
syn_a: admirable, commendable, estimable, exemplary, praiseworthy

syn: garrulous, voluble, over-talkative, long-winded, wordy, verbose, profuse, prolix, effusive, gushing, rambling
etym: Borrowed from Latin loquāx (“talkative”) + -cious.
en: If you describe someone as loquacious, you mean that they talk a lot.
example: The normally loquacious Mr O'Reilly has said little.
syn_a: gabby, garrulous, long-winded, prolix, talkative, verbose

syn: creative, inventive, fertile
etym: 1640-1650: from French prolifique, from Latin proles (“offspring”) and facere (“to make”).
en: A prolific writer, artist, or composer produces a large number of works.
example: She is a prolific writer of novels and short stories
example_ko: a prolific author
syn_a: abundant, copious, profuse, bounteous, fertile, fruitful, productive

syn: flat, horizontal, stretched out, sprawled, spreadeagled, reclining, resting, lounging, prone, prostrate, supine
etym: From Latin present participle recumbēns, from recumbere, infinitive of recumbō (“I recline”).
en: A recumbent figure or person is lying down.
example: He looked down at the recumbent figure.

syn: lily-livered, chicken-hearted, pigeon-hearted, spiritless, spineless, craven
etym: From Middle English craven (adjective).
en: Someone who is craven is very cowardly.
example: They condemned the deal as a craven surrender.
example_ko: The enemy finally had cried craven.
syn_a: dastardly, fainthearted, gutless, pusillanimous, spineless, timid

syn: as poor as a church mouse, poverty-stricken, destitute, necessitous, in penury, impecunious, impoverished, indigent, needy, in need, in want, badly off, in reduced circumstances, in straitened circumstances, hard up, on one's beam-ends, unable to make ends meet, underprivileged, penniless, without a sou, moneyless, bankrupt, bust, insolvent
etym: From Medieval Latin pēnūriōsus. See penury from Latin penuria (“want”), related to paene (“scarcely”), c. 1400. Compare French pénurie.
en: niggardly with money
syn_a: destitute, indigent, needy, poor, miserly, niggardly, parsimonious, stingy, tight

zh_Hans: 臭名昭著的，声名狼藉的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：not 知道 + or 表人 + ious 多…的 →〔因做坏事〕让很多人知道 → 恶名昭彰的
syn: of ill repute, with a bad name, with a bad reputation, ill-famed, scandalous
etym: First attested 1548, from Medieval Latin nōtōrius (“widely or fully known”), from Latin nōtus (“known”), perfect passive participle of nōscō (“get to know”). Negative sense appeared in seventeenth century.
en: To be notorious means to be well-known for something bad.
example: an area notorious for drugs, crime and violence
example_ko: a notorious criminal
syn_a: disreputable, egregious, infamous, nefarious, celebrated, distinguished, famed, renowned, well-known

syn: blaze, flames, inferno, firestorm, holocaust
etym: From Middle French, from Latin cōnflagrātiō (“burning, conflagration”).
en: A conflagration is a fire that burns over a large area and destroys property.
syn_n: blaze, fire, firestorm, holocaust, inferno  wildfire

syn: overstatement, magnification, amplification, embroidery, embellishment, overplaying, excess, overkill
etym: From Latin hyperbolē, from Ancient Greek ὑπερβολή (huperbolḗ, “excess, exaggeration”), from ὑπέρ (hupér, “above”) + βάλλω (bállō, “I throw”). Doublet of hyperbola.
en: If someone uses hyperbole, they say or write things that make something sound much more impressive than it really is.
example: the hyperbole that portrays him as one of the greatest visionaries in the world.
syn_n: embellishment, enhancement, exaggeration, overstatement

syn: hand over, send back, send home, repatriate, expel, banish
etym: Back-formation from extradition. (Source: SOED 1983.)
en: If someone is extradited, they are officially sent back to their own or another country to be tried for a crime that they have been accused of.
example: He was extradited to Britain from the Irish Republic to face explosives charges
example_ko: The British government attempted to extradite the suspects from Belgium.

syn: full, well stocked, well supplied, well provided, crammed, crowded, packed, jammed, stuffed, teeming, overflowing, bursting, brimful, brimming, loaded, overloaded, thick, solid, charged, abounding
en: Something that is chock-full is completely full.
example: The 32-page catalog is chock-full of things that add fun to festive occasions.

syn: encroacher, trespasser, invader, infiltrator, unwanted person, unwanted visitor, uninvited guest
etym: 1590s, from inter- +‎ loper (“runner, rover”), as in landloper (“vagrant”) (from lope (“to leap, to jump”) (originally dialectal). Originally spelt enterloper and used in specific sense “unauthorized trader trespassing on privileges of chartered companies”, later general sense of “self-interested intruder” from 1630s.[1]
en: If you describe someone as an interloper, you mean that they have come into a situation or a place where they are not wanted or do not belong.
example: She had no wish to share her father with any outsider and regarded us as interlopers.

syn: denigrate, deprecate, depreciate, downgrade, play down, deflate, trivialize, minimize, make light of, treat lightly, undervalue, underrate, underestimate
etym: From Middle English disparage (noun), disparagen (verb), from Old French desparage (noun), desparagier (verb), from des- + parage (“equal rank, rank”).
en: If you disparage someone or something, you speak about them in a way which shows that you do not have a good opinion of them.
example: Larkin's tendency to disparage literature.
example_ko: I don’t mean to disparage your achievements.
syn_v: abuse, belittle, decry, deprecate, depreciate, ridicule

etym: carcino- +‎ -genic
en: A substance that is carcinogenic is likely to cause cancer.

syn: composed, collected, calm, cool, calm, and collected, as cool as a cucumber, cool-headed, self-controlled, poised, tranquil, serene, relaxed, easy-going, unexcitable, even-tempered, placid, sedate, phlegmatic
etym: From Old French fleumatique, from Latin phlegmaticus, from Ancient Greek φλεγματικός (phlegmatikós), from φλέγμα (phlégma).
en: Someone who is phlegmatic stays calm even when upsetting or exciting things happen.
example_ko: a phlegmatic temperament
syn_a: languid, lethargic, listless, passive, sluggish, apathetic, impassive, indifferent, nonchalant

syn: abhorrence, repugnance, revulsion, repulsion, loathing, detestation, hatred, hate, execration, obloquy, dislike, disapproval, disapprobation, distaste, disfavour, aversion, antipathy, animosity, animus, enmity, hostility, contempt, censure, condemnation
etym: Borrowed from Latin odium.
en: Odium is the dislike, disapproval, or hatred that people feel for a particular person, usually because of something that the person has done.
example: The complainant has been exposed to public odium, scandal and contempt.
example_ko: What an odious man!

syn: sawtoothed, sawtooth, saw-edged, zigzag, notched, indented, toothed
etym: Past participle of serrate, From Latin  serratus (“saw shaped”), from serra (“saw”).
en: A serrated object such as a knife or blade has a row of V-shaped points along the edge.
example: Bread knives should have a serrated edge.
example_ko: a knife with a serrated edge

zh_Hans: 聪颖的；敏锐的；有洞察力的
syn: sharp-witted, sharp, acute, intelligent, clever, alert, canny, media-savvy, perceptive, perspicacious, observant, discriminating, sagacious, sage, wise, far-seeing, far-sighted
etym: First attested 1548, from Late Latin perspicācitās (“discernment”), from Latin perspicax (“sharp-sighted”), from perspiciō (“look through”), from per- (“through”) + speciō (“look at”). See also perspective.
en: Someone who is perspicacious notices, realizes, and understands things quickly.
example: one of the most perspicacious and perceptive historians of that period.
example_ko: a perspicacious remark
syn_a: astute, clear-eyed, discerning, keen, perceptiv

syn: go into raptures about, go into raptures over, wax lyrical about, sing the praises of, praise to the skies, heap praise on, rhapsodize about, rhapsodize over, rave about, rave over, enthuse about, enthuse over, gush about, gush over, throw bouquets at, express delight over, acclaim, extol
en: If you eulogize someone or something, you praise them very highly.
example: Barry Davies eulogized Keegan's part in the operation
example_ko: He was eulogized as a hero.

ko: (장기적이고 흔히 이유를 알 수 없는) 우울감[비애]
syn: sadness, pensiveness, woe, sorrow, melancholia
etym: From Middle English malencolie, from Old French melancolie, from Ancient Greek μελαγχολία (melankholía, “atrabiliousness”), from μέλας (mélas), μελαν- (melan-, “black, dark, murky”) + χολή (kholḗ, “bile”). Compare the Latin ātra bīlis (“black bile”).
en: You describe something that you see or hear as melancholy when it gives you an intense feeling of sadness.
example: The only sounds were the distant, melancholy cries of the sheep
example_ko: A mood of melancholy descended on us.
syn_n: dejection, depression, despair, despondency, gloom, woe
syn_a: dejected, depressed, despondent, disconsolate, gloomy, morose

zh_Hans: 周围的；（尤指）周围环境条件的
etym: From Latin ambiēns (“going around”), from ambiō (“go around”).
en: The ambient temperature is the temperature of the air above the ground in a particular place.
example_ko: ambient temperature/light/conditions
syn_a: embracing, encompassing, encircling  enveloping

ko: 밀실 공포증; 갇혀 있는 듯한 느낌
etym: From Latin claustrum (“a shut-in place”), from claudō (“I shut, close; I imprison, confine”) + -phobia. First attested in the British Medical Journal.
en: Someone who suffers from claustrophobia feels very uncomfortable or anxious when they are in small or enclosed places.
example_ko: to suffer from claustrophobia

zh_Hans: （尤指对鸡毛蒜皮的事情）喋喋不休的，絮叨的，饶舌的
syn: loquacious, voluble, verbose, long-winded, chatty, chattery, chattering, gossipy, gossiping, babbling, blathering, prattling, prating, jabbering, gushing, effusive, expansive, forthcoming, conversational, communicative
etym: Borrowed from Latin garrulus (“talkative”), from the verb garriō (“I chatter”).
en: If you describe someone as garrulous, you mean that they talk a great deal, especially about unimportant things.
example: a garrulous old woman.
syn_a: effusive, loquacious, talkative, voluble

syn: reprimand, reproach, reprove, admonish, remonstrate with, chastise, chide, upbraid, take to task, pull up, castigate, lambaste, read someone the Riot Act, give someone a piece of one's mind, go on at, haul over the coals, criticize, censure
etym: be- +‎ rate (“to scold, upbraid”)
en: If you berate someone, you speak to them angrily about something they have done wrong.
example: Marion berated Joe for the noise he made.
syn_v: castigate, censure, chide, rebuke, reprimand, scold

zh_Hans: 同时用双目的；双目并用的
etym: From French binoculaire.
en: involving, relating to, seeing with or intended for both eyes
example: binocular vision
example_ko: binocular vision

syn: swiftness, speediness, alacrity, quickness, fastness, celerity, velocity, dispatch, promptness, immediacy, expeditiousness, expedition, briskness, sharpness
etym: From Old French celeritee (compare French célérité), from Latin celeritas, from celer (“fast, swift”).
en: rapidity; swiftness; speed
syn_n: alacrity, dispatch, expedience, haste, speed, swiftness

zh_Hans: 愚蠢的；昏庸的；错误的；未经认真考虑的
syn: foolish, stupid, inane, nonsensical, childish, puerile, infantile, idiotic, brainless, mindless, vacuous, imbecilic, asinine, witless, empty-headed, hare-brained
etym: From Latin fatuus (“foolish, silly, simple”).
en: If you describe a person, action, or remark as fatuous, you think that they are extremely silly, showing a lack of intelligence or thought.
example: The Chief was left speechless by this fatuous remark.
example_ko: a fatuous comment/grin
syn_a: foolish, idiotic, inane, ludicrous, silly

ko: [U] 자신이 없음(opp. confidence); 기가 죽음; 삼감, 수줍음(shyness)
syn: bashfulness, unassertiveness, modesty, modestness, self-effacement, humility, humbleness, meekness, timidity, timidness, timorousness, reserve, reticence, introversion
etym: From Latin diffīdentiam (“distrust”), from diffīdere (“to mistrust”), from dis- and fīdere (“to trust”). Attested since ∼1400. The original sense was antonymous with confidence, and the modern sense of ‘distrusting oneself’ dates from the 1650s.[1]
example: He entered the room with a certain diffidence.
example_ko: a diffident manner/smile
syn_n: bashfulness, insecurity, reserve, shyness, timidity

ko: 반론의 여지가 없는, 부인할 수 없는
zh_Hans: 不容置疑的，无可争辩的
syn: incontestable, undeniable, irrefutable, unassailable, beyond dispute, unquestionable, beyond question, indubitable, not in doubt, beyond doubt, beyond a shadow of a doubt, unarguable, inarguable, undebatable, unanswerable
etym: in- +‎ disputable
en: If you say that something is indisputable, you are emphasizing that it is true and cannot be shown to be untrue.
example: It is indisputable that birds in the UK are harbouring this illness
example_ko: indisputable evidence
syn_a: beyond doubt, conclusive, incontrovertible, sure  undeniable

syn: encourage, call on, enjoin, adjure, charge, try to persuade, press, pressure, put pressure on, use pressure on, pressurize, lean on, push
etym: From Old French exhorter, from Latin exhortor (“encourage”), from ex (“out of, from”) + hortor (“incite, spur”).
en: If you exhort someone to do something, you try hard to persuade or encourage them to do it.
example: Kennedy exhorted his listeners to turn away from violence
example_ko: [VN to inf.] The party leader exhorted his members to start preparing for government.
syn_v: admonish, counsel, entreat, persuade, urge

zh_Hans: 费解的；难以捉摸的；神秘的
syn: puzzling, hard to understand, mystifying, inexplicable, baffling, perplexing, bewildering, confusing, impenetrable, inscrutable, incomprehensible, unexplainable, unfathomable, indecipherable, Delphic, oracular
etym: French énigmatique
en: Someone or something that is enigmatic is mysterious and difficult to understand.
example: Haley studied her, an enigmatic smile on his face
example_ko: an enigmatic smile
syn_a: baffling, cryptic, mysterious, paradoxical, puzzling

syn: clutches, hands, control, grip, grasp, yoke
en: If you say that someone is in thrall to a person or thing, you mean that they are completely in their power or are greatly influenced by them.
example: He is not in thrall to the media

zh_Hans: 非典型的；异常的；不同寻常的
syn: untypical, non-typical, uncommon, unconventional, unorthodox, off-centre, anomalous, irregular, abnormal, aberrant, deviant, divergent
etym: a- +‎ typical
en: Someone or something that is atypical is not typical of its kind.
example: The economy of the province was atypical because it was particularly small
example_ko: atypical behaviour

syn: uncommunicative, reticent, unforthcoming, quiet, unresponsive, secretive, silent, tight-lipped, close-mouthed, mute, dumb, inarticulate
etym: Back-formation from taciturnity, from Middle English taciturnite, from Latin taciturnitas; or alternatively from French taciturne, likely reinforced by Latin taciturnus, from tacitus (“secret, tacit”).
en: A taciturn person does not say very much and can seem unfriendly.
example: A taciturn man, he replied to my questions in monosyllables.
syn_a: aloof, laconic, quiet, reserved, shy, uncommunicative

zh_Hans: （尤指人或其行为）淫荡的，放荡的
syn: dissipated, debauched, degenerate, salacious, immoral, wanton, decadent, depraved, profligate, impure, sinful, wicked, corrupt, indecent, libertine
etym: Latin licentiōsus, from licentia (“license, freedom”)
en: If you describe a person as licentious, you mean that they are very immoral, especially in their sexual behaviour.
example: alarming stories of licentious behaviour.
syn_a: debauched, lascivious, promiscuous, prurient, salacious

zh_Hans: （一些广为流传的故事）可疑的，不足为信的，杜撰的
syn: made-up, untrue, fabricated, false, spurious
etym: From Late Latin apocryphus (“secret, not approved for public reading”), from Ancient Greek ἀπόκρυφος (apókruphos, “hidden, obscure”, thus “(books) of unknown authorship”), from ἀπό (apó, “from”) + κρύπτω (krúptō, “I hide”). Properly plural (the singular would be apocryphon), but commonly treated as a collective singular. “Apocryphal” meaning “of doubtful authenticity” is first attested in English in 1590.
en: An apocryphal story is one which is probably not true or did not happen, but which may give a true picture of someone or something.
example_ko: Most of the stories about him are apocryphal.

ko: (이미 한 말을, 특히 강조하기 위해) 반복하다[되풀이하다]
syn: say again, restate, retell, recapitulate, go over, go over and over, iterate, rehearse, belabour, dwell on, harp on, hammer away at
etym: re- +‎ iterate.
en: If you reiterate something, you say it again, usually in order to emphasize it.
example: He reiterated his opposition to the creation of a central bank
example_ko: [VN] to reiterate an argument/a demand/an offer
syn_v: repeat, rephrase, restate  reword

syn: preamble, opening, opening remarks, prefatory remarks, formalities
etym: Borrowed from Old French preambule (French préambule), from Medieval Latin praeambulum, from praeambulō (“I walk before”).
en: A preamble is an introduction that comes before something you say or write.
example: The controversy has arisen over the text of the preamble to the unification treaty
example_ko: The aims of the treaty are stated in its preamble.
syn_n: foreword, opening, preamble, prelude, prologue, meeting, presentation

zh_Hans: 恶意的，恶毒的，意在伤人的
syn: malevolent, hostile, bitter, venomous, poisonous, evil-intentioned, ill-natured, evil, baleful, vindictive, vengeful, vitriolic, rancorous, malign, malignant, pernicious, mean, nasty, harmful, hurtful, mischievous, destructive, wounding, cruel, unkind, defamatory
etym: From Old French malicios, from Latin malitiosus, from malitia (“malice”), from malus (“bad”).
en: If you describe someone's words or actions as malicious, you mean that they are intended to harm people or their reputation, or cause them embarrassment and upset.
example: That might merely have been malicious gossip
example_ko: malicious gossip/lies/rumours
syn_a: baleful, hateful, nasty, spiteful, vicious

syn: strengthen with defensive works, secure, protect, surround
etym: From Old French fortifier
en: To fortify a place means to make it stronger and more difficult to attack, often by building a wall or ditch round it.
example: British soldiers working to fortify an airbase in Bahrain.
example_ko: a fortified town
syn_v: bulwark, reinforce, secure, shield, strengthen, brace, encourage, hearten, reassure, sustain, augment, enhance, enrich, supplement

syn: decomposed, decaying, decayed, rotting, rotten, bad, off, putrefied, putrescent, rancid, mouldy, spoilt
etym: Borrowed from Old French putride, from Latin putridus (“rotten, decayed”), from putreō (“I am rotten or putrid”), from puter (“rotten, decaying, putrid”).
en: Something that is putrid has decayed and smells very unpleasant.
example: a foul, putrid stench.
example_ko: the putrid smell of rotten meat
syn_a: decaying, decomposing, rotten, stagnant, fetid, foul, pungent, rank, stinking

syn: advantageous, favourable, auspicious, propitious, heaven-sent, welcome, golden, good, right, lucky, happy, fortunate, benign, felicitous, timely, well timed, ripe, convenient, expedient
etym: From Latin prōvidentia (“providence”) +‎ -al
en: A providential event is lucky because it happens at exactly the right time.
example: He explained the yellow fever epidemic as a providential act to discourage urban growth
example_ko: to trust in divine providence

ko: <정력·결심 등이> 축 늘어지는, 맥이 빠지는; 줄어드는, 쇠약해 가는
en: flagstones or a flagged area
example: The Marines climbed to the roof of the embassy building to raise the American flag
example_ko: the Italian flag
syn_n: banner, emblem, ensign, pennant, standard
syn_v: signal, wave, decline, languish, wane  wilt

syn: sleeping, slumbering, resting, reposing, drowsing, comatose, supine
etym: From Middle English, from Old French, from Latin dormiēns, present participle of dormiō (“I sleep”).
en: Something that is dormant is not active, growing, or being used at the present time but is capable of becoming active later on.
example: The virus remains dormant in nerve tissue until activated
example_ko: a dormant volcano
syn_a: idle, inactive, latent, lethargic, quiescent, somnolent

syn: rebuke, admonish, chastise, chide, upbraid, reprove, reproach, scold, remonstrate with, berate, take to task, pull up, lambaste, read someone the Riot Act, give someone a piece of one's mind, haul over the coals, lecture, criticize, censure
etym: Early 17th cent., borrowed from Latin castīgātus, past participle of castīgō (“I reprove”), from castus (“pure, chaste”), from Proto-Indo-European *kesa (“cut”)[1][2]. Doublet of chastise, taken through Old French. See also chaste.
en: If you castigate someone or something, you speak to them angrily or criticize them severely.
example: Marx never lost an opportunity to castigate colonialism
example_ko: He castigated himself for being so stupid.
syn_v: admonish, castigate, chide, rebuke, reprimand, reproach

syn: teenage, teenaged, adolescent, junior, underage, pubescent, prepubescent
etym: A juvenile female (adjective sense 1) – a young Aka girl – from the Central African Republic
en: A juvenile is a child or young person who is not yet old enough to be regarded as an adult.
example: The number of juveniles in the general population has fallen by a fifth in the past 10 years.
example_ko: juvenile crime / employment
syn_n: child, minor, youngster, youth
syn_a: adolescent, young, youthful, childish, immature, infantile

zh_Hans: 亲密的；有性关系的；宜于密切关系的
syn: bosom, boon, dear, cherished, familiar, confidential, faithful, constant, devoted, fast, firm, favourite, special
etym: From Latin intimare (“to put or bring into, to impress, to make familiar”), from intimus (“inmost, innermost, most intimate”), superlative of intus (“within”), from in (“in”); see interior.
en: If you have an intimate friendship with someone, you know them very well and like them a lot.
example: I discussed with my intimate friends whether I would immediately have a baby.
example_ko: intimate friends
syn_n: associate, companion, friend, lover
syn_v: imply, insinuate, suggest
syn_a: bosom, close, familiar, trusted, confidential, innermost, inside, intrinsic, private, secret

syn: incorrect, mistaken, in error, inaccurate, not accurate, inexact, not exact, imprecise, invalid, untrue, false, fallacious, wide of the mark, off target
etym: From Old French and Latin erroneus
en: Beliefs, opinions, or methods that are erroneous are incorrect or only partly correct.
example: Some people have the erroneous notion that one can contract AIDS by giving blood
example_ko: erroneous conclusions/assumptions
syn_a: false, faulty, groundless, inaccurate, mistaken, wrong

ko: (동식물에게 생긴 아주 보기 싫은) 이상 성장물[혹], 사마귀
syn: lump, swelling, protuberance, protrusion, knob, nodule, outgrowth
etym: From Middle English, early 15th century, in sense “(action of) growing out (of something else)”. Borrowed from Latin excrescentia (“abnormal growths”), from excrescentem, from excrēscere, from ex- (“out”) (English ex-) + crēscere (“to grow”) (English crescent). Sense of “abnormal growth” from 1570s, from earlier excrescency (1540s in this sense).[1]
en: If you describe something such as a building, addition, or development as an excrescence, you strongly disapprove of it because you think it is unnecessary, bad, or ugly.
example: an architectural excrescence
example_ko: (비유) The new office block is an excrescence.

zh_Hans: （尤指气体或其他物质）有毒的，有害的
syn: toxic, deadly, virulent
etym: From Latin noxius (“hurtful, injurious”), from noxa (“hurt, injury”), from nocere (“to hurt, injure”); see nocent.
en: A noxious gas or substance is poisonous or very harmful.
example: Many household products give off noxious fumes.
example_ko: noxious fumes
syn_a: deleterious, harmful, malignant, nocuous, pernicious, poisonous

zh_Hans: 令人费解的事物，令人困惑的事物
syn: puzzle, riddle, conundrum, paradox, problem, unsolved problem, question, question mark, quandary, a closed book
etym: From Latin aenigma (“riddle”), being derived itself from the Ancient Greek verbal noun αἴνιγμα (aínigma, “dark saying, speaking in riddles”).
en: If you describe something or someone as an enigma, you mean they are mysterious or difficult to understand.
example: Iran remains an enigma for the outside world.
syn_n: dilemma, mystery, puzzle, quandary  riddle

zh_Hans: 特种部队；特殊兵种；军（团）
syn: regiment, battalion, company, troop, division, squadron, squad, platoon, contingent, unit, force, corps, garrison, section, group, detachment, commando, battery, band, outfit, cohort
etym: From French corps d'armée (literally “army body”), from Latin corpus (“body”). Doublet of corpse and corpus. See also English riff.
en: A corps is a part of the army which has special duties.
example: the Army Medical Corps.
example_ko: the commander of the third army corps
syn_n: body, crew, group, team, battalion, brigade, detachment, division, platoon  squad

zh_Hans: 歪歪斜斜地疾行；横冲直撞
syn: tip, list, slope, camber, bank, slant, incline, pitch, dip, cant, bevel, angle, cock, heel, careen, bend, be at an angle
etym: Late 16th century, from French carene (“keel”), from Genoese Ligurian carena, from Latin carina (“keel of a ship”).
en: To careen somewhere means to rush forward in an uncontrollable way.
example: He stood to one side as they careened past him
example_ko: The wall was on the careen.
syn_v: lurch, stagger, sway, weave, lean, list, pitch  tilt

syn: infertile, unfruitful, sterile, arid, desert, waste, desolate, uncultivatable
etym: From Middle English barein, barain, from Old French baraigne, baraing (“sterile; barren”), of obscure origin; probably from a Germanic language, perhaps Frankish *bar (“bare; barren”), from Proto-Germanic *bazaz (“bare”). More at bare.
en: A barren landscape is dry and bare, and has very few plants and no trees.
example: the Tibetan landscape of high barren mountains.
example_ko: a barren desert
syn_a: arid, desert, unproductive, childless, infertile, sterile, bare, empty, stark, void, deficient, lacking, wanting, bereft, destitute, devoid

zh_Hans: （尤指宗教或法律上）为（某人）解罪；赦免（某人）的罪；宣告（某人）无罪；免除（某人）的责任
syn: discharge, acquit, exculpate, vindicate
etym: First attested in the early 15th Century. From Middle English absolven, from Latin absolvere, present active infinitive of absolvō (“set free, acquit”), from ab (“away from”) + solvō (“loosen, free, release”).
en: If a report or investigation absolves someone from blame or responsibility, it formally states that he or she is not guilty or is not to blame.
example: A police investigation yesterday absolved the police of all blame in the incident.
example_ko: The court absolved him of all responsibility for the accident.
syn_v: acquit, clear, exonerate, vindicate, forgive, pardon, shrive, excuse, exempt, release

syn: enchant, entrance, enrapture, charm, beguile, delight, fascinate, enthral, seduce, ravish, spellbind, hold spellbound, mesmerize, hypnotize, transfix
etym: From Middle English bewicchen; equivalent to be- +‎ witch.
en: If someone or something bewitches you, you are so attracted to them that you cannot think about anything else.
example: She was not moving, as if someone had bewitched her
example_ko: He was completely bewitched by her beauty.
syn_v: curse, enchant, hex, jinx, possess, beguile, captivate, charm, entice  fascinate

syn: damaging, deleterious, detrimental, hurtful, dangerous
etym: From Middle English injurious, from Anglo-Norman enjurius, from Latin iniūriōsus; analysable as injury +‎ -ous.
en: Something that is injurious to someone or to their health or reputation is harmful or damaging to them.
example: substances that are injurious to health
example_ko: serious injury/injuries
syn_a: damaging, deleterious, destructive, detrimental, harmful, defamatory, denigrating, libelous, slanderous

syn: raucous, rough, grating, rasping, jarring, loud, stentorian, shrill, screeching, piercing, ear-piercing
etym: From French strident, from Latin strīdēns, present active participle of strīdō.
en: If you use strident to describe someone or the way they express themselves, you mean that they make their feelings or opinions known in a very strong way that perhaps makes people uncomfortable.
example: the unnecessarily strident tone of the President's remarks
example_ko: a strident voice
syn_a: cacophonous, discordant, dissonant, harsh, piercing, shrill

syn: upholder, supporter, backer, promoter, proponent, exponent, protector, patron
etym: Borrowed from Old French advocat, from Latin advocātus (past participle of advocāre (“to call for”)), a calque of Ancient Greek παράκλητος (paráklētos) (whence English paraclete). Doublet of advoke, avouch, and avow.
en: If you advocate a particular action or plan, you recommend it publicly.
example: Mr Williams is a conservative who advocates fewer government controls on business.
example_ko: [VN] The group does not advocate the use of violence.
syn_n: defender, patron, proponent, supporter, attorney, counselor, lawyer
syn_v: champion, encourage, support, uphold, advance, promote, recommend, urge

zh_Hans: 单色的；单色光的；单频的；单能的
etym: From mono- +‎ chromatic, mono- from Ancient Greek μόνος (mónos, “alone, only, sole, single”), chromatic from Ancient Greek χρῶμα (khrôma, “color”).
en: Also : homochromatic (of light or other electromagnetic radiation) having only one wavelength

syn: the whole truth, the naked truth, gospel truth, God's truth, the honest truth
etym: Borrowing from Anglo-Norman verité or Middle French verité, from Old French verité, from Latin vēritās, from the adjective vērus (“true”).
en: The verities of something are all the things that are believed to be true about it.
example: some verities of human nature.
example_ko: the eternal verities of life
syn_n: actuality, authenticity, fact, truth, verity, corporeality, materiality, tangibility

zh_Hans: （文章或讲话的）含意，弦外之音；（事件或情况的）蕴含意义
syn: murmur, whisper, mutter
etym: under- +‎ tone
en: If you say something in an undertone, you say it very quietly.
example: What d'you think?' she asked in an undertone
example_ko: His soft words contained an undertone of warning.

syn: loyal, faithful, committed, devoted, dedicated, dependable, reliable, steady, constant, trusty, hard-working, vigorous, stable, firm, steadfast, redoubtable, resolute, unswerving, unwavering, unhesitating, unfaltering
etym: From Scots stalwart, from Middle English stal-worth (“physically strong, hardy, robust; brave, courageous”), from Old English stǣlwierþe (“able to stand in good stead, serviceable”),[1] probably from staþol (“establishment; foundation”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *steh₂- (“to stand (up)”)) or stǣl (“place; condition, stead”) + -wierþe (“suffix meaning ‘able to, capable of’”) (probably ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wert- (“to rotate, turn”)).
en: A stalwart is a loyal worker or supporter of an organization, especially a political party.
example: His free-trade policies aroused suspicion among Tory stalwarts
syn_a: faithful, loyal, staunch, steadfast, true, brave, courageous, intrepid, stouthearted, valiant, husky, robust, stout, sturdy

zh_Hans: （为给伤口止血或防止感染而）烙，烧灼
syn: sear, singe, scorch
etym: From Middle French cauteriser, from Late Latin cauterizō (“to burn with a hot iron”), from Ancient Greek καυτηριάζω (kautēriázō, “to brand”), from καυτήρ (kautḗr, “branding iron”), from καίειν (kaíein, “to burn”).
en: If a doctor cauterizes a wound, he or she burns it with heat or with a chemical in order to close it up and prevent it from becoming infected.
example: He cauterized the wound with a piece of red-hot iron.

syn: be in agreement, be in accord, be in accordance, accord, go along, fall in, be in harmony, be in sympathy
etym: Borrowed from Latin concurro (“to run together, agree”).
en: If one person concurs with another person, the two people agree. You can also say that two people concur.
example: Local feeling does not necessarily concur with the press
example_ko: [V] Historians have concurred with each other in this view.
syn_v: acknowledge, admit, concede, recognize, accede, acquiesce, allow, assent, coincide, concur, harmonize, accord, conform, correspond, fit

syn: quirk, idiosyncrasy, eccentricity, oddity, foible, whim, whimsy, caprice, vagary, twist, crotchet, mannerism, fad
etym: First attested in 1604, in modern sense since 1665, from Old French idiosyncrasie, from Ancient Greek ἰδιοσυγκρασία (idiosunkrasía, “one’s own temperament”), from ἴδιος (ídios, “one’s own”) + σύν (sún, “together”) + κρᾶσις (krâsis, “temperament”).
en: If you talk about the idiosyncrasies of someone or something, you are referring to their rather unusual habits or characteristics.
example: Everyone has a few little idiosyncrasies
example_ko: The car has its little idiosyncrasies.
syn_n: eccentricity, peculiarity, quirk, singularity, characteristic, trait, disposition, habit  tendency

syn: measuring device, meter, measure
etym: The original meaning was 'sundial' and/or 'clock dial'; from Middle English diall, from Middle French dyal, from Latin diālis (“daily, concerning the day”), because of its use in telling the time of day, from Latin diēs (“day”). Compare Spanish dial and día (“day”).
en: A dial is the part of a machine or instrument such as a clock or watch which shows you the time or a measurement that has been recorded.
example: The luminous dial on the clock showed five minutes to seven
example_ko: an alarm clock with a luminous dial
syn_n: bump, lump, protuberance, swelling, dial, grip, handle, hill, knoll, mountain, prominence

zh_Hans: 无名的；鲜为人知的；默默无闻的
syn: uncertain, unknown, in doubt, doubtful, dubious, mysterious, hazy, vague, indeterminate, concealed, hidden
etym: From Old French obscur, from Latin obscūrus (“dark, dusky, indistinct”), possibly, from ob (“over”) + -scurus (“covered”), from root scu (“cover”), seen also in scutum (“a shield”); see scutum, sky.
en: If something or someone is obscure, they are unknown, or are known by only a few people.
example: The origin of the custom is obscure
example_ko: an obscure German poet
syn_v: darken, dim, eclipse, overshadow, camouflage, cloak, conceal, screen, shroud
syn_a: ambiguous, cryptic, enigmatic, recondite, veiled, forgotten, little-known, unfamiliar, unknown, unrenowned, unsung, cloudy, dim, indefinite, indistinct, vague

zh_Hans: 目光敏锐的；洞察力强的
syn: perceptive, shrewd, discerning, perspicacious, sharp, sharp-witted, acute, penetrating, discriminating, clear-sighted, clear-eyed, far-sighted, intelligent, clever, canny, intuitive, quick, alert, sensible, judicious, wise, sagacious, sage, incisive, sharp-sighted, far-seeing, open-eyed, understanding, responsive, sensitive
etym: From Latin percipiēns, present participle of percipiō (“to perceive”).
en: able to perceive

zh_Hans: （尤指失败或错误引起的）失望，懊丧，懊恼
syn: irritation, vexation, exasperation, displeasure, pique, spleen, crossness, anger, rage, fury, wrath
etym: From French chagrin (“sorrow”), from Middle French chagrin (“pain, affliction”) (compare Middle French chagriner, chagrigner (“to experience sorrow”), Old French chagrin (“painful, afflicted”)), probably derived from Old Northern French chagreiner, chagraigner (“to sadden”)[1], of uncertain origin. Likely an enlargement of Old French greignier, graignier (“to cringe, growl, be sullen, be angry, grieve over”)[2], from Old French graigne (“sadness, resentment, grief”), from graim (“sorrowful”), related to Old High German gram (“furious, gloomy, grieved”)[3]. The initial syllable is obscure. It may represent Old French chat (“cat”) to express the idea of "lamenting or yowling like cats" (compare German Katzenjammer (“distress, frustration, depression, chagrin”, literally “cat-wailing, cat-misery”), katzbalgen (“to cat-fight”))[4].
en: Chagrin is a feeling of disappointment, upset, or annoyance, perhaps because of your own failure.
example: One of the first things we did when we moved in, to the chagrin of the architect, was to replace the leaded windows.
example_ko: The experiment was a failure, to his chagrin.
syn_n: embarrassment, humiliation, mortification, shame, aggravation, annoyance, frustration, irritation, dejection, disappointment, dismay, distress
syn_v: abash, discomfit, disconcert  embarrass

zh_Hans: 自命不凡的，自大的；装模作样的
syn: warning, foreshadowing, predictive, premonitory, prognosticatory, momentous, fateful
etym: Borrowed from Latin portentōsus, from portentus; equivalent to portent +‎ -ous.
en: If someone's way of speaking, writing, or behaving is portentous, they speak, write, or behave more seriously than necessary because they want to impress other people.
example: There was nothing portentous or solemn about him. He was bubbling with humour.
example_ko: a portentous sign
syn_a: foreboding, ominous, prophetic, threatening, consequential, crucial, major, momentous, amazing, incredible, phenomenal, bombastic, pompous, pretentious

etym: anthropo- +‎ -centric.
en: regarding man as the most important and central factor in the universe

zh_Hans: （人）贪赃的，腐败的，见利忘义的
syn: corruptible, bribable, open to bribery, purchasable, buyable, grafting
en: If you describe someone as venal, you disapprove of them because they are prepared to do almost anything in return for money, even things which are dishonest or immoral.
example: Ian Trimmer is corrupt and thoroughly venal.
example_ko: venal journalists
syn_a: corrupt, mercenary, unscrupulous, avaricious, covetous, greedy, selfish

syn: irascible, fractious, fretful, cross, petulant, pettish, crabbed, crabby, crotchety, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, disagreeable, miserable, morose, peppery, on edge, edgy, impatient, complaining, querulous
etym: From Middle English pevische, pevisse, pevysse, peivesshe, also peyuesshe, peeuish, of obscure origin. Perhaps from Middle English pew, pue (“a plaintive cry, the cry of a bird”), equivalent to pue +‎ -ish. Cognate with Scots pevis, pevess, pevych, pevach (“peevish”), Scots pew, peu (“to cry in a plaintive manner”). See pue.
en: Someone who is peevish is bad-tempered.
example: Aubrey had slept little and that always made him peevish
syn_a: cantankerous, cross, grouchy, irritable, quarrelsome, testy, waspish

syn: pacify, placate, mollify, appease, conciliate
etym: From Latin dulcificāre.
en: to make pleasant or agreeable

zh_Hans: 死尸般的；惨白的；形容枯槁的
syn: deathly pale, pallid, white, bloodless, ashen, ashen-faced, ashy, chalky, chalk white, grey, white-faced, whey-faced, waxen, waxy, corpse-like, deathlike, ghostly
etym: cadaver +‎ -ous
en: If you describe someone as cadaverous, you mean they are extremely thin and pale.
example: a tall man with a long, cadaverous face.
syn_a: drawn, emaciated, gaunt, haggard, ashen, pale, sallow

zh_Hans: 武断的；自以为是的；教条的
syn: peremptory, assertive, imperative, insistent, emphatic, adamant, doctrinaire, authoritarian, authoritative, domineering, imperious, high-handed, pontifical, arrogant, overbearing, dictatorial, uncompromising, unyielding, unbending, inflexible, rigid, entrenched, unquestionable, unchallengeable
etym: From French dogmatique, from Late Latin dogmaticus, from Hellenistic Ancient Greek δογματικός (dogmatikós, “didactic”), from δόγμα (dógma, “dogma”).
en: If you say that someone is dogmatic, you are critical of them because they are convinced that they are right, and refuse to consider that other opinions might also be justified.
example: Many writers at this time held rigidly dogmatic views
example_ko: a dogmatic approach
syn_a: biased, emphatic, imperious, insistent, intolerant, opinionated, stubborn

zh_Hans: 不容置疑地;毫无疑问地
etym: indubitable +‎ -ly
example: His behaviour was indubitably ill-judged.
example_ko: He was, indubitably, the most suitable candidate.
syn_a: absolute, certain, indisputable, irrefutable, positive, unquestionable

syn: plague, scourge, infestation
etym: From French épidémique, from épidémie, from Latin epidemia, from Ancient Greek ἐπιδήμιος (epidḗmios), from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + δῆμος (dêmos, “people”).
en: If there is an epidemic of a particular disease somewhere, it affects a very large number of people there and spreads quickly to other areas.
example: A flu epidemic is sweeping through Moscow.
example_ko: the outbreak of a flu epidemic
syn_n: disease, outbreak, pestilence, plague, sickness, increase, rise, upsurge  upswing
syn_a: extensive, increasing, prevalent, rampant, widespread

syn: pietist, whited sepulchre, plaster saint, humbug, pretender, deceiver, dissembler, impostor
etym: Old French ypocrite (Modern French hypocrite), from Ecclesiastical Latin hypocrita, from Ancient Greek ὑποκριτής (hupokritḗs, “actor, hypocrite”), from ὑποκρίνομαι (hupokrínomai, “I answer, act, feign”).
en: If you accuse someone of being a hypocrite, you mean that they pretend to have qualities, beliefs, or feelings that they do not really have.
example_ko: They played the hypocrite to deceive us.
syn_n: deceiver, fraud, pharisee, phony  pretender

zh_Hans: 为两党派所支持的；包括两个党派的
etym: From bi- +‎ partisan.
en: Bipartisan means concerning or involving two different political parties or groups.
example: a bipartisan approach to educational reform.
example_ko: a bipartisan policy

zh_Hans: 公开放弃，声明放弃（信念、行为、活动）
syn: relinquish, reject, dispense with, forgo, forswear, disavow, abandon, deny, gainsay, disclaim, repudiate, give up, spurn, abnegate, wash one's hands of, drop, do away with
etym: From Middle English abjuren, from Latin abiūrō (“deny upon oath”) (possibly via Middle French abjurer), formed from ab (“from, away from”) + iūro (“swear or take an oath”), from iūs (“law, right, duty”).[1]
en: If you abjure something such as a belief or way of life, you state publicly that you will give it up or that you reject it.
example: a formal statement abjuring military action.
example_ko: It was hard for him to abjure the realm and emigrate.
syn_v: disavow, forswear, renounce, repudiate, abandon, desert, forsake, relinquish

zh_Hans: 使回忆起(人或事);回忆过去的;怀旧的;缅怀往事的
syn: comparable with, bearing comparison with, inviting comparison with, tending to make one think of
etym: From Latin reminīscēns, present participle of reminīscor (“remember”), from re- (“again”) + min-, base of me-min-isse (“to remember, think over”), akin to mens (“mind”); see mental, mind, etc.
en: If you say that one thing is reminiscent of another, you mean that it reminds you of it.
example: The decor was reminiscent of a municipal arts-and-leisure centre
example_ko: The way he laughed was strongly reminiscent of his father.

syn: predate, come before, go before, be earlier than, anticipate
etym: ante- +‎ date
en: to be or occur at an earlier date than
example_ko: Few of the town’s fine buildings pre-date the earthquake of 1755.

zh_Hans: （疾病）大规模流行的，广泛蔓延的
syn: prevalent, pervasive, rife, rampant, epidemic
etym: From Late Latin pandēmus (“affecting all the people, public, general”), from Ancient Greek πᾶν (pân, “all”) (equivalent to English pan-) + δῆμος (dêmos, “the people”).
en: A pandemic is an occurrence of a disease that affects many people over a very wide area.
example: They feared a new cholera pandemic

zh_Hans: 扰嚷;(表示抗议,支持等的)叫喊
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：clam 呼喊，叫喊 + or 表情况 → 喧哗，吵闹
syn: racket, loud noise, uproar, tumult, babel, shouting, yelling, screaming, baying, roaring, blaring, clangour
etym: Recorded in English since c. 1385, from Old French clamor (modern clameur), from Latin clāmor (“a shout, cry”), from clāmō (“cry out, complain”); the sense to silence may have a distinct (unknown) etymology.
en: If people are clamouring for something, they are demanding it in a noisy or angry way.
example: competing parties clamouring for the attention of the voter
example_ko: [V] People began to clamour for his resignation.
syn_n: bedlam, commotion, din, tumult, uproar
syn_v: call, cry, howl, yell

etym: From Latin centrum (“center”) + fugiō (“to flee”)  +‎ -al, probably coined by Christiaan Huygens.
en: acting, moving, or tending to move away from a centre Compare centripetal
example: The juice is extracted by centrifugal force.

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：umbr 影子 + age 表状态 → 树荫；不快〔心中有影子〕
syn: be offended, take exception, bridle, take something personally, be aggrieved, be affronted, take something amiss, be upset, be annoyed, be angry, be indignant, get one's hackles up, be put out, be insulted, be hurt, be wounded, be piqued, be resentful, be disgruntled, get into a huff, go into a huff, get huffy
etym: Borrowed from Middle French ombrage (“umbrage”), from Old French ombrage, from Latin umbrāticus (“in the shade”), from umbra (“shadow, shade”).
en: If you say that a person takes umbrage, you mean that they are upset or offended by something that someone says or does to them, often without much reason.
example: He takes umbrage against anyone who criticises him.
example_ko: His gesture wasn't necessary and it would have made people doubts of giving umbrage to others.

etym: From New Latin anthropologia, from anthropo- (from Ancient Greek ἄνθρωπος (ánthrōpos, “man, mankind, human, humanity”)) + -logy (from Ancient Greek -λογία (-logía)).
en: Anthropology is the scientific study of people, society, and culture.
example: an anthropologist who had been in China for three years.

zh_Hans: （常指结伴同行的）远足，短程旅行
syn: outing, jaunt, expedition, journey, tour
etym: Borrowed from Latin excursio (“a running out, an inroad, invasion, a setting out, beginning of a speech”), from excurrere (“to run out”), from ex (“out”) + currere (“to run”).
en: You can refer to a short journey as an excursion, especially if it is made for pleasure or enjoyment.
example: In Bermuda, Sam's father took him on an excursion to a coral barrier.
example_ko: They’ve gone on an excursion to York.
syn_n: expedition, jaunt, journey, junket, outing, trip  voyage

zh_Hans: （尤指国家的）霸权，支配权，领导权
syn: dominance, dominion, supremacy, ascendancy, predominance, primacy, authority, mastery, control, power, sway, rule, sovereignty
etym: From Ancient Greek ἡγεμονία (hēgemonía, “supremacy or leadership, chief command”), from ἡγεμών (hēgemṓn, “a leader, guide, commander, chief”), from ἡγέομαι (hēgéomai, “to lead”).
en: Hegemony is a situation in which one country, organization, or group has more power, control, or importance than others.
syn_n: ascendancy, dominance, preeminence  superiority

ko: …에 언짢은 표정을 짓다, 무안을 주다; …에 찬성하지 않다, …을 승인하지 않다
syn: frown on, take a dim view of, be against, not believe in, object to, find unacceptable, think wrong
etym: From Middle French descontenancer (compare French décontenancer).
en: to make ashamed or confused

zh_Hans: （尤指因为某人没成功或没达到预期目标而）责备，责怪，批评
syn: have a poor opinion of, dislike, be against, object to, find unacceptable, think wrong, take exception to, not believe in, not support, frown on, take a dim view of, look askance at
etym: Old French reprochier (Modern reprocher).
en: If you reproach someone, you say or show that you are disappointed, upset, or angry because they have done something wrong.
example: She is quick to reproach anyone who doesn't live up to her own high standards
example_ko: His voice was full of reproach.
syn_n: criticism, disapproval, rebuke, reproof, disgrace, embarrassment, shame, stigma
syn_v: chide, condemn, criticize, rebuke, reprimand

zh_Hans: 当地的；本土的，土生土长的
syn: aboriginal, local
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin indigenus (“native, born in a country”), from indi- (indu-), an old derivative of in (“in”), gen- the root of gignō (“give birth to”), and English -ous. Compare indigene, Ancient Greek ἐνδογενής (endogenḗs, “born in the house”), and the separately formed endogenous.
en: Indigenous people or things belong to the country in which they are found, rather than coming there or being brought there from another country.
example: the country's indigenous population.
example_ko: the indigenous peoples/languages of the area
syn_a: endemic, local, native, inborn, inherent, innate, intrinsic

syn: irascible, tetchy, testy, touchy, scratchy, grumpy, grouchy, moody, crotchety, in a mood, in a bad mood, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, ill-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, peevish, having got out of bed on the wrong side, cross, as cross as two sticks, fractious, disagreeable, pettish, crabbed, crabby, waspish, prickly, peppery, crusty, splenetic, shrewish, short-tempered, hot-tempered, quick-tempered, dyspeptic, choleric, bilious, liverish, cross-grained
etym: Borrowed from French irritable, from Latin irritabilis
en: If you are irritable, you are easily annoyed.
example: He had been waiting for over an hour and was beginning to feel irritable.
example_ko: to be tired and irritable
syn_a: cantankerous, irascible, oversensitive, peevish, testy, touchy

syn: self-contradictory, inconsistent, incongruous, anomalous, conflicting
etym: paradox +‎ -ical
en: If something is paradoxical, it involves two facts or qualities which seem to contradict each other.
example: Some sedatives produce the paradoxical effect of making the person more anxious
example_ko: He was a paradox—a loner who loved to chat to strangers.
syn_n: contradiction, incongruity, inconsistency, ambiguity, dilemma  puzzle

syn: hackneyed, clichéd, platitudinous, vapid, commonplace, ordinary, common, stock, conventional, stereotyped, predictable, overused, overdone, overworked, stale, worn out, time-worn, tired, threadbare, hoary, hack, unimaginative, unoriginal, derivative, uninspired, prosaic, dull, boring, pedestrian, run-of-the-mill, routine, humdrum
etym: Borrowed from French banal, from Medieval Latin bannalis (“pertaining to compulsory feudal service, applied especially to mills, wells, ovens, etc., used in common by people of the lower classes, upon the command of a feudal superior; hence, common, commonplace”), from bannum (“command, proclamation”). See also ban, abandon.
en: If you describe something as banal, you do not like it because you think that it is so ordinary that it is not at all effective or interesting.
example: Bland, banal music tinkled discreetly from hidden loudspeakers.
syn_a: fatuous, insipid, ordinary, trite, vapid

syn: peripatetic, wandering, wayfaring, roving, roaming, rambling, touring, nomadic, gypsy, migrant, migratory, ambulatory
etym: From Late Latin itinerāntem, from itinerāns, present active participle of itineror (“I travel”). See also itinerate, itinerary.
en: An itinerant worker travels around a region, working for short periods in different places.
example: the author's experiences as an itinerant musician.
example_ko: itinerant workers/musicians
syn_n: rover, transient, vagabond, wanderer
syn_a: migrant, roving, traveling, vagrant, wandering

syn: irregular, fitful, spasmodic, broken, fragmentary, discontinuous, disconnected, isolated, odd, random, patchy, scattered
etym: From Middle French intermittent, from Latin intermittens (“sending between”), from prefix inter- (“among, on”), plus present participle mittens (“sending”), from mittere (“to send”).
en: Something that is intermittent happens occasionally rather than continuously.
example: After three hours of intermittent rain, the game was abandoned.
example_ko: intermittent bursts of applause
syn_a: alternating, cyclic, interrupted, periodic, rhythmic, sporadic

zh_Hans: 屈从，屈服；放弃抵抗；承认失败
syn: give in, give way, submit, surrender, capitulate, cave in
etym: From Old French succomber, from Latin succumbō.
en: If you succumb to temptation or pressure, you do something that you want to do, or that other people want you to do, although you feel it might be wrong.
example: Don't succumb to the temptation to have just one cigarette
example_ko: The town succumbed after a short siege.
syn_v: capitulate, give in, relent, surrender, yield, die, expire, perish

syn: declaim, protest, rail, rage, remonstrate, storm
etym: From Latin invehō (“bring in, carry in”), from in- + vehō (“carry”). Compare vehicle, invective.
en: If you inveigh against something, you criticize it strongly.
example: A lot of his writings inveigh against luxury and riches.
syn_v: abuse, belittle, castigate, criticize, denounce, rebuke

ko: (큰 방 한 쪽을 칸막이 해 만든) 좁은 방
zh_Hans: （大房间中分隔出来的）小房间，小隔间
syn: oubliette, lock-up, prison
etym: Borrowed from Latin cubiculum (“bedroom”), from cubō (“lie down”). Doublet of cubiculum, an unadapted borrowing.
en: A cubicle is a very small enclosed area, for example one where you can have a shower or change your clothes.
example: a separate shower cubicle
example_ko: a shower cubicle

syn: features, physiognomy, profile
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman countenance, from Old French, from the present participle of contenir, or from Late Latin continentia, and therefore a doublet of continence.
en: If someone will not countenance something, they do not agree with it and will not allow it to happen.
example: Jake would not countenance Janis's marrying while still a student.
syn_n: air, aspect, expression, mien, approval, endorsement, support
syn_v: condone, endorse, permit, sanction

etym: Borrowed from French faux pas (“faux pas, blunder; misstep, false step”), from faux (“false, wrong”) and pas (“step”).
en: A faux pas is a socially embarrassing action or mistake.
example: It was not long before I realised the enormity of my faux pas.

etym: See altruism.
en: Altruism is unselfish concern for other people's happiness and welfare.
syn_n: benefactor, good Samaritan, humanitarian  philanthropist

syn: dried up, waterless, as dry as a bone, moistureless, parched, scorched, baked, thirsty
etym: Ultimately from the Latin term āridus (“dry, arid, parched”), confer its synonymous contracted form ardus. Originally from the verb āreo (“I am dry, I am parched”), akin to ārdeō (“I am on fire, I burn”).
en: Arid land is so dry that very few plants can grow on it.
example: new strains of crops that can withstand arid conditions.
example_ko: arid and semi-arid deserts
syn_a: barren, desert, dry, parched, boring, dull, tedious, vapid

etym: From Ancient Greek χρωματικός (khrōmatikós), from χρῶμα (khrôma, “colour”).
en: In music, chromatic means related to the scale that consists only of semitones.
example: the notes of the chromatic scale.

zh_Hans: 可共存的；协调的；相容的
syn: suited, well matched, like-minded, of the same mind, in agreement, in tune, in harmony, reconcilable
etym: from Middle French compatible, from Medieval Latin compatibilis (“in compatible beneficium, a benefice which could be held together with another one”), from Late Latin compati (“to suffer with”)
en: If things, for example systems, ideas, and beliefs, are compatible, they work well together or can exist together successfully.
example: Free enterprise, he argued, was compatible with Russian values and traditions
example_ko: compatible software
syn_a: agreeable, congruous, harmonious, appropriate, fitting, suitable

syn: chop down, hack down, saw down, knock down, hew, demolish, tear down, bring down, raze, level, clear
etym: From Proto-Albanian *spesla, metathesized form of *spelsa, from Proto-Indo-European *pels (“rock, boulder”), variant of *spel- (“to cleave, break”). Compare Latin hydronym Pelso, Latin Palatium, Pashto پرښه‎ (parša, “rock, rocky ledge”), Ancient Greek πέλλα (pélla, “stone”), German Felsen (“boulder, cliff”). Mostly dialectal, used in Gheg Albanian.
en: Fell is the past tense of fall.
example: Her father fell into the sea after a massive heart attack
example_ko: with one's fell look
syn_v: down, flatten, floor, level, chop, cut, hack, hew
syn_a: barbarous, cruel, fierce, savage, deadly, lethal, mortal, noxious

zh_Hans: 激烈的；尖刻的；充满火药味的
