syn: rancorous, caustic, acerbic, scathing, sarcastic, acid, harsh, sharp, razor-edged, cutting, astringent, trenchant, mordant, virulent
etym: An acrimonious argument (sense 2)
en: Acrimonious words or quarrels are bitter and angry.
example: There followed an acrimonious debate.
example_ko: His parents went through an acrimonious divorce.
syn_a: caustic, mordant, rancorous, sarcastic, cranky, irascible, peevish, testy

zh_Hans: 使欣喜若狂;使兴高采烈
syn: give great pleasure to, give joy to, please greatly, charm, enchant, captivate, enthral, entrance, bewitch, beguile, transport, ravish, thrill, excite, exhilarate, intoxicate, take someone's breath away
etym: en- +‎ rapture
en: If something or someone enraptures you, you think they are wonderful or fascinating.
example: The place at once enraptured me
example_ko: Charles listened with rapture to her singing.
syn_v: captivate, charm, delight, enthrall  fascinate

syn: most favourable, most advantageous, most appropriate, ideal, perfect, prime, optimal, model
etym: From New Latin, neuter of Latin optimus (“best, very good”), from the root or in ops (“work”), omnis (“all”).
en: The optimum or optimal level or state of something is the best level or state that it could achieve.
example: Aim to do some physical activity three times a week for optimum health.
example_ko: optimum growth
syn_a: best, ideal, peak, prime, select

zh_Hans: 一无所有的，赤贫的，一贫如洗的
syn: impoverished, poverty-stricken, poor, impecunious, indigent, down and out, pauperized, without a penny to one's name, without two farthings to rub together, without two pennies to rub together
etym: From Latin dēstitūtus.
en: Someone who is destitute has no money or possessions.
example: destitute children who live on the streets.
example_ko: When he died, his family was left completely destitute.
syn_a: destitute, impoverished, indigent, needy, penniless, meager, scant, sparse, miserable, pathetic, wretched, faulty, inadequate, inferior, shoddy, substandard

zh_Hans: 水栖的；水生的；水上的；水中（进行）的
etym: Borrowed from Middle French aquatique (“living in water”), from Latin aquaticus (“relating to water”), from aqua (“water”)
en: An aquatic animal or plant lives or grows on or in water.
example: aquatic birds.
example_ko: aquatic plants/life/ecosystems

zh_Hans: （尤指喜悦）言语难以表达的，不可言喻的
syn: indescribable, beyond words, beyond description, beggaring description
etym: From Middle French ineffable (modern French ineffable), from Latin ineffābilis, from in- (“not”) +‎ effor (“utter”) +‎ -bilis (“-able”).
en: You use ineffable to say that something is so great or extreme that it cannot be described in words.
example: the ineffable sadness of many of the portraits.
example_ko: ineffable joy
syn_a: indescribable, inexpressible, nameless, transcendent, unspeakable, unutterable

syn: complaining, pettish, touchy, testy, tetchy, waspish, prickly, crusty, peppery, fractious, fretful, irritable, cross, crabbed, crabby, crotchety, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, disagreeable, miserable, morose, on edge, edgy, impatient, bitter, moody, in a bad mood, grumpy, huffy, scratchy, out of sorts, out of temper, ill-tempered, bad-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, sullen, surly, sulky, sour, churlish, bilious, liverish, dyspeptic, splenetic, choleric
etym: From Old French querelos, from Late Latin querulōsus, from Latin querulus, from queror (“I complain”).
en: Someone who is querulous often complains about things.
example: A querulous male voice said, 'Look, are you going to order, or what?'
syn_a: crotchety, difficult, disagreeable, irritable, peevish, testy, caviling, complaining, finicky, grumbling, whining

zh_Hans: 表面上的；假称的，假托的
syn: seeming, outward, surface, superficial, professed, supposed, avowed, presumed, so-called, alleged, declared, claimed, purported, pretended, feigned, specious
etym: Borrowed from French ostensible, formed, with the suffix -ible, from Latin ostensus, the past participle of ostendō (“show”), itself from obs- (“in front of”) (akin to ob- (“in the way”) and to Ancient Greek ἐπί (epí, “on, at, besides, after”) and Old English eofot (“crime”)) + tendō (“stretch”) (akin to Ancient Greek τείνω (teínō)). Cf. also Medieval Latin ostensibilis.
en: Ostensible is used to describe something that seems to be true or is officially stated to be true, but about which you or other people have doubts.
example: The ostensible purpose of these meetings was to gather information on financial strategies.
example_ko: The ostensible reason for his absence was illness.
syn_a: apparent, nominal, outward, seeming, alleged, pretended, professed, supposed

zh_Hans: 发脾气的(尤因未能遂愿);使性子的
syn: irascible, tetchy, testy, touchy, scratchy, grumpy, grouchy, moody, crotchety, in a mood, in a bad mood, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, ill-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, peevish, having got out of bed on the wrong side, cross, as cross as two sticks, fractious, disagreeable, pettish, crabbed, crabby, waspish, prickly, peppery, crusty, splenetic, shrewish, short-tempered, hot-tempered, quick-tempered, dyspeptic, choleric, bilious, liverish, cross-grained
etym: pet +‎ -ish
en: peevish; petulant
example: a pettish child
syn_n: darling, favorite, minion
syn_v: caress, fondle, pat, stroke
syn_a: choice, favored  preferred

zh_Hans: 使…负担沉重；妨碍，阻碍；拖累
syn: hinder, obstruct, impede, check, cramp, inhibit, restrict, limit, constrain, restrain, bog down, retard, slow, slow down, stall, delay
etym: From Middle English encombren, from Old French encombrer, from en- + combrer (“to hinder”); see cumber.
en: If you are encumbered by something, it prevents you from moving freely or doing what you want.
example: Lead weights and air cylinders encumbered the divers as they walked to the shore
example_ko: The police operation was encumbered by crowds of reporters.
syn_v: burden, hinder, impede, obstruct, oppress

zh_Hans: 暗示死亡的；坟墓似的；阴森森的
syn: lugubrious, sombre, melancholy, melancholic, sad, sorrowful, mournful, doleful, mirthless, cheerless, joyless, funereal, dismal
etym: From Latin sepulcralis.
en: Something that is sepulchral is serious or sad and rather frightening.
example: He's gone,' Rory whispered in sepulchral tones.
example_ko: He spoke in sepulchral tones.

etym: From Middle French vénération, from Old French veneracion, from Latin veneratio.
example: Churchill was held in near veneration during his lifetime.
syn_n: adoration, awe, homage, honor, respect, reverence, worship

syn: apprehension, dread, fearfulness, apprehensiveness, agitation, anxiety, worry, nervousness, tension, misgivings, unease, uneasiness, foreboding, disquiet, disquietude, perturbation, discomposure, dismay, consternation, alarm, panic, trembling, jumpiness
etym: Borrowed from Latin trepidātiō, from trepidō (“be agitated”)
en: Trepidation is fear or anxiety about something that you are going to do or experience.
example: It was with some trepidation that I viewed the prospect of cycling across Uganda.
syn_n: anxiety, apprehension, disquiet, worry, alarm, dread, fear, panic

syn: temperance, sobriety, abstemiousness, abstention
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French abstinence, from Latin abstinentia, from abstinēns, present participle of abstineō (“I withhold”). Equivalent to abstain +‎ -ence.
en: Abstinence is the practice of abstaining from something such as alcoholic drink or sex, often for health or religious reasons.
example: six months of abstinence.
example_ko: total abstinence from strong drink
syn_n: continence, control, discipline, forbearance, moderation, restraint, temperance

zh_Hans: 阴郁的；脾气不好的；孤僻的
syn: sulky, gloomy, bad-tempered, ill-tempered, in a bad mood, dour, surly, sour, glum, moody, unsmiling, humourless, uncommunicative, taciturn, unresponsive, unsociable, scowling, glowering, ill-humoured, sombre, sober, saturnine, pessimistic, lugubrious, Eeyorish, mournful, melancholy, melancholic, doleful, miserable, dismal, depressed, dejected, despondent, downcast, unhappy, low-spirited, in low spirits, low, with a long face, blue, down, fed up, grumpy, irritable, churlish, cantankerous, crotchety, cross, crabbed, crabby, grouchy, testy, snappish, peevish, crusty, waspish
etym: From French morose, from Latin morosus (“particular, scrupulous, fastidious, self-willed, wayward, capricious, fretful, peevish”), from mos (“way, custom, habit, self-will”). See moral.
en: Someone who is morose is miserable, bad-tempered, and not willing to talk very much to other people.
example: She was morose, pale, and reticent.
example_ko: She just sat there looking morose.
syn_a: gloomy, melancholy, somber, sulky, sullen

zh_Hans: （团体）意见一致的；（决定或裁决）一致通过的，获得全体支援的
syn: in complete agreement, in complete accord, of one mind, like-minded, of the same mind, in harmony, at one, with one voice, concordant, undivided
etym: From Latin ūnanimus (“of one mind”), from ūnus (“one”) +‎ animus (“mind”).
en: When a group of people are unanimous, they all agree about something or all vote for the same thing.
example: Editors were unanimous in their condemnation of the proposals
example_ko: a unanimous vote
syn_a: accordant, agreed, consonant, unified, united

syn: craftiness, craft, artfulness, art, artifice, wiliness, slyness, deviousness, shrewdness, canniness, ingenuity
etym: From Middle English gile, from Anglo-Norman gile, from Old French guile (“deception”)[1], from Frankish *wigila (“ruse”). Cognate via Proto-Germanic with wile.
en: Guile is the quality of being good at deceiving people in a clever way.
example: I love children's innocence and lack of guile.
syn_n: artfulness, cunning, deceit, shrewdness, subtlety, wiliness

zh_Hans: 装饰，修饰；给…锦上添花，渲染
syn: adorn, ornament, dress, dress up, furnish
etym: From Old French embellir, from em- + bel.
en: If something is embellished with decorative features or patterns, it has those features or patterns on it and they make it look more attractive.
example: The stern was embellished with carvings in red and blue
syn_v: adorn, color, decorate, dress up, elaborate, ornament

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：in 不 + dol 悲伤 + ence 状态，行为 → 懒惰
syn: idleness, slothfulness, sloth, shiftlessness, inactivity, inaction, inertia, lifelessness, sluggishness, lethargy, languor, languidness, torpor, torpidity, slowness, dullness
etym: From Middle French indolence, from Latin indolentia
en: Indolence means laziness.
syn_n: idleness, inactivity, laziness, lethargy, procrastination, sloth

zh_Hans: 迂回;迂说式;迂回的;语法上迂回的;委婉的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：peri 周围 + phras〔 = phrase词语〕+ tic 有…性质的 → 词语绕圈子 → 冗赘的
syn: circuitous, roundabout, indirect, tautological, prolix, verbose, wordy, long-winded, rambling, wandering, tortuous, diffuse, discursive
etym: Borrowed from Ancient Greek περιφραστικός (periphrastikós), from περίφρασις (períphrasis, “periphrasis”).
en: employing or involving periphrasis

syn: fattish, obese, overweight, plump, portly, stout, chubby, paunchy, beer-bellied, thickset, hefty, heavy, heavyset, burly, bulky, chunky, well padded, well covered, well upholstered, meaty, fleshy, rotund, round, well rounded, broad, broad in the beam, of ample proportions, big, large, gargantuan, elephantine
etym: Borrowed from Old French corpulent, from Latin corpulentus.
en: If you describe someone as corpulent, you mean they are fat.
example: a rather corpulent farmer.
syn_n: grease, lard, suet, tallow, best, choice, elite, prime, excess, overabundance, surplus
syn_a: big, heavy, plump, stocky, stout, corpulent, gross, massive, obese, overweight, bloated, swollen, fatty, greasy, oily, fruitful, lucrative, rewarding, copious, full, plentiful, replete
ant2: thin, gaunt, deflated, lean, unprofitable  scarce

zh_Hans: 杀害兄弟罪；杀害同类罪；杀害同胞罪
syn: homicide, assassination, liquidation, extermination, execution, slaughter, butchery, massacre
etym: From Middle English fratricide, from Old French fratricide, from Latin frātricīda.
en: If someone commits fratricide, they kill their brother.

zh_Hans: 虚假的，欺骗的；（原因、判断）谬误的
syn: fake, not genuine, specious, false, factitious, counterfeit, fraudulent, trumped-up, sham, mock, feigned, pretended, contrived, fabricated, manufactured, fictitious, make-believe, invalid, fallacious, meretricious
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin spurius (“illegitimate, bastardly”), possibly related to sperno or from Etruscan.
en: Something that is spurious seems to be genuine, but is false.
example: He was arrested in 1979 on spurious corruption charges
example_ko: He had managed to create the entirely spurious impression that the company was thriving.
syn_a: artificial, bogus, counterfeit, fake, false, imitation, phony

zh_Hans: （尤指离家出走而）犯错的，行为不当的，出格的
syn: guilty, culpable, misbehaving, delinquent, lawless, lawbreaking, criminal, transgressing, aberrant, deviant, erring, sinning
etym: From Middle English erraunt, from Anglo-Norman erraunt, from Old French errant, from Latin errans (“wandering”). Doublet of arrant.
en: Errant is used to describe someone whose actions are considered unacceptable or wrong by other people. For example, an errant husband is unfaithful to his wife.
example: Usually his cases involved errant husbands and wandering wives
syn_a: aimless, roaming, roving, wandering, deviant, erring, wayward

en: If something burgeons, it grows or develops rapidly.
example: My confidence began to burgeon later in life.
syn_v: bloom, blossom, bud, flower, sprout, develop, flourish, grow, mushroom, thrive

syn: inert, latent, fallow, passive, idle, at rest, inoperative, deactivated, in abeyance, quiet
etym: Borrowed from Latin quiēscēns (“resting, reposing, sleeping”), present participle of quiēscere, from quiēs (“rest, repose, quiet”).
en: Someone or something that is quiescent is quiet and inactive.
example: a society which was politically quiescent and above all deferential.

zh_Hans: 清晰的，明了的；（人）头脑清醒的，说话清楚的
syn: comprehensible, understandable, cogent, coherent, communicative, articulate, eloquent
etym: Latin lucidus, from lux (“light”) + -idus.
en: Lucid writing or speech is clear and easy to understand.
example: a lucid account of the history of mankind
example_ko: a lucid style / explanation
syn_a: comprehensible, explicit, plain, understandable, clearheaded, perceptive, rational, clear, limpid, translucent, transparent

syn: good-humoured mockery, chaff, banter, ragging, badinage, japing
etym: From French raillerie.
en: light-hearted satire or ridicule; banter
syn_n: badinage, banter, jesting, joking, kidding, ribbing  teasing

syn: maxim, aphorism, axiom, adage, saw, tag, motto, precept, epigram, epigraph, dictum, gnome, pearl of wisdom
etym: From Middle French aphorisme, from Late Latin aphorismus, from Ancient Greek ἀφορισμός (aphorismós, “pithy phrase containing a general truth”), from ἀφορίζω (aphorízō, “I define, mark off or determine”), from ἀπό (apó, “off”) + ὁρίζω (horízō, “I divide, bound”), from ὅρος (hóros, “boundary”).
en: An aphorism is a short witty sentence which expresses a general truth or comment.
syn_n: adage, aphorism, epigram, expression, maxim, motto  proverb

syn: short, brief, compact, condensed, crisp, laconic, terse, tight, to the point, economic, pithy, thumbnail, summary, short and sweet, in a few well-chosen words, compendious, epigrammatic, synoptic, aphoristic, gnomic
etym: From Middle English succinte, succynt, from Old French succinct, from Latin succinctus, perfect passive participle of succingō (“gird from below”), from sub + cingō (“gird, wrap, surround”).
en: Something that is succinct expresses facts or ideas clearly and in few words.
example: The book gives an admirably succinct account of the technology and its history
example_ko: Keep your answers as succinct as possible.
syn_a: brief, concise, direct, pithy, terse, abbreviated, abridged, capsulized, compact, condensed

zh_Hans: 隶属（关系）；从属关系；联系
syn: attaching, connecting, joining, bonding, uniting, combining, associating, aligning, allying, amalgamation, amalgamating, merging, incorporation, incorporating, integration, integrating, federating, federation, confederating, confederation, coupling, fusion
etym: From French affiliation, from Latin affiliatiō, noun of action from verb affiliō, from af- (form of ad- (“to”) before an f) + filiō (from filius (“son”)).
en: If one group has an affiliation with another group, it has a close or official connection with it.
example: The group has no affiliation to any political party
example_ko: He was arrested because of his political affiliation.
syn_n: alliance, association, coalition, connection, partnership  union

syn: head first, on one's head
etym: From Middle English hedlong, alteration of hedling, heedling, hevedlynge (“headlong”), assimilated to long. More at headling.
en: If you move headlong in a particular direction, you move there very quickly.
example: He ran headlong for the open door.
example_ko: She fell headlong into the icy pool.

syn: propagandize, proselytize, inculcate, re-educate, persuade, convince, condition, discipline, mould
en: If people are indoctrinated, they are taught a particular belief with the aim that they will reject other beliefs.
example: They have been completely indoctrinated
example_ko: [VN] They had been indoctrinated from an early age with their parents’ beliefs.
syn_v: brainwash, inculcate, infuse, instill, propagandize, educate, school, teach  train

zh_Hans: 条件;环境;状况;境况;境遇;(尤指)经济状况;命运;客观环境
en: The circumstances of a particular situation are the conditions which affect what happens.
example: Recent opinion polls show that 60 percent favor abortion under certain circumstances
example_ko: The company reserves the right to cancel this agreement in certain circumstances.
syn_n: case, condition, estate, situation, state, event, happening, incident, occurrence, ceremony, formality, pageantry  pomp

zh_Hans: （尤指政府消亡或垮台而引起的）无政府状态，混乱状态
syn: absence of government, nihilism, mobocracy, revolution, insurrection, riot, rebellion, mutiny, disorder, disorganization, misrule, chaos, tumult, turmoil, mayhem, pandemonium
etym: From New Latin anarchia, from Ancient Greek ἀναρχία (anarkhía).
en: If you describe a situation as anarchy, you mean that nobody seems to be paying any attention to rules or laws.
example: Civil war and famine sent the nation plunging into anarchy.
example_ko: The overthrow of the military regime was followed by a period of anarchy.
syn_n: insurrection, lawlessness, mobocracy, ochlocracy, revolution, chaos, bedlam, disorder, tumult

syn: avengement, retribution, retributive justice, retaliation, requital, reprisal
etym: From Anglo-Norman vengeaunce, from Old French vengeance, venjance, from vengier (“to avenge”). Analysable as venge +‎ -ance
en: Vengeance is the act of killing, injuring, or harming someone because they have harmed you.
example: He swore vengeance on everyone involved in the murder
example_ko: a desire for vengeance
syn_n: reprisal, retaliation, vengeance
syn_v: avenge, punish, repay, retaliate, vindicate

zh_Hans: 过度的；不合理的；极端的
syn: heavy, intemperate, unrestrained, unrestricted, uncontrolled, unlimited, unbridled, uncurbed, self-indulgent, overindulgent, imprudent, reckless, wild
etym: From im- +‎ moderate.
en: If you describe something as immoderate, you disapprove of it because it is too extreme.
example: He launched an immoderate tirade on Turner.
example_ko: immoderate drinking
syn_a: excessive, extreme, inordinate, intemperate, undue, unreasonable

zh_Hans: （暂时的）脱离常规；反常现象；异常行为
syn: deviation, divergence, abnormality, irregularity, variation, digression, freak, rogue, rarity, quirk, oddity, curiosity, mistake
etym: A learned borrowing from Latin aberrātiō (“relief, diversion”), first attested in 1594 [1], from aberrō (“wander away, go astray”), from ab (“away”) + errō (“wander”)[2]. Compare French aberration. See also aberrate.
en: An aberration is an incident or way of behaving that is not typical.
example: It became very clear that the incident was not just an aberration, it was not just a single incident.
example_ko: The job is in aberration.
syn_n: abnormality, anomaly, deviation, divergence, irregularity, eccentricity, oddity, peculiarity  quirk

zh_Hans: 讲究实际的，重实效的；实用主义的
syn: hands-on, pragmatic, real, actual, active, applied, experiential, experimental, non-theoretical, in the field
etym: From Middle French pragmatique, from Late Latin pragmaticus (“relating to civil affair; in Latin, as a noun, a person versed in the law who furnished arguments and points to advocates and orators, a kind of attorney”), from Ancient Greek πραγματικός (pragmatikós, “active, versed in affairs”), from πρᾶγμα (prâgma, “a thing done, a fact”), in plural πράγματα (prágmata, “affairs, state affairs, public business, etc.”), from πράσσειν (prássein, “to do”) (whence English practical).
en: A pragmatic way of dealing with something is based on practical considerations, rather than theoretical ones. A pragmatic person deals with things in a practical way.
example: a pragmatic approach to the problems faced by Latin America.
example_ko: a pragmatic approach to management problems
syn_a: basic, fundamental, practical, realistic, sensible, utilitarian

syn: revoke, repeal, rescind, overturn, overrule, override, do away with, annul, cancel, break off, invalidate, nullify, void, negate, dissolve, countermand, veto, declare null and void, discontinue
etym: First attested in 1526, from Middle English abrogat (“abolished”), from Latin abrogātus, perfect passive participle of abrogō (“repeal”), formed from ab (“away”) + rogō (“ask, inquire, propose”). See rogation.
en: If someone in a position of authority abrogates something such as a law, agreement, or practice, they put an end to it.
example: The next prime minister could abrogate the treaty.
syn_v: annul, break, invalidate, void, recall, repeal, rescind, revoke, abolish, cancel, terminate

syn: bank clerk, teller, bank teller, banker, treasurer, bursar, purser
etym: Borrowed from Medieval Latin bursārius, from bursa (“purse”) (English purse).
en: The bursar of a school or college is the person who is in charge of its finance or general administration.

syn: encourage, try to persuade, adjure, admonish, press, prompt, prod, goad, egg on, spur, push, pressure, put pressure on, use pressure on, pressurize, lean on
etym: From Latin adiūrō (“beg earnestly”), from ad- (“near, at; towards, to”)' + iūrō (“swear by oath”).
en: to command, often by exacting an oath; charge
example_ko: He adjured them to tell the truth.
syn_v: command, compel, direct, order, press, appeal, entreat, petition, plead  request

ko: [UC] 열정, 정열, 열심; 열렬, 열중; [U] 작열
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：ard 燃烧 + or 表性质 → 热情；热切
syn: avidity, fervour, zeal, wholeheartedness, eagerness, vehemence, intensity, fierceness, zest, gusto, energy, animation, fire, fieriness, emotion, emotionalism, feeling, hot-bloodedness
etym: From Middle English ardour, ardowr, ardure, from Anglo-Norman ardour, from Latin ardor, from ardere (“to burn”).
en: → see ardour
example_ko: She becomes a new person when she dances with ardor.
syn_n: eagerness, enthusiasm, fervor, intensity, zeal, devotion, love, passion, rapture

syn: escaper, runaway, deserter, refugee, renegade, absconder
en: A fugitive is someone who is running away or hiding, usually in order to avoid being caught by the police.
example: the fugitive train robber.
example_ko: a fugitive from justice
syn_n: deserter, outlaw, renegade, exile, refugee, runaway, truant
syn_a: escaped, runaway, itinerant, nomadic, roaming, wandering, elusive, ephemeral, evanescent, impermanent

syn: predict, prophesy, foretell, divine
etym: From Medieval Latin prognosticare; see prognostic for more.
en: to foretell (future events) according to present signs or indications; prophesy
example_ko: prognosticate a depression

zh_Hans: （尤指针对建筑物的）纵火（罪），放火（罪）
syn: pyromania, firebombing
etym: Anglo-Norman and Old French arson, from the verb ardoir, from Latin ardeō (“to burn”). Compare ardent.
en: Arson is the crime of deliberately setting fire to a building or vehicle.
example: a terrible wave of rioting, theft and arson
example_ko: to carry out an arson attack

syn: merrily, delightedly, joyfully, gaily, cheerfully, cheerily, agreeably, blithely, light-heartedly, gleefully, blissfully, with pleasure, to one's heart's content
etym: From happy +‎ -ly.
en: You can add happily to a statement to indicate that you are glad that something happened or is true.→ see also happy
example: Happily, his neck injuries were not serious
example_ko: children playing happily on the beach
syn_a: cheerful, content, delighted, glad, pleased, fortuitous, fortunate, lucky, opportune, seasonable, timely

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：af 加强 + flu 流动 + ent 具有…性质的 →〔钱多得〕不断流出 → 富裕的
syn: rich, prosperous, opulent, well off, moneyed, cash rich, with deep pockets, well-to-do, comfortable
etym: Middle French affluent, from Latin affluentem, accusative singular of affluēns, present active participle of affluō (“flow to or towards; overflow with”), from ad (“to, towards”) + fluō (“flow”) (cognate via latter to fluid, flow). Sense of “wealthy” (plentiful flow of goods) c. 1600, which also led to nominalization affluence.[1]
en: If you are affluent, you have a lot of money.
example: Cigarette smoking used to be commoner among affluent people.
example_ko: affluent Western countries
syn_a: affluent, moneyed, prosperous, rich, thriving

zh_Hans: （对未来或即将发生的不愉快之事的）忧虑，担心；恐惧
syn: angst, alarm, worry, uneasiness, unease, nervousness, misgiving, disquiet, concern, agitation, restlessness, edginess, fidgetiness, nerves, tension, trepidation, perturbation, consternation, panic, fearfulness, dread, fear, shock, horror, terror
etym: Borrowed from Latin apprehensio, apprehensionis, compare with French appréhension. See apprehend.
en: Apprehension is a feeling of fear that something bad may happen.
example: It reflects real anger and apprehension about the future
example_ko: There is growing apprehension that fighting will begin again.
syn_n: anxiety, dread, fear, foreboding, comprehension, insight, perception, understanding, arrest, capture, seizure

syn: melodious, melodic, sweet-sounding, pleasant-sounding, sweet-toned, mellifluous, dulcet, lyrical
etym: From Middle French harmonieux.
en: A harmonious relationship, agreement, or discussion is friendly and peaceful.
example: Their harmonious relationship resulted in part from their similar goals
example_ko: the need to be in harmony with our environment
syn_a: euphonious, harmonic, mellifluous, melodious, fluent, synchronized, unified, agreeable, appropriate, compatible, complimentary, symmetric

zh_Hans: 寡头统治（的政府）；寡头统治集团
etym:
From French oligarchie, from Latin oligarchia, from Ancient Greek ὀλιγαρχία (oligarkhía), from ὀλίγος (olígos, “few”) + ἀρχή (arkhḗ, “rule”).
Surface analysis: olig- (“few”) +‎ -archy (“rule”, “command”).
en: An oligarchy is a small group of people who control and run a particular country or organization. You can also refer to a country which is governed in this way as an oligarchy.

zh_Hans: （尤指以书的形式出现的关于特定主题的）汇编，概要，概略，纲要
syn: compilation, anthology, treasury, digest
etym: From the Latin compendium (“that which is weighed together; a sparing, a saving, an abbreviation”), from com- (“with”) + pendō (“I weigh”).
en: A compendium is a short but detailed collection of information, usually in a book.
example: The Roman Catholic Church has issued a compendium of its teachings.

zh_Hans: 促成；使突如其来地发生；加速…的发生
syn: bring on, cause, lead to, occasion, give rise to, trigger, spark, touch off, provoke, hasten, accelerate, expedite, speed up, advance, quicken, push forward, further, instigate, induce
en: If something precipitates an event or situation, usually a bad one, it causes it to happen suddenly or sooner than normal.
example: The killings in Vilnius have precipitated the worst crisis yet
example_ko: His resignation precipitated a leadership crisis.
syn_v: accelerate, expedite, hasten, quicken, arouse, motivate, stimulate, trigger, settle, sink
syn_a: abrupt, hasty, hurried, sudden, headlong, impetuous, impulsive, rash

syn: spread out, spread around, send out, scatter, disperse
etym: From diffūsus (“scattered, spread”)
en: If something such as knowledge or information is diffused, or if it diffuses somewhere, it is made known over a wide area or to a lot of people.
example: Over time, the technology is diffused and adopted by other countries.
example_ko: diffuse light
syn_v: circulate, disperse, distribute, scatter, spread
syn_a: dispersed, extended, scattered, spread out, discursive, rambling, verbose, wordy

syn: woeful, doleful, sorrowful, sad, unhappy, depressed, dismal, gloomy, morose, melancholy, miserable, forlorn, wretched, woebegone, despondent, dejected, disconsolate, downcast, crestfallen, downhearted, heartbroken, heavy-hearted, despairing, desolate, grief-stricken
etym: Borrowed from Old French dolerous (modern French douloureux), from Late Latin dolōrōsus (“painful”), from Latin dolor. Doublet of dolorose.
en: causing or involving pain or sorrow
syn_a: distressing, grievous, harrowing, mournful, rueful, sorrowful

syn: spread over, spread throughout, cover, bathe, pervade, wash, saturate, imbue, fill, load, charge, impregnate, inform, steep, colour
etym: From Latin suffundō.
en: If something, especially a colour or feeling, suffuses a person or thing, it gradually spreads over or through them.
example: A dull red flush suffused Selby's face.
example_ko: Her face was suffused with colour.
syn_v: diffuse, permeate, saturate  soak

syn: idiot, ass, halfwit, nincompoop, blockhead, buffoon, dunce, dolt, cretin, imbecile, dullard, moron, simpleton, clod
en: If you describe someone as an ignoramus, you are being critical of them because they do not have the knowledge you think they ought to have.
example_ko: When it comes to music, I’m a complete ignoramus.
syn_n: cretin, dimwit, fool, ignoramus, imbecile, moron, simpleton

zh_Hans: （常指盲目）支持的，拥护的；偏袒的
syn: follower, adherent, devotee, champion, backer, upholder, promoter, fanatic, fan, enthusiast, stalwart, zealot, disciple, votary
etym: From Italian partigiano.
en: Someone who is partisan strongly supports a particular person or cause, often without thinking carefully about the matter.
example: He is clearly too partisan to be a referee.
example_ko: Most newspapers are politically partisan.
syn_n: adherent, enthusiast, fan, follower, supporter, guerrilla, insurgent, irregular
syn_a: biased, myopic, narrow, partial, prejudiced

zh_Hans: 严厉批评的，尖刻斥责的
syn: withering, blistering, extremely critical, coruscating, searing, scorching, fierce, ferocious, savage, severe, stinging, biting, cutting, mordant, trenchant, virulent, caustic, vitriolic, scornful, sharp, bitter, acid, harsh, unsparing
en: If you say that someone is being scathing about something, you mean that they are being very critical of it.
example: His report was scathing about Loyalist and Republican terror groups
example_ko: a scathing attack on the new management
syn_a: biting, brutal, caustic, cutting, searing, stinging

syn: adeptness, adroitness, agility, nimbleness, handiness, ability, capability, talent, skilfulness, skill, proficiency, accomplishment, expertise, experience, efficiency, effortlessness, slickness, mastery, delicacy, knack, facility, artistry, sleight of hand, craft, finesse, felicity
etym: Borrowed from Middle French dextérité, from Latin dexteritas, from dexter (“on the right”)
en: Dexterity is skill in using your hands, or sometimes your mind.
example_ko: You need manual dexterity to be good at video games.
syn_n: agility, adroitness, deftness, facility, proficiency, skill

syn: naive, impressionable, trusting, over-trusting, over-trustful, exploitable, dupable, deceivable, easily deceived, easily taken in, easily led, unsuspicious, unwary, unguarded, unsceptical, uncritical, unquestioning
etym: Originated in 1576, borrowed from Latin crēdulus (“that easily believes a thing, credulous”), from crēdō (“to believe”).
en: If you describe someone as credulous, you have a low opinion of them because they are too ready to believe what people tell them and are easily deceived.
example: quack doctors charming money out of the pockets of credulous health-hungry citizens.
example_ko: The plot of the novel stretches credulity to the limit.
syn_a: believing, gullible, naive, trusting, unsuspecting

syn: proficient, accomplished, skilful, talented, gifted, masterly, virtuoso, consummate, peerless
etym: From French adepte, from Latin adeptus (“who has achieved”), the past participle of adipisci (“to attain”).
en: Someone who is adept at something can do it skilfully.
example: He's usually very adept at keeping his private life out of the media
syn_a: competent, expert, masterful, proficient, qualified, adroit, deft, dexterous, skillful

zh_Hans: 极其苦恼（赤贫，极度恐怖等）
syn: miserable, hopeless, pathetic, pitiful, pitiable, piteous, stark, sorry, forlorn, woeful, lamentable, degrading, appalling, atrocious, awful
etym: Borrowed from French abject, from Latin abiectus.
en: You use abject to emphasize that a situation or quality is extremely bad.
example: Both of them died in abject poverty
example_ko: abject poverty/misery/failure
syn_a: cowering, groveling, obeisant, obsequious, servile, base, contemptible, low, odious, vile, deplorable, hopeless, miserable, pitiful, wretched

syn: join, join up, join forces, team up, get together, come together, band together, work together, work jointly, participate, unite, combine, merge, link, ally, associate, amalgamate, integrate, form an alliance, pool resources, club together
etym: From collaborator, from French collaborateur, from Latin collaborare.
en: When one person or group collaborates with another, they work together, especially on a book or on some research.
example: He collaborated with his son Michael on the English translation of a text on food production
example_ko: [V] We have collaborated on many projects over the years.
syn_v: cooperate, join, unite, collude, conspire

syn: gift, present, donation, reward, handout, recompense, boon, baksheesh
etym: From Old French gratuite (French gratuité), from Medieval Latin gratuitas (“a free gift”), from Latin gratuitus (“freely given, free”); see gratuitous.
en: A gratuity is a gift of money to someone who has done something for you.
example: The porter expects a gratuity.
example_ko: No gratuity accepted.

ko: (특히 무엇을 배우거나 가르칠 때) 지나치게 규칙을 찾는[세세한 것에 얽매이는] 사람
syn: purist, literalist, formalist, doctrinaire
etym: From Middle French pedant, pedante, from Italian pedante (“a teacher, schoolmaster, pedant”), associated with Italian pedagogo (“teacher, pedagogue”). Compare French pédant.
en: If you say that someone is a pedant, you mean that they are too concerned with unimportant details or traditional rules, especially in connection with academic subjects.
example: I am no pedant and avoid being dogmatic concerning English grammar and expression.
syn_n: intellectual, pedagogue, scholar, bookworm, casuist, dogmatist  purist

syn: monocratic, undemocratic, totalitarian, authoritarian
etym: dictator +‎ -ial.
en: Dictatorial means controlled or used by a dictator.
example: He suspended the constitution and assumed dictatorial powers.
example_ko: a dictatorial ruler

syn: convince, prevail upon, get, make, prompt, move, inspire, instigate, influence, exert influence on, press, urge, incite, encourage, impel, actuate, motivate
etym: From Middle English enducen, borrowed from Latin indūcere, present active infinitive of indūcō (“lead in, bring in, introduce”), from in + dūcō (“lead, conduct”). Compare also abduce, adduce, conduce, deduce, produce, reduce etc. Doublet of endue.
en: To induce a state or condition means to cause it.
example: Doctors said surgery could induce a heart attack.
example_ko: Nothing would induce me to take the job.
syn_v: coax, encourage, influence, convince, persuade, reason, bring on, cause, produce, provoke

syn: carry off, capture, seize, snatch, hold to ransom, take as hostage, hijack
etym: From Latin abductus, perfect passive participle of abduco (“to lead away”), from ab (“away”) + duco (“to lead”)[1].
en: If someone is abducted by another person, he or she is taken away illegally, usually using force.
example: His car was held up and he was abducted by four gunmen
syn_v: seize, snatch, steal, impress, kidnap, shanghai, commandeer, hijack, pirate

syn: prolific, abundant, ample, extravagant, lavish, liberal, unstinting, fulsome, effusive, gushing, immoderate, unrestrained, excessive, inordinate
etym: From Latin profusus.
en: Profuse sweating, bleeding, or vomiting is sweating, bleeding, or vomiting large amounts.
example: a remedy that produces profuse sweating.
example_ko: profuse apologies/thanks
syn_v: bestow, give, heap, offer, dissipate, exhaust, squander
syn_a: luxuriant, munificent, opulent, plentiful, profuse, excessive, extravagant, improvident, prodigal, profligate

syn: unsparing, willingly given, free, free-handed, ready, beneficent, benevolent, big-hearted, kind-hearted, kind, unselfish
etym: un- +‎ stinting
en: Unstinting help, care, or praise is great in amount or degree and is given generously.
example: The task of producing the text was made easier by the unstinting help and generosity extended to me.
example_ko: unstinting support

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：dexter 右边 + ous …的 → 右手比左手灵巧 → 惯用右手的
syn: adept, adroit, agile, nimble, neat, nimble-fingered, handy, able, capable, talented, skilful, skilled, proficient, accomplished, expert, experienced, practised, polished, efficient, effortless, slick, professional, masterful, masterly, impressive, finely judged, delicate
etym: From Latin dexter (“right, ready”) + -ous.
en: Someone who is dexterous is very skilful and clever with their hands.
example: As people grow older they generally become less dexterous.
example_ko: You need manual dexterity to be good at video games.
syn_a: adept, adroit, deft, nimble, skillful, artful, clever, ingenious

syn: vanish, evaporate, dissolve, melt away, melt into thin air, be dispelled, dematerialize
etym: Borrowed from Latin dissipatus, past participle of dissipare, also written dissupare (“to scatter, disperse, demolish, destroy, squander, dissipate”), from dis- (“apart”) + supare (“to throw”), also in comp. insipare (“to throw into”).
en: When something dissipates or when you dissipate it, it becomes less or becomes less strong until it disappears or goes away completely.
example: The tension in the room had dissipated
example_ko: [V] Eventually, his anger dissipated.
syn_v: deplete, squander, waste, dispel, disperse, scatter, disappear, evanesce, evaporate, vanish

syn: sexual, erotic, amatory, ardent
etym: (14th century) From Old French amoros, amoreus, from Medieval Latin amōrōsus, from Latin amor (“love”), related to Latin amāre (“to love”). Compare French amoureux (“in love”).
en: If you describe someone's feelings or actions as amorous, you mean that they involve sexual desire.
example_ko: Mary rejected Tony’s amorous advances.
syn_a: ardent, enamored, fond, impassioned, loving, passionate

syn: dictatorial, totalitarian, authoritarian, absolute, absolutist, arbitrary, unconstitutional, undemocratic, anti-democratic, uncontrolled, unaccountable, summary
etym: From Ancient Greek δεσποτικός (despotikós) via French despotique.
en: If you say that someone is despotic, you are emphasizing that they use their power over other people in a very unfair or cruel way.
example: The country was ruled by a despotic tyrant.
example_ko: an enlightened despot
syn_a: harsh, oppressive, severe, tyrannical

zh_Hans: （尤指对未来的事情）概括说明，勾画轮廓
syn: presage, portend, foretell, prophesy, predict
etym: Borrowed from Latin adumbrātus (“represented in outline”), from adumbrāre (“cast a shadow on”), from umbra (“shadow”).
en: to outline; give a faint indication of

syn: blaring, booming, deafening, roaring, thunderous, thundering, tumultuous, clamorous, blasting, head-splitting, ear-splitting, ear-piercing, piercing
etym: Borrowed from Italian fortissimo.
en: A piece of music that is played fortissimo is played very loudly.

ko: (이동 중에 우아하게) 선회하는; 물결 모양의, 구불구불한
syn: windy, serpentine, curving, twisting, meandering, snaking, snaky, zigzag, zigzagging, turning, bending, curling, coiling, undulating
etym: Borrowed from Latin sinuōsus.
en: Something that is sinuous moves with smooth twists and turns.
example: the silent, sinuous approach of a snake through the long grass
example_ko: a sinuous movement
syn_a: curving, meandering, serpentine, snaky, twisting, undulating

zh_Hans: 克制感情的；（尤指面对逆境）坚忍的，隐忍的
etym: From Latin stoicus, from Ancient Greek Στωϊκός (Stōïkós), from Ποικίλη Στοά (Poikílē Stoá, “painted portico”), the portico in Athens where Zeno was teaching.
en: Stoic means the same as stoical.
example: The kids of Kobe try to be as stoic as their parents in this tragic situation.
syn_a: detached, dispassionate, impassive, imperturbable, stolid, unimpassioned, unruffled

zh_Hans: 半信半疑的，可疑的；不确定的；不可信的
syn: uncertain, unsure, in doubt, hesitant
etym: From Latin dubius.
en: If you describe something as dubious, you mean that you do not consider it to be completely honest, safe, or reliable.
example: This claim seems to us to be rather dubious
example_ko: I was rather dubious about the whole idea.
syn_a: doubtful, skeptical, ambivalent, irresolute, uncertain, ambiguous, debatable, disputable, moot, shady, suspect, suspicious, untrustworthy

zh_Hans: 不容置辩的；专横的，霸道的
syn: imperious, high-handed, brisk, abrupt, summary, commanding, authoritative, overbearing, dogmatic, autocratic, dictatorial, bossy, domineering, arbitrary, arrogant, overweening, lordly, tyrannical, despotic, imperial, magisterial, authoritarian
etym: From Anglo-Norman peremptorie, parentorie et al. (Modern French péremptoire), and its source, Latin peremptōrius (“deadly; decisive”), from perimō (“destroy”), from per- (“thorough”) + emō (“I take, I acquire”) (compare English emporium (“store”)).
en: Someone who does something in a peremptory way does it in a way that shows that they expect to be obeyed immediately.
example: With a brief, almost peremptory gesture he pointed to a chair.
example_ko: a peremptory summons
syn_a: aggressive, domineering, imperious, overbearing, absolute, categorical, final, ultimate, conclusive, decisive, definitive, unequivocal, unmitigated

zh_Hans: 我的过失；我应受谴责；我应负责任
etym: From the Latin phrase meā culpā (“through my fault”), from mea (“my, mine”) and culpa (“fault”) in the ablative
en: an acknowledgment of guilt
example: ‘Who broke this glass?' ‘Mea culpa,' Frank said.
example_ko: ‘Who broke this glass?' ‘Mea culpa,' Frank said.

zh_Hans: 专注，专心；全神贯注；集中（注意力）
syn: direct, centre, centralize, bring to bear
etym: From French concentrer.
en: If you concentrate on something, or concentrate your mind on it, you give all your attention to it.
example: It was up to him to concentrate on his studies and make something of himself
example_ko: [V] I can’t concentrate with all that noise going on.
syn_v: center, fasten, fix, focus, rivet, compact, condense, consolidate, integrate, unify, amass, cluster, converge

zh_Hans: 含糊的；模棱两可的；有歧义的
syn: to be decided, unresolved, undetermined, uncertain, open, arguable, debatable, disputed, unanswered, open to debate, doubtful, in doubt, moot, up in the air, in limbo, in a state of limbo, in a state of uncertainty, indefinite, inconclusive, unconfirmed, unsolved, ongoing, pending
etym: From Late Latin aequivocus, from aequus +‎ vocō.
en: If you are equivocal, you are deliberately vague in what you say, because you want to avoid speaking the truth or making a decision.
example: Many were equivocal about the idea
example_ko: She gave an equivocal answer, typical of a politician.
syn_a: ambiguous, ambivalent, uncertain, vague, misleading, paradoxical, perplexing

zh_Hans: （对财物）渴望得到的，迫切求取的；贪婪的
syn: hoarding, covetous, avaricious, possessive, grasping, grabbing, predatory, avid, rapacious, mercenary, materialistic, money-oriented
en: If you describe a person or an organization as acquisitive, you do not approve of them because you think they are too concerned with getting new possessions.
example: We live in an acquisitive society
example_ko: She has acquired a good knowledge of English.
syn_a: avaricious, covetous, grasping, greedy, materialistic, possessive

syn: transparent, clear, crystal clear, crystalline, bright, glassy, limpid, unclouded
etym: From Latin pellūcidus, from per- (“very”) + lūcidus (“clear, bright”) (whence lucid), from lūceō (“shine, be visible”). Surface analysis per- +‎ lucid; compare perfervid. Compare clear, crystal clear, both also with literal meaning “transparent” but metaphorical meaning “easily understood”.
en: Something that is pellucid is extremely clear.
example: her pellucid blue eyes

etym: From French centipède, from Latin centi- (“hundred”) + pes (“foot”).
en: A centipede is a long, thin creature with a lot of legs.

syn: disseminate, distribute, spread, broadcast, diffuse, strew, sow, sprinkle, pepper
etym: From French disperser, from Latin dispersus, past participle of dispergere (“to scatter abroad, disperse”), from dis- (“apart”) + spargere (“to scatter”); see sparse.
en: When something disperses or when you disperse it, it spreads over a wide area.
example: The oil appeared to be dispersing
example_ko: [V] The fog began to disperse.
syn_v: break up, disband, scatter, dispel, dissipate, vanish, circulate, dispense, disseminate, distribute

syn: intrigue, deviousness, evasion, deceit, deception, dishonesty, cheating, duplicity, guile, cunning, craft, craftiness, slyness, chicanery, bluff, pretence, fraud, fraudulence, sophistry, sharp practice
etym: Borrowed from Middle French subterfuge, from Medieval Latin subterfugium, from Latin subterfugio (“I flee secretly”), from subter (“under”) and fugio (“I flee”).
en: Subterfuge is a trick or a dishonest way of getting what you want.
example: Most people can see right through that type of subterfuge
syn_n: artifice, scheme, stratagem, trick, deceit, fraud, chicanery, duplicity, guile, sophistry

syn: hetero, het
etym: From hetero- +‎ -sexual.
en: A heterosexual relationship is a sexual relationship between a man and a woman.

syn: listlessness, weariness, languor, sluggishness, enervation, tiredness, exhaustion, fatigue, sleepiness, drowsiness, torpor, torpidity, ennui, lifelessness, sloth, apathy
etym: Borrowed from French lassitude, from Latin lassitūdō (“faintness, weariness”), from lassus (“faint, weary”), perhaps for *ladtus, and thus akin to English late.
en: Lassitude is a state of tiredness, laziness, or lack of interest.
example: Symptoms of anaemia include general fatigue and lassitude.
syn_n: debility, exhaustion, fatigue, languor, weariness, apathy, ennui, indifference, malaise

syn: avid, impassioned, fervent, fervid, zealous, wholehearted, eager, vehement, intense, fierce, fiery, flaming, emotional, hot-blooded
etym: First attested circa 14th century, from Middle English ardaunt, borrowed from Anglo-Norman ardent, from Old French ardant, from Latin ardentem, accusative of ardēns, present participle of ardeō (“I burn”).
en: Ardent is used to describe someone who has extremely strong feelings about something or someone.
example: He's been one of the most ardent supporters of the administration's policy.
example_ko: an ardent supporter of European unity
syn_a: eager, fervent, fervid, impassioned, zealous

zh_Hans: （常指幸灾乐祸地）哈哈大笑，咯咯地笑
syn: laugh, giggle, titter, tee-hee, snigger
etym: Perhaps a blend of chuckle +‎ snort. Coined by Lewis Carroll in his poem Jabberwocky, first published in 1855 but only introduced to the public in his 1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass.
en: To chortle means to laugh in a way that shows you are very pleased.
example: There was silence for a moment, then Larry began chortling like an idiot.
example_ko: [V] Gill chortled with delight.
syn_n: chortle, giggle, laugh, snicker, snigger

ko: 화를 잘 내는, 걸핏하면 화를 내는
zh_Hans: 暴怒的；易怒的，性情暴躁的
syn: irascible, irritable, grumpy, grouchy, crotchety, tetchy, testy, crusty, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, ill-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, peevish, cross, fractious, disagreeable, pettish, crabbed, crabby, waspish, prickly, peppery, touchy, scratchy, splenetic, shrewish, short-tempered, hot-tempered, quick-tempered, dyspeptic, bilious, liverish, cross-grained
etym: From Middle English colerik, from Old French colerique, from Latin cholericus.
en: A choleric person gets angry very easily. You can also use choleric to describe a person who is very angry.
example: his choleric disposition
syn_a: angry, cantankerous, irate, peevish, testy, touchy

syn: honesty, uprightness, decency, morality, rectitude, goodness, virtue, right-mindedness, trustworthiness, truthfulness, honour, honourableness, justice, fairness, equity
etym: From Middle French probité, from Latin probitas (“uprightness, honesty”), from probus (“good, excellent, honest”); see probe, prove.
en: Probity is a high standard of correct moral behaviour.
example: He asserted his innocence and his financial probity.
example_ko: financial probity
syn_n: character, decency, honesty, honor, integrity, principle

syn: propitious, promising, full of promise, bright, rosy, good, optimistic, hopeful, encouraging
etym: From auspice +‎ -ious, from Latin auspicium (“augury”), from auspex (“augur”), possibly via French.
en: Something that is auspicious indicates that success is likely.
example: His career as a playwright had an auspicious start.
example_ko: an auspicious start to the new school year
syn_a: favorable, felicitous, fortunate, lucky, opportune, propitious

zh_Hans: （尤指巧妙或非法地）逃避，规避，绕过
syn: get round, find a way round, evade, get past, bypass, sidestep, dodge
etym: Latin circum (“about”) + venire (“to come”)
en: If someone circumvents a rule or restriction, they avoid having to obey the rule or restriction, in a clever and perhaps dishonest way.
example: Military planners tried to circumvent the treaty.
example_ko: They found a way of circumventing the law.
syn_v: avoid, bypass, evade, skirt, circle, ensnare, entrap, envelop, surround

ko: 인내하며[굴하지 않고] 계속하다, 인내심을 갖고 하다
syn: continue, carry on, go on, keep on, keep going, not give up, struggle on, hammer away, be persistent, be determined, follow something through, see something through, keep at it, show determination, press ahead, press on, stay with something, not take no for an answer, be tenacious, be pertinacious, be patient, stand one's ground, stand fast, stand firm, hold on, hold out, go the distance, stay the course, plod on, plough on, grind away, stop at nothing, leave no stone unturned
etym: From Old French perseverer, from Latin perseverare (“to continue steadfastly, persist, persevere”), from perseverus (“very strict or earnest”), from per (“through, by the means of”) + severus (“strict, earnest”).
en: If you persevere with something, you keep trying to do it and do not give up, even though it is difficult.
example: his ability to persevere despite obstacles and setbacks.
example_ko: Despite a number of setbacks, they persevered in their attempts to fly around the world in a balloon.
syn_v: abide, continue, endure, persist, labor, strive, struggle  toil

zh_Hans: （尤指跨越山谷的多拱的）高架渠，渡槽
syn: race, channel, watercourse, waterway, sluice, sluiceway, spillway
etym: Adapted from the Latin aquaeductus (“conveyance of water”), from aqua (“water”) + dūcō (“I lead”, “I bring”); compare the French aqueduc.
en: An aqueduct is a long bridge with many arches, which carries a water supply or a canal over a valley.
example: an old Roman aqueduct.
syn_n: canal, channel, course, river, strait  stream

syn: parable, apologue, allegory, bestiary
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French fable, from Latin fabula, from fā(rī) (“to speak, say”) + -bula (“instrumental suffix”). See ban, and compare fabulous, fame.
en: A fable is a story which teaches a moral lesson. Fables sometimes have animals as the main characters.
example: the fable of the tortoise and the hare
example_ko: Aesop’s Fables
syn_n: allegory, folk tale, legend, parable, story, tale, fabrication, falsehood, hoax, lie

syn: person on foot, hiker, rambler, stroller, wayfarer, footslogger
etym: Borrowed from the Latin root pedestri-, from pedester.
en: A pedestrian is a person who is walking, especially in a town or city, rather than travelling in a vehicle.
example: In Los Angeles a pedestrian is a rare spectacle
syn_a: commonplace, lifeless, mediocre, mundane  unimaginative

ko: 스모가스보드(온갖 음식이 다양하게 나오는 뷔페식 식사)
zh_Hans: （包含不同热菜和冷菜的）北欧式自助餐
syn: cold meal, self-service, smorgasbord
etym: A smorgasbord
en: Smorgasbord is a meal with a variety of hot and cold savoury dishes, from which people serve themselves.

syn: seedy, seamy, unsavoury, shoddy, vile, foul, tawdry, louche, cheap, base, low, low-minded, debased, degenerate, corrupt, dishonest, dishonourable, disreputable, despicable, discreditable, contemptible, ignominious, ignoble, shameful, wretched, abhorrent, abominable, disgusting
etym: Latin sordidus, from sordēre (“be dirty”).
en: If you describe someone's behaviour as sordid, you mean that it is immoral or dishonest.
example: I don't want to hear the sordid details of your relationship with Sandra
example_ko: It was a shock to discover the truth about his sordid past.
syn_a: base, contemptible, corrupt, depraved, ignoble, mean, miserable, poor, dirty, filthy, squalid

ko: (의견·생각이 남이 볼 때 짜증스러울 정도로) 흔들리다[자꾸 바뀌다]
syn: be indecisive, be irresolute, be undecided, be uncertain, be unsure, be doubtful, waver, teeter, temporize, hesitate, oscillate, fluctuate, keep changing one's mind
etym: From Latin vacillātum, supine form of vacillō (“sway, waver”).
en: If you vacillate between two alternatives or choices, you keep changing your mind.
example: She vacillates between men twice her age and men younger than she
syn_v: dither, hedge, hesitate  waver

zh_Hans: 环（状物）；圆形的东西；环形排列
syn: band of gold, marriage token
etym: From Middle Dutch rinc, from Old Dutch ring, from Proto-Germanic *hringaz.
en: When you ring someone, you telephone them.in AM, usually use call
example: He rang me at my mother's
example_ko: [VN] I’ll ring you up later.
syn_n: band, bracelet, collar, circle, coupling, link, loop, round
syn_v: encircle, enclose, gird, rim, surround, jingle, tinkle, bong, chime, knell, peal, toll, echo, resound, reverberate, call  telephone

ko: <사람·이야기 등이>  되돌아가다 , 회상하다, 되돌아가 말하다 ((to)); 마음에 다시 떠오르다, 회상되다
zh_Hans: 反复出现；再次发生；重新产生
syn: reoccur, occur again, be repeated, repeat, repeat itself
etym: From Latin recurrō (“run back”)
en: If something recurs, it happens more than once.
example: a theme that was to recur frequently in his work.
syn_v: continue, persist, repeat, resume  return

syn: melancholic, melancholy, plaintive, sorrowful, sad, lamenting, doleful
etym: From Middle French élégiaque.
en: Something that is elegiac expresses or shows sadness.
example: The music has a dreamy, elegiac quality.

zh_Hans: 显然易见的；明白的，明显的
syn: apparent, noticeable, conspicuous, perceptible, perceivable, visible, observable, discernible, transparent, clear, crystal clear, clear-cut, writ large, plain, manifest, patent, palpable, tangible, distinct, pronounced, marked, striking, glaring, blatant
etym: From Middle English [Term?], from Old French [Term?], from Latin ēvidēns (“visible, apparent, clear, plain”) (compare Late Latin ēvideor (“to appear plainly”)), from ē (“out”) + videō (“see”), present participle vidēns, deponent videor (“to appear, seem”).
en: If something is evident, you notice it easily and clearly.
example: His footprints were clearly evident in the heavy dust
example_ko: It has now become evident to us that a mistake has been made.
syn_a: apparent, conspicuous, manifest, obvious, unmistakable, visible

ko: 많이 알려지지 않은, 잘 이해받지 못하는
syn: abstruse, arcane, esoteric, little known, recherché, abstract, deep, profound, cryptic, difficult, complex, complicated, involved
etym: From Latin reconditus (“hidden, concealed”), past participle of recondō (“to put back, to reëstablish; to put away, to hide”), from re- (“again”) + condō (“to build, to form; to store; to conceal”)
en: Recondite areas of knowledge or learning are difficult to understand, and not many people know about them.
example: Her poems are modishly experimental in style and recondite in subject-matter.
syn_a: abstruse, complex, difficult, incomprehensible, obscure, perplexing

syn: vanquish, defeat, crush, quell, quash, gain mastery over, gain ascendancy over, gain control of, bring under the yoke, bring to heel, bring someone to their knees, overcome, overpower, hegemonize
etym: Romans Under the Yoke (1858), Charles Gleyre
en: If someone subjugates a group of people, they take complete control of them, especially by defeating them in a war.
example: Their costly and futile attempt to subjugate the Afghans lasted just 10 years.
example_ko: a subjugated race
syn_v: conquer, crush, defeat, subdue, vanquish, control, dominate, suppress, tyrannize

syn: tiny, minuscule, extremely small, very small
etym: From Latin infinitesimus, from infinitus (“infinite”) + -esimus, as in centesimus (“hundredth”)
en: Something that is infinitesimal is extremely small.
example: mineral substances present in infinitesimal amounts in the soil
example_ko: infinitesimal traces of poison
syn_a: microscopic, minuscule, minute, teeny, tiny, inappreciable, insignificant, negligible, slight

zh_Hans: 违反常规的；反常的；异常的（尤指不能接受的）
syn: deviating, divergent, abnormal, atypical, anomalous, digressive, irregular
etym: From Latin aberrāns, present active participle of aberrō (“go astray; err”), from ab (“from”) + errō (“to wander”).[1] See aberr.[2]
en: Aberrant means unusual and not socially acceptable.
example: Ian's rages and aberrant behavior worsened.
example_ko: aberrant behaviour
syn_a: abnormal, anomalous, deviant, irregular, unconventional, bizarre, eccentric, odd, peculiar, strange

zh_Hans: 守财奴似的；吝啬鬼似的；吝啬的，小气的
syn: niggardly, parsimonious, close-fisted
etym: miser +‎ -ly, attested from the 1540s.
en: If you describe someone as miserly, you disapprove of them because they seem to hate spending money, and to spend as little as possible.
example: He is miserly with both his time and his money.
syn_a: closefisted, greedy, stingy, tight, frugal, prudent, scrimping, thrifty

zh_Hans: （成功、流行、权力等的）顶峰，顶点，最高点
syn: pinnacle, peak, high point, highest point, height, high water mark, top, summit, crest, zenith, crowning moment, apotheosis
etym: From French apogée, from Latin apogaeum, apogeum, from Ancient Greek ἀπόγειον (apógeion, “away from Earth”), from ἀπό (apó, “away”) + γῆ (gê, “Earth”).
en: The apogee of something such as a culture or a business is its highest or its greatest point.
syn_n: acme, apex, climax, height, peak, pinnacle, summit

zh_Hans: 婚姻的；夫妻间的（尤指性生活）
syn: matrimonial, nuptial, marriage, married, wedded, connubial, bridal
etym: From Middle French conjugal, from Latin coniugālis.
en: Conjugal means relating to marriage and the relationship between a husband and wife, especially their sexual relationship.
example: a man deprived of his conjugal rights.
example_ko: conjugal love
syn_a: connubial, marital, matrimonial, nuptial  wedded

syn: sparkling, carbonated, gassy, aerated, bubbly, bubbling, frothy, foaming
etym: From French effervescent, from Latin effervēscō (“boil up”).
en: An effervescent liquid is one that contains or releases bubbles of gas.
example: an effervescent mineral water.
syn_a: animated, gay, hilarious, lively, volatile, boiling, bubbling, frothy

etym: Inherited from the Middle English brevet (“official letter”), from the Anglo-Norman diminutive of bref (“letter”), from the Latin brevis (“short”), whence brief.
en: a document entitling a commissioned officer to hold temporarily a higher military rank without the appropriate pay and allowances

syn: hate, loathe, despise, abominate, execrate, regard with disgust, feel disgust for, feel repugnance towards, feel distaste for, shrink from, recoil from, shudder at, be unable to bear, be unable to abide, feel hostility to, feel aversion to, feel animosity to, find intolerable, dislike, disdain, have an aversion to
etym: First attested in 1449, from Middle English abhorren, borrowed from Middle French abhorrer, from Latin abhorreō (“shrink away from in horror”), from ab- (“from”) +‎ horreō (“stand aghast, bristle with fear”).[1]
en: If you abhor something, you hate it very much, especially for moral reasons.
example: He was a man who abhorred violence and was deeply committed to reconciliation
syn_v: despise, execrate, hate, loathe, scorn

syn: supporter, upholder, exponent, promoter, adherent, endorser, champion, defender, backer, subscriber, patron, espouser, friend, apostle, apologist, pleader, proposer, propounder, spokesperson, spokesman, spokeswoman
etym: From Latin prōpōnēns, present participle of prōpōnō (“to put forward; propose”)
en: If you are a proponent of a particular idea or course of action, you actively support it.
example: Halsey was identified as a leading proponent of the values of progressive education.
syn_n: advocate, backer, champion, defender, patron, supporter

syn: negative, defeatist, downbeat, gloom-ridden, cynical, bleak, fatalistic, dark, black, despairing, despondent, depressed, dejected, demoralized, hopeless, melancholy, glum, lugubrious, suspicious, distrustful, doubting, alarmist
etym: pessimist +‎ -ic
en: Someone who is pessimistic thinks that bad things are going to happen.
example: Not everyone is so pessimistic about the future
example_ko: They appeared surprisingly pessimistic about their chances of winning.
syn_a: bleak, cynical, dismal, gloomy, hopeless

ko: 건조시키다, <식품을> 물기를 빼서 건물(乾物)[가루]로 보관하다
zh_Hans: 把…弄干，使干（燥），使完全干燥；使脱水;用干燥法保存（食物），干贮（食物）；晒干；烘干；烤干;使智力枯竭；使…的感情枯竭
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：de 去掉 + sicc 干 + ate 表动词 → 脱水；干燥
syn: dried up, dry, dehydrated, powdered
etym: From Latin dēsiccāre (“to dry completely, dry up”)  +‎ -ate (verb suffix indicating acting in the specified manner).[1] Dēsiccāre is derived from dēsiccō (“to desiccate, dry up; to drain dry”) (from dē- (prefix meaning ‘completely, to exhaustion’) + siccō (“to dry; to drain, exhaust”), from siccus (“dry”), from Proto-Indo-European *seyk-) + -āre.
en: to remove most of the water from (a substance or material); dehydrate
example_ko: desiccate[/hw]d milk
syn_v: dehydrate, dry, parch

syn: tender, present, extend, give, submit, volunteer, suggest, propose, put forward
etym: From Middle English profren, from Old French proffrir, poroffrir, from por- + offrir (“offer”), from Latin pro (for, in front of) + offerre (“to carry forward”), from ob- (“to, toward”) + ferre (“to bring”).
en: If you proffer something to someone, you hold it towards them so that they can take it or touch it.
example: He rose and proffered a silver box full of cigarettes.
example_ko: [VN] ‘Try this,’ she said, proffering a plate.
syn_n: bid, presentation, proposal, proposition, submission
syn_v: extend, propose, submit, suggest, advance, donate, proffer, tender

zh_Hans: （尤指因自尊心受损而产生的）不悦，生气
syn: annoyance, resentment, anger, displeasure, indignation, temper, bad temper, hurt pride, wounded pride, hurt feelings, wounded feelings, petulance, ill humour, peevishness, offence, umbrage, vexation, exasperation, disgruntlement, discontent, discontentment
etym: Deverbal of piquer.
en: Pique is the feeling of annoyance you have when you think someone has not treated you properly.
example: Mimi had gotten over her pique at Susan's refusal to accept the job.
example_ko: When he realized nobody was listening to him, he left in a fit of pique.
syn_n: annoyance, exasperation, indignation, resentment
syn_v: annoy, irritate, miff, offend, peeve, arouse, excite, kindle, provoke, stimulate

zh_Hans: （某语言或学科的）全部辞汇；词典
syn: word stock, lexis
etym: English Wikipedia has articles on:lexiconWikipedia
en: The lexicon of a particular subject is all the terms associated with it. The lexicon of a person or group is all the words they commonly use.
example: the lexicon of management
example_ko: the lexicon of finance and economics

syn: devastate, ruin, leave in ruins, destroy, wreak havoc on, leave desolate, level, raze, demolish, wipe out, wreck, damage
etym: From French ravage (“ravage, havoc, spoil”), from ravir (“to bear away suddenly”), from Latin rapere (“to snatch, seize”), akin to Ancient Greek ἁρπάζω (harpázō, “to seize”)
en: A town, country, or economy that has been ravaged is one that has been damaged so much that it is almost completely destroyed.
example: For two decades the country has been ravaged by civil war and foreign intervention.
example_ko: a country ravaged by civil war
syn_v: despoil, pillage, plunder, raid, ransack, demolish, destroy, raze, rape  violate

zh_Hans: 战前的；尤指美国内战之前的
etym: From the Latin phrase ante bellum (literally “before the war”), from ante (“before”) + bellum (“war”).
en: of or during the period before a war, esp the American Civil War
example: the antebellum South
example_ko: the laws of the antebellum American South

syn: faked, copied, forged, feigned, simulated, sham, spurious, bogus, imitation, substitute, dummy, ersatz
etym: Anglo-Norman countrefait, from Old French contrefait.
en: Counterfeit money, goods, or documents are not genuine, but have been made to look exactly like genuine ones in order to deceive people.
example: He admitted possessing and delivering counterfeit currency.
example_ko: counterfeit watches
syn_n: fake, forgery, fraud, phony, copy, facsimile, imitation, substitute
syn_v: falsify, forge, plagiarize
syn_a: bogus, forged, fraudulent, sham, artificial, imitation, simulated

zh_Hans: （尤指派对）疯狂地饮酒作乐的
syn: sensualist, pleasure-seeking, self-indulgent, indulgent, libertine, sybaritic, voluptuary, lotus-eating
en: characterized by or involving drunken revelry

syn: independence, self-rule, home rule, sovereignty, self-determination, freedom, autarchy
etym: From Ancient Greek αὐτονομία (autonomía), from αὐτόνομος (autónomos), from αὐτός (autós, “self”) + νόμος (nómos, “law”). Surface analysis auto- (“self”) +‎ -nomy (“a system of rules or laws about a particular field”).
en: Autonomy is the control or government of a country, organization, or group by itself rather than by others.
example: Activists stepped up their demands for local autonomy last month.
example_ko: a campaign in Wales for greater autonomy
syn_n: freedom, home rule, independence, sovereignty

syn: adherent, believer, admirer, devotee, acolyte, votary
etym: From Middle English disciple, discipul, from Old English discipul m (“disciple; scholar”) and discipula f (“female disciple”), both from Latin discipulus (“a pupil, learner”). Later influenced or superseded in Middle English by Old French deciple.
en: If you are someone's disciple, you are influenced by their teachings and try to follow their example.
example: a disciple of Freud.
example_ko: a disciple of the economist John Maynard Keynes
syn_n: adherent, apostle, believer, convert, devotee, follower, pupil

syn: duplicitous, deceitful, disloyal, faithless, unfaithful, traitorous, treasonous, false, untrue, double-dealing, dishonest, two-faced, Janus-faced, untrustworthy
etym: From Latin perfidiōsus (“treacherous”), from perfidia.
en: If you describe someone as perfidious, you mean that they have betrayed someone or cannot be trusted.
example: Their feet will trample on the dead bodies of their perfidious aggressors.
syn_a: deceitful, disloyal, faithless, false, insidious, treacherous

zh_Hans: （用毒性气体）薰蒸，烟熏（以除害虫或消毒）
syn: purify, sterilize, sanitize, sanitate, decontaminate, cleanse, clean out
etym: Borrowed from Latin fūmigātus, past participle of fūmigō, from fūmus (“smoke”).
en: If you fumigate something, you get rid of germs or insects from it using special chemicals.
example: fruit which has been treated with insecticide and fumigated.
example_ko: to fumigate a room

zh_Hans: 乏味的；平淡无奇的；缺乏想像力的
syn: uninspired, matter-of-fact, dull, dry, humdrum, mundane, pedestrian, heavy, plodding, lifeless, dead, spiritless, lacklustre, undistinguished, stale, jejune, bland, insipid, vapid, vacuous, banal, hackneyed, trite, literal, factual, unpoetic, unemotional, unsentimental, clear, plain, unadorned, unembellished, unvarnished, monotonous, deadpan, flat
etym: From Middle French prosaïque, from Medieval Latin prosaicus (“in prose”), from Latin prosa (“prose”), from prorsus (“straightforward, in prose”), from Old Latin provorsus (“straight ahead”), from pro- (“forward”) + vorsus (“turned”), from vertō (“to turn”), from Proto-Indo-European *wer- (“to turn, to bend”).
en: Something that is prosaic is dull and uninteresting.
example: His instructor offered a more prosaic explanation for the surge in interest
example_ko: a prosaic style
syn_a: common, everyday, ordinary, routine, dry, dull, stale, trite, unimaginative

syn: object, take exception, take issue, protest, lodge a protest, cavil, dissent
etym:
From Anglo-Norman demorer, from Old French demorer (French demeurer), from Vulgar Latin demoro, Latin
demorari (“to tarry”), from de- + morari (“to delay”).[1]
en: If you demur, you say that you do not agree with something or will not do something that you have been asked to do.
example: The doctor demurred, but Piercey was insistent.
example_ko: [V] At first she demurred, but then finally agreed.
syn_n: compunction, hesitation, misgiving, objection, protest
syn_v: disagree, disapprove, dispute, dissent, object

syn: antiserum
etym: From Latin antidotum, from Ancient Greek ἀντίδοτον (antídoton), neuter of ἀντίδοτος (antídotos, “given as a remedy for”), from ἀντιδίδωμι (antidídōmi, “I give in return, repay”), from ἀντί (antí, “against”) + δίδωμι (dídōmi, “I give”). Compare French antidote.
en: An antidote is a chemical substance that stops or controls the effect of a poison.
example: When he returned, he noticed their sickness and prepared an antidote.
example_ko: There is no known antidote to the poison.
syn_n: corrective, cure, remedy, antitoxin, counteragent

zh_Hans: 证明…无罪；宣布…无罪；使免受责备
syn: clear, acquit, declare innocent, find innocent, pronounce not guilty, discharge
etym: From Latin exonerāt-, the participle stem of exonerāre, from exonerō (“to discharge, to unload; to exonerate”), from ex- (“a prefix denoting privation”) + onerō (“to burden, to lade, to load”) (from onus (“burden, load”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃énh₂os (“burden, load”), from *h₃enh₂- (“to charge, to onerate”)). Cognate with French exonérer.
en: If a court, report, or person in authority exonerates someone, they officially say or show that that person is not responsible for something wrong or unpleasant that has happened.
example: The official report basically exonerated everyone
example_ko: The police report exonerated Lewis from all charges of corruption.
syn_v: absolve, acquit, clear, exculpate, vindicate, discharge, free, release

syn: repulsive, repellent, repugnant, disgusting, offensive, objectionable, vile, foul, abhorrent, loathsome, nauseating, nauseous, sickening, hateful, detestable, execrable, abominable, monstrous, appalling, reprehensible, deplorable, insufferable, intolerable, unacceptable, despicable, contemptible, beyond the pale, unspeakable, poisonous, noxious, obscene, base, hideous, grisly, gruesome, horrendous, heinous, atrocious, awful, terrible, dreadful, frightful, obnoxious, unsavoury, unpalatable, unpleasant, disagreeable, nasty, distasteful, dislikeable, off-putting, displeasing
etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman, from Old French odieus, from Latin odiōsus, from odium (“hate”).
en: If you describe people or things as odious, you think that they are extremely unpleasant.
example: Herr Schmidt is certainly the most odious man I have ever met
example_ko: What an odious man!
syn_a: abhorrent, contemptible, detestable, heinous, loathsome, offensive, repugnant, repulsive, revolting, sickening

syn: untruthfulness, dishonesty, deceit, deceitfulness, deception, dissembling, insincerity, disingenuousness, hypocrisy, fraud, fraudulence, double-dealing, two-timing, duplicity, perjury, perfidy
etym: From Late Latin mendacitas [1], from Latin mendāx (“deceitful, deceptive, lying”) +‎ -itās (“suffix forming nouns indicating a state of being”). Mendāx is derived from mentior (“to deceive, lie”) (from mēns, mentis (“mind; intellect; judgment, reasoning”), from Proto-Indo-European *méntis (“thought”)) + -āx (“suffix forming adjectives expressing a tendency or inclination”), or from Proto-Indo-European *mend- (“to fault”).
en: Mendacity is lying, rather than telling the truth.
example: an astonishing display of cowardice and mendacity.

syn: blustering, ranting, blathering
etym: 18th century, from bombast (“padding, stuffing”).
en: If you describe someone as bombastic, you are criticizing them for trying to impress other people by saying things that sound impressive but have little meaning.
example: He was vain and bombastic.
syn_a: flamboyant, grandiloquent, pompous, pretentious, rhetorical

syn: antagonism, animosity, aversion, animus, opposition, enmity, dislike, distaste, ill will, ill feeling, hatred, hate, abhorrence, loathing, repugnance, odium
etym: From Ancient Greek ἀντιπάθεια (antipátheia), noun of state from ἀντιπαθής (antipathḗs, “opposed in feeling”), from ἀντί (antí, “against”) + root of πάθος (páthos, “feeling”).
en: Antipathy is a strong feeling of dislike or hostility towards someone or something.
example: She'd often spoken of her antipathy towards London.
example_ko: personal/mutual antipathy
syn_n: animosity, aversion, dislike, enmity, hostility, loathing

zh_Hans: 反常的；异常的；变态的（尤指不好的）
syn: uncommon, atypical, untypical, non-typical, unrepresentative, rare, isolated, irregular, anomalous, deviant, deviating, divergent, wayward, aberrant, freak, freakish
etym: From ab- +‎ normal. First attested in 1835, replacing the earlier anormal and even earlier abnormous,[1] from Latin abnormis (“departing from normal”), from either (ab- (“away from”) + norma (“rule, norm”)),[2] or Ancient Greek ἀνώμαλος (anṓmalos)[3].
en: Someone or something that is abnormal is unusual, especially in a way that is worrying.
example: abnormal heart rhythms and high anxiety levels.
example_ko: abnormal levels of sugar in the blood
syn_a: aberrant, anomalous, deviant, irregular, unnatural, exceptional, extraordinary, rare, bizarre, curious, odd, peculiar, strange

etym: Borrowed from French fugue, from Italian fuga (“flight, ardor”), from Latin fuga (“act of fleeing”), from fugere (“to flee”); compare Ancient Greek φυγή (phugḗ). Apparently from the metaphor that the first part starts alone on its course, and is pursued by later parts.
en: A fugue is a piece of music that begins with a simple tune which is then repeated by other voices or instrumental parts with small variations.

syn: speak at length about, write at length about, pontificate about, discourse on, expound, go into detail about, go on about, dwell on
etym: From the participle stem of Latin expatior, from ex- + spatior (“walk about”).
en: to enlarge (on a theme, topic, etc) at length or in detail; elaborate (on)

syn: inherited, hereditary, in the blood, in the family, innate, inbred, constitutional, built-in, inbuilt, ingrown, natural, native, original, inherent, unlearned, instinctual, deep-rooted, deep-seated
en: A congenital disease or medical condition is one that a person has had from birth, but is not inherited.
example: When John was 17, he died of congenital heart disease.
example_ko: congenital abnormalities
syn_a: hereditary, inborn, inherited, natural, deep-rooted, ingrained

syn: sharp, sharp-witted, razor-sharp, acute, quick, quick-witted, ingenious, clever, intelligent, bright, brilliant, smart, canny, media-savvy, intuitive, discerning, perceptive, perspicacious, penetrating, insightful, incisive, piercing, discriminating, sagacious, wise, judicious
etym: Latin astūtus, from astus (“craft”).
en: If you describe someone as astute, you think they show an understanding of behaviour and situations, and are skilful at using this knowledge to their own advantage.
example: She was politically astute
example_ko: an astute businessman/politician/observer
syn_a: bright, intelligent, perceptive, perspicacious, sagacious, smart, canny, clever, cunning, shrewd, sly

zh_Hans: 开始发展的；崭露头角的
syn: up-and-coming, rising, coming, in the making, aspiring, future, prospective, with potential
en: If you describe someone as, for example, a budding businessman or a budding artist, you mean that they are starting to succeed or become interested in business or art.
example: The forum is now open to all budding entrepreneurs
example_ko: a budding artist/writer
syn_a: blooming, blossoming, burgeoning, sprouting, aspiring, hopeful, promising

zh_Hans: （尤指对性伴侣的）忠诚，忠实，忠贞
syn: allegiance, obedience, constancy, fealty, homage
etym: 15th century, from Middle French fidélité, from Latin fidēlitās, from fidēlis (“faithful”), from fidēs (“faith, loyalty”) (English faith), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰidʰ-, zero-grade of Proto-Indo-European *bʰeydʰ- (“to command, to persuade, to trust”) (English bide). Doublet of fealty.
en: Fidelity is loyalty to a person, organization, or set of beliefs.
example: I had to promise fidelity to the Queen.
example_ko: fidelity to your principles
syn_n: allegiance, devotion, faithfulness, loyalty, adherence, adhesion, attachment, honesty, integrity, probity, accuracy, correctness, exactness

syn: supporter, upholder, defender, advocate, disciple, votary, partisan, member, friend, stalwart
etym: From Middle English adherent, from Old French adherent, from Latin adhaerēns, present participle of adhaereō (“to stick to, cling”).
en: An adherent is someone who holds a particular belief or supports a particular person or group.
example: This idea is gaining adherents.
example_ko: Once in the bloodstream, the bacteria adhere to the surface of the red cells.
syn_n: devotee, disciple, follower, satellite, backer, champion, patron, supporter
syn_a: adhesive, gluey, gummy, sticky, tacky

zh_Hans: 人型机器人；模拟机器人
etym: From New Latin androides, from Ancient Greek ἀνδρός (andrós, “man”) (genitive of ἀνήρ (anḗr)) + -ειδής (-eidḗs), itself from εἶδος (eîdos, “form, image, shape, appearance, look”). Note the form ἀνδρώδης (andrṓdēs, “manly”) already existed in Ancient Greek. Synchronically, andro- +‎ -oid.
en: In science fiction books and films, an android is a robot that looks like a human being.
example_ko: I’ve downloaded dozens of apps on my Android phone.

zh_Hans: （人或其言行）无节制的，过激的，放纵的
syn: excessive, undue, inordinate, unreasonable, unjustified, unwarranted, uncalled for
etym: in- +‎ temperate
en: If you describe someone's words as intemperate, you are critical of them because they are too forceful and uncontrolled.
example: The tone of the article is intemperate.
example_ko: intemperate language
syn_a: excessive, extravagant, immoderate, unrestrained, wanton, wild, drunken, intoxicated

syn: digressive, meandering, wandering, maundering, diffuse, long, lengthy
etym: Borrowed from Middle French discursif, formed from the stem of Latin discursus and the suffix -if, and in part borrowed from Medieval Latin discursivus.
en: If a style of writing is discursive, it includes a lot of facts or opinions that are not necessarily relevant.
example: a livelier, more candid and more discursive treatment of the subject.
example_ko: the discursive style of the novel
syn_a: circuitous, digressive, meandering, rambling, wandering

zh_Hans: 耍孩子脾气的，任性的；脾气暴躁的
syn: complaining, pettish, touchy, testy, tetchy, waspish, prickly, crusty, peppery, fractious, fretful, irritable, cross, crabbed, crabby, crotchety, cantankerous, curmudgeonly, disagreeable, miserable, morose, on edge, edgy, impatient, bitter, moody, in a bad mood, grumpy, huffy, scratchy, out of sorts, out of temper, ill-tempered, bad-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, sullen, surly, sulky, sour, churlish, bilious, liverish, dyspeptic, splenetic, choleric
etym: From Middle French, from Latin petulāns, akin to petere.
