en: Someone who is petulant is unreasonably angry and upset in a childish way.
example: His critics say he's just being silly and petulant
syn_a: cantankerous, cross, fractious, irritable, peevish, surly, testy

ko: 멍하게 만들다, 어리벙벙하게 하다; 생각에 잠기게 하다
en: If something bemuses you, it puzzles or confuses you.
example: The sheer quantity of detail would bemuse even the most clear-headed author.
example_ko: a bemused expression/smile
syn_a: bewildered, confused, perplexed, puzzled, engrossed, enthralled  preoccupied

syn: smile coquettishly, giggle, titter, smirk, look coy
etym: Origin uncertain; compare (probably from[1]) Danish simper / semper (“coy”), German zimper (“elegant, dainty”).
en: When someone simpers, they smile in a rather silly way.
example: The maid lowered her chin and simpered.
example_ko: [V] a silly simpering girl

syn: meeting, junction, joining, conflux, watersmeet
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin confluentia, from con- + fluere.
en: The confluence of two rivers is the place where they join and become one larger river.
example: The 160-metre falls mark the dramatic confluence of the rivers Nera and Velino.
example_ko: confluence hunters around the world
syn_n: concourse, junction, nexus, union

syn: lithe, sprightly, acrobatic, light-footed, nimble-footed, light, light on one's feet, fleet-footed, spry, lively, active, quick, quick-moving, graceful, supple, limber, lissom, flexible, skilful, deft, dexterous, adroit
etym: From Middle English defte, daft (“gentle”), from Old English dæfte, ġedæfte (“mild, gentle, meek”), from Proto-Germanic *daftuz (“accommodating, convenient”), derived from *dabaną (“to be suitable”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰh₂ebʰ- (“fitting, fit together”). Near cognates include Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐌳𐍉𐍆𐍃 (gadōfs, “suitable”), West Frisian deftich (“distinguished”), Dutch deftig (“distinguished”), German deftig (“coarse”). Further cognates include Russian добро (dobro, “wealth, good”) and Latin faber (“craftsman; skillful”).
en: A deft action is skilful and often quick.
example: With a deft flick of his foot, Mr Worth tripped one of the raiders up.
example_ko: deft hands/fingers/footwork
syn_a: able, expert, quick, sure, adroit, dexterous, skillful

zh_Hans: 无节制的，过分的，恣意的；不负责的
syn: wilful, malicious, malevolent, spiteful, vicious, wicked, evil, cruel
etym: From Middle English wantoun, wantowen, wantoȝen, wantowe (“uneducated; unrestrained; licentious; sportive; playful”), from wan- (“not, un-, mis-”) + towen, i-towen (“educated”, literally “towed; led; drawn”), from Old English togen, ġetogen, past participle of tēon (“to train, discipline”), equivalent to wan- +‎ towed.
en: A wanton action deliberately causes harm, damage, or waste without having any reason to.
example: this unnecessary and wanton destruction of our environment
example_ko: wanton destruction
syn_a: dissolute, fast, loose, promiscuous, cruel, malicious, spiteful, vicious, perverse, unruly, wild, willful

etym: From intra- +‎ venous.
en: Intravenous foods or drugs are given to sick people through their veins, rather than their mouths.
example: an intravenous drip.
example_ko: intravenous fluids

syn: concurrence, coincidence, coexistence, simultaneity, simultaneousness, contemporaneity, contemporaneousness, concomitance, synchronicity, synchrony
etym: From Old French conjonction, from Latin coniūnctiō (“joining”), from coniungere (“to join”).
en: A conjunction of two or more things is the occurrence of them at the same time or place.
example: the conjunction of two events.
example_ko: The police are working in conjunction with tax officers on the investigation.
syn_n: amalgamation, combination, joining, unification, accord, concert, synergy, union

zh_Hans: （地方）环境宜人且有益健康的，宜居的
syn: health-giving, healthful, beneficial, good for one's health, wholesome, salutary
etym: From Latin salūbris (“healthy”)  +‎ -ous.
en: A place that is salubrious is pleasant and healthy.
example: your salubrious lochside hotel.

syn: visit, stop, stopover, residence
etym: Borrowed from Old French sojor, sojorner (modern séjour, séjourner), from (assumed) Vulgar Latin *subdiurnāre, from Latin sub- (“under, a little over”) + Late Latin diurnus (“lasting for a day”), from Latin dies (“day”).[1]
en: A sojourn is a short stay in a place that is not your home.

syn: unhurried, tardy, unpunctual, lax, slack, sluggish, sluggardly, snail-like, tortoise-like, lazy, idle, indolent, slothful
etym: From Old French dilatoire [1], from Latin dilatorius (“extending or putting off (time)”), from dilator, from differo. Not etymologically related to delay.
en: Someone or something that is dilatory is slow and causes delay.
example: You might expect politicians to smooth things out when civil servants are being dilatory.
example_ko: The government has been dilatory in dealing with the problem of unemployment.
syn_a: indolent, lackadaisical, lazy, negligent, remiss, slothful, procrastinating, slow, sluggish, tardy

syn: pious, pietistic, self-righteous, holier-than-thou, superior, insincere, specious, feigned, pretended, hollow, false
etym: From hypocritic + -al, from ὑποκριτικός (hupokritikós), from ὑποκριτής (hupokritḗs, “actor, hypocrite”), from ὑποκρίνομαι (hupokrínomai, “I play a part on stage”), from ὑπό (hupó, “below”) + κρίνω (krínō, “I choose”).
en: If you accuse someone of being hypocritical, you mean that they pretend to have qualities, beliefs, or feelings that they do not really have.
example: It would be hypocritical to say I travel at 70mph simply because that is the law
example_ko: He condemned the hypocrisy of those politicians who do one thing and say another.
syn_a: counterfeit, deceptive, insincere, phony, two-faced

syn: announce, make known, state, communicate, reveal, divulge, mention, talk about, raise, moot, air, bring into the open, voice, articulate, pronounce, express, vent, set forth, make public, publicize, disseminate, circulate, publish, broadcast, promulgate, trumpet, blazon
etym: From Latin habeō.
en: If you aver that something is the case, you say very firmly that it is true.
example: He avers that chaos will erupt if he loses
example_ko: [V that] She averred that she had never seen the man before.
syn_v: affirm, attest, aver, avouch, avow, declare, profess, allege, claim, maintain, advance, argue, contend, insist, propound, accuse, charge, impugn, impute

zh_Hans: 患胆病的；胆汁分泌过多的
syn: sick, queasy, nauseated, green about the gills, liverish
etym: From French bilieux, from Latin bīliōsus (“full of bile”), from bīlis (“bile”) + -ōsus (“full of”).
en: If someone describes the appearance of something as bilious, they mean that they think it looks unpleasant and rather disgusting.
example: a bilious shade of green.
syn_a: cranky, grouchy, irritable, peevish, testy, nauseous, queasy, sick

zh_Hans: 温和的；温顺的，驯服的；易控制的
syn: obedient, pliant, dutiful, willing, passive, submissive, deferential, tame, meek, mild, lamblike, unassertive, unresisting, yielding, cooperative, amenable, accommodating, biddable, persuadable, ductile, manageable, controllable, tractable, malleable, manipulable, easily manipulated, easily handled, like putty in one's hands
etym: Borrowed from Middle French docile, from Latin docilis, from docere (“teach”).
en: A person or animal that is docile is quiet, not aggressive, and easily controlled.
example: docile, obedient children
example_ko: a docile child/horse
syn_a: manageable, obedient, pliant, submissive, teachable, tractable, gentle, tame, accommodating, agreeable, complacent, obliging, willing

syn: violate, transgress, break, breach, commit a breach of, disobey, defy, flout, fly in the face of, ride roughshod over, kick against
etym: Borrowed from Latin infringere (“to break off, break, bruise, weaken, destroy”), from in (“in”) + frangere (“to break”).
en: If someone infringes a law or a rule, they break it or do something which disobeys it.
example: The film exploited his image and infringed his copyright
example_ko: The material can be copied without infringing copyright.
syn_v: encroach, impinge, intrude, invade, trespass, break, infract, transgress, violate

etym: phonetic +‎ -ics.
en: In linguistics, phonetics is the study of speech sounds.

zh_Hans: （指言语）粗俗诙谐的；猥亵逗笑的
syn: indecent, risqué, rude, racy, broad, earthy, Rabelaisian, spicy, suggestive, titillating, improper, naughty, indelicate, indecorous, off colour, locker-room
etym: From Middle English ribald, from Old French ribaud, ribauld (“rogue, scoundrel”) ( > English ribaud), from Old French riber (“to be licentious”), from Frankish *rīban (“to copulate, be in heat”, literally “to rub”), from Proto-Germanic *wrībaną (“to turn, twist, writhe”), from Proto-Indo-European *werp-, *werb- (“to turn, twist”) + Old French -aud, from Frankish *-wald. Related to Old High German rīban (“to rub”), German reiben (“to rub”), Dutch wrijven (“to rub”). Compare also Old High German hrība (“prostitute”). See also English wrap.
en: A ribald remark or sense of humour is rather rude and refers to sex in a humorous way.
example: her ribald comments about a fellow guest's body language.
syn_a: coarse, earthy, lewd, obscene, suggestive, vulgar

zh_Hans: 小孔；缝隙；（尤指照相机的）孔径，光圈
syn: hole, gap, space, slit, slot, vent, passage, crevice, chink, crack, fissure, perforation, breach, eye, interstice
etym: Borrowed from Latin apertūra (“opening”), from apertus, past participle of aperīre (“to open, uncover”), opposed to operīre (“to close, cover”). See aperient. Doublet of overture.
en: An aperture is a narrow hole or gap.
example: Through the aperture he could see daylight.
syn_n: breach, hole, opening, orifice, slit  slot

zh_Hans: 相反的;对立的;不相容的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：anti 相反；反对 + thet 放置 + ical …的 → 反着放的 → 对立的
syn: directly opposed to, contrary to, contradictory to, conflicting with, incompatible with, irreconcilable with, inconsistent with, at variance with, at odds with, contrasting with, different from, different to, differing from, divergent from, unlike
etym: From antithetic +‎ -al.
en: Something that is antithetical to something else is the opposite of it and is unable to exist with it.
example: Their priorities are antithetical to those of environmentalists.
example_ko: Love is the antithesis of selfishness.

syn: group, cabal, clique, party, set, ring, gang, league, confederacy
etym: Borrowed from Spanish junta, feminine form of junto, from Latin iunctus, perfect passive participle of iungō (“join”). 1623.
en: A junta is a military government that has taken power by force, and not through elections.
syn_n: band, coalition, committee, council, faction  gang

syn: time, period, era, epoch, century, decade, year, stage
etym: From Middle English centurie (“a count of one hundred (of anything); a division of the Roman army; century; a division of land”), from Old French centurie, from Latin centuria, from centum (“one hundred”). The most common modern use is a shortening of century of years.
en: A century is a period of a hundred years that is used when stating a date. For example, the 19th century was the period from 1801 to 1900.
example: celebrated figures of the late eighteenth century.

syn: rental agreement, hire agreement, charter, contract
en: A lease is a legal agreement by which the owner of a building, a piece of land, or something such as a car allows someone else to use it for a period of time in return for money.
example: He took up a 10 year lease on the house at Rossie Priory.
example_ko: to take out a lease on a house

syn: enthralling, entrancing, bewitching, captivating, intriguing, riveting, transfixing, engrossing, gripping, very interesting, very exciting, thrilling, absorbing, compelling, compulsive, mesmerizing, mesmeric, hypnotic, magical
etym: spell +‎ bind
en: to cause to be spellbound; entrance or enthral

syn: complain, expostulate
etym: From (the participle stem of) Late Latin remōnstrō, from Latin re- + mōnstrō.
en: If you remonstrate with someone, you protest to them about something you do not approve of or agree with, and you try to get it changed or stopped.
example: He remonstrated with the referee
example_ko: [V] They remonstrated with the official about the decision.
syn_v: admonish, censure, chide, reprimand, reprove, scold

zh_Hans: 离开预期方向（的）；出错（的）
syn: wrong, not right
etym: a- (preposition) +‎ wry
en: If something goes awry, it does not happen in the way it was planned.
example: She was in a fury over a plan that had gone awry.
example_ko: All my plans for the party had gone awry.
syn_a: amiss, wrong, askance, askew, crooked, uneven

syn: harmony, accord, consensus, concurrence, unity, unanimity, unison, oneness
en: Concord is a state of peaceful agreement.
example: They expressed the hope that he would pursue a neutral and balanced policy for the sake of national concord.
example_ko: living in concord with neighbouring states
syn_n: friendship, goodwill, harmony, peace, accord, agreement, treaty

syn: ridiculing, jeering, scoffing, jibing, pillorying, teasing, derisory, snide
etym: From the participle stem of Latin dērīdeō (“I deride”).
en: A derisive noise, expression, or remark expresses contempt.
example: There was a short, derisive laugh.
example_ko: She gave a short, derisive laugh.
syn_a: contemptuous, disdainful, mocking, scornful

syn: defeat, vanquish, get the better of, overpower, overcome, overwhelm, crush, quash, quell, beat, trounce, subjugate, master, suppress, gain the upper hand over, triumph over, tame, bring someone to their knees, hold in check, humble, chasten, cow
etym: From Old French souduire, from Latin subdūcere (“to draw away”), perhaps influenced by Latin subdere (“subdue, subject”).
en: If soldiers or the police subdue a group of people, they defeat them or bring them under control by using force.
example: Senior government officials admit they have not been able to subdue the rebels.
example_ko: Troops were called in to subdue the rebels.
syn_v: repress, stifle, suppress, lower, moderate, temper, assuage, calm, mollify, soothe, conquer, defeat, master, overthrow, vanquish

syn: fib, untruth, false statement, falsification, fabrication, invention, piece of fiction, fiction, story, yarn, made-up story, trumped-up story, fake news, cock and bull story, flight of fancy, figment of the imagination
etym: From Middle English falshede, from false + -hede.
en: Falsehood is the quality or fact of being untrue or of being a lie.
example: She called the verdict a victory of truth over falsehood.
example_ko: to test the truth or falsehood of her claims
syn_n: fib, lie, story, tale, fabrication, misrepresentation, untruth, deceit, dishonesty, lying

zh_Hans: 暂停；暂时中止；暂时缓解
syn: break, breathing space, interval, intermission, interlude, recess, lull, pause, time out, hiatus, halt, stop, stoppage, cessation, discontinuation, standstill
etym: From Anglo-Norman and Old French respit (“rest”), from Latin respectus. Doublet of respect.
en: A respite is a short period of rest from something unpleasant.
example: It was some weeks now since they had had any respite from shellfire.
example_ko: The drug brought a brief respite from the pain.
syn_n: break, lull, recess  rest

syn: consecration, sanctification, hallowing, benediction
etym: Borrowed from Ecclesiastical Latin benedictio, benedictionis, from benedictus (“blessed; well spoken of”). Doublet of benison.
en: A benediction is a kind of Christian prayer.
example: The minister pronounced the benediction
syn_n: benison, blessing, consecration, prayer

zh_Hans: 声明放弃；宣布放弃；弃绝
syn: refuse to abide by, refuse to recognize, repudiate
etym: From Old French renoncier (French renoncer), from Latin renuntiare.
en: If you renounce a belief or a way of behaving, you decide and declare publicly that you no longer have that belief or will no longer behave in that way.
example: After a period of imprisonment she renounced terrorism
example_ko: to renounce a claim/title/privilege/right
syn_v: abjure, forswear, reject, repudiate, abandon, disown, forsake, abdicate, give up, relinquish

zh_Hans: 预后，预断（指医生对病情发展的预测）
syn: prognosis, judgement, verdict, pronouncement, conclusion, interpretation
etym: Borrowed from Latin prognōsis, from Ancient Greek πρόγνωσις (prógnōsis, “foreknowledge, perceiving beforehand, prediction”), from prefix προ- (pro-, “before”) + γνῶσις (gnôsis, “inquiry, investigation, knowing”), from γιγνώσκω (gignṓskō, “know”). First attested in the mid 17th century. Equivalent to Germanic cognate foreknowledge, Latinate cognate precognition, and Sanskritic cognate prajna.
en: A prognosis is an estimate of the future of someone or something, especially about whether a patient will recover from an illness.
example: If the cancer is caught early the prognosis is excellent.
syn_n: forecast, guess, outlook, prognostication, projection  prophecy

zh_Hans: 内环境稳定，体内动态平衡（生物、活细胞、组织等，在其外部环境变化的情况下，保持内部不变或平衡状态的能力或趋向）
etym: Coined from Ancient Greek ὅμοιος (hómoios, “similar”) + ἵστημι (hístēmi, “standing still”)/stasis (from στάσις (stásis)) by Walter Bradford Cannon.
en: the maintenance of metabolic equilibrium within an animal by a tendency to compensate for disrupting changes

zh_Hans: 显而易见的作假；明显的伪装
syn: pantomime, travesty, mockery, parody, pretence, act, masquerade, sham, fake, false display, show, front, facade
etym: From French charade, charrade (“prattle, idle conversation; a kind of riddle”), probably from Occitan charrada (“conversation; chatter”), from charrar (“to chat; to chatter”) + -ada.[1] As a round of the game, originally a clipping of acting charade but now usually understood and formed as a back-formation from charades.
en: If you describe someone's actions as a charade, you mean that their actions are so obviously false that they do not convince anyone.
example: I wondered why he had gone through the elaborate charade
example_ko: Their whole marriage had been a charade—they had never loved each other.

ko: (다른 장소나 상황에서 어떤 사람·사물과 동일한 지위나 기능을 갖는) 상대, 대응 관계에 있는 사람[것]
zh_Hans: （与不同地方或组织的人或物）作用相同者，相对应者
syn: opposite number, peer, equal, parallel, complement, match, twin, mate, fellow, brother, sister, analogue, correlative
etym: Recorded since 1451, originally as countre part "duplicate of a legal document", from Old French contrepartie, itself from contre (“facing, opposite”) (from Latin contra (“against”)) + partie (“copy of a person or thing”) (originally past participle of partīre (“to divide”)). Equivalent to counter- +‎ part.
en: Someone's or something's counterpart is another person or thing that has a similar function or position in a different place.
example: The Foreign Secretary telephoned his Italian counterpart to protest.
example_ko: The Foreign Minister held talks with his Chinese counterpart.
syn_n: companion, complement, correlative, analogue, equal, parallel  twin

zh_Hans: 虚假的，捏造的，不真实的
syn: untruthful, dishonest, deceitful, false, dissembling, insincere, disingenuous, hypocritical, fraudulent, double-dealing, two-faced, Janus-faced, two-timing, duplicitous, perjured, perfidious
etym: Borrowed from Middle French mendacieux, from Latin mendācium (“lie, untruth”), from mendāx (“lying”).
en: A mendacious person is someone who tells lies. A mendacious statement is one that is a lie.
example: an astonishing display of cowardice and mendacity.

zh_Hans: 引起（某种感觉）；导致；产生
syn: be the cause of, give rise to, bring about, lead to, result in, produce, create, generate, arouse, rouse, provoke, incite, kindle, trigger, spark off, touch off, stir up, whip up, induce, inspire, instigate, foment, effect, occasion, promote, foster
en: If someone or something engenders a particular feeling, atmosphere, or situation, they cause it to occur.
example: It helps engender a sense of common humanity
example_ko: The issue engendered controversy.
syn_v: cause, generate, occasion, produce, bear, beget, breed, sire

etym: From French centrifuge from Latin centrum (“center”) + fugiō (“to flee”)
en: A centrifuge is a machine that spins mixtures of different substances around very quickly so that they separate by centrifugal force.

syn: belief, conviction, tenet, principle, ethic, precept, maxim, article of faith, canon, law, rule
etym: English Wikipedia has an article on:dogmaWikipedia
en: If you refer to a belief or a system of beliefs as a dogma, you disapprove of it because people are expected to accept that it is true, without questioning it.
example: Their political dogma has blinded them to the real needs of the country
example_ko: political/religious/party dogma
syn_n: beliefs, convictions, creed, doctrine, precepts, teachings  tenets

zh_Hans: （尤指在分配物短缺时的）配给量，定量配给
syn: allocation, quota, fixed amount, amount, quantity, share, portion, helping, allotment, measure, part, lot, proportion, percentage
etym: From French ration. Doublet of reason and ratio.
en: When there is not enough of something, your ration of it is the amount that you are allowed to have.
example: The meat ration was down to one pound per person per week
example_ko: the weekly butter ration
syn_n: allocation, measure, portion, quota, share, rations, provisions, stock, supplies, victuals
syn_v: allocate, allot, apportion, dole out, mete out  proportion

syn: gentle, temperate, summery, calm, tranquil, clement, fine, pleasant, benign, soothing, soft
etym: From Old French, from Latin clēmēns.[1]
en: Clement weather is pleasantly mild and dry.
syn_a: charitable, compassionate, indulgent, lenient, merciful, balmy, fair, mild, moderate, temperate

syn: polyphony, consonance
etym: From poly- +‎ -phony.
en: polyphonic style of composition or a piece of music utilizing it

etym: enamor +‎ -ed
en: If you are enamoured of something, you like or admire it a lot. If you are not enamoured of something, you dislike or disapprove of it.
example: I became totally enamored of the wildflowers there
example_ko: He was less than enamoured of the music.
syn_v: charm, enchant, enthrall, fascinate, infatuate

zh_Hans: 鉴定，化验，分析（化学物质的纯度）
syn: assessment, analysis, examination, test, trial, check, inspection, appraisal, investigation, scrutiny, probe
etym: From Middle English assay (noun) and assayen (verb), from Anglo-Norman assai (noun) and Anglo-Norman assaier (verb), from Old French essai. Doublet of essay.
en: An assay is a test of a substance to find out what chemicals it contains. It is usually carried out to find out how pure a substance is.
syn_v: attempt, endeavor, try, undertake, analyze, appraise, estimate, evaluate  test

syn: decline, say no to, reject, rebuff, scorn, turn down, turn away, repudiate, treat with contempt, disdain, look down one's nose at, despise
etym: From Middle English spurnen, spornen, from Old English spurnan (“to strike against, kick, spurn, reject; stumble”)[1], from Proto-Germanic *spurnaną (“to tread, kick, knock out”), from Proto-Indo-European *sper-, *sperw- (“to twitch, push, fidget, be quick”). Cognate with Scots spurn (“to strike, push, kick”), German spornen (“to spur on”), Icelandic sporna, spyrna (“to kick”), Latin spernō (“despise, distain, scorn”). Related to spur and spread.
en: If you spurn someone or something, you reject them.
example: He spurned the advice of management consultants
example_ko: Eve spurned Mark’s invitation.
syn_v: defy, disdain, reject, repudiate, scorn, ignore, mock, slight, snub

syn: resentfully, angrily, furiously, wrathfully
en: If you say that someone is in high dudgeon, you are emphasizing that they are very angry or unhappy about something.
example: Washington businesses are in high dudgeon over the plan.
example_ko: in high[or deep] dudgeon

zh_Hans: 由同类事物（或人）组成的；同类的；相似的
syn: comparable, equivalent, like, analogous, corresponding, correspondent, parallel, matching, kindred, related, correlative, congruent, cognate
etym: From Medieval Latin homogeneus, from Ancient Greek ὁμογενής (homogenḗs, “of the same race, family or kind”), from ὁμός (homós, “same”) + γένος (génos, “kind”). Compare homo- (“same”) and -ous (adjectival suffix).
en: Homogeneous is used to describe a group or thing which has members or parts that are all the same.
example: The unemployed are not a homogeneous group
example_ko: a homogeneous group/mixture/population
syn_a: alike, consistent, identical, similar, uniform  unvarying

syn: confused, puzzled, perplexed, baffled, stumped, mystified, stupefied, nonplussed, muddled, befuddled, fuddled, dumbfounded, at sea, at a loss, at sixes and sevens, thrown, thrown off balance, taken aback, disoriented, disconcerted, discomposed, troubled, discomfited, unnerved, shaken, shaken up, dazed, stunned, astonished, astounded
en: If you are bemused, you are puzzled or confused.
example: He was rather bemused by children
example_ko: a bemused expression/smile
syn_a: bewildered, confused, perplexed, puzzled, engrossed, enthralled  preoccupied

syn: Casanova, Don Juan, Lothario, flirt, ladies' man, playboy, Romeo, seducer, rake, roué, libertine, debauchee
etym: From philander (“lover”) +‎ -er, from Ancient Greek φίλανδρος (phílandros), from φίλος (phílos, “love”) + ἀνήρ (anḗr, “man”).
en: If you say that a man is a philanderer, you mean that he has a lot of casual sexual relationships with women.

zh_Hans: 对…感到悲痛，对…表示失望，痛惜
syn: wailing, lamentation, moan, moaning, groan, weeping, crying, sob, sobbing, keening, howl, complaint
etym: From French lamenter, from Latin lāmentor (“I wail, weep”), from lāmenta (“wailings, laments, moanings”); with formative -mentum, from the root *la-, probably ultimately imitative. Also see latrare.
en: If you lament something, you express your sadness, regret, or disappointment about it.
example: Ken began to lament the death of his only son
example_ko: [VN] In the poem he laments the destruction of the countryside.
syn_n: complaint, lamentation, howl, moan, whimper, dirge, requiem
syn_v: commiserate, deplore, grieve, mourn, sorrow, cry, sob, wail, weep

en: Rationing is the system of limiting the amount of food, water, petrol, or other necessary substances that each person is allowed to have or buy when there is not enough of them.
example: The municipal authorities here are preparing for food rationing.
example_ko: the weekly butter ration

syn: ending, termination, stopping, halting, ceasing, finish, finishing, stoppage, closing, closure, close, conclusion, winding up, discontinuation, discontinuance, breaking off, abandonment, interruption, suspension, cutting short
etym: From Middle French cessation, from Latin cessatio.
en: The cessation of something is the stopping of it.
example: He would not agree to a cessation of hostilities.
example_ko: Mexico called for an immediate cessation of hostilities.
syn_n: completion, conclusion, ending, finish, break, intermission, lull, pause

syn: stick fast, cling, hold fast, cohere, bond, attach
etym: From Middle English *adheren (suggested by Middle English adherande (“adhering, adherent”, present participle)), from Latin adhaerēre, adhaesum: ad (“to”) + haerēre (“to stick”). Compare French adhérer.
en: If you adhere to a rule or agreement, you act in the way that it says you should.
example: All members of the association adhere to a strict code of practice
example_ko: Once in the bloodstream, the bacteria adhere to the surface of the red cells.
syn_v: attach, cling, fasten, hold, stick, cleave, follow, heed, keep, maintain

syn: woeful, sorrowful, sad, unhappy, depressed, dismal, gloomy, morose, melancholy, miserable, forlorn, wretched, woebegone, despondent, dejected, disconsolate, downcast, crestfallen, downhearted, heartbroken, heavy-hearted, despairing, desolate, grief-stricken
etym: From Middle English doleful, doolful, deolful, equivalent to dole +‎ -ful.
en: A doleful expression, manner, or voice is depressing and miserable.
example: He gave me a long, doleful look.
example_ko: a doleful expression/face/song
syn_a: dismal, gloomy, melancholy, sad, unhappy, woeful

syn: turn away, turn to one side
etym: From Old French avertir (“turn, direct, avert; turn the attention, make aware”), from Latin āvertere, present active infinitive of āvertō, from ab + vertō (“to turn”).
en: If you avert something unpleasant, you prevent it from happening.
example: Talks with the teachers' union over the weekend have averted a strike
example_ko: A disaster was narrowly averted.
syn_v: avert, deflect, deter, preclude, stay, frustrate, hinder, interfere, obstruct, thwart

syn: yellowish brown, pale brown, buff, sand, sandy, oatmeal, wheaten, biscuit, café au lait, camel, kasha, ecru, taupe, stone, stone-coloured, greige, greyish brown, mushroom, putty
en: Fawn is a pale yellowish-brown colour.
example: a light fawn coat.
example_ko: a fawn coat
syn_v: brownnose, grovel, kowtow, toady

zh_Hans: （信仰、观点或活动）正统的，传统的，普遍接受的
syn: traditional, observant, conformist, devout, strict, true, true blue, of the faith, of the true faith
etym: From Late Latin orthodoxus, from Ancient Greek ὀρθόδοξος (orthódoxos), from ὀρθός (orthós, “straight”) + δόξα (dóxa, “opinion”).
en: Orthodox beliefs, methods, or systems are ones which are accepted or used by most people.
example: Many of these ideas are now being incorporated into orthodox medical treatment.
example_ko: orthodox medicine
syn_a: accepted, approved, conventional, established, kosher, traditional, conservative, dogmatic, puritanical, unyielding, devout, doctrinal, pious, religious

syn: learner, inexperienced person, neophyte, newcomer, new member, new recruit, raw recruit, new boy, new girl, initiate, tyro, fledgling
etym: From Latin tīro (“young soldier, recruit”).
en: A tyro is a person who is just beginning to learn something or who has very little experience of something.
example: a tyro journalist.

syn: learner, novice, newcomer, new member, new entrant, new recruit, raw recruit, new boy, new girl, initiate, tyro, fledgling
etym: Borrowed from Latin neophytus, from Ancient Greek νεόφυτος (neóphutos, “newly planted”), from νέος (néos, “new”) + φυτόν (phutón, “plant, child”). Surface analysis is neo- +‎ -phyte.
en: A neophyte is someone who is new to a particular activity.
example: the self-proclaimed political neophyte Ross Perot.
example_ko: The site gives neophytes the chance to learn from experts.
syn_n: apprentice, beginner, freshman, newcomer, novice, convert, proselyte  veteran

syn: momentousness, import, consequence, note, noteworthiness, substance, value
etym: Borrowed from Middle French importance, from Medieval Latin importantia.
en: The importance of something is its quality of being significant, valued, or necessary in a particular situation.
example: We have always stressed the importance of economic reform
syn_n: consequence, import, magnitude, relevance, significance, distinction, eminence, influence, position, prominence, gravity, value, weight, worth

zh_Hans: （通常指因为某物过于昂贵或稀有而以其他事物）代用的
syn: substitute, imitation, synthetic, fake, false, faux, mock, simulated
etym: Borrowed from German Ersatz (“replacement”); and from the German ersetzen (“to replace”, verb).
en: If you describe something as ersatz, you dislike it because it is not genuine and is a poor imitation of something better.
example: an ersatz Victorian shopping precinct
example_ko: ersatz coffee
syn_a: artificial, fake, imitation, synthetic

syn: sample, exemplar, exemplification, instance, case, representative case, typical case, case in point, illustration
etym: Established 1475-85 from Late Latin paradīgma, from Ancient Greek παράδειγμα (parádeigma, “pattern”), from παραδείκνυμι (paradeíknumi, “I show [beside] or compare”) + -μα (-ma, “forming nouns concerning the results of actions”).
en: A paradigm is a model for something which explains it or shows how it can be produced.
example: a new paradigm of production.
example_ko: a paradigm for students to copy
syn_n: example, ideal, model, pattern, prototype  standard

syn: propensity, proclivity, leaning
etym: From Middle English inclinacioun, inclinacyon, from Old French inclination and Latin inclīnātiō.
en: An inclination is a feeling that makes you want to act in a particular way.
example: He had neither the time nor the inclination to think of other things
example_ko: He did not show the slightest inclination to leave.
syn_n: bent, leaning, preference, proclivity, propensity, tendency, acclivity, pitch, rise, slope, bow, tilt

ko: (진술·이론 등을 뒷받침하는 증거나 정보를) 제공하다, 확증[입증]하다
syn: verify, endorse, ratify, authenticate, validate, certify
etym: From Latin corrōborātus (“strengthened”), perfect passive participle of corrōborō (“I support, corroborate”), from com- (“together”) + rōborō (“I strengthen”), from rōbur (“strength”).
en: To corroborate something that has been said or reported means to provide evidence or information that supports it.
example: I had access to a wide range of documents which corroborated the story
example_ko: The evidence was corroborated by two independent witnesses.
syn_v: authenticate, confirm, corroborate, document, support, validate, verify

syn: baby bird, nestling
etym: From fledge (“prepare for flying”) +‎ -ling.
en: A fledgling is a young bird that has its feathers and is learning to fly.

zh_Hans: 时代错误，年代误植，不合时代的人（或物）
etym: From New Latin anachronismus, from Ancient Greek ἀναχρονισμός (anakhronismós), from ἀναχρονίζομαι (anakhronízomai, “referring to the wrong time”), from ἀνά (aná, “up against”) + χρονίζω (khronízō, “spending time”), from χρόνος (khrónos, “time”). Analyzable as ana- +‎ chrono- +‎ -ism
en: You say that something is an anachronism when you think that it is out of date or old-fashioned.
example: The President tended to regard the Church as an anachronism.
example_ko: The monarchy is seen by many people as an anachronism in the modern world.

etym: Old French synagoge, from Ancient Greek συναγωγή (sunagōgḗ, “assembly, gathering”), from συνάγω (sunágō, “I gather together”), from σύν (sún, “with, together”) + ἄγω (ágō, “I lead”)
en: A synagogue is a building where Jewish people meet to worship or to study their religion.

syn: placate, pacify, mollify, propitiate, assuage, calm down, soothe, humour, reconcile, disarm, win over, make peace with
etym: From Latin plācātus, past participle of plācō (“appease, placate”, literally “smooth, smoothen”), from Proto-Indo-European *plāk- (“smooth, flat”), from Proto-Indo-European *pele- (“broad, flat, plain”). Related to Latin placeō (“appease”), Old English flōh (“flat stone, chip”). More at please.
en: If you placate someone, you do or say something to make them stop feeling angry.
example: He smiled, trying to placate me
example_ko: a placating smile
syn_v: appease, assuage, calm, mollify, pacify  propitiate

syn: lecherous, lascivious, lewd, carnal
etym: From Middle English libidinous, borrowed from Latin libīdinōsus.
en: People who are libidinous have strong sexual feelings and express them in their behaviour.
example: Powell let his libidinous imagination run away with him.

syn: quiet, hush, lullaby
etym: From Middle English lullen, lollen. Cognate with Scots lul, lule, loll (“to lull, put to sleep, howl, caterwaul”), Dutch lollen (“to sing badly, caterwaul”), Dutch lullen (“to chatter, prate, cheat, deceive”), Low German lullen (“to lull”), German lullen (“to lull”), Danish lulle (“to lull, sing to sleep”), Swedish lulla (“to lull”), Icelandic lulla (“to lull”). Originally, perhaps expressive in origin from la-la-la or lu-lu-lu sounds made in calming a child.
en: A lull is a period of quiet or calm in a longer period of activity or excitement.
example: There was a lull in political violence after the election of the current president.
example_ko: a lull in the conversation/fighting
syn_n: calm, hush, quiet, break, lapse, pause, respite
syn_v: assuage, mollify, pacify, placate, soothe

etym: From Old English wæps, wæsp, from Proto-Germanic *wapsō, from Proto-Indo-European *wobʰséh₂.
en: A wasp is an insect with wings and yellow and black stripes across its body. Wasps have a painful sting like a bee but do not produce honey.
example: a WASP with a Yale degree.
example_ko: a wasp sting

syn: bashful, modest, self-effacing, unassuming, unpresuming, humble, meek, unconfident, unassertive, timid, timorous, shrinking, reserved, withdrawn, introverted, inhibited
etym: Latin diffīdentem, present participle of diffīdere (“to mistrust”).
en: Someone who is diffident is rather shy and does not enjoy talking about themselves or being noticed by other people.
example: Helen was diffident and reserved.
example_ko: a diffident manner/smile
syn_v: balk, flinch, recoil, start
syn_a: bashful, diffident, reserved, reticent, timid, timorous

syn: make worse, worsen, inflame, compound
etym: From Latin exacerbo (“to provoke”); ex (“out of; thoroughly”) + acerbo (“to embitter, harshen or worsen”).
en: If something exacerbates a problem or bad situation, it makes it worse.
example: Longstanding poverty has been exacerbated by racial divisions.
example_ko: The symptoms may be exacerbated by certain drugs.
syn_v: aggravate, intensify, sharpen, worsen, embitter, poison, rankle, sour, distress, exasperate, grate, annoy, bother, harass, irritate, torment

etym: From the Latin bonā fidē (“in good faith”), the ablative case of bona fidēs (“good faith”).
en: If something or someone is bona fide, they are genuine or real.
example: We are happy to donate to bona fide charitable causes
example_ko: a bona fide reason

syn: route, journey, way, road, path, course
etym: From Late Latin itinerarius (“pertaining to a journey”), neuter itinerārium (“an account of a journey, a road-book”), from iter (“a way, journey”); see itinerate, itinerant.
en: An itinerary is a plan of a journey, including the route and the places that you will visit.
example: The next place on our itinerary was Silistra.
syn_n: agenda, docket, log, outline, route  travel plan

syn: repeal, cancel, reverse, abrogate, overturn, overrule, override, annul, nullify, declare null and void, make void, void, invalidate, render invalid, quash, abolish, set aside, countermand, retract, withdraw
etym: From the Latin rescindō (“I cut back”), from re- (“back”) + scindō (“I cut”).
en: If a government or a group of people in power rescind a law or agreement, they officially withdraw it and state that it is no longer valid.
example: Trade Union leaders have demanded the government rescind the price rise.
syn_v: annul, cancel, repeal, revoke, veto  void

zh_Hans: 教条主义的；脱离实际的
syn: rigid, inflexible, uncompromising, unyielding, holding fixed views, adamant, insistent, pontifical
etym: Borrowed from French doctrinaire, from doctrine  +‎ -aire.
en: If you say that someone is doctrinaire or has a doctrinaire attitude, you disapprove of them because they have fixed principles which they try to force on other people.
example: He is firm but not doctrinaire.
example_ko: a doctrinaire communist

zh_Hans: 心平气和的；不伤和气的
syn: good-natured, cordial, civil, courteous, polite, easy, easy-going, neighbourly, brotherly, fraternal, harmonious, cooperative, civilized
etym: From Late Latin amīcābilis (“friendly”); see amiable.
en: When people have an amicable relationship, they are pleasant to each other and solve their problems without quarrelling.
example: The meeting ended on reasonably amicable terms
example_ko: an amicable relationship
syn_a: affable, congenial, friendly, pleasant, sociable, accommodating, agreeable, gracious, neighborly, obliging

syn: selfless, self-sacrificing, self-denying
etym: From altruist +‎ -ic. See altruism.
en: If your behaviour or motives are altruistic, you show concern for the happiness and welfare of other people rather than for yourself.
example_ko: Altruistic love is a vital element of a happy marriage.
syn_a: benevolent, charitable, eleemosynary, generous, magnanimous, philanthropic, selfless

syn: unquenchable, unappeasable, prodigious, uncontrollable, uncontrolled, omnivorous, compulsive, gluttonous, greedy, rapacious
etym: Borrowed from Latin ēsurient, ēsurientem, from ēsuriēns (“hungering”), present participle of ēsuriō (“to be hungry, to hunger for something”), a desiderative verb from edō (“to eat”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₁édti (“to eat”)) + -turiō (suffix indicating a desire for an action).[1]
en: greedy; voracious

syn: transmigration of the soul, metempsychosis
etym: From reincarnate +‎ -ion
en: If you believe in reincarnation, you believe that you will be reincarnated after you die.
example: Many African tribes believe in reincarnation.

syn: charm, delight, dazzle, enrapture, entrance, enthral, beguile, bewitch, spellbind, ensnare, fascinate, hypnotize, mesmerize
etym:
From Old French enchanter, from Latin incantāre, present active infinitive of incantō.
Doublet of incant.
en: If you are enchanted by someone or something, they cause you to have feelings of great delight or pleasure.
example: Dena was enchanted by the house
syn_v: bewitch, charm, hypnotize, mesmerize, spellbind, captivate, delight, enrapture, enthrall, entrance, fascinate

zh_Hans: （尤指教堂、修道院等宗教建筑的）回廊
syn: covered walk, corridor, aisle, arcade, loggia, gallery, piazza
etym: Recorded since about 1300 as Middle English cloistre, borrowed from Old French cloistre, clostre, or via Old English clauster, both from Medieval Latin claustrum (“portion of monastery closed off to laity”), from Latin claustrum (“place shut in, bar, bolt, enclosure”), a derivation of the past participle of claudere (“to close”). Doublet of claustrum.
en: A cloister is a covered area round a square in a monastery or a cathedral.

syn: denigrate, run down, deprecate, depreciate, downgrade, play down, trivialize, minimize, make light of, treat lightly, undervalue, underrate, underestimate
etym: From be- +‎ little. Coined by Thomas Jefferson in 1782[1].
en: If you belittle someone or something, you say or imply that they are unimportant or not very good.
example: We mustn't belittle her outstanding achievement
example_ko: She felt her husband constantly belittled her achievements.
syn_n: derision, mockery, sarcasm, scorn, sneering
syn_v: belittle, humiliate, jeer, mock, taunt, tease

syn: recovering, getting better, on the road to recovery, improving, making progress
etym: From French convalescent, from Latin convalēscēn(t-)s, present participle of convalēscere (“to become strong or well”); see convalesce.
en: Convalescent means relating to convalescence.
example: an officers' convalescent home.
example_ko: a convalescent home

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：re 一再 + fulg 发光 + ent 具有…性质的 → 不断发光的 → 光辉的
syn: light, brilliant, vivid, blazing, dazzling, beaming, intense, glaring
etym: From Latin refulgentem, accusative singular of refulgēns, present active participle of refulgeō, from re- (“back”) + fulgeō (“shine”).
en: shining, brilliant, or radiant
syn_a: brilliant, dazzling, gleaming, glittering, radiant, resplendent, sparkling

syn: despotic, autocratic, oppressive, repressive, fascistic, tyrannous, absolute, totalitarian, arbitrary, undemocratic, anti-democratic, illiberal
en: If you describe someone as tyrannical, you mean that they are severe or unfair towards the people that they have authority over.
example: He killed his tyrannical father with a blow to the head
example_ko: a victim of oppression and tyranny
syn_n: despotism, dictatorship, fascism, totalitarianism, enslavement, oppression, persecution, repression, cruelty, harshness, inhumanity, severity

zh_Hans: 入教;改宗蛸;犹太教的人;皈依者;改变宗教信仰者
syn: new believer, catechumen, recruit, neophyte, newcomer, initiate, tyro, novice
etym: From prose +‎ -lyte, from Old French proselite, from Late Latin proselutus (proselytus, “proselyte, alien resident”), from Ancient Greek προσήλυτος (prosḗlutos, “newcomer, convert”) (from πρός (prós, “to, towards”) and the stem -ηλυ- of ἐλήλυθα (elḗlutha), perfect of ἔρχομαι (érkhomai, “come”)), translation of Hebrew גר‎ (ger) in the Septuagint translation of the Torah (e.g., Exodus 12:49); also used in Matthew 23:15, Acts 2:10, Acts 6:5.
en: a person newly converted to a religious faith or sect; a convert, esp a gentile converted to Judaism

syn: friendliness, peace, peacefulness, peaceableness, harmony, harmoniousness, understanding, accord, concord, concurrence, cooperation, amicableness, goodwill, cordiality, warmth, geniality, fellowship, fraternity, brotherhood, brotherliness
etym: Borrowed from Old French amitié, from Vulgar Latin *amīcitās, *amīcitātem, from Latin amīcus (“friendly, a friend”) (based on amīcitia, from amō (“I love”).
en: Amity is peaceful, friendly relations between people or countries.
example: He wished to live in amity with his neighbour.
example_ko: The politician had lunch in amity with the reporters.
syn_n: friendship, goodwill, harmony, peace, unity, camaraderie, fraternity, rapport

syn: free, release, disentangle, get out, remove, withdraw, let loose, loosen, unloose, detach, disengage, disencumber, untwine, disentwine, unfasten, unclasp, disconnect
etym: Borrowed from Latin extricatus, past participle of extricō.
en: If you extricate yourself or another person from a difficult or serious situation, you free yourself or the other person from it.
example: It represents a last ditch attempt by the country to extricate itself from its economic crisis
example_ko: He had managed to extricate himself from most of his official duties.
syn_n: disentangle, extract, free, loose, remove, untie

syn: gap, interval, aperture, opening, hole, cranny, crevice, chink, slit, slot, crack, breach, vent
etym: Old French interstice, from Latin interstitium.
en: a minute opening or crevice between things

zh_Hans: （尤指疾病或情况）地方性的；（在某地或某些人中）特有的，流行的
syn: prevailing, frequent, usual, common, general, universal, pervasive, extensive, ubiquitous, ordinary
etym: From Ancient Greek ἐν (en, “in”) + δῆμος (dêmos, “people”). Possibly via ἔνδημος (éndēmos, “among one's people, at home, native”) and/or French endémique.
en: If a disease or illness is endemic in a place, it is frequently found among the people who live there.
example: Polio was then endemic among children my age.
example_ko: Malaria is endemic in many hot countries.

syn: slipshod, negligent, neglectful, remiss, careless, heedless, unmindful, inattentive, slapdash, offhand, casual
etym: From Latin laxus
en: If you say that a person's behaviour or a system is lax, you mean they are not careful or strict about maintaining high standards.
example: One of the problem areas is lax security for airport personnel
example_ko: lax security / discipline
syn_a: derelict, negligent, remiss, careless, indifferent, permissive, soft, inaccurate, inexact, nebulous, vague, drooping, loose, relaxed, slack

zh_Hans: 十分贫困的，十分贫穷的
syn: impecunious, destitute, penniless, impoverished, poverty-stricken, down and out, pauperized, without a penny to one's name, without two farthings to rub together, without two pennies to rub together
etym: Circa 1400, Middle French, from Latin indigentem, from indigere (“to need”), from indu (“in, within”) + egēre (“be in need, want”).[1][2]
en: Someone who is indigent is very poor.
syn_a: destitute, impoverished, needy, penurious, poor, poverty-stricken

zh_Hans: 勇敢的，有胆量的，有勇气的
syn: plucky, fearless, valiant, valorous, intrepid, heroic, lionhearted, manful, bold, daring, daredevil, adventurous, audacious
etym: From Old French corageus, from corage + -eus
en: Someone who is courageous shows courage.
example: It was a very frightening experience and they were very courageous
example_ko: a very courageous decision
syn_a: bold, brave, dauntless, fearless, intrepid, chivalrous, gallant, heroic, valiant

zh_Hans: 厌恶，反感；讨厌的人（或事物）
syn: distaste for, disinclination, abhorrence, hatred, hate, loathing, detestation, odium, antipathy, hostility
etym: From Middle French aversion, from Latin āversiō.
en: If you have an aversion to someone or something, you dislike them very much.
example: Many people have a natural and emotional aversion to insects.
example_ko: a strong aversion
syn_n: antagonism, antipathy, dislike, enmity, hostility, repugnance

syn: extol, hail, applaud, acclaim, commend, admire, approve of, make much of, sing the praises of, lionize, speak highly of, pay homage to, pay tribute to, eulogize, sing paeans to
etym: Borrowed from Old French lauder, from Latin laudō, laudāre, from laus (“praise, glory, fame, renown”), from echoic Proto-Indo-European root *leh₁wdʰ- (“song, sound”).
en: If people laud someone, they praise and admire them.
example: He lauded the work of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees
example_ko: She is a trustful person that everybody lauds her to the skies.
syn_v: acclaim, celebrate, glorify, praise, commend, compliment, congratulate, flatter, eulogize, honor, revere, venerate

syn: complimentary, congratulatory, praising, extolling, acclamatory, adulatory, commendatory, admiring, approving, approbatory, flattering, celebratory, glorifying, eulogizing, eulogistic, panegyric, panegyrical
etym: Borrowed from Latin laudatorius: compare Old French laudatoire.
en: A laudatory piece of writing or speech expresses praise or admiration for someone.
example: The New York Times has this very laudatory article about your retirement
syn_a: acclamatory, complimentary, favorable, flattering, positive

zh_Hans: 不容置疑的；无可辩驳的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：in 不 + controvert 反驳 + ible …的 → 不容反驳的 → 不容争论的
syn: incontestable, undeniable, irrefutable, unassailable, beyond dispute, unquestionable, beyond question, indubitable, not in doubt, beyond doubt, beyond a shadow of a doubt, unarguable, inarguable, undebatable, unanswerable
etym: in- +‎ controvertible
en: Incontrovertible evidence or facts are absolutely certain and cannot be shown to be wrong.
example: We have incontrovertible evidence of what took place.
example_ko: incontrovertible evidence/proof
syn_a: incontestable, indisputable, irrefutable, undebatable, undeniable, unquestionable

syn: lie down, lie back, lean back
etym: Borrowed from Latin reclīnāre (“to bend back”). Confer decline, incline.
en: If you recline on something, you sit or lie on it with the upper part of your body supported at an angle.
example: She proceeded to recline on a chaise longue
example_ko: She was reclining on a sofa.

zh_Hans: 节制；戒绝（尤指不好的享乐）
syn: desist, hold back, forbear, keep
etym: First attested around 1380. From Middle English absteynen, absteinen, abstenen, from Old French astenir, abstenir, from Latin abstineō (“to hold oneself back”) from abs- (“from”) + teneō (“I hold”). See also tenable.
en: If you abstain from something, usually something you want to do, you deliberately do not do it.
example: Abstain from sex or use condoms
example_ko: Ten people voted in favour, five against and two abstained.
syn_v: decline, eschew, forbear, forego, refrain, refuse

zh_Hans: 孤苦伶仃的，孤苦无依的
syn: sad, miserable, sorrowful, dejected, despondent, disconsolate, wretched, abject, morose, regretful, broken-hearted, heartbroken, down, downcast, dispirited, downhearted, heavy-hearted, crestfallen, depressed, melancholy, blue, gloomy, glum, mournful, despairing, doleful, woebegone, woeful, tearful, long-faced, joyless, cheerless, out of sorts
etym:
From Middle English forlorn, forloren, from Old English forloren (past participle of forlēosan (“to lose”)), from Proto-Germanic *fraluzanaz (“lost”), past participle of Proto-Germanic *fraleusaną (“to lose”), equivalent to for- +‎ lorn. Cognate with West Frisian ferlern (“lost”), Saterland Frisian ferlädden (“lost”), Dutch verloren (“lost”), German Low German verloren (“lost”),
German verloren (“lost”), Swedish förlorad (“lost”). See further at lese/leese, lorn.
en: If someone is forlorn, they feel alone and unhappy.
example: One of the demonstrators, a young woman, sat forlorn on the pavement
example_ko: She looked so forlorn, standing there in the rain.
syn_a: dejected, depressed, despondent, miserable, unhappy, woebegone, abandoned, deserted, desolate, forsaken, lonesome

syn: unanticipated, unforeseen, unpredictable, unpredicted
etym: un- +‎ toward (“to +‎ -ward”)
en: If you say that something untoward happens, you mean that something happens that is unexpected and causes difficulties.
example: The surveyor's report didn't highlight anything untoward
example_ko: That’s the plan—unless anything untoward happens.

ko: 신앙심 없는 자(진정한 종교라고 여겨지는 것을 믿지 않는 사람을 모욕적으로 가리키는 말)
zh_Hans: （尤被基督徒和穆斯林用来互指）异教徒
syn: disbeliever, non-believer, heathen, pagan, idolater, idolatress, heretic, agnostic, atheist, non-theist, nihilist, apostate, freethinker, libertine, dissenter, nonconformist
etym: First attested 1460, from Middle French infidèle, from Latin īnfidēlis (“unfaithful”), from in- (“not”) + fidēlis (“faithful”). See fidelity.
en: If one person refers to another as an infidel, the first person is hostile towards the second person because that person has a different religion or has no religion.
example: a holy war, to drive the infidels and the non-believers out of this holy land.
syn_n: agnostic, atheist, heathen, heretic, pagan, unbeliever

zh_Hans: （尤指在精神上）使感到不舒服，使不安
syn: make uncomfortable, make uneasy, abash, disconcert, nonplus, discompose, discomfort, take aback, unsettle, unnerve, put someone off their stroke, ruffle, confuse, fluster, agitate, disorientate, upset, disturb, perturb, distress
etym: From Old French desconfit, past participle of desconfire (“to undo, to destroy”), from des- (“completely”), from Latin dis- + confire (“to make”), from Latin conficio (“to finish up, to destroy”), from com- (“with, together”) + facio (“to do, to make”).
en: If you are discomfited by something, it causes you to feel slightly embarrassed or confused.
example: He will be particularly discomfited by the minister's dismissal of his plan
syn_v: bewilder, distract, nonplus, perplex, agitate, disturb, unsettle, annoy, perturb, upset

zh_Hans: 愤怒的;恶意的;尖酸刻薄的
syn: rancorous, bitter, caustic, mordant, acerbic, astringent, acid, acrid, trenchant, virulent, spiteful, crabbed, savage, venomous, poisonous, malicious, malignant, malign, pernicious, splenetic
etym: From vitriol +‎ -ic; or from French vitriolique (cognate with Italian vetriolico, Portuguese vitriolico, Spanish vitriolico).
en: If you describe someone's language or behaviour as vitriolic, you disapprove of it because it is full of bitterness and hate, and so causes a lot of distress and pain.
example: There was a vicious and vitriolic attack on him in one of the Sunday newspapers two weeks ago.
example_ko: The newspaper launched a vitriolic attack on the president.

syn: grasping, greedy, acquisitive, avaricious, covetous, rapacious, bribable, venal, materialistic
etym: Borrowed from Latin mercēnārius (“hired for money”), from mercēs (“reward, wages, price”).
en: A mercenary is a soldier who is paid to fight by a country or group that they do not belong to.
example_ko: foreign mercenaries
syn_n: hireling, legionnaire, soldier of fortune
syn_a: avaricious, grasping, greedy, money-grubbing

en: A town, country, or economy that has been ravaged is one that has been damaged so much that it is almost completely destroyed.
example: For two decades the country has been ravaged by civil war and foreign intervention.
example_ko: a country ravaged by civil war
syn_v: despoil, pillage, plunder, raid, ransack, demolish, destroy, raze, rape  violate

etym: From hol- +‎ -istic. See holism.
en: Holistic means based on the principles of holism.
example: practitioners of holistic medicine.
example_ko: a holistic approach to life
syn_n: aperture, opening, perforation, puncture, cavity, crater, dent, depression, hollow  impression

zh_Hans: 大胆的；敢于冒险的；鲁莽的；放肆的
syn: daring, fearless, intrepid, brave, unafraid, unflinching, courageous, valiant, valorous, heroic, dashing, plucky, daredevil, devil-may-care, death-or-glory, reckless, wild, madcap
etym: From Latin audacia (“boldness”), from audax (“bold”), from audeō (“I am bold, I dare”)
en: Someone who is audacious takes risks in order to achieve something.
example: an audacious plan to win the presidency.
example_ko: an audacious decision
syn_a: brazen, cheeky, impertinent, presumptuous, outrageous, bold, brave, courageous, daring, intrepid, impulsive, rash, reckless, wild

zh_Hans: （通常指在褒贬人时使用的）表述形容词，修饰语
syn: nickname, byname, title, name, label, tag
etym: From Middle French épithète, from Latin, from Ancient Greek ἐπίθετον (epítheton, “epithet, adjective”), the neuter of ἐπίθετος (epíthetos, “attributed, added”), from ἐπιτίθημι (epitíthēmi, “to add on”), from ἐπι- (epi-, “in addition”) + τίθημι (títhēmi, “to put”) (from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, to do”)).
en: An epithet is an adjective or short phrase which is used as a way of criticizing or praising someone.
example: the religious issue which led to the epithet 'bible-basher'.
example_ko: The film is long and dramatic but does not quite earn the epithet ‘epic’.

syn: surprise, shock, stupefaction, bafflement, bewilderment, confusion, perplexity, incredulity, disbelief, dismay, consternation, speechlessness, awe, wonder, wonderment
etym: From astonish +‎ -ment.
en: Astonishment is a feeling of great surprise.
example: I spotted a shooting star which, to my astonishment, was bright green in colour
example_ko: To my utter astonishment, she remembered my name.
syn_n: amazement, awe, shock, surprise  wonder

syn: reconcilable, consonant, congruous, congruent, fitting
etym: Middle English, from Latin congruēns, present active participle of congruō (“meet together, agree”).
en: If one thing is congruent with another thing, they are similar or fit together well.
example: They want to work in an organisation whose values are congruent with their own.
example_ko: congruent triangles
syn_a: comparable, corresponding, similar, compatible, complementary, congruous, harmonious, appropriate, fitting, proper, suitable

syn: reject, refuse, abandon, spurn, abdicate, give up, relinquish, abjure, repudiate, forswear, disavow, cast aside, drop, turn one's back on, wash one's hands of, eschew
etym: First attested in 1657.
en: to deny to oneself; renounce (privileges, pleasure, etc)
syn_v: deny, reject, renounce, relinquish, sacrifice, surrender, yield

zh_Hans: 粗鲁无礼的，粗野的；不友好的；令人讨厌的
syn: ill-mannered, discourteous, impolite, ungracious, unmannerly, uncivil, ungentlemanly, ungallant, unchivalrous
etym: From Middle English churlysshe, cherlissh, from late Old English ċeorlisċ, ċierlisċ (“of or pertaining to churls”), equivalent to churl +‎ -ish.
en: Someone who is churlish is unfriendly, bad-tempered, or impolite.
example: She would think him churlish if he refused
example_ko: It would be churlish to refuse such a generous offer.
syn_a: brusque, choleric, irritable, rancorous, surly, boorish, coarse, crass, crude

etym: From Latin paenultimus, from paene (“almost”) + ultimus (“last”).
en: The penultimate thing in a series of things is the last but one.
example: on the penultimate day of the Asian Games.
example_ko: the penultimate chapter/day/stage

syn: instructional, educational, educative, informative, informational, doctrinal, preceptive, teaching, pedagogic, academic, scholastic, tuitional
etym: From French didactique, from Ancient Greek διδακτικός (didaktikós, “skilled in teaching”), from διδακτός (didaktós, “taught, learnt”), from διδάσκω (didáskō, “I teach, educate”).
en: Something that is didactic is intended to teach people something, especially a moral lesson.
example: In totalitarian societies, art exists for didactic purposes.
example_ko: didactic art
syn_a: academic, moralizing, pedantic, preachy, edifying, educational, instructive  prescriptive

syn: racket, loud noise, confused noise, commotion, cacophony, babel, hubbub, tumult, fracas, clangour, crash, clatter, clash
etym: From Proto-Albanian *deina (“day”), from Proto-Indo-European *déi-no-, ultimately from *dyew- (“to shine”), cognate with Proto-Slavic *dьnь, Latvian diena, Lithuanian dėina, Old Prussian dēinā.[1]
en: A din is a very loud and unpleasant noise that lasts for some time.
example: They tried to make themselves heard over the din of the crowd.
example_ko: The children were making an awful din.
syn_n: bedlam, chaos, riot, turmoil, upheaval, commotion, din, maelstrom, pandemonium, agitation, paroxysm, stir, turbulence

syn: trouble, problem, difficulty, issue, setback, reverse, adversity, reverse of fortune, misadventure, misfortune, mischance, stroke of bad luck, blow
etym: mis- +‎ hap
en: A mishap is an unfortunate but not very serious event that happens to someone.
example: After a number of mishaps she did manage to get back to Germany
example_ko: a slight mishap
syn_n: accident, misadventure, mischance  misfortune

syn: degrade, debase, spoil, taint, defile, contaminate, pollute, foul, sully
etym: Dated 16th century CE; modified from adulteration, likely with earlier origin in the Latin past‐participle adulterātus.
en: If something such as food or drink is adulterated, someone has made its quality worse by adding water or cheaper products to it.
example: The food had been adulterated to increase its weight
syn_v: contaminate, defile, pervert, pollute, prostitute, spoil, taint

ko: 놀려대다, 비웃다, 우롱하다, 조롱하다(jeer) ((at)), 웃음거리로 만들다
en: → see jibe
example_ko: He made several cheap jibes at his opponent during the interview.

zh_Hans: 咬的;刻薄的;辛辣的;锐利的
syn: satirical
etym: From Latin mordax (“given to biting, corrosive”) (from mordere (“to bite, sting”)) + -ious.
en: sarcastic, caustic, or biting

syn: atypical, non-typical, irregular, aberrant, exceptional, freak, freakish, odd, bizarre, peculiar, unusual, out of the ordinary, inconsistent, incongruous, deviant, deviating, divergent, eccentric
etym: From Late Latin anomalus, from Ancient Greek ἀνώμᾰλος (anṓmalos).[1][2]
en: Something that is anomalous is different from what is usual or expected.
example: For years this anomalous behaviour has baffled scientists
syn_a: abnormal, atypical, deviant, irregular, unusual, odd, peculiar, strange, unconventional

syn: recognition, privilege, award, gift, title
etym:
First attested in the 1620s.
(award, praise): First attested in 1852.
Borrowed from French accolade, from Occitan acolada (“an embrace”), from Occitan acolar (“to embrace”), from Italian accollato, from Vulgar Latin accolāre (“to hug around the neck”), from Latin ad- + collum (“neck”) (English collar).
en: If someone is given an accolade, something is done or said about them which shows how much people admire them.
example: The Nobel prize has become the ultimate accolade in the sciences
example_ko: For his outstanding achievement, he received the accolade.
syn_n: citation, commendation, decoration, honor, laurel, tribute

example: There remains, however, another and more vexing problem.
syn_v: annoy, irritate, pester, plague, rankle, exasperate, irk, miff, pique, provoke, anger, enrage, gall, madden

zh_Hans: 税；（法国1789年大革命前的）盐税
etym: From French gabelle.
en: a salt tax levied until 1790

ko: 기면(嗜眠)성[증]의; 혼수(상태)의; 무기력한, 활발하지 못한; 둔감한
zh_Hans: 萎靡不振的，无精打采的；懒散的，倦怠的
syn: inert, inactive, slow, torpid, lifeless, dull
etym: From Ancient Greek ληθαργικός (lēthargikós), from λήθαργος (lḗthargos, “forgetful, lethargic”), from λήθη (lḗthē, “a forgetting, forgetfulness”) (from which Lethe (“river in Hades”)) + ἀργός (argós, “not working”)
en: If you are lethargic, you do not have much energy or enthusiasm.
example: He felt too miserable and lethargic to get dressed.
syn_a: languid, lifeless, listless, phlegmatic, sluggish, idle, indolent, lazy, slothful

ko: 최면을 걸듯 마음을 사로잡다, 완전 넋을 빼놓다
syn: bewitch, beguile, enrapture, captivate, capture, mesmerize, hypnotize, spellbind, hold spellbound, send into raptures, send into transports
etym: Back-formation from mesmerism, thus mesmerism +‎ -ize; first attested in 1829.
en: If you are mesmerized by something, you are so interested in it or so attracted to it that you cannot think about anything else.
example: He was absolutely mesmerised by Pavarotti on television
syn_v: bewitch, captivate, enchant, enthrall, fascinate, hypnotize, spellbind

syn: unwillingness, lack of enthusiasm, indisposition, slowness, hesitancy, hesitance, diffidence
etym: dis- +‎ inclination
en: A disinclination to do something is a feeling that you do not want to do it.
example: They are showing a marked disinclination to pursue these opportunities.
example_ko: There was a general disinclination to return to the office after lunch.

syn: lacking courage, fearful, apprehensive, afraid, frightened, scared, faint-hearted
etym: From Anglo-Norman recreant, Middle French recreant (“defeated”), from recroire (“to yield in a trial by combat, surrender allegiance”). See recray; and compare miscreant.
en: cowardly; faint-hearted
syn_n: chicken, coward, defector, heretic, judas, traitor
syn_a: afraid, cowardly, fearful, nervous, timid, deceitful, dishonest, two-faced, unfaithful

etym: From bane +‎ -ful.
en: destructive, poisonous, or fatal
syn_n: affliction, blight, curse, plague, scourge, torment

zh_Hans: 内涵意义；隐含意义；联想意义
syn: undertone, undercurrent, implication, hidden meaning, secondary meaning, nuance, flavour, feeling, aura, atmosphere, colouring, smack, hint, vein, echo, vibrations, association, intimation, suggestion, suspicion, insinuation
etym: Borrowed from Medieval Latin connotātiō, from Latin connotō; equivalent to connote +‎ -ation.
en: The connotations of a particular word or name are the ideas or qualities which it makes you think of.
example: It's just one of those words that's got so many negative connotations
example_ko: The word ‘professional’ has connotations of skill and excellence.
syn_n: coloring, implication, insinuation, spirit, undertone

zh_Hans: （因吃惊、害怕、喜悦等）呼喊，惊叫
syn: cry, declare, come out with, burst out with, blurt out, utter suddenly
etym: From Middle French exclamer, from Latin exclāmō, exclāmāre (“call out”), from ex- + clāmō (“to call”).
en: Writers sometimes use exclaim to show that someone is speaking suddenly, loudly, or emphatically, often because they are excited, shocked, or angry.
example: He went back to the lab', Iris exclaimed impatiently
example_ko: [V speech] ‘It isn’t fair!’, he exclaimed angrily.
syn_v: cry, ejaculate, holler, shout, vociferate, yell

syn: proclamation, direction, injunction, assertion, statement
etym: From Latin dictum (“proverb, maxim”), from dictus (“having been said”), perfect passive participle of dico (“I say”). Compare Spanish dicho (“saying”).
en: A dictum is a saying that describes an aspect of life in an interesting or wise way.
example: the dictum that it is preferable to be roughly right than precisely wrong
syn_n: decree, edict, order, pronouncement, adage, maxim, proverb  saying

syn: wailing, lamentation, moan, moaning, groan, weeping, crying, sob, sobbing, keening, howl, complaint
etym: Ancient Greek θρηνῳδία (thrēnōidía, “lamentation”). Compare the New Latin thrēnōdia.
en: an ode, song, or speech of lamentation, esp for the dead

etym: From Middle French politie, from Latin politia (circa. 1530s CE), from Ancient Greek πολιτεία (politeía, “polity, policy, the state”). Doublet of policy and police.
en: A polity is an organized society, such as a nation, city, or church, together with its government and administration.
example: the role of religious belief in a democratic polity.
syn_a: considerate, cordial, courteous, mannerly, respectful, tactful, chivalrous, courtly, gallant, cultured, fashionable, genteel, polished

zh_Hans: 无端指责；挑剔，吹毛求疵
syn: carp, grumble, moan, grouse, grouch, whine, bleat, find fault with, quibble about, niggle about
etym: From Old French caviller (“mock, jest, rail”), from Latin cavillor (“jeer, mock, satirise, reason captiously”), from cavilla (“jeering, raillery, scoffing”); cognate with Italian cavillare, Portuguese cavillar, and Spanish cavilar; nominal usage developed within English from the original verbal usage.[1]
en: If you say that someone cavils at something, you mean that they make criticisms of it that you think are unimportant or unnecessary.
example: Let us not cavil too much

zh_Hans: （尤指对属于别人的东西）贪求的，垂涎的
syn: greedy, rapacious, insatiable, yearning, acquisitive, desirous, possessive, selfish
etym: From Middle English coveitous, from Anglo-Norman *cuveitus, from Medieval Latin as if *cupiditosus, from Latin cupiditas (“desire”); see covet.
en: A covetous person has a strong desire to possess something, especially something that belongs to another person.
example: Even here a red Lamborghini Diablo sports car attracts covetous stares.
example_ko: [VN] He had long coveted the chance to work with a famous musician.
syn_a: craving, desirous, envious, grasping, jealous  lustful

syn: peak, height, high point, high spot, summit, top, climax, crowning point, peak of perfection, apex, vertex, zenith, apogee, ascendancy, upper limit, acme, meridian
etym: From Middle English, borrowed from Old French, from Latin meridianus (“of or belonging to midday or to the south, southern”), from meridies (“midday, the south”), originally *medidies, from medius (“middle”) + diēs (“day”).
en: A meridian is an imaginary line from the North Pole to the South Pole. Meridians are drawn on maps to help you describe the position of a place.
syn_n: acme, apex, apogee, zenith, peak, pinnacle, summit, top

syn: gloomy, sad, unhappy, doleful, Eeyorish, glum, melancholy, melancholic, woeful, miserable, woebegone, forlorn, despondent, dejected, depressed, long-faced, sombre, solemn, serious, sorrowful, morose, dour, mirthless, cheerless, joyless, wretched, dismal, grim, saturnine, pessimistic
etym: Borrowed from Latin lūgubris (“mournful; gloomy”), with the suffix -ious.
en: If you say that someone or something is lugubrious, you mean that they are sad rather than lively or cheerful.
example: a tall, thin man with a long and lugubrious face
example_ko: a lugubrious expression
syn_a: disconsolate, dismal, funereal, melancholy, mournful, oppressive

syn: soothsayer, fortune teller, crystal gazer, clairvoyant, psychic, visionary, prognosticator, diviner, prophesier, prophet, prophetess, oracle, sibyl, sage, wise man, wise woman
etym: English Wikipedia has an article on:augurWikipedia
en: If something augurs well or badly for a person or a future situation, it is a sign that things will go well or badly.
example: The renewed violence this week hardly augurs well for smooth or peaceful change
example_ko: Conflicts among the various groups do not augur well for the future of the peace talks.
syn_n: diviner, oracle, prophet, seer, soothsayer
syn_v: foretell, herald, portend, predict  prophesy

syn: dispute, disputation, argument, variance
etym: From Middle English contencion, borrowed from Old French contencion, from Latin contentio, contentionem, from contendō (past participle contentus); see contend.
en: Someone's contention is the idea or opinion that they are expressing in an argument or discussion.
example: This evidence supports their contention that the outbreak of violence was prearranged.
example_ko: One area of contention is the availability of nursery care.
syn_n: controversy, dissension, friction, strife, clash, confrontation, contest, struggle, tussle
syn_v: contend, differ, disagree, oppose

zh_Hans: 无兴趣，懈怠；（尤指对重要事情的）漠不关心，无动于衷
syn: lack of interest, lack of enthusiasm, lack of concern, unconcern, uninterestedness, unresponsiveness, impassivity, passivity, passiveness, detachment, dispassion, dispassionateness, lack of involvement, phlegm, coolness
etym: From French apathie, from Latin apathīa, from Ancient Greek ἀπάθεια (apátheia, “impassibility”, “insensibility”, “freedom from emotion”), from ἀπαθής (apathḗs, “not suffering or having suffered”, “without experience of”), from ἀ- (a-, “not”) + πάθος (páthos, “anything that befalls one”, “incident”, “emotion”, “passion”).
en: You can use apathy to talk about someone's state of mind if you are criticizing them because they do not seem to be interested in or enthusiastic about anything.
example_ko: There is widespread apathy among the electorate.
syn_n: impassivity, inattention, indifference, lethargy, passiveness

zh_Hans: 严厉抨击；（尤指）公开批评
syn: criticize, censure, condemn, denigrate, find fault with, give a bad press to, lambaste, flay, savage, brand, stigmatize, cast a slur on, denounce
etym: From Old French pilori, pellori, which is either from Old Occitan espilori or Latin pīla (“pillar”).
en: If someone is pilloried, a lot of people, especially journalists, criticize them and make them look stupid.
example: A man has been forced to resign as a result of being pilloried by some of the press.
example_ko: He was regularly pilloried by the press for his radical ideas.

syn: fail to honour, go back on, break, back out of, pull out of, withdraw from, retreat from, welsh on, backtrack on
etym: Borrowed from Latin renegō, from negō (“I deny”). Possibly influenced by renegotiate. See also renegade.
en: If someone reneges on a promise or an agreement, they do not do what they have promised or agreed to do.
example: If someone reneged on a deal, they could never trade here again.
example_ko: to renege on a deal/debt/contract, etc.
syn_v: back out, default, go back on, withdraw

zh_Hans: 合法的，正当的，法律允许的
syn: lawful, licit, legalized, authorized, permitted, permissible, allowable, allowed, admissible, recognized, sanctioned, approved, licensed, statutory, constitutional, within the law, going by the rules, above board, valid, honest, upright
etym: From Middle English legitimat, legytymat, from Medieval Latin lēgitimatus, perfect passive participle of Latin lēgitimō (“make legal”), from Latin lēgitimus (“lawful”), originally "fixed by law, in line with the law," from Latin lēx (“law”). Originally "lawfully begotten".
en: Something that is legitimate is acceptable according to the law.
example: The government will not seek to disrupt the legitimate business activities of the defendant.
example_ko: a legitimate grievance
syn_a: authentic, genuine, verifiable, logical, reasonable, sound, tenable, appropriate, correct, proper, lawful, legal, licensed, rightful

syn: humble, respectful, considerate, attentive, thoughtful
en: Someone who is deferential is polite and respectful towards someone else.
example: They like five-star hotels and deferential treatment.
example_ko: The women wore veils in deference to the customs of the country.
syn_a: considerate, courteous, respectful, reverent, acquiescent, agreeable, solicitous, yielding, fawning, groveling, obsequious, servile

syn: grouchy, crotchety, in a mood, in a bad mood, cantankerous, bad-tempered, ill-tempered, ill-natured, ill-humoured, peevish, having got out of bed on the wrong side, cross, as cross as two sticks, disagreeable, pettish
etym: fraction (“discord, (now obsolete)”) +‎ -ous
en: If you describe someone as fractious, you disapprove of them because they become upset or angry very quickly about small unimportant things.
example: Nancy was in a fractious mood
example_ko: Children often get fractious and tearful when tired.
syn_a: insubordinate, rebellious, troublesome, unruly, cranky, cross, irritable, peevish, testy

syn: indirect, winding, meandering, serpentine, tortuous, twisting
etym: First attested in 1664. From Latin circuitōsus, from circuitus, from circumeō (“I go around”), from circum (“around”) + eō (“I go”).
en: A circuitous route is long and complicated rather than simple and direct.
example: The cabdriver took them on a circuitous route to the police station
example_ko: The race ended with eight laps of a city centre circuit.
syn_a: ambiguous, circular, meandering, rambling, roundabout

ko: 빙빙 돌다, 선회하다; (특히 신체 일부를) 빙빙 돌리다
zh_Hans: （通常指很快地）旋转，回旋，转动
syn: revolve, move in circles, go round in circles, circle, spiral, wheel round, turn round, whirl, pirouette, twirl, swirl, spin, swivel
etym: from Ancient Greek γυρός (gurós, “round, curved”) through Latin into Middle English to English
en: If you gyrate, you dance or move your body quickly with circular movements.
example: The woman began to gyrate to the music.
example_ko: [V] They began gyrating to the music.
syn_v: revolve, rotate, spin, twirl  whirl

zh_Hans: （错误等）极其严重的，极坏的，令人震惊的
syn: horrific, horrifying, horrible, terrible, awful, dreadful, ghastly, hideous, horrendous, frightful, atrocious, abominable, abhorrent, outrageous, hateful, loathsome, odious, gruesome, grisly, monstrous, nightmarish, heinous, harrowing, dire, vile, shameful, unspeakable, unforgivable, unpardonable
etym: From Latin prefix e- (“out of”), + grex (“flock”), + English adjective suffix -ous, from Latin suffix -osus (“full of”); reflecting the positive connotations of "standing out from the flock".
en: Egregious means very bad indeed.
example: the most egregious abuses of human rights.
syn_a: deplorable, flagrant, glaring, infamous, notorious, outrageous

syn: speech of praise, panegyric, paean, accolade, tribute, testimonial, compliment
etym: From Latin encōmium (“praise, eulogy”), from Ancient Greek ἐγκώμιον (enkṓmion, “laudatory ode, praise”), from ἐγκώμιος (enkṓmios, “of or pertaining to the victor”), from κῶμος (kômos, “festival, revel, ode”).
en: a formal expression of praise; eulogy; panegyric

syn: penurious, in penury, poor, impoverished, indigent, insolvent, moneyless, hard up, poverty-stricken, needy, in need, in want, destitute
etym: First attested in 1596. From im- +‎ pecunious, from Latin pecūniōsus, from pecūnia (“money”) + -ōsus (“full of”).
en: Someone who is impecunious has very little money.
syn_a: broke, busted, destitute, poor, poverty-stricken, ruined

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：syn 共同 + onym 名称，名字 → 同名 → 同义词
etym: From Middle English sinonyme, from Latin synōnymum, from Ancient Greek συνώνυμον (sunṓnumon), neuter singular form of συνώνυμος (sunṓnumos, “synonymous”), from σύν (sún, “with”) + ὄνομα (ónoma, “name”). Corresponds to syn- +‎ -onym.
en: A synonym is a word or expression which means the same as another word or expression.
example: The term 'industrial democracy' is often used as a synonym for worker participation.
example_ko: ‘Big’ and ‘large’ are synonyms.

ko: 주제에서 벗어나다, 다른 말을 하기 시작하다
syn: go off at a tangent, diverge, turn aside, turn away, depart, drift, stray, ramble, wander, meander, maunder
etym: From Latin digressum, past participle of digredi.
en: If you digress, you move away from the subject you are talking or writing about and talk or write about something different for a while.
example: I've digressed a little to explain the situation so far, so let me now recap
syn_v: deviate, diverge, drift, ramble, stray, wander

syn: disputation, argument, variance, dispute
etym: From Middle English contencion, borrowed from Old French contencion, from Latin contentio, contentionem, from contendō (past participle contentus); see contend.
en: Someone's contention is the idea or opinion that they are expressing in an argument or discussion.
example: This evidence supports their contention that the outbreak of violence was prearranged.
example_ko: One area of contention is the availability of nursery care.
syn_n: controversy, dissension, friction, strife, clash, confrontation, contest, struggle, tussle
syn_v: contend, differ, disagree, oppose

etym: From French apathie, from Latin apathīa, from Ancient Greek ἀπάθεια (apátheia, “impassibility”, “insensibility”, “freedom from emotion”), from ἀπαθής (apathḗs, “not suffering or having suffered”, “without experience of”), from ἀ- (a-, “not”) + πάθος (páthos, “anything that befalls one”, “incident”, “emotion”, “passion”).
en: lack    [WS]

example_ko: to renege on a deal/debt/contract, etc.

example_ko: a legitimate grievance

syn_a: considerate, courteous, respectful, reverent, acquiescent, agreeable, solicitous, yielding, fawning, groveling, obsequious, servile

example: The woman began to gyrate to the music.
