syn_v: revolve, rotate, spin, twirl  whirl

zh_Hans: （错误等）极其严重的，极坏的，令人震惊的
syn: terrible, shameful, hateful, harrowing, monstrous, gruesome, unforgivable, awful, loathsome, horrible, atrocious, horrendous, outrageous, grisly, nightmarish, horrific, frightful, vile, ghastly, dire, hideous, unspeakable, abhorrent, horrifying, heinous, dreadful, abominable, unpardonable, odious
etym: From Latin prefix e- (“out of”), + grex (“flock”), + English adjective suffix -ous, from Latin suffix -osus (“full of”); reflecting the positive connotations of "standing out from the flock".
en: Egregious means very bad indeed.
example: the most egregious abuses of human rights.
syn_a: deplorable, flagrant, glaring, infamous, notorious, outrageous

syn: compliment, tribute, speech of praise, paean, panegyric, testimonial, accolade
etym: From Latin encōmium (“praise, eulogy”), from Ancient Greek ἐγκώμιον (enkṓmion, “laudatory ode, praise”), from ἐγκώμιος (enkṓmios, “of or pertaining to the victor”), from κῶμος (kômos, “festival, revel, ode”).
en: a formal expression of praise; eulogy; panegyric

syn: penurious, poor, needy, moneyless, in want, impoverished, in need, insolvent, indigent, poverty-stricken, destitute, hard up, in penury
etym: First attested in 1596. From im- +‎ pecunious, from Latin pecūniōsus, from pecūnia (“money”) + -ōsus (“full of”).
en: Someone who is impecunious has very little money.
syn_a: broke, busted, destitute, poor, poverty-stricken, ruined

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：syn 共同 + onym 名称，名字 → 同名 → 同义词
etym: From Middle English sinonyme, from Latin synōnymum, from Ancient Greek συνώνυμον (sunṓnumon), neuter singular form of συνώνυμος (sunṓnumos, “synonymous”), from σύν (sún, “with”) + ὄνομα (ónoma, “name”). Corresponds to syn- +‎ -onym.
en: A synonym is a word or expression which means the same as another word or expression.
example: The term 'industrial democracy' is often used as a synonym for worker participation.
example_ko: ‘Big’ and ‘large’ are synonyms.

ko: 주제에서 벗어나다, 다른 말을 하기 시작하다
syn: meander, diverge, wander, maunder, ramble, drift, depart, turn away, stray, turn aside, go off at a tangent
etym: From Latin digressum, past participle of digredi.
en: If you digress, you move away from the subject you are talking or writing about and talk or write about something different for a while.
example: I've digressed a little to explain the situation so far, so let me now recap
syn_v: deviate, diverge, drift, ramble, stray, wander

etym: From Middle English tempestuous, tempestious, variants of tempestous, from Old French tempesteus, tempestos, tempestuose, from Latin tempestuōsus, equivalent to tempest +‎ -uous.
en: If you describe a relationship or a situation as tempestuous, you mean that very strong and intense emotions, especially anger, are involved.
example: For years, the couple's tempestuous relationship made the headlines
example_ko: a tempestuous relationship
syn_a: stormy, tumultuous, turbulent, fierce, frantic, impassioned, violent

etym: From French placide, from Latin placidus (“peaceful, calm, placid”), from placeō (“please, satisfy”).
en: A placid person or animal is calm and does not easily become excited, angry, or upset.
example: She was a placid child who rarely cried
example_ko: a placid baby / horse
syn_n: repose, serenity, stillness, tranquility, composure, control, placidity
syn_v: compose, lull, pacify, quiet, allay, placate, quell, soothe
syn_a: collected, composed, cool, sedate, serene, quiet, smooth, tranquil, undisturbed, unruffled
ant2: agitated, rough, excite, aggravate, commotion  nervousness

etym: The annual mercury (Mercurialis annua), one of the varieties of mercurial (noun sense 1)A sample of a mercurial (noun sense 3), in this case a compound with the molecular formula Ag2HgI4An 18th-century jar used for storing mercurials (noun sense 4) in the form of pills[n 1]
en: If you describe someone as mercurial, you mean that they frequently change their mind or mood without warning.
example: his mercurial temperament.
example_ko: Emily’s mercurial temperament made her difficult to live with.
syn_a: capricious, temperamental, unpredictable, volatile, immediate, instantaneous, sudden

etym: From Old French ploiant[1], present participle of ploiier (“to fold”).
en: A pliant person can be easily influenced and controlled by other people.
example: She's proud and stubborn, you know, under that pliant exterior.
example_ko: her pliant body
syn_a: ductile, limber, malleable, plastic, pliant, supple, impressionable, receptive, susceptible, vulnerable

etym: From Old French frenetike, from Latin phreneticus, from Ancient Greek φρενητικός (phrenētikós, “delirious”), from φρενῖτις (phrenîtis, “delirium”), from φρήν (phrḗn, “mind”). Compare frantic.
en: If you describe an activity as frenetic, you mean that it is fast and energetic, but rather uncontrolled.
example: the frenetic pace of life in New York
example_ko: a scene of frenetic activity

etym: From the Latin īnstīgātus, past participle of īnstīgāre (“to instigate”), from prefix in- (“in”) + *stigare, akin to stinguere (“push, goad”). Akin to German stechen (“to prick”), English stick.
en: Someone who instigates an event causes it to happen.
example: Jenkinson instigated a refurbishment of the old gallery
example_ko: The government has instigated a programme of economic reform.
syn_v: excite, foment, incite, kindle, provoke, begin, initiate, start, encourage, inspire, prompt

etym: From Latin arrogātus, perfect passive participle of adrogō, arrogō (“ask of, adopt, appropriate, assume”), from ad (“to”) + rogō (“ask”).[1]
en: If someone arrogates to themselves something such as a responsibility or privilege, they claim or take it even though they have no right to do so.
example: The assembly arrogated to itself the right to make changes
example_ko: arrogate  a person's rights

etym: From Middle English eschewen, from Anglo-Norman eschiver (Modern French esquiver), (third-person present eschiu), from Frankish *sciuhan (“to dread, shun, avoid”), from Proto-Germanic *skiuhwijaną (“to frighten”). Cognate with Old High German sciuhen (“to frighten off”), German scheuen (“eschew”) (German scheuchen (“shoo”)), and Spanish esquivar. More at shy.
en: If you eschew something, you deliberately avoid doing it or becoming involved in it.
example: Although he appeared to enjoy a jet-setting life, he eschewed publicity and avoided nightclubs.
syn_v: avoid, forbear, refrain, refuse, shun

etym: From Middle English enteren, borrowed from Old French enterrer, enterer, from Vulgar Latin *interrāre (“to put in earth”).
en: When a dead person is interred, they are buried.
example: the spot where his bones were originally interred.
example_ko: interface
syn_v: associate, hobnob, mingle, socialize, alloy, blend, combine, compound, mix, stir

etym: From Latin imbuō (“wet, moisten”).
en: If someone or something is imbued with an idea, feeling, or quality, they become filled with it.
example: As you listen, you notice how every single word is imbued with a breathless sense of wonder.
example_ko: Her voice was imbued with an unusual seriousness.
syn_v: endow, fill, infuse, inspire, permeate, bathe, suffuse, tinge  tint

etym: From the Late Latin exorbitāns, the present active participle of exorbitō (“I go out of the track”), from ex (“out”) + orbita (“wheel-track”); see orbit. Compare the French exorbitant.
en: If you describe something such as a price or fee as exorbitant, you are emphasizing that it is much greater than it should be.
example: Exorbitant housing prices have created an acute shortage of affordable housing for the poor.
example_ko: exorbitant costs/fares/fees/prices/rents
syn_a: costly, expensive, high-priced, excessive, extreme, immoderate, outrageous

etym: From Middle English fathome, fadome, from Old English fæþm, fæþme (“outstretched or encircling arms, embrace, grasp, protection, interior, bosom, lap, breast, womb, fathom, cubit, power, expanse, surface”), from Proto-Germanic *faþmaz (“embrace”), from Proto-Indo-European *pet- (“to spread out, extend”). Cognate with Low German fadem, faem (“a cubit, thread”), Dutch vadem, vaam (“fathom”), German Faden (“thread, filament, fathom”), Danish favn (“embrace, fathom”), Norwegian Bokmål favn (“embrace, fathom”), Swedish famn (“the arms, bosom, embrace”), Icelandic faðmur (“embrace”), Latin pateō, Ancient Greek πετάννυμι (petánnumi), Ancient Greek πέταλος (pétalos) [whence English petal].
en: A fathom is a measurement of 1.8 metres or 6 feet, used when referring to the depth of water.
example: We sailed into the bay and dropped anchor in five fathoms of water.
example_ko: [VN] It is hard to fathom the pain felt at the death of a child.
syn_v: mark, measure, plumb, sound, comprehend, discover, perceive  understand

en: If something is floundering, it has many problems and may soon fail completely.
example: What a pity that his career was left to flounder
example_ko: [V] His abrupt change of subject left her floundering helplessly.
syn_v: falter, halt, hesitate, waver, lurch, muddle, struggle  wallow

etym: From French apogée, from Latin apogaeum, apogeum, from Ancient Greek ἀπόγειον (apógeion, “away from Earth”), from ἀπό (apó, “away”) + γῆ (gê, “Earth”).
en: The apogee of something such as a culture or a business is its highest or its greatest point.
syn_n: acme, apex, climax, height, peak, pinnacle, summit

ko: [the E~] (동방의 세 박사의 베들레헴 내방이 상징하는) 예수 공현
etym: From Old French epyphanie, from Late Latin epiphania, from Ancient Greek ἐπιφάνεια (epipháneia, “manifestation, striking appearance”), from ἐπιφαίνω (epiphaínō, “I appear, display”), from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + φαίνω (phaínō, “I shine, appear”). English Epiphany (of Christ) since the 14th century, generic use since the 17th century.
en: Epiphany is a Christian festival on the 6th of January which celebrates the arrival of the wise men who came to see Jesus Christ soon after he was born.

etym: [1851] Borrowed from French impasse, from French in- + passer.
en: If people are in a difficult position in which it is impossible to make any progress, you can refer to the situation as an impasse.
example: The company says it has reached an impasse in negotiations with the union.
example_ko: to break/end the impasse
syn_n: deadlock, halt, stalemate, standoff, standstill, dilemma, predicament, quandary, blind alley, cul-de-sac  dead end

etym: From the participle stem of Medieval Latin capitulare (“draw up under headings”), from Latin capitulum (“heading, chapter, title”), diminutive of caput (“head”).
en: If you capitulate, you stop resisting and do what someone else wants you to do.
example: The club eventually capitulated and now grants equal rights to women
example_ko: They were finally forced to capitulate to the terrorists’ demands.
syn_n: crop, output, production, dividend, interest, return, revenue
syn_v: accede, acquiesce, capitulate, relent, succumb, abdicate, relinquish, resign, surrender, bear, produce, earn, generate, pay, return

etym: (verb) From Latin regressus, past participle of regredi (“to go back”), from re- (“back”) + gradi (“to go”).
en: When people or things regress, they return to an earlier and less advanced stage of development.
example: if your child regresses to babyish behaviour
syn_v: backslide, relapse, retrogress, revert, degenerate, deteriorate

etym: Borrowed from Middle French impugner, from Latin impugnō, from im- + pugnō (“fight”), from pugnus (“fist”), as in English pugilism (“fighting with fists, boxing”); from Proto-Indo-European roots.
en: If you impugn something such as someone's motives or integrity, you imply that they are not entirely honest or honourable.
example: The Secretary's letter questions my veracity and impugns my motives
syn_v: attack, censure, denigrate, execrate, oppose, libel, malign, slander

etym: From Middle French acrimonie, from Latin ācrimōnia (“sharpness, pungency”).
en: Acrimony is bitter and angry words or quarrels.
example: The council's first meeting ended in acrimony.
example_ko: The dispute was settled without acrimony.
syn_n: animosity, asperity, mordancy, rancor, sarcasm, spleen

etym: From French cacophonie, from Ancient Greek κακοφωνία (kakophōnía), from κακός (kakós, “bad”) + φωνή (phōnḗ, “sound”).
en: You can describe a loud, unpleasant mixture of sounds as a cacophony.
example: All around was bubbling a cacophony of voices.
syn_n: discord, dissonance, stridency

etym: From Latin sine (“without”) + cūrā (“care”) in beneficium sine cūrā (“benefice without care”).
en: A sinecure is a job for which you receive payment but which does not involve much work or responsibility.
example: She found him an exalted sinecure as a Fellow of the Library of Congress.

etym: From Middle Low German paltrig (“ragged, rubbishy, worthless”), from palter, palte (“cloth, rag, shred”), from Old Saxon *paltro, *palto (“cloth, rag”), from Proto-Germanic *paltrô, *paltô (“scrap, rag, patch”). Cognate with Low German palterig (“ragged, torn”), dialectal German palterig (“paltry”). Compare also Low German palte (“rag”), West Frisian palt (“rag”), Saterland Frisian Palte (“strip; band; tape”), dialectal German Palter (“rag”), Danish pjalt (“rag, tatter”), Swedish palta (“rag”). See also palterly.
en: A paltry amount of money or of something else is one that you consider to be very small.
example: a paltry fine of ￡150
example_ko: This account offers a paltry 1% return on your investment.
syn_a: inconsequential, insignificant, minor, petty, trifling, common, mediocre, pathetic, worthless, base, ignoble, immoral, low, mean

etym: From Latin elusus past participle of eludo (“to parry a blow, to deceive”)
en: Something or someone that is elusive is difficult to find, describe, remember, or achieve.
example: In London late-night taxis are elusive and far from cheap.
example_ko: Eric, as elusive as ever, was nowhere to be found.
syn_a: evasive, slippery, sly, baffling, inexplicable, puzzling

etym: From Latin dēsultōrius (“hasty, casual, superficial”), from dēsultōr (“a circus rider who jumped from one galloping horse to another”), from dēsiliō (“jump down”), from dē (“down”) + saliō (“jump, leap”).[1]
en: Something that is desultory is done in an unplanned and disorganized way, and without enthusiasm.
example: The constables made a desultory attempt to keep them away from the barn.
example_ko: I wandered about in a desultory fashion.

etym: parsimony +‎ -ious
en: Someone who is parsimonious is very unwilling to spend money.
example: Due to official parsimony only the one machine was built.
syn_a: avaricious, miserly, niggardly, parsimonious, penurious, frugal, lean, meager, paltry, sparse

etym: First attested circa 1540, from Middle French, from Latin truculentus (“fierce, savage”), from trux (“fierce, wild”).
en: If you say that someone is truculent, you mean that they are bad-tempered and aggressive.
example: Your secretary said you'd be wanting a cleaner,' she announced with her usual truculence.
syn_a: aggressive, bellicose, belligerent, combative, biting, harsh, scathing, vitriolic, brutal, cruel, ferocious, vicious

etym: Borrowed from Latin circumnāvigātus, perfect passive participle of circumnāvigō (“sail round something, circumnavigate”), from circum (“about, around”) + nāvigō (“sail, navigate”), from nāvis (“ship”) + agō (“do”). Surface analysis: circum- +‎ navigate.
en: If someone circumnavigates the world or an island, they sail all the way around it.
example: For this year at least, our race to circumnavigate the globe in less than 80 days is over.

etym: Latin circum (“about”) + venire (“to come”)
en: If someone circumvents a rule or restriction, they avoid having to obey the rule or restriction, in a clever and perhaps dishonest way.
example: Military planners tried to circumvent the treaty.
example_ko: They found a way of circumventing the law.
syn_v: avoid, bypass, evade, skirt, circle, ensnare, entrap, envelop, surround

ko: (이론 등의 근거로 삼기 위해 무엇이 사실이라고) 상정하다
etym: From Medieval Latin  postulāt- (“asked”), from the verb postulāre (“to ask”), from Latin postulō (“request”).
en: If you postulate something, you suggest it as the basis for a theory, argument, or calculation, or assume that it is the basis.
example: arguments postulating differing standards for human rights in different cultures
example_ko: [VN] They postulated a 500-year lifespan for a plastic container.
syn_n: assumption, axiom, hypothesis, premise, theory
syn_v: conjecture, propose, speculate, submit  theorize

en: An embryonic process, idea, organization, or organism is one at a very early stage in its development.
example: Romania's embryonic democracy.
example_ko: The plan, as yet, only exists in embryonic form.
syn_a: beginning, fetal, initial, rudimentary, undeveloped

en: Pestilential is used to refer to things that cause disease or are caused by disease.
example: people who were dependent for their water supply on this pestilential stream.

etym: From Latin annexus.
en: If a country annexes another country or an area of land, it seizes it and takes control of it.
example: Rome annexed the Nabatean kingdom in 106 AD
example_ko: Germany annexed Austria in 1938.
syn_n: addition, expansion, extension  wing
syn_v: add, append, attach, connect, join, acquire, appropriate, obtain, procure

etym: From Old French enemisté, ennemistié, from Late Latin, Vulgar Latin *inimīcitās, *inimīcitātem, from Latin inimīcus (“enemy”); cognates: French inimitié, Portuguese inimizade, Spanish enemistad.[1]
en: Enmity is a feeling of hatred towards someone that lasts for a long time.
example: I think there is an historic enmity between them
example_ko: the traditional problem of the enmity between Protestants and Catholics
syn_n: animosity, bitterness, hatred, hostility, rancor

etym: Late Middle English approbacioun, from Old French approbacion (French approbation), from Latin approbatio, from approbare (“to assent to as good, approve, also show to be good, confirm”), from ad (“to”) + probare (“approve, commend”), from probus (“good”).
en: Approbation is approval of something or agreement to it.
example_ko: He said to the merchant that he would purchase the product on approbation.
syn_n: acceptance, approval, commendation, congratulations, praise, sanction

ko: 아낌없이 줌; (아낌없이 주어진) 선물, 축의(祝儀).
etym: French largesse, Old French largesce
en: [Noun] (obsolete) The bestowment of a largess or gift.
example: grateful recipients of their largesse.
example_ko: She is not noted for her largesse.

etym: From Middle English abiden, from Old English ābīdan (“to abide, wait, remain, delay, remain behind; survive; wait for, await; expect”), from Proto-Germanic *uzbīdaną (“to expect, tolerate”), equivalent to a- +‎ bide. Cognate with Scots abyde (“to abide, remain”), Middle High German erbīten (“to await, expect”), Gothic 𐌿𐍃𐌱𐌴𐌹𐌳𐌰𐌽 (usbeidan, “to expect, await, have patience”). The sense of pay for is due to influence from aby.[1]
en: If you can't abide someone or something, you dislike them very much.→ see also abiding→ see also law-abiding
example: I can't abide people who can't make up their minds
example_ko: I can’t abide people with no sense of humour.
syn_v: linger, remain, tarry, wait, bear, endure, suffer, tolerate

etym: From Latin repudiātus, from repudiō (“I cast off, reject”), from repudium (“divorce”), 1540s.[1]
en: If you repudiate something or someone, you show that you strongly disagree with them and do not want to be connected with them in any way.
example: Leaders urged people to turn out in large numbers to repudiate the violence
example_ko: to repudiate a suggestion
syn_v: disavow, disclaim, reject, retract, discard, disown, recant, renounce, annul, nullify, rescind, revoke, condemn, disagree, oppose, protest, disregard, ignore, neglect, slight

etym: From Anglo-Norman oratour, from Latin orator.
en: An orator is someone who is skilled at making formal speeches, especially ones which affect people's feelings and beliefs.
example: Lenin was the great orator of the Russian Revolution.
example_ko: a fine political orator
syn_n: lecturer, rhetorician, speaker  talker

etym: From Old French mescreant (1080) "mis-believer", present participle of mescreire "to misbelieve" (modern mécroire).
en: A miscreant is someone who has done something illegal or behaved badly.
example: Local people demanded that the District Magistrate apprehend the miscreants.
syn_n: criminal, devil, rogue, scoundrel, villain
syn_a: corrupt, degenerate, depraved, evil, nefarious, wicked

etym: 1590s, from inter- +‎ loper (“runner, rover”), as in landloper (“vagrant”) (from lope (“to leap, to jump”) (originally dialectal). Originally spelt enterloper and used in specific sense “unauthorized trader trespassing on privileges of chartered companies”, later general sense of “self-interested intruder” from 1630s.[1]
en: If you describe someone as an interloper, you mean that they have come into a situation or a place where they are not wanted or do not belong.
example: She had no wish to share her father with any outsider and regarded us as interlopers.

etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman despeir, from Old French desperer (from Latin despero, desperare), or desesperer, from des- (“dis-”) + esperer (“hope”). See also desperate
en: Despair is the feeling that everything is wrong and that nothing will improve.
example: I looked at my wife in despair
example_ko: She uttered a cry of despair.
syn_n: desperation, hopelessness, resignation, depression, discouragement, dolor, gloom, melancholy
syn_v: give in, lose hope, quit, surrender

etym: Borrowed from Old French duresse, from Latin duritia (“hardness”), from durus (“hard”).
en: To do something under duress means to do it because someone forces you to do it or threatens you.
example: He thought her confession had been made under duress.
example_ko: He signed the confession under duress.
syn_n: coercion, compulsion, force, pressure

ko: [U] [문어] 비등(沸騰); (감정 등의) 격발, 격정의 발로
etym: Borrowed from Latin ēbulliēns, present participle of ēbulliō (“I boil”) + English suffix -ence.
example: His natural ebullience began to return.
example_ko: The Prime Minister was in ebullient mood.
syn_n: enthusiasm, exuberance, spirit, vitality  zest

etym: From the Latin inscrutabilis, from in- (“not”) + scrutare (“to examine”), corresponding to in- +‎ scrutable
en: If a person or their expression is inscrutable, it is very hard to know what they are really thinking or what they mean.
example: In public he remained inscrutable.
syn_a: enigmatic, impenetrable, insoluble, mysterious, perplexing, unfathomable

en: Draconian laws or measures are extremely harsh and severe.
example: draconian measures to lower US healthcare costs.

etym: From French insipide, from Latin īnsipidus (“tasteless”), from in- (“not”) + sapidus (“savory”). In some senses, perhaps influenced by insipient (“unwise, foolish, stupid”).
en: If you describe food or drink as insipid, you dislike it because it has very little taste.
example: It tasted indescribably bland and insipid, like warmed cardboard.
example_ko: a cup of insipid coffee
syn_a: banal, dull, dumb, empty, pointless, flat, savorless, stale, tasteless

etym: Latin pro (“before”) + locūtus (“having spoken”)
en: a chairman, esp of the lower house of clergy in a convocation of the Anglican Church

etym: From Middle French despote, from Old French despote, from Medieval Latin despota, from Ancient Greek δεσπότης (despótēs, “lord, master, owner”), from the Proto-Indo-European phrase *déms pótis (“master of the house”).[1] Cognate with Sanskrit दम्पति (dámpati).
en: A despot is a ruler or other person who has a lot of power and who uses it unfairly or cruelly.
example_ko: an enlightened despot
syn_n: despot, dictator, oppressor, totalitarian, overlord, slave driver, taskmaster

etym: figure +‎ head
en: If someone is the figurehead of an organization or movement, they are recognized as being its leader, although they have little real power.
example: The President will be little more than a figurehead.

ko: [P] 인식하고 있는, 알고 있는 ((of)); 재판 관할권이 있는
etym: cognizance +‎ -ant, or from Old French conoissant, present participle of conoistre (“know”), under the influence of its Latin etymon cognōscentem, accusative singular present participle of cōgnōscō (“learn, be acquainted with”).
en: If someone is cognizant of something, they are aware of it or understand it.
example: We are cognizant of the problem.
syn_a: aware, conscious, conversant, familiar, knowledgeable

en: When you are conciliatory in your actions or behaviour, you show that you are willing to end a disagreement with someone.
example: The President's speech was hailed as a conciliatory gesture toward business.
example_ko: a conciliatory approach/attitude/gesture/move
syn_a: acquiescent, appeasing, mollifying, pacifying, agreeable, amiable, friendly

etym: Perhaps derived from earlier contenkerous, from contentious + rancorous.
en: Someone who is cantankerous is always finding things to argue or complain about.
example: a cantankerous old man.
example_ko: a cantankerous old man
syn_a: crabby, cross, disagreeable, grouchy, petulant, touchy

etym: From Middle French contentieux, from Latin contentiōsus (“quarrelsome, perverse”), from contentiō (“contention”), from contendere, past participle contentus (“to contend”); see contend.
en: A contentious issue causes a lot of disagreement or arguments.
example: Sanctions are expected to be among the most contentious issues.
example_ko: a contentious issue/topic/subject
syn_a: antagonistic, argumentative, belligerent, litigious, pugnacious, quarrelsome

etym: Borrowed from Middle French ignoble, from Latin ignōbilis, from in- (“not”) + gnōbilis, later nōbilis (“noble”).
en: If you describe something as ignoble, you mean that it is bad and something to be ashamed of.
example: ignoble thoughts.
example_ko: ignoble thoughts
syn_a: contemptible, debased, disgraceful, dishonorable, foul, heinous, nefarious, base, low, mean, vile, common, peasant, plebeian

en: If your situation is precarious, you are not in complete control of events and might fail in what you are doing at any moment.
example: Our financial situation had become precarious.
example_ko: He earned a precarious living as an artist.
syn_a: chancy, delicate, shaky, unstable, dangerous, hazardous, perilous, risky, baseless, groundless, problematic, untenable, weak

etym: From French facétieux, from Latin facētia (“jest, wit, humor”), from facētus (“witty, jocose, facetious”).
en: If you say that someone is being facetious, you are criticizing them because they are making humorous remarks or saying things that they do not mean in a situation where they ought to be serious.
example: The woman eyed him coldly. 'Don't be facetious,' she said.
example_ko: a facetious comment/remark
syn_a: jesting, joking, amusing, comical, funny, humorous

etym: Anglo-Norman aversaire (in Wace's Life of Saint Margaret), from Old French aversier, aversaire (French adversaire), from Latin adversārius, from adversus (“turned toward”).
en: Your adversary is someone you are competing with, or arguing or fighting against.
example: His political adversaries were creating a certain amount of trouble for him.
syn_n: antagonist, enemy, foe, competitor, contestant, opponent, rival

etym: discretion +‎ -ary (“pertaining to”). Compare French discrétionnaire.
en: Discretionary things are not fixed by rules but are decided on by people in authority, who consider each individual case.
example: Magistrates were given wider discretionary powers
example_ko: You may be eligible for a discretionary grant for your university course.
syn_n: caution, judgment, prudence, sagacity, sense, wisdom, inclination, predilection, preference, volition, will

etym: in- +‎ judicious
en: If you describe a person or something that they have done as injudicious, you are critical of them because they have shown very poor judgment.
example: He blamed injudicious comments by bankers for last week's devaluation.
example_ko: an injudicious remark

etym: Borrowed from Latin sacrosanctus.
en: If you describe something as sacrosanct, you consider it to be special and are unwilling to see it criticized or changed.
example: Freedom of the press is sacrosanct.
example_ko: I’ll work till late in the evening, but my weekends are sacrosanct.

etym: Borrowed from Latin negātus, past participle of negāre (“to deny, refuse, decline”), reduced from *nec-aiare (or a similar form), from nec (“not, nor”) + aiere (“to say”).
en: If one thing negates another, it causes that other thing to lose the effect or value that it had.
example: These weaknesses negated his otherwise progressive attitude towards the staff.
example_ko: Alcohol negates the effects of the drug.
syn_v: annul, cancel, nullify, void

etym: Borrowed from Latin mercēnārius (“hired for money”), from mercēs (“reward, wages, price”).
en: A mercenary is a soldier who is paid to fight by a country or group that they do not belong to.
example_ko: foreign mercenaries
syn_n: hireling, legionnaire, soldier of fortune
syn_a: avaricious, grasping, greedy, money-grubbing

etym: From Middle French intermittent, from Latin intermittens (“sending between”), from prefix inter- (“among, on”), plus present participle mittens (“sending”), from mittere (“to send”).
en: Something that is intermittent happens occasionally rather than continuously.
example: After three hours of intermittent rain, the game was abandoned.
example_ko: intermittent bursts of applause
syn_a: alternating, cyclic, interrupted, periodic, rhythmic, sporadic

ko: [U] 처신, 거동, 행실, 품행(conduct); 태도, 몸가짐; 표정
etym: From Middle English demenen, demeinen, from Anglo-Norman demener, from Old French demener, from de- + mener (“to conduct, lead”) + -or, from Latin *mināre (“to drive”) and Latin minārī (“to project or jut forth”).
en: Your demeanour is the way you behave, which gives people an impression of your character and feelings.
example: her calm and cheerful demeanour.
example_ko: a kind and gentle demeanor
syn_n: behavior, comportment, conduct  deportment

etym: From Old French eloquent, from Latin eloquens (“speaking, having the faculty of speech, eloquent”), present participle of eloqui (“to speak out”), from e (“out”) + loqui (“to speak”).
en: Speech or writing that is eloquent is well expressed and effective in persuading people.
example: I heard him make a very eloquent speech at that dinner.
example_ko: an eloquent speech/speaker
syn_a: articulate, expressive, fluent, rhetorical, well-spoken, effective, meaningful, persuasive

en: If you describe someone as articulate, you mean that they are able to express their thoughts and ideas easily and well.
example: She is an articulate young woman
example_ko: She struggled to articulate her thoughts.
syn_v: enunciate, pronounce, utter, vocalize, clarify, explain, explicate, expound
syn_a: eloquent, fluent, smooth, clear, definite, distinct, intelligible, lucid, hinged, jointed

etym: First at end of 16th century; borrowed from Middle French estimer, from Latin aestimō (“to value, rate, weigh, estimate”); see estimate and aim, an older word, partly a doublet of esteem.
en: Esteem is the admiration and respect that you feel towards another person.
example: He is held in high esteem by colleagues in the construction industry
example_ko: She is held in high esteem by her colleagues.
syn_n: awe, deference, honor, admiration, appreciation, regard, respect
syn_v: honor, respect, revere, worship, cherish, prize, treasure, consider, deem, judge, regard
